123. Erickson v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. March 05, 1973 507 P.2d 508


Defendants were convicted in the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Gerald Van Hoomissen, J., of possession of marijuana and LSD for purpose of sale, and one defendant was also convicted of simple possession of marijuana and they appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that where individual who transported defendant's...

Synopsis

Defendants were convicted in the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Gerald Van Hoomissen, J., of possession of marijuana and LSD for purpose of sale, and one defendant was also convicted of simple possession of marijuana and they appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that where individual who transported defendant's suitcase to police station did not have any independent right of access to or authorization, expressed or implied, from defendants to open suitcase, so that any consent by him to a search of suitcase was invalid, nor was there any likelihood that suitcase would be removed and contraband possibly contained therein destroyed, and suitcase was in possession of police at police station where a district court judge and competent witnesses were immediately available for a warrant hearing, and no emergency situation existed, warrantless search which occurred when officer forcibly opened suitcase was unreasonable and failure to suppress evidence obtained thereby was error; however, illegality of search did not taint subsequent arrest of one defendant for possession of marijuana and did not render invalid search made incident to that arrest, where there was probable cause for arrest of defendant prior to illegal search of suitcase.

Affirmed in part and reversed in part.


124. State v. Davenport

Supreme Court of Alaska. May 14, 1973 510 P.2d 78


Prosecution for receiving and concealing stolen property, in which State appealed from a decision of the Third Judicial District Court, C. J. Occhipinti, J., which granted motion seeking to suppress certain evidence. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held, inter alia, that officers had probable cause to believe that furs which they discovered,...

Synopsis

Prosecution for receiving and concealing stolen property, in which State appealed from a decision of the Third Judicial District Court, C. J. Occhipinti, J., which granted motion seeking to suppress certain evidence. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held, inter alia, that officers had probable cause to believe that furs which they discovered, during search for handguns under search warrant which did not mention furs, were fruits of certain burglary, so that police had reasonable basis to believe that the furs were stolen and that the crime of possessing stolen goods was being committed in their presence, where officer stated that he knew that certain furs had recently been stolen, where various fur pieces which officers uncovered appeared to be new, where there were no retail labels attached to the garments, and where they appeared to have been carefully hidden in attic.

Case remanded for further proceedings. Fitzgerald, J., not participating.


1. Disciplinary Matter Involving Collins

Supreme Court of Alaska. August 11, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 3443666


LEGAL SERVICES - Discipline. Disbarment was the appropriate discipline to impose on attorney who converted client funds and practiced law while his license was suspended.

Synopsis

Editor's Note: Opinion superseded. For superseding opinion see, 2017 WL 3974509.


2. Recreational Data Services, Inc. v. Trimble Navigation Limited

Supreme Court of Alaska. March 24, 2017 394 P.3d 491 2017 WL 1101400


TORTS - Damages. Even though software developer proved element of damages by preponderance of evidence, evidence was too speculative to award lost profits.

Synopsis

Editor's Note: The opinion of the Supreme Court of Alaska, in Recreational Data Services, Inc. v. Trimble Navigation Limited, published in the advance sheet at this citation, 394 P.3d 491, was withdrawn from the bound volume and republished. For republished opinion, see 2017 WL 2951450.


3. Odom v. State Division of Corporations, Business & Professional Licensing

Supreme Court of Alaska. August 11, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 3443677


HEALTH - Licensing. Medical Board abused its discretion in revoking medical license based on prescription of weight-loss drug to patient with heart condition.

Synopsis

Editor's Note: Opinion superseded. For superseding opinion see, 2018 WL 794366.

  2. Mark B. v. State , Department of Health & Social Services , Office of Children's Services

The Office of Children's Services (OCS) removed Tabitha from the care of her parents, Mark and Lavern, after Mark assaulted Lavern on multiple occasions, including one time when...

He filed his request at the agency level, appealed the agency decision to the superior court, then appealed that decision to us. Because the road construction adjacent to his property is complete and he has other avenues to...



  4. Carrico v. Brown

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 08, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 955247


    This appeal is from the superior court's order awarding shared custody of a child to the child's father and paternal grandmother following an evidentiary hearing on the father's motion to modify custody. The existing order gave him only visitation rights, while the mother had primary legal and physical custody; his motion requested joint...



  5. Katairoak v. State , Department of Revenue, Child Support Services Division

    A father appeals two separate superior court orders allowing the Department of Revenue's Child Support Services Division (CSSD) to attach his Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act (ANCSA) corporate stock dividends for child support arrears. He argues that: (1) the superior courts improperly attached his ANCSA stock dividends through summary...



  6. Linny S. v. State

    Supreme Court of Alaska. January 25, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 383345


    The superior court granted a petition by the Office of Children's Services (OCS) to terminate a mother's parental rights to her daughter. The mother now appeals, arguing that the superior court erred when it found that OCS made active efforts to provide remedial services to prevent the breakup of the family and when it found that the daughter would...


  7. Jordan v. Watson

    Supreme Court of Alaska. December 08, 2017 407 P.3d 497 2017 WL 6094245


    FAMILY LAW Visitation. In order to be entitled to visitation, grandparents were required to allege that child suffered detriment from a lack of court-ordered visitation.

    Synopsis

    Background: Paternal grandparents moved to intervene in custody dispute between child's parents and sought court-ordered visitation. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Sitka, No. 1SI-16-00027 CI, David V. George, J., denied the motion. Grandparents appealed.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Carney, J., held that, in order to be entitled to grandparent visitation, grandparents were required to allege that child suffered detriment from a lack of court-ordered visitation.

    Affirmed.


  8. Ellingstad v. Petersburg Borough

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 31, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 2392433


    This appeal arises from a decision issued by the superior court sitting as an intermediate appellate court in an administrative appeal. In 2012 Petersburg Borough ordered two homeowners to repair or demolish their home after it determined that the building was dangerous. The homeowners challenged the order and appealed the Borough Assembly's...



  9. Jerome F. v. State , Department of Health & Social Services , Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 07, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 2492489


    A father challenges the trial court's decision terminating his parental rights to his son. The father argues the court erred by finding that prior to termination he was given a reasonable amount of time to remedy the conditions placing his son at risk. Because the evidence supports the trial court's finding, we affirm the court's decision. Jerome...



  10. Giocondo v. Fairbanks Daily NewsMiner

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 19, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 3122388


    Gregory Giocondo sued the Fairbanks Daily NewsMiner and three other defendantsin Anchoragefor defamation. The Anchorage superior court transferred venue to Fairbanks, and the Fairbanks superior court ultimately dismissed Giocondo's complaint as untimely. We agree that initial venue belonged in Fairbanks, and we also agree that...



  11. LongwayMarotta v. Nelson


    Supreme Court of Alaska. November 15, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 5505390


    Domestic partners Shannon LongwayMarotta and Ronald Dean Nelson separated in 2014 and sought division of their partnership assets and an order for shared custody of their child. The superior court divided the assets and debts equally and granted the parties shared legal and physical custody of their child. LongwayMarotta appeals the...



  12. Matter of Estate of Bavilla

    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 14, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 2609222


    Etta Bavilla attempted to informally probate her mother's 1987 will, but the court did not allow the informal probate because her mother had signed a new will in 2006. In a prior appeal we held that Etta should have been permitted to amend her pleadings and convert the matter to a formal probate proceeding to contest the 2006 will. On remand she...



  13. Remy K. v. State Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. January 18, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 280691


    FAMILY LAW Child Protection. Evidence supported finding that termination of father's parental rights was in the best interests of his children.

    Synopsis

    Background: The Office of Children's Services (OCS) petitioned to terminate father's parental rights to his two Indian children. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Paul E. Olson, J., terminated parental rights. Father appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. trial court denial of father's motion to continue termination of parental rights trial was not an abuse of discretion, and

    2. evidence supported finding that termination of father's parental rights was in the best interests of his children.

    Affirmed.


  14. Barton v. Means

    Supreme Court of Alaska. December 06, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 6094551


    A father sought to enforce a Texas child support order against a mother living in Alaska, arguing that she owed him thousands of dollars in unpaid child support and medical support. The superior court denied his request. He appeals, arguing that the court's denial amounted to a retroactive modification of the Texas order, and that the court...


  15. Hopper v. Estate of Goard

    Supreme Court of Alaska. January 13, 2017 386 P.3d 1245 2017 WL 127526


    LITIGATION Parties. Co-conservators were entitled to intervene as matter of right in their ward's action to seek relief from judgment based on settlement agreement.

    Synopsis

    Background: Co-conservators moved to intervene in action involving their ward in order to seek relief from judgment based on settlement agreement that awarded properties to the estate of ward's former business partner. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Michael A. MacDonald, J., denied motion. Co-conservators appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

    1. co-conservators were entitled to intervene as a matter of right, and

    2. denial of co-conservators' motion to intervene was not harmless error. Reversed and remanded.


  16. Coulson v. Steiner

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 03, 2017 390 P.3d 1139 2017 WL 836564


    TORTS Tortious Interference. Alienation of affections is not a valid cause of action.

    Synopsis

    Background: Ex-husband, whose wife had affair during their marriage, sued ex-wife's lover, claiming alienation of affections, fraud and civil conspiracy, and intentional and negligent infliction of emotional distress. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Catherine M. Easter, J., Superior Court No. 3AN-14-10963 CI, entered summary judgment for ex-wife's lover, and ex-husband appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

    1. as matter of apparent first impression, alienation of affections is not a valid cause of action, and

    2. ex-husband's claims for fraud and civil conspiracy and for intentional and negligent infliction of emotional distress were for damages caused by fraudulent misrepresentations made during the divorce proceedings.

    Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.


  17. Sagers v. Alaska Fast Cash, LLC

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 01, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 838636


    1. Adam Sagers filed a personal injury action against Alaska Fast Cash and one of its employees on behalf of C.S., his minor son. Colleen Sackinger, C.S.'s mother who had sole physical and legal custody of C.S., intervened and settled the action for $19,000. Following the settlement to C.S. the superior court approvedwithout...



  18. Tunley v. Milspaugh

    Supreme Court of Alaska. September 27, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 4322549



    FAMILY LAW Marital Property. Evidence supported court's calculations as to value of husband's 40% equity in home and credit against judgment.

    Synopsis

    Background: Former wife filed motion to enforce post-divorce judgments regarding former husband's property division obligations. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Frank A. Pfiffner, J., entered judgment against former husband, and former husband appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. evidence was sufficient to support trial court's calculations and decision to credit former husband's 40% equity in the former marital home against $94,683.30 judgment and accrued interest and enter judgment against him for $10,924.72 balance, and

    2. evidence was sufficient to support $74,942 judgment against former husband for failure to make monthly $3300 payments.

    Affirmed.


  19. Comsult LLC v. Girdwood Mining Company

    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 23, 2017 397 P.3d 318 2017 WL 2709739


    COMMERCIAL LAW Contracts. Statute that barred suits based on contracts that violated securities law did not bar suit to enforce stock and royalty interests from contract.

    Synopsis

    Background: Corporation brought action against its consultant, which was retained to obtain new capital investments, seeking declaratory judgment that consulting contract violated state securities law, equitable rescission of contract, and cancellation of shares of stock and royalty interests granted under contract. Following remand from the Supreme Court, 329 P.3d 194, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, 2015 WL 9898981, 2015 WL 9898950, Patrick J. McKay, J., determined that contract was illegal and denied relief to both parties. Corporation appealed.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Stowers, C.J., held that statute that barred suits based on contracts that violated securities law did not render unenforceable stock and mineral royalty interests stemming from illegal contract.

    Reversed and remanded.


  20. Thomson v. Thomson

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 19, 2017 394 P.3d 604 2017 WL 2209882


    FAMILY LAW Qualified Domestic Relations Orders. Ex-wife's benefit under Qualified Domestic Relations Order was to be calculated using ex-husband's highest salary data at the time of retirement.

    Synopsis

    Background: Following entry of divorce decree, ex-husband moved to amend Qualified Domestic Relations Order (QDRO), which divided ex-husband's Public Employees' Retirement System (PERS) retirement account, to require that ex-wife's benefit under the QDRO be calculated using ex-husband's


    salary at the time of divorce, rather than his salary at the time of retirement. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, No. 1JU-06-00608 CI, William B. Carey, J., denied motion. Ex-husband appealed.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Carney, J., held that property settlement agreement that was incorporated into divorce decree did not contain clear language requiring the use of ex-husband's salary at the time of divorce when calculating ex-wife's benefit under QDRO, and thus, ex-wife's benefit was to be calculated using ex-husband's highest salary data at retirement.

    Affirmed.


  21. Russell v. Municipality of Anchorage, Animal Care and Control

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 29, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 1200907


    AGRICULTURE Animals. The animal control officer, rather than the court, had to determine whether the juvenile victim was committing trespass at the time dog bit victim.

    Synopsis

    Background: After dog owner's dog was classified at a level five, which required the dog to be euthanized, owner sought review of the decision. The Animal Control Appeals Board affirmed. Dog owner appealed. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No. 3AN1206581 CI, Erin B. Marston, J., affirmed. Dog owner appealed.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court held that the animal control officer, rather than the court, had to determine whether the juvenile victim was committing trespass at the time dog bit victim, which would provide an exception to the classification of dog at a level five.

    Vacated and remanded.


  22. Davis v. King Craig Trust

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 17, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 2209879


    REAL PROPERTY Landlord and Tenant. Commercial lease did not violate municipal code, which required that business have off-street parking spaces, and thus, lease was not illegal.

    Synopsis

    Background: Commercial tenant sued his landlord, alleging that city ordinances required the landlord to provide him overnight parking spaces and that the landlord had retaliated against him for complaining about the issue. Landlord responded by filing a forcible entry and detainer action based on the tenant's failure to pay rent. The cases were consolidated. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, John Suddock, J., awarded possession to the landlord and later granted summary judgment to the landlord on the tenant's claims for damages. Tenant appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. commercial lease did not violate municipal code, which required that business operating as an automotive repair shop have four off-street parking spaces, and thus, lease was not illegal, and

    2. tenant did not establish claims for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment or wrongful eviction. Affirmed.


  23. Yassick v. Yassick

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 08, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 955245


    FAMILY LAW Marital Property. Trial court's determination that a piece of real property in Wisconsin was husband's separate property was not clearly erroneous, in divorce case.

    Synopsis

    Background: Wife filed a complaint for divorce. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No. 3AN1209463 CI, Erin B. Marston, J., classified, valued and distributed marital property. Wife appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. the trial court's determination that a piece of real property in Wisconsin was husband's separate property was not clearly erroneous;

    2. the trial court's assignment of a rental credit of $11,434 to wife for her use of a commercial building that was part of the marital estate was proper; and

    3. wife failed to establish that she was entitled to a credit for payment of post-separation medical bills of $13,565.22.

    Affirmed.


  24. Kent P. v. State , Division of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 05, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 2884377


    The trial court terminated a father's parental rights to his daughter. The father appeals, arguing that the trial court clearly erred in finding that his daughter was a child in need of aid under AS 47.10.011(10) (parental substance abuse). We affirm the trial court's termination of his parental rights. Allison was born in 2008 to her parents Kent...



  25. Wagner v. Wagner

    Supreme Court of Alaska. January 13, 2017 386 P.3d 1249 2017 WL 127990


    FAMILY LAW Equitable Distribution. Trial court's finding that wife did not waste student loan funds on gambling, as basis for allocating marital debt to her, was not abuse of discretion.

    Synopsis

    Background: Wife filed suit for divorce. After denying husband's request for continuance of trial, the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Michael P. McConahy, J., entered judgment of divorce and distributed parties' marital estate following hearing at which only wife appeared, after determining that husband's absence was unexcused. Husband appealed. The Supreme Court, 299 P.3d 170, reversed and remanded. On remand, the Superior Court again entered judgment dividing marital assets and liabilities, and husband appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

    1. trial court's determination that wife's student loan debt, including premarital student loan debt that was consolidated with two loans taken out during marriage, was marital debt was not clearly erroneous;

    2. trial court's finding that wife did not waste student loan funds on gambling was not abuse of


      discretion; and

    3. trial court's adverse rulings and refusal to sua sponte schedule evidentiary hearing regarding wife's premarital student loan debt was not evidence of impermissible judicial bias.

    Affirmed.


  26. Meehan v. Greffenius

    Supreme Court of Alaska. April 26, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 1535979


    FAMILY LAW Child Support. Husband presented a prima facie case of wife's voluntary unemployment or underemployment, in divorce proceeding.

    Synopsis

    Background: Husband sought a divorce. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No. 3AN1211888 CI, Paul E. Olson, J., granted the divorce. Husband appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. evidence supported the trial court's characterization and valuation of a portion of husband's post-retirement health benefits as a marital asset, and

    2. husband presented a prima facie case of wife's voluntary unemployment or underemployment. Affirmed in part; remanded in part.


  27. Jane A. v. State , Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. October 25, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 4855654


    FAMILY LAW Child Protection. Evidence supported finding that mother failed to remedy her conduct within a reasonable time.

    Synopsis

    Background: The Office of Children's Services (OCS) petitioned to terminate mother's parental rights to her two children. The Superior Court Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No. 3AN1500175/00176 CN, Gregory Miller, J., terminated parental rights. Mother appealed.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court held that evidence supported finding that mother failed to remedy her conduct within a reasonable time.

    Affirmed.


  28. Emily S. v. State , Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 02, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 3318821


    The superior court terminated a mother's parental rights, and she appeals. She argues that the superior court erred in three of its findings: (1) that she failed to remedy the conduct that endangered her child; (2) that the Office of Children's Services (OCS) made reasonable efforts to



    reunify the family; and (3) that termination of her parental...


  29. Matthew H. v. State Department of Health & Social Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 02, 2017 397 P.3d 279 2017 WL 2391681


    FAMILY LAW Child Protection. Evidence supported finding that father failed to remedy the conduct or conditions that made child a child in need of aid.

    Synopsis

    Background: The Office of Children's Services (OCS) petitioned to terminate mother and father's parental rights. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, No. 4FA-13-00042 CN, Michael

    A. MacDonald, J., terminated parental rights. Father appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

    1. evidence supported finding that father failed to remedy the conduct or conditions that made child a child in need of aid, and

    2. the trial court's denial of father's motion to allow his attorney to withdraw was not an abuse of discretion.

    Affirmed.


  30. Jasper R. v. State , Department of Health & Social Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 24, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 2303496


    A father challenges a trial court's decision terminating his parental rights to his child. Because the court correctly applied the law and the challenged finding is not clearly erroneous, we affirm the termination of the father's parental rights. Jasper R. has a child who is an Indian child as defined by the Indian Child Welfare Act...



  31. Darwin B. v. State Department of Health & Social Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. January 04, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 65547


    FAMILY LAW Child Protection. Record in termination of parental rights action supported determination that Office of Children's Services made reasonable efforts to reunify the family.

    Synopsis

    Background: Father appealed from decision of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Erin B. Marston, J., terminating his parental rights.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court held that record supported the superior court's determination that Office of Children's Services (OCS) made reasonable efforts to reunify the family.

    Affirmed.


  32. Prax v. Zalewski

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 11, 2017 400 P.3d 116 2017 WL 3443684


    REAL PROPERTY Adverse Possession. Amendments to adverse possession statutes that added good-faith requirement applied to adverse possessor's claim to record owner's parking lot.

    Synopsis

    Background: Claimant brought adverse possession action against record owner of parking lot. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, No. 4FA-13-02190 CI, Douglas L. Blankenship, J., 2015 WL 10734856, entered judgment in favor of claimant. Record owner appealed.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Carney, J., held that amendments to adverse possession statutes that added good-faith requirement applied to adverse possessor's claim to record owner's parking lot.

    Reversed and remanded.


  33. Arbuckle v. DiTomaso, Inc.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. October 25, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 4855385


    TORTS Evidence. Any error in allowing references to driver's health insurance, and to a workers' compensation claim, was harmless in personal injury action.

    Synopsis

    Background: Driver of a vehicle brought personal injury action against driver of truck that rear-ended him and truck's owner. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Kenai, Carl Bauman, J., found that driver was not physically injured in the accident, and did not award damages to driver. Driver appealed. [Holding:] The Supreme Court held that any error in allowing references to driver's health insurance, and references to driver's unrelated workers' compensation claim, was harmless.

    Affirmed.


  34. Rogers v. Babcock

    Supreme Court of Alaska. February 15, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 655747


    FAMILY LAW Child Custody. Court abused its discretion when it ordered 64/36 custody split in wife's favor, without explanation, after orally finding that 50/50 shared custody was in child's best interest.

    Synopsis

    Background: In her complaint for divorce, wife requested sole legal and primary physical custody and asked that the court allow husband only supervised visitation. Husband responded by requesting 50/50 shared custody. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, Kari Kristiansen, J., adopted wife's proposed findings of fact and conclusions of law, which divided custody 64/36 in her favor. Husband appealed.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court held that court abused its discretion when it ordered 64/36 custody split in wife's favor, without explanation, after orally finding that 50/50 shared custody was in the child's best interests.

    Vacated and remanded.



  35. Gamboa v. Alaska Housing Finance Corporation

    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 28, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 2822786


    LITIGATION Counsel. Superior Court was not required to provide indigent plaintiff procedural advice on how to obtain counsel.

    Synopsis

    Background: Indigent plaintiff filed an administrative appeal following an Alaska Housing Finance Corporation administrative grievance proceeding relating to changes to his housing subsidy. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Mark Rindner, J., dismissed the appeal for lack of prosecution, and plaintiff appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. the Superior Court was not required to provide plaintiff procedural advice on how to obtain an attorney, and

    2. the Superior Court provided plaintiff sufficient time to file an opening brief. Affirmed.


  36. Yankee v. City and Borough of Juneau

    Supreme Court of Alaska. October 20, 2017 407 P.3d 460 2017 WL 4767770


    ADMINISTRATIVE PRACTICE Judicial Review. Community development department's allowance of neighbor's fence was an exercise of enforcement discretion, and thus would not be reviewed.

    Synopsis

    Background: Landowner sought review of town assembly's determination that he lacked standing to appeal planning commission's affirmance of community development department's decision that his neighbor's fence did not violate restrictive plat notes. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, 2015 WL 10013912, Louis J. Menendez, J., affirmed, and landowner appealed.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that the department's decision was an appropriate exercise of its enforcement discretion.

    Affirmed.


  37. Alaska Miners Association v. Holman

    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 16, 2017 397 P.3d 312 2017 WL 2609533


    GOVERNMENT Attorney Fees. Plaintiffs did not have sufficient economic incentive to remove them from constitutional-claimant status, and thus, were not subject to attorney fees.

    Synopsis

    Background: Mining engineer and associations filed suit challenging lieutenant governor's certification of ballot initiative that would require final legislative approval for any large-scale metallic sulfide mining


    operation located within bay watershed. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Paul R. Lyle, J., granted summary judgment in favor of State and initiative sponsors, declining to enjoin placement of initiative on ballot. Mining engineer and associations appealed. The Supreme Court, Stowers, C.J., 341 P.3d 1121, affirmed. Initiative sponsors moved for attorney fees as constitutional claimants. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Paul R. Lyle, J., awarded initiative sponsors full reasonable attorney fees in the amount of $63,944, and mining engineer and association appealed.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Stowers, C.J., held that plaintiffs did not have sufficient economic incentive to remove them from constitutional-claimant status, and thus, were protected from an award of attorney fees.

    Reversed.


  38. Haley B. v. State , Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. October 19, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 4767710


    FAMILY LAW Child Protection. The trial court's determination that mother had failed to remedy her substance abuse within a reasonable time was not clearly erroneous.

    Synopsis

    Background: The Office of Children's Services (OCS) filed a petition to terminate mother's parental rights to her three children. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, No. 3PA1500078/00079/00080 CN, Kari Kristiansen, J., terminated parental rights and mother appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. trial counsel's failure to ask for a continuance at or after a status hearing to allow mother to complete drug treatment did not constitute performance below a level that any reasonably competent attorney would provide;

    2. the trial court's determination that mother had failed to remedy her substance abuse within a reasonable time was not clearly erroneous; and

    3. the trial court's determination that it was in the best interest of the children to terminate mother's parental rights was not clearly erroneous.

    Affirmed.


  39. Dixon v. Dixon

    Supreme Court of Alaska. October 20, 2017 407 P.3d 453 2017 WL 4767708


    REAL PROPERTY Deeds. Quitclaim deed to house did not constitute persuasive evidence of grantor's intent to convey title to grantee's father as deed was unambiguous.

    Synopsis

    Background: After grantor filed a complaint to recover house from grantee's father and was granted a writ of assistance, grantee's father counterclaimed for quiet title of house against grantor, alleging that grantor transferred the house to him, not grantee. Following a bench trial, the Superior Court, Ketchikan, First Judicial District, No. 1KE-15-00056 CI, William B. Carey, J., dismissed the counterclaim, finding that grantee's father failed to prove grantor's intent to transfer property to him.

    Grantee's father appealed.


    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

    1. quitclaim deed to house was unambiguous, and thus did not constitute persuasive evidence that grantor intended to convey title to house to grantee's father, and

    2. grantee's father failed to prove that grantor intended to make a present gift of house to him, and thus there was no parol gift of land that warranted quieting title to house in grantee's father. Affirmed.


  40. Fiona P. v. State , Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. February 22, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 729765


    FAMILY LAW Child Protection. Court did not commit legal error by terminating mother's parental rights before deciding whether a guardianship or an adoption was in children's best interests.

    Synopsis

    Background: Mother appealed from decision of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eric A. Aarseth, J., terminating her parental rights.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court held that trial court did not commit legal error by terminating mother's parental rights before deciding whether guardianship or an adoption was in children's best interests. Affirmed.

    Carney, J., filed dissenting opinion.


  41. Disciplinary Matter Involving Collins

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 23, 2017 403 P.3d 1076 2017 WL 3974509


    LEGAL SERVICES Discipline. When issuing decision in disciplinary matter that includes financial obligations, Supreme Court will issue separate final money judgment.

    Synopsis

    Background: Bar Counsel petitioned for formal hearing against attorney with Bar Association's Disciplinary Board. Disciplinary Board rejected stipulation between attorney and Bar Counsel regarding attorney's disbarment, on basis that stipulation did not include an agreement on part of attorney that formal enforceable money judgment be entered against him to reflect amount paid by Lawyers' Fund for Client Protection (LFCP) in connection with one of client matters underlying uncontested disbarment.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. disbarment was appropriate sanction for attorney's misconduct, and

    2. as a matter of first impression, when issuing decision in disciplinary matter that includes financial obligations, the Supreme Court will issue a separate final money judgment for those obligations. Attorney disbarred.


  42. Keira H. v. State , Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services


    Supreme Court of Alaska. December 13, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 6395824


    Keira H. appeals the superior court's order terminating her parental rights to her two children, Emmy and Jeremy. Keira challenges the superior court's findings that (1) she failed to remedy the conduct or conditions that placed her children in need of aid and (2) the Office of Children's Services (OCS) made reasonable efforts to reunify the...



  43. Johnson v. Johnson

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 19, 2017 394 P.3d 598 2017 WL 2209880


    FAMILY LAW Marital Property. Former wife was not entitled to relief from marital property division that was included in divorce judgment.

    Synopsis

    Background: After former wife was unable to refinance marital home, which she was awarded in distribution of marital property in divorce decree on condition that she refinanced home in her name, former husband exercised option to refinance the home himself and take possession of it, and wife filed a motion to reopen divorce case, a motion to order that items of personal property be delivered to her, a motion to redistribute the marital estate due to the change in marital home's ownership, and a motion for change of venue, which wife characterized as a motion to recuse the judge on appeal. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, No. 3PA-12-02502 CI, Vanessa White, J., denied wife's motions. Wife appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

    1. wife did not show that she was entitled to order enforcing divorce decree regarding the return of her personal property;

    2. wife was not entitled to relief from marital property division that was included in divorce judgment; and

    3. trial court acted within its discretion in denying former wife's motion for motion for disqualification of trial judge.

    Affirmed.


  44. Kayla L. v. Kelvin D.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 08, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 955249


    FAMILY LAW Child Custody. Trial court did not abuse its discretion in awarding physical custody of son to father who wanted to move out of state.

    Synopsis

    Background: Father filed a custody complaint against mother and sought sole legal and physical custody of son. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Erin B. Marston, J., granted father primary physical custody, granted both parents legal custody with final decision-making authority in father, and granted mother supervised visitation rights. Mother appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. father did not have a history of domestic violence such that he needed to overcome a rebuttable presumption against being awarded any type of child custody, and

    2. trial court did not abuse its discretion in awarding father physical custody of son.


    Affirmed.


  45. Tyler K. v. State

    Supreme Court of Alaska. February 01, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 464380


    FAMILY LAW Child Protection. Evidence supported finding that father had failed to remedy the conditions that placed child at substantial risk of harm in a reasonable time.

    Synopsis

    Background: The Office of Children's Services (OCS) filed a petition to terminate father's parental rights to child. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Patrick J. McKay, J., terminated parental rights. Father appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. the trial court's determination that father had exposed child to domestic violence, as defined in the child in need of aid statute, was not clearly erroneous;

    2. evidence supported finding that father had failed to remedy the conditions that placed child at substantial risk of harm in a reasonable time; and

    3. evidence supported finding that the OCS made reasonable efforts to reunify father and child. Affirmed.


  46. Dropik v. Dropik

    Supreme Court of Alaska. November 01, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 5017059


    A couple divorced and distributed their marital property through a court-approved settlement agreement. When the ex-husband failed to make a required equalization payment, the ex-wife sought a judgment enforcing the settlement; in response the ex-husband alleged newly discovered evidence and the ex-wife's fraud and sought relief from...



  47. Bernadette K. v. State Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 21, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 2709738


    The superior court terminated the parental rights of a mother and father, citing a history of domestic violence, substance abuse, and child neglect and the parents' failure to fully engage with the Office of Children's Services (OCS) and remedial programs. The court acknowledged that the parents had made progress in improving their parenting...



  48. Sally C. v. State Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 02, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 3319144



    FAMILY LAW Child Protection. Evidence was sufficient to establish that child was child in need of aid due to mother's opioid use.

    Synopsis

    Background: State Office of Children's Services filed petition alleging that child was a child in need of aid (CINA). Following contested adjudication trial, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, No. 3PA-15-00144 CN, Gregory Heath, J., found that child was a child in need of aid. Mother appealed. Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. evidence was sufficient to support finding that mother's use of opioids during pregnancy was addictive or habitual;

    2. evidence was sufficient to support finding that mother's opioid use caused substantial harm to child; and

    3. evidence was sufficient to support finding that it was not safe for child to return home to mother. Affirmed.


  49. Harrell v. Calvin

    Supreme Court of Alaska. September 08, 2017 403 P.3d 1182 2017 WL 3929001


    LITIGATION Limitations. Adult children of mother who died in duplex fire were on inquiry notice of wrongful-death and emotional-distress claims at least by day after fire.

    Synopsis

    Background: Deceased mother's adult children brought action on behalf of estate for wrongful death and on their own behalf for negligent infliction of emotional distress regarding mother's death in a duplex fire that neighbor's electric fish smoker allegedly caused. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Ketchikan, Trevor Stephens, J., granted summary judgment for neighbor and awarded neighbor attorney fees jointly and severally against estate and children. Children appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

    1. children were on inquiry notice of causes of action at least by the day after the fire;

    2. children had actual notice of causes of action within the two-year limitations period while a reasonable time remained within which to file suit;

    3. children could be held liable for attorney fees; and

    4. trial court could award attorney fees to neighbor and jointly and severally against estate and children.

    Affirmed.


  50. Studley v. Alaska Public Offices Commission

    Supreme Court of Alaska. January 27, 2017 389 P.3d 18 2017 WL 382647


    GOVERNMENT Elections. Statutes prohibiting a real estate broker from disclosing confidential information did not prohibit candidate from disclosing information under election disclosure requirements.

    Synopsis


    Background: Candidate for borough assembly seat sought an exemption from financial disclosure requirements. The Public Offices Commission denied the request and assessed a $175 civil penalty. Candidate appealed and the Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Philip M. Pallenberg, J., affirmed. Candidate appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

    1. candidate's disclosure of hypothetical situations where disclosure of the name of an individual who was a source of income would be detrimental to one of candidate's business clients was insufficient to qualify for an exemption from the financial disclosure requirements;

    2. statutes prohibiting a real estate broker from disclosing confidential information about a client did not prohibit candidate for local office, who was a self-employed real estate agent, from disclosing client information and derived earnings pursuant to election disclosure requirements; and

    3. candidate failed to establish that disclosure of his clients names and derived income, pursuant to candidate financial disclosure requirements, would violate his clients' constitutional right to privacy. Affirmed.


  51. Alaska Fur Gallery, Inc. v. Tok Hwang

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 31, 2017 394 P.3d 511 2017 WL 1192890


    REAL PROPERTY Landlord and Tenant. Provision that sublease includes option to purchase with lease amount applied to negotiated purchase price was too indefinite to be enforceable.

    Synopsis

    Background: Commercial sublessee brought action against lessee seeking specific performance of alleged option to purchase lessee's interest in the lease and leasehold improvements. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, No. 4FA-14-03039, Douglas Blankenship, J., granted summary judgment for lessee, and sublessee appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

    1. sublease provision, which stated sublease includes an option to purchase premises with lease amount to be applied to negotiated purchase price was too indefinite to enforce as an option to purchase;

    2. provision was not enforceable as agreement to negotiate; and

    3. lessee did not breach implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing. Affirmed.


  52. Rae v. State, Department of Corrections

    Supreme Court of Alaska. October 27, 2017 407 P.3d 474 2017 WL 4855421


    LITIGATION Prisoners. Prisoner who alleged he was being held illegally, and demanding release, failed to state a claim upon which relief could be granted.

    Synopsis

    Background: Prisoner brought action against Department of Corrections (DOC), alleging he was being held illegally and demanding release. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Seward, Carl Bauman, J., dismissed for failing to state a claim upon which relief could be granted. Prisoner appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

    1. neither statute governing commitment of a prisoner to the custody of the commissioner for the term


      of imprisonment the court directs, nor any other statutory provision regarding prisoners in the custody of the DOC cited by prisoner, constituted unconstitutional ex post facto laws;

    2. prisoner failed to state a claim upon which relief could be granted;

    3. the Superior Court was not precluded from sua sponte dismissing prisoner's complaint;

    4. prisoner was not entitled to a default judgment against the DOC;

    5. the Superior Court did not violate prisoner's right to a trial;

    6. dismissal for failure to state a claim did not violate prisoner's right to petition the government for a redress of grievances; and

    7. the Superior Court did not abuse its discretion by failing to give prisoner advice on how to avoid dismissal of his complaint.

    Affirmed.


  53. Fredrickson v. Hackett

Supreme Court of Alaska. October 27, 2017 407 P.3d 480 2017 WL 4855431


FAMILY LAW Child Custody. Ex-husband alleged a substantial change in his living conditions that was sufficient for a hearing on motion to modify child custody and visitation.

Synopsis

Background: Ex-husband moved to modify child custody and visitation. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Sitka, David V. George, J., denied motion without a hearing. Ex-husband appealed. Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, C.J., held that:

  1. divorce settlement agreement unambiguously provided ex-husband with shared physical custody of children approximately 25% of the time rather than 40% of the time, but

  2. ex-husband alleged a substantial change in his living conditions that was sufficient to entitle him to a hearing.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.


57. Easley v. Easley

Supreme Court of Alaska. April 07, 2017 394 P.3d 517 2017 WL 1291152


FAMILY LAW Spousal Support. Former husband was not entitled to offset his spousal support payments to former wife against property distribution payment outlined in divorce judgment.

Synopsis

Background: Trial court entered judgment of divorce and as part of divorce judgment, former husband was ordered to pay former wife property distribution payment upon selling marital home. Following former husband's failure to sell home for seven years after divorce judgment, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No. 3AN-07-06831 CI, Catherine M. Easter, J., entered judgment in amount of property distribution payment against former husband, but denied former wife's motion for prejudgment interest, attorney's fees, and costs. Former husband appealed and former wife appealed. Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

  1. husband received adequate notice and opportunity to be heard regarding previous divorce judgment's order prior to trial court's entrance of judgment against husband, and thus husband's due process rights were not violated;

  2. husband was not entitled to offset his spousal support payments to wife against property distribution


    payment outlined in divorce judgment;

  3. wife was not entitled to prejudgment interest to compensate her for delay between divorce judgment and trial court's entrance of judgment against husband; and

  4. wife was not prevailing party under rule governing award of attorney fees to prevailing party in civil cases, and thus was not entitled to partial award of attorney fees.

Affirmed.


58. Barber v. State , Department of Corrections

Supreme Court of Alaska. March 17, 2017 393 P.3d 412 2017 WL 1034569


CIVIL RIGHTS Prisons. Prior judgment that declined to terminate Cleary settlement agreement was law of the case, and was not subject to reconsideration absent certain findings.

Synopsis

Background: Following settlement of class action challenging conditions in state prisons, 24 P.3d 1245, prisoners filed motions alleging lack of compliance with comprehensive settlement agreement. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No. 3AN-81-05274 CI, John Suddock, J., dismissed the prisoners' motions, concluding that the settlement agreement was unenforceable because it had been terminated. Prisoners' appeals were consolidated.

[Holding:] The Supreme Court, Stowers, C.J., held that prior judgment that had declined to terminate settlement agreement on constitutional grounds was the law of the case, and was not subject to reconsideration absent certain findings.

Reversed and remanded.


59. Taryn M. v. State , Department of Health & Social Services , Office of Children's Services

Supreme Court of Alaska. July 19, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 3122387


The superior court found a child to be in need of aid pursuant to AS 47.10.011(1) (abandonment),

(6) (substantial physical harm or substantial risk thereof), (8) (domestic violence), and (10) (substance abuse). The child's mother appeals, arguing that the court violated her right to due process when it precluded the child from testifying at the...



60. Grove v. Grove

Supreme Court of Alaska. August 11, 2017 400 P.3d 109 2017 WL 3443680


FAMILY LAW Equitable Distribution. Failure to put a value on husband's post-retirement military health care benefits constituted reversible error.

Synopsis

Background: Wife brought divorce action. Following a bench trial, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, William F. Morse, J., granted the divorce and distributed the marital estate. Both parties appealed.


Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

  1. the Superior Court's characterization of $50,000 of wife's student loan debt as marital was not clearly erroneous; but

  2. the Superior Court's characterization of all of husband's post-retirement military health insurance benefit as a martial asset for purposes of property division was clearly erroneous; and

  3. the Superior Court's failure to put a fair market value on the benefits constituted reversible error. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.


61. Benjamin S. v. Stephenie S.

Supreme Court of Alaska. November 15, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 5505389


FAMILY LAW - Child Custody. Father alleged sufficient evidence of changed circumstances to warrant hearing on his motion for modification of child custody.



  1. In re Brown

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 10, 2017 392 P.3d 474 2017 WL 942606


    LEGAL SERVICES Discipline. Public censure was appropriate sanction for attorney's violation of professional conduct rules governing competence and fairness to opposing party.

    Synopsis

    Background: In attorney disciplinary proceeding, attorney and Bar Counsel entered into stipulation for discipline by consent that would result in public censure.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court held that public censure was appropriate sanction for attorney's misconduct.

    Public censure ordered. Carney, J., dissented.


  2. Yuk v. Robertson

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 26, 2017 397 P.3d 261 2017 WL 2298432


    REAL PROPERTY Adverse Possession. Encroaching fence owners' active use of disputed property, coupled with fence's existence, satisfied hostility element of adverse possession.

    Synopsis

    Background: Landowners sued to quiet title to fenced-off section of their lot, and owners of encroaching fence claimed adverse possession of fenced-off section. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, No. 3AN-15-08659 CI, Mark Rindner, J., 2016 WL 1698079, granted summary judgment in favor of fence owners. Property owners appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

    1. superior court did not violate rule by citing unpublished decision;

    2. municipal sewer easement on disputed property did not destroy fence owners' exclusivity; and

    3. fence owners' active use of disputed property satisfied hostility element. Affirmed.



  3. Zenk v. City & Borough of Juneau

    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 28, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 2825797


    Homeowners in a residential subdivision sought a conditional use permit to relocate their existing greenhouse and landscaping business to their property. They then initiated the process to lease an adjacent municipally owned property and later amended the use permit application to include the municipal property. Neighbors opposed the permit,...



  4. Jessie R. v. Timothy F.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. April 05, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 1291151


    FAMILY LAW Child Custody. Court did not abuse its discretion by finding that a prohibition on corporal punishment was in 11 year old child's best interests.

    Synopsis

    Background: Child custody modification action was brought. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, William F. Morse, J., granted modification and required daughter to split time equally between both parents, and unwed mother appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. superior court's custody order would be vacated and the case would be remanded for a determination of whether father had satisfied the statutory rebuttal criteria for domestic violence presumption, and

    2. superior court did not abuse its discretion by finding that a prohibition on corporal punishment was in 11 year old child's best interests.

    Vacated and remanded.


  5. Bob S. v. State

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 28, 2017 400 P.3d 99 2017 WL 3202761


    NATIVE AMERICANS Child Welfare. Evidence supported finding that terminating father's rights to child, an Indian child under Indian Child Welfare Act, was in child's best interests.

    Synopsis

    Background: In child protection proceeding, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Andrew Guidi, J., terminated father's parental rights to child, who was an Indian child under the Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA). Father appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

    1. evidence supported finding that father failed to remedy his harmful conduct;

    2. evidence supported finding that allowing father visitation with child was not in child's best interests;

    3. evidence supported finding that Office of Children's Services (OCS) made active but unsuccessful efforts to prevent breakup of Indian family; and

    4. evidence supported finding that termination of father's parental rights was in child's best interests.


    Affirmed.


  6. Rice v. McDonald

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 03, 2017 390 P.3d 1133 2017 WL 836561


    FAMILY LAW Child Custody. Protection from domestic violence factor favored Alaska in determining whether to decline to exercise jurisdiction over child custody proceeding.

    Synopsis

    Background: Maternal relative filed custody petition against paternal relative, seeking custody of three Indian children after father allegedly killed their mother and seeking to vacate Texas order that awarded custody of the children to paternal relative. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, No. 4FA-14-03084 CI, Michael A. MacDonald, J., dismissed case and ceded jurisdiction to Texas. Maternal relative appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

    1. dispute between maternal relative and paternal relative as to who should have custody of three Indian children was child custody proceeding involving Indian children, and thus, Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA) applied to the proceeding;

    2. protection from domestic violence factor favored Alaska, and thus, trial court abused its discretion by minimizing importance of protecting Indian children from father's alleged domestic violence when declining to exercise its jurisdiction over child custody proceeding; and

    3. nature and location of evidence factor favored Alaska, and thus, trial court abused its discretion by minimizing evidence required to resolve domestic violence and ICWA issues when declining to exercise its jurisdiction over child custody proceeding.

    Vacated and remanded.


  7. Margot B. v. State , Department of Health & Social Services , Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 22, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 1102975


    FAMILY LAW Child Protection. Evidence supported finding that returning to parents would harm children, as required to terminate parental rights under Indian Child Welfare Act.

    Synopsis

    Background: Proceedings to terminate parental rights were initiated. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Mark Rindner, J., terminated father's parental rights to two children, who were born to two different mothers and were Indian children within the meaning of the Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA), and terminated parental rights of both mothers. Father appealed, and mother of younger child appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. trial court acted within its discretion in declining parents' request for six-month continuance to delay disposition;

    2. Office of Children's Services demonstrated that it made active efforts to prevent breakup of Indian Family, as required under Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA) to terminate parental rights;

    3. evidence supported finding that returning children to parents would result in serious emotional or physical damage, as required to terminate parental rights under ICWA; and


    4. trial court did not err in finding that termination of parental rights was in best interest of children. Affirmed.

    Carney, J., with whom Maassen, J., joined, filed opinion dissenting in part.


  8. Parker M. v. State , Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 07, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 2492490


    A father and mother challenge the termination of their parental rights to two Indian children. The superior court found that the children were in need of aid based on the parents' substantial impairment due to alcohol use. Both parents challenge the court's active efforts finding, and the father challenges the qualifications of the expert witness...



  9. Central Recycling Services, Inc. v. Municipality of Anchorage

    Supreme Court of Alaska. February 10, 2017 389 P.3d 54 2017 WL 542467


    GOVERNMENT Municipalities. Recycling rebate ordinance did not apply to fees for disposal of company's solid waste residue from recycling of concrete, asphalt, tires, and lumber.

    Synopsis

    Background: Recycling company filed suit against municipality, seeking declaratory judgment that municipal ordinance providing for reduction in fees for disposal of solid waste residue at municipal landfill for businesses engaged in recycling of paper, plastic, glass, steel, aluminum, copper, and brass, which fees were refunded to business in form of quarterly rebate, applied to solid waste residue from recycling of concrete, asphalt, tires, and lumber. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eric A. Aarseth, J., entered summary judgment for municipality, and company appealed.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that rebate program did not apply to company's solid waste residue from recycling of concrete, asphalt, tires, and lumber.

    Affirmed.


  10. Blas v. Bank of America, N.A.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. April 12, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 1379317


    COMMERCIAL LAW Debt Collection. Servicer of deed of trust was not debt collector, within meaning of Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA).

    Synopsis

    Background: Grantor brought action against servicer of his deed of trust alleging that number of deficiencies, including improper authority, notice, and procedure, prevented servicer's attempt to non-judicially foreclose deed of trust. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No.

    3AN1404595 CI, Eric A. Aarseth, J., entered summary judgment in favor of servicer. Grantor appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. allowing grantor to amend his complaint for second time would have caused undue delay;


    2. servicer was not debt collector, within meaning of Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA);

    3. servicer had authority to non-judicially foreclose deed of trust;

    4. statute prohibiting non-judicial foreclosure in certain circumstances did not apply to prevent servicer from pursuing non-judicial foreclosure;

    5. twenty-day time period to deliver notice of default after it was recorded applied, rather than ten-day time period;

    6. substitutions of trust deed beneficiary and trustee by servicer were proper; and

    7. grantor was not denied his day in court by grant of summary judgment. Affirmed.


  11. Barry H. v. State Department of Health & Social Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 11, 2017 404 P.3d 1231 2017 WL 3443670


    FAMILY LAW Child Protection. Trial court acted within its discretion in denying father's request to represent himself in termination of parental rights proceeding.

    Synopsis

    Background: After the Office of Children's Services (OCS) of the Department of Health and Social Services took emergency custody of children following receipt of reports that father was physically and sexually abusing members of his family, OCS sought to terminate father's parental rights to children in a Child in Need of Aid (CINA) proceeding. After denying father's motion to dismiss his court-appointed attorney and represent himself, the Superior Court, Kotzebue, Second Judicial District, Paul A. Roetman, J., terminated father's parental rights. Father appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carney, J., held that:

    1. rule governing a parent's waiver of counsel in child in need of aid (CINA) proceedings effectively incorporates the standard a trial court uses to determine whether to allow self-representation, under McCracken v. State, 518 P.2d 85, into CINA proceedings, and

    2. trial court acted within its discretion in denying father's request to represent himself in CINA proceeding regarding the termination of father's parental rights to his children.

    Affirmed.


  12. Kelly C. v. State , Department of Health & Social Services , Office of Children's Services,

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 19, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 3122391


    NATIVE AMERICANS Child Welfare. ICWA expert witness testimony was not required to terminate parental rights of mother, since there was clear evidence of physical neglect.

    Synopsis

    Background: Office of Children's Services (OCS) petitioned for termination of parental rights of mother to Native American daughter. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, Kari Kristiansen, J., granted petition and terminated mother's parental rights. Mother appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. trial court did not fail to comply with Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA) in disregarding ICWA at beginning of proceedings;

    2. even if expert witnesses upon whom trial court relied were not qualified as ICWA experts, such


      reliance was not failure to comply with ICWA;

    3. daughter was child in need of aid for purposes of Alaska Child in Need of Aid (CINA) statutes;

    4. OCS made active efforts to provide remedial services and rehabilitative programs designed to prevent breakup of family; and

    5. termination of mother's parental rights was in best interests of daughter. Affirmed.


  13. Cozzetti v. Madrid

    Supreme Court of Alaska. December 13, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 6395736


    REAL PROPERTY Vendor and Purchaser. Trial court properly declined to enforce forfeiture provisions of installment purchase agreement for mobile home.

    Synopsis

    Background: Owner of closely held corporation that held title to the mobile home brought action against purchaser, alleging that purchaser was actually a renter under the parties' contract, and asserting claim for forcible entry and detainer. Owner subsequently filed a complaint for ejectment, which was consolidated with the original claim, and purchaser filed counterclaims under the Unfair Trade Practices and Consumer Protection Act (UTPA), asserting UTPA violations based on owner's misrepresentations that purchaser was only a renter and that owner directly owned the home. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Alex Swiderski, Judge Pro Tempore, dismissed the forcible entry and detainer claim and, following bench trial, the court issued order rejecting the ejectment claim, issued a second order determining that owner violated UTPA, and awarded damages to purchaser based on the violations totaling $1,500. Owner appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court of Alaska held that:

    1. contract between the parties was an installment purchase agreement, rather than a lease;

    2. trial court properly declined to enforce contract's forfeiture provisions;

    3. owner's misrepresentation that he directly owned the home was not an UTPA violation;

    4. misrepresentation in contract that third-party owned the home was not an UTPA violation;

    5. misrepresentation that purchaser was only a renter resulted in damages, thus supporting purchaser's UTPA claim; and

    6. phrase in connection with, as used in UTPA, encompassed owner's post-sale conduct. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.


  14. Matter of Adoption of Hannah L.

Supreme Court of Alaska. March 10, 2017 390 P.3d 1153 2017 WL 942608


FAMILY LAW Adoption. Evidence supported finding that it was not in child's best interests to grant stepfather's petition to adopt child.

Synopsis

Background: Stepfather petitioned to adopt wife's daughter over biological father's objection. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, No. 3PA-13-00149 PR, Vanessa White, J., denied the petition and stepfather appealed.

Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

  1. the superior court's issuance of its order on stepfather's motion for reconsideration two days after


    the motion was deemed denied did not violate the rules of civil procedure, and

  2. evidence supported finding that it was not in child's best interests to grant stepfather's petition to adopt child.

Affirmed.


76. Caitlyn E. v. State , Department of Health & Social Services , Office of Children's Services

Supreme Court of Alaska. June 16, 2017 399 P.3d 646 2017 WL 2609221


NATIVE AMERICANS Child Welfare. Witness was properly qualified as an expert in Indian child-rearing practices and child protection under Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA).

Synopsis

Background: Office of Children's Services (OCS) filed petition to terminate mother's parental rights to her two Indian children. Following trial, the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Bethel, Nos. 4BE-13-, Dwayne W. McConnell, J., terminated mother's parental rights. Mother appealed.

Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

  1. OCS's witness was properly qualified as an expert, and thus her testimony was properly admitted under Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA);

  2. any error in permitting OCS's witness to testify about substance and verbal abuse was harmless;

  3. witness's testimony was not improperly admitted under rule governing standard for admission of expert testimony;

  4. evidence supported determination that loss of mother's file did not demonstrate OCS failed to make active efforts to prevent breakup of family;

  5. evidence supported determination that OCS did not fail to make efforts to prevent breakup of family when it placed mother in minimally-invasive treatment center;

  6. OCS did not fail to make active efforts to prevent the breakup of family when it failed to help mother get back into treatment center;

  7. assignment of multiple caseworkers to mother did not demonstrate that OCS failed to make active efforts to prevent breakup of family; and

  8. OCS's efforts toward family as a whole supported determination that it took active efforts to prevent the breakup of family.

Affirmed.


  1. McAnally v. Thompson

    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 23, 2017 397 P.3d 322 2017 WL 2709741


    LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT Wrongful Discharge. An employer does not violate implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing by terminating an at-will employee for a personality conflict with another employee.

    Synopsis

    Background: Former city police captain brought wrongful termination employment action against city, mayor, and deputy mayor, alleging a breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing and retaliatory discharge based on his investigations of mayor. After dismissing captain's Alaska Whistleblower Act claim that he attempted to add in his trial brief without moving to amend his


    complaint, the Superior Court, Palmer, Third Judicial District, Kari Kristiansen, J., entered verdict in favor of defendants and awarded attorney fees and costs to city pursuant to city's prior offer of judgment. Captain appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, C.J., held that:

    1. trial court acted within its discretion in dismissing captain's claim under Alaska Whistleblower Act;

    2. an employer does not violate the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing by terminating an at-will employee for a personality conflict with another employee; and

    3. rule governing offers of judgment applied to allow trial court's award of attorney fees to city pursuant to offer of judgment city made to captain.

    Affirmed.


  2. Matter of Estate of Fields

    Supreme Court of Alaska. November 15, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 5504969


    ESTATE PLANNING AND PROBATE Estate Administration. Previous court order establishing constructive trust did not establish certain real property as part of decedent's estate.

    Synopsis

    Background: Personal representative of estate filed petition to close the estate. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, No. 4FA9100041 PR, Michael P. McConahy, J., entered order closing estate, directing that certain property be distributed to decedent's children, and directing that personal representative receive the rest of the estate as reimbursement for administrative expenses. Personal representative appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. previous court order establishing constructive trust did not establish certain real property as part of decedent's estate, and

    2. any error in trial court's denial of personal representative's request for reimbursement of appellate attorney's fees was harmless.

    Affirmed.


  3. Burnett v. Government Employees Insurance Company

Supreme Court of Alaska. January 27, 2017 389 P.3d 27 2017 WL 382648


INSURANCE Automobile. Automobile liability insurer could owe duty to cabin owner as result of decision to cleanup heating oil spill caused by insured.

Synopsis

Background: Cabin owner brought action against driver's automobile insurer to recover for failure to cleanup heating fuel spill for nearly two years after driver crashed truck into cabin. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Michael P. McConahy, J., entered summary judgment that insurer owed no actionable duty to owner. Owner appealed.

Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

  1. as a matter of first impression, liability insurer can owe tort duty to third party claimant when insurer's claims handling actions affirmatively create a new and independent duty to the claimant, and

  2. factual issues as to insurer's decision to cleanup precluded summary judgment on duty to owner. Reversed and remanded.


Maassen, J., dissented and filed opinion joined by Fabe, J.


80. Kollander v. Kollander

Supreme Court of Alaska. July 21, 2017 400 P.3d 91 2017 WL 3122385


FAMILY LAW Sanctions. Rule 11 sanctions on wife's attorney were warranted as he failed to conduct reasonable inquiry into factual basis of contempt motion against husband.

Synopsis

Background: Former wife sought to modify pension division in a qualified domestic relations order (QDRO). The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Mark Rindner, J., found former wife's claim barred by laches, and awarded full attorney fees and costs to former husband. Former wife appealed. The Supreme Court, 322 P.3d 897, affirmed trial court's application of laches, but remanded for recalculation of attorney fees. On remand, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No. 3AN-90-06548 CI, Mark Rindner, J., awarded enhanced attorney fees to former husband and issued a Rule 11 sanction against former wife's attorney. Former wife appealed.

Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carney, J., held that:

  1. trial court's award of enhanced attorney fees to former husband was warranted, and

  2. former wife's attorney failed to conduct a reasonable inquiry into the factual basis of his motions for contempt and to show cause accusing former husband and former husband's attorney of dishonesty, and thus trial court's issuance of Rule 11 sanctions on former wife's attorney was warranted.

Affirmed.


  1. Basey v. State , Department of Public Safety, Division of Alaska State Troopers, Bureau of Investigations

    Supreme Court of Alaska. December 29, 2017 408 P.3d 1173 2017 WL 6627023


    GOVERNMENT Records. Requestor was not involved in litigation with public agency, and thus statutory exception for records regarding such litigation did not apply.

    Synopsis

    Background: Requestor brought action against state police agency, seeking to compel police agency to produce certain public records related to police agency's criminal investigation of requestor. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, No. 4FA-16-02509 CI, Douglas Blankenship, J., granted police agency's motion to dismiss. Requestor appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

    1. requestor was not involved in litigation involving a public agency within meaning of statute providing that records sought by a person involved in litigation involving public agency shall be disclosed in accordance with the rules of procedure applicable in a court[,] and

    2. disclosure of records sought by requestor could not reasonably be expected to interfere with enforcement proceedings[,] and thus statute providing that public records were not subject to production if disclosing them could reasonably be expected to interfere with enforcement proceedings did not apply.

    Reversed and remanded.


  2. Ivy v. Calais Company, Inc.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 02, 2017 397 P.3d 267 2017 WL 2391462


    BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS Interest. Minority shareholder was entitled to post-judgment interest from corporation, less $447,500 she received in dividends after judgment was entered.

    Synopsis

    Background: Minority shareholder brought action for involuntary corporate dissolution, and shareholder and corporation settled, agreeing upon purchase of shareholder's shares based on valuation determined by appraisal. After the Alaska Supreme Court, 303 P.3d 410, reversed and remanded appraisers' initial valuation of corporation, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No. 3AN-07-08813 CI, William F. Morse, J., approved appraisers' second valuation but denied shareholder's motion for post-judgment interest. Shareholder appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

    1. trial court complied with mandate on remand to instruct appraisers that fair market value was not equivalent to fair value;

    2. shareholder failed to show that appraisers did not complete contractually assigned task;

    3. trial court did not abuse its discretion in determining that appraisers' report complied with its instructions;

    4. shareholder was entitled to post-judgment interest from corporation from date of entry of judgment; but

    5. corporation was entitled to deduct from its interest obligation the $447,500 shareholder received in corporate dividends following judgment.

    Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.


  3. Linus L. v. State , Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 09, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 3443674


    The superior court terminated a father's parental rights, finding that his children were in need of aid on five different grounds, including mental illness. The father, who has bipolar disorder, appeals the mental illness finding and the court's finding that the Office of Children's Services (OCS) made reasonable efforts to reunite the family. He...
