  4. Kocurek v. Wagner

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 03, 2017 390 P.3d 1144 2017 WL 839443


    TORTS Conversion. Jury verdict of $5,000 for wrongful conversion of Mexican artifact collection was not against the weight of the evidence.

    Synopsis

    Background: Artifact collector brought action against his business and personal acquaintance for conversion, alleging that acquaintance removed a Mexican artifact collection from his home without authorization. Following a jury verdict in favor of collector of $5,000, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eric A. Aarseth, J., No. 3AN1306181 CI, entered judgment in favor of collector.


    Collector appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, C.J., held that:

    1. trial court applied correct legal standard in denying collector's motion for a partial new trial on the issue of damages, and

    2. denial of motion was not an abuse of discretion, even though nothing in the record suggested that collection was worth exactly $5,000.

    Affirmed.


  5. Swaney v. Granger

    Supreme Court of Alaska. February 15, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 655746


    FAMILY LAW Jurisdiction. Alaska court had continuing, exclusive jurisdiction to modify child support, and thus, Alaska court's order releasing jurisdiction would be vacated.

    Synopsis

    Background: After custody arrangements between ex-wife and ex-husband were modified on ex-wife's motion, hearing was held on modification of support arrangement. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eric A. Aarseth, J., modified child support order. Ex-husband appealed. The Supreme Court, Fabe, C.J., 297 P.3d 132, vacated and remanded. On remand, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eric A. Aarseth, J., ordered ex-husband to pay ex-wife $2,960 per month, and he appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. it was not clearly erroneous for superior court to disallow $5,270.05 of the $8,840 ex-husband claimed as deduction for vehicle expenses and then divide the remaining expenses when calculating income of ex-husband, who was self-employed;

    2. trial court's summary disallowance of ex-husband's moving expenses was not supported by the record; and

    3. Alaska court had continuing, exclusive jurisdiction to modify child support order, and thus, Alaska court's order releasing jurisdiction would be vacated.

    Vacated and remanded.


  6. Radebaugh v. State , Department of Health & Social Services, Division of Senior & Disabilities Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 09, 2017 397 P.3d 285 2017 WL 2492753


    HEALTH Home Care. Substantial evidence supported termination of recipient's in-home nurse care benefits under waiver program.

    Synopsis

    Background: Recipient of in-home nursing care benefits through waiver program brought action challenging termination of her benefits by Department of Health and Social Services. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No. 3AN-13-07629 Cl, Kevin M. Saxby, J., affirmed. Recipient appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, C.J., held that:

    1. recipient waived her right to challenge her inability, at hearing, to cross-examine nurse who performed test to assess her eligibility for continued benefits;


    2. substantial evidence supported Department's termination of recipient's benefits; and

    3. Department adequately explained its reasoning for reversing ALJ's credibility determinations. Affirmed.


  7. Bonnie M. v. State

    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 07, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 2493100


    A mother who struggles with substance abuse and mental health issues had her four-month-old daughter taken into emergency custody by the Office of Children's Services (OCS) after an alcohol-related incident in June 2014. Her one-year-old son was living elsewhere and was not taken into OCS custody at the time. OCS worked with the mother over the...



  8. Mattox v. State Department of Corrections

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 19, 2017 397 P.3d 250 2017 WL 2209881


    LITIGATION Evidence. Discretionary function immunity jury instruction was not extraneous prejudicial information that could be considered when ruling on new trial motion.

    Synopsis

    Background: Inmate brought action against Department of Corrections (DOC), alleging that DOC was negligent in failing to accommodate his requests for transfer to different housing module prior to assault by another prisoner and in permitting correctional officer on duty to leave module during time assault occurred. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, Vanessa White, J., granted Department summary judgment. Inmate appealed. The Supreme Court, 323 P.3d 23, reversed and remanded. On remand, the Superior Court entered judgment, upon jury verdict, in favor of DOC and denied inmate's new trial motion. Inmate appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, C.J., held that:

    1. jury instruction regarding discretionary function immunity did not constitute extraneous prejudicial information that could be considered when determining whether to grant new trial;

    2. jurors' thoughts and analyses about whether to apply discretionary function immunity to DOC's decision to permit correctional officer on duty to leave housing module at time of alleged assault were not extraneous prejudicial information that could be considered when determining whether to grant new trial; and

    3. by failing to object to jury instruction on discretionary function immunity, inmate impliedly consented to have jury apply that accurate statement of law to facts as jury found them.

    Affirmed.


  9. In re District Court Judge

Supreme Court of Alaska. March 10, 2017 392 P.3d 480 2017 WL 942607


JUDICIAL ADMINISTRATION Discipline. Judge's failure to publicly address retention campaign advertisements produced by independent campaign did not violate canons of judicial conduct.



Synopsis

Background: Alaska Commission on Judicial Conduct, No. 2014-007, initiated judicial discipline proceedings against District Court judge and imposed informal private admonishment for failure to correct statements made by independent campaign in judicial election. Judge filed application for relief following denial of motion for reconsideration, which the Supreme Court granted.

Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

  1. conduct of judge in failing to publicly address mailer and website produced by independent campaign did not violate canons of judicial conduct, and

  2. conduct of judge in failing to publicly address social media advertisement did not violate canons of judicial conduct.

Admonishment reversed; complaint dismissed.


90. Dennis O. v. Stephanie O.

Supreme Court of Alaska. March 17, 2017 393 P.3d 401 2017 WL 1034529


FAMILY LAW Child Custody. Indigent father did not have an individual due process right to counsel in child custody case.

Synopsis

Background: Mother moved to modify custody order, seeking sole legal and primary physical custody of all four children, and after referral by the Superior Court, Family Court master denied father's request for court appointed counsel. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, Gregory Heath, J., adopted the master's recommendations and awarded mother primary physical and sole legal custody of the children. Father appealed.

Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

  1. any error by the Superior Court in failing to address the master's denial of father's request for court appointed counsel when the court adopted the master's custody recommendations was harmless;

  2. indigent father did not have an individual due process right to counsel in child custody case; and

  3. statutory provision that required the office of public advocacy (OPA) to represent indigent parents in cases involving child custody in which the opposing party is represented by counsel provided by a public agency, but did not require the OPA, or any other state-appointed counsel, to represent indigent parents if the opposing party is represented by private counsel, did not violate indigent father's equal protection rights under State constitution.

Affirmed.


91. Patterson v. Cox

Supreme Court of Alaska. November 29, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 5999883


TRANSPORTATION Jury. Court did not abuse its discretion in permitting parties' attorneys and party himself to talk with alternate jurors after their release from jury duty.

Synopsis

Background: Motorist, who alleged that he stopped to avoid vehicle in front of him and that his seatbelt failed when he was rear-ended, brought suit against manufacturer of his vehicle, driver of car that was in front of him, and rear-ending driver. The Superior Court entered judgment on jury verdict


finding that driver in car in front of motorist and manufacturer were not negligent. Motorist appealed. The Supreme Court reversed and remanded. After trial on remand, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, William F. Morse, J., Superior Court No. 3AN0811817 Ci, entered judgment on jury verdict finding that front driver and manufacturer were not negligent, and motorist appealed.

Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

  1. trial court did not abuse its discretion in permitting the parties' attorneys and motorist himself to talk with alternate jurors after their release from jury duty;

  2. prospective juror could return to the courtroom after a voir dire conference;

  3. trial court did not abuse its discretion in denying motorist's for cause challenge to juror, who was acquainted with family members of attorney for vehicle manufacturer;

  4. fact that only 11 of the 12 jurors voted that driver, who was in front of motorist, was not negligent did not warrant mistrial;

  5. trial court did not abuse its discretion in allowing manufacturer's witnesses to be present in courtroom and listen to each other testify;

  6. trial court did not abuse its discretion by allowing driver and manufacturer to replace expert witness used in first trial with new expert for the second trial;

  7. engineer was qualified as an expert to testify about seatbelt buckles, the estimated speed of the collision, and recalls; and

  8. motorist's wife was not a party and, therefore, could not bring a claim for loss of spousal consortium. Affirmed.


92. Bruce H. v. Jennifer L.

Supreme Court of Alaska. October 06, 2017 407 P.3d 432 2017 WL 4450886


FAMILY LAW Child Custody. Evidence supported court's finding that mother's move with child was legitimate in child custody action.

Synopsis

Background: Father filed for modification of child custody, and mother filed motion seeking authorization to relocate with child out of state. The Superior Court Third Judicial District, Unalaska, Pat

L. Douglass, J., denied father's motion for modification and granted mother authorization to move. Father appealed.

Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

  1. determination that mother did not commit acts of domestic violence against a boyfriend was based on clearly erroneous factual findings and erroneous legal conclusions;

  2. evidence supported court's finding that mother's move with child was legitimate;

  3. findings of child's best interests, with the exception of an erroneous finding concerning mother's domestic violence, were supported by evidence; and

  4. court failed to make required findings in making a limited visitation award to father. Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.


  1. Kylie L. v. State Department of Health & Social Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. October 13, 2017 407 P.3d 442 2017 WL 4558786


    FAMILY LAW Child Protection. Trial court's determination that state failed to make reasonable efforts to reunify mother with child was supported by evidence in the record.



    Synopsis

    Background: Office of Children's Services (OCS) petitioned to terminate parental rights to child. After finding that OCS had failed to demonstrate it had made reasonable efforts to reunify a family, the Superior Court, Fairbanks, Fourth Judicial District, No. 4FA-13-00120 CN, Michael P. McConahy, J., found OCS's failure was excused and terminated mother's parental rights. Mother appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

    1. trial court's determination that OCS failed to demonstrate it had made reasonable efforts to reunify mother with child was supported by evidence in the record, and

    2. trial court was required to find by clear and convincing evidence that one of the bases in Child In Need of Aid (CINA) statutory provision governing reasonable efforts requirement applied to excuse OCS from making reasonable efforts, and thus court was not permitted to exclusively rely on its conviction that further efforts would be pointless in excusing OCS's failure.

    Order of the Superior Court reversed, vacated, and remanded.


  2. Horning v. Horning

    Supreme Court of Alaska. February 17, 2017 389 P.3d 61 2017 WL 655745


    FAMILY LAW Marital Property. Wife's eligibility to receive Indian Health Service (IHS) healthcare was separate property in divorce action.

    Synopsis

    Background: Husband filed for divorce from wife. Following trial, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Erin B. Marston, J., entered final property distribution order dividing the marital estate without classifying, valuing, or distributing either party's healthcare. Wife appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

    1. husband's post-retirement military health insurance benefit was marital property to the extent that it was earned during the marriage,

    2. as matter of first impression, wife's eligibility to receive Indian Health Service (IHS) healthcare was acquired before marriage, and thus was separate property; and

    3. trial court could not invade wife's separate property by using that property to offset the value of husband's marital property.

    Vacated and remanded.


  3. Alaska Building, Inc. v. Legislative Affairs Agency

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 25, 2017 403 P.3d 1132 2017 WL 3666552


    LITIGATION Sanctions. Argument that plaintiff was entitled to compensation in form of percentage of savings stemming from invalidation of illegal lease was not frivolous.

    Synopsis

    Background: Building owner brought action against Legislative Affairs Agency and private developer, alleging that Agency and developer had entered into an illegal lease for the building next door to owner's The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No. 3AN-15-05969 CI, Patrick J. McKay, J., invalidated lease, but determined that owner's claim for compensation was frivolous and justified imposition of sanctions. Owner appealed.


    [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that owner's argument that it was entitled to monetary compensation in form of percentage of savings stemming from invalidation of illegal lease was not frivolous.

    Reversed and remanded

    Bolger, J., filed dissenting opinion.


  4. Shanigan v. Shanigan

    Supreme Court of Alaska. January 06, 2017 386 P.3d 1238 2017 WL 65345


    FAMILY LAW Child Support. Court's reliance on Child Support Services Division's erroneous income calculations resulted in unwarranted modification of child support obligation.

    Synopsis

    Background: Child Support Services Division (CSSD) filed motion to modify father's existing child support obligation to reflect its new calculations. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Patrick J. McKay, J., entered order reducing father's child support obligation. Mother appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

    1. CSSD incorrectly calculated father's adjusted annual income by overstating his federal income tax obligations;

    2. CSSD incorrectly calculated father's adjusted annual income by overstating his Medicare tax obligations;

    3. Superior Court's reliance on CSSD's calculations for father's adjusted annual income resulted in unwarranted modification of father's child support obligation; and

    4. father was required to submit income affidavit before Superior Court could grant requested child support modification.

    Reversed.


  5. Estate of James V. Seward

    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 02, 2017 401 P.3d 976 2017 WL 2391461


    ESTATE PLANNING AND PROBATE Beneficiaries. Paternity adjudication could be made during estate proceedings to determine whether man claiming to be decedent's son was entitled to share in estate.

    Synopsis

    Background: Man claiming to be decedent's son filed motions in probate proceeding requesting genetic testing on decedent's cremated remains and attempting to share in decedent's estate. Man's mother filed numerous motions claiming to be creditor of decedent's estate and seeking recovery of child support. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No. 3AN-13-02105 Pr, Erin B. Marston, J., denied motions. Man petitioned for review by Supreme Court, and Supreme Court converted petition for review into appeal and ordered full briefing.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

    1. paternity adjudication could be made during probate estate proceedings to determine whether man claiming to be decedent's son was in fact decedent's son;

    2. laches was not available defense to preclude man and his mother from pursuing their requests for declaratory judgment and related legal relief;


    3. even if man was decedent's son and man's mother had standing to assert her claim for long-past-due child support, ten-year statute of limitations period barred mother's claim as creditor of decedent's estate for child support;

    4. personal representative's mistake in including the wrong year that will was executed in her paperwork opening the estate did not affect Superior Court's acceptance of the will for probate;

    5. even if man claiming to be decedent's son was in fact decedent's son, man could not obtain statutory homestead allowance or family allowance from decedent's estate; and

    6. if man claiming to be decedent's son was in fact decedent's son, man could obtain statutory exempt property allowance from decedent's estate.

    Affirmed in part and reversed in part.


  6. Burton v. Fountainhead Development, Inc.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 17, 2017 393 P.3d 387 2017 WL 1034376


    TORTS Tortious Interference. Hotel owner did not tortiously interfere with employee's prospective business relationship with tour company by making defamatory statements.

    Synopsis

    Background: Employee of tour company brought action against owner of hotel, alleging defamation and tortious interference, after hotel management stated employee was difficult to work with, and tour company fired employee. Following bench trial, the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, No. 4FA-12-01642 CI, Jane F. Kauvar, J., 2015 WL 5159738, awarded employee $15,000 in general damages and denied employee's motion to amend complaint. Employee appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

    1. owner was protected by conditional business privilege and, thus, was not liable for tortious interference with prospective business relationship;

    2. employee's termination was caused by refusal to work at other locations, rather than owner's defamatory statements;

    3. general damages award was proper;

    4. employee was not entitled to special damages; and

    5. employee was not entitled to punitive damages. Affirmed.


  7. Jovanov v. State Department of Corrections

    Supreme Court of Alaska. September 15, 2017 404 P.3d 140 2017 WL 4079130


    TORTS Judgment. Trial court's sua sponte grant of summary judgment to DOC on its counterclaim for medical costs was reversible error in inmate's negligence action.

    Synopsis

    Background: Inmate brought action against Department of Corrections (DOC), corrections officer and fellow prisoner, seeking to recover for injuries sustained when inmate was attacked by fellow prisoner. DOC counterclaimed for the cost of the medical treatment inmate received. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No. 3AN-12-10167 CI, Mark Rindner, J., granted summary judgment in favor of inmate against fellow prisoner on the issue of liability, and in favor of DOC on its counterclaim. Inmate appealed.


    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, C.J., held that:

    1. attack on inmate was not foreseeable;

    2. officer's five-second response time was reasonable

    3. discretionary function immunity precluded claims arising out of DOC decisions regarding resource allocation;

    4. DOC was not required to seek medical-cost reimbursement from fellow prisoner, rather than from injured inmate;

    5. trial court's sua sponte grant of summary judgment to DOC on its counterclaim was reversible error;

    6. trial court committed plain error in issuing a complete judgment in DOC's favor, where inmate's claim against fellow prisoner was still live; and

    7. DOC's counterclaim did not improperly curtail inmate's right to access the courts. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, vacated in part and remanded.


  8. Horner-Neufeld v. University of Alaska Fairbanks

Supreme Court of Alaska. January 20, 2017 389 P.3d 6 2017 WL 280689


EDUCATION Abuse and Harassment. Substantial evidence supported findings by university office of equal opportunity (OEO) that university did not discriminate against graduate student.

Synopsis

Background: Former graduate student appealed decision by university upholding determination by university office of equal opportunity (OEO) that student's dismissal from Ph.D. program was not product of discrimination or retaliation, and claiming that university violated due process and breached duties owed to her under implied contract. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Jane

F. Kauvar, J., denied trial de novo, 2013 WL 10569019, and dismissed appeal, 2014 WL 8764782.

Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

  1. substantial evidence supported OEO's findings that university did not subject student to hostile education environment or discrimination;

  2. record reflected that OEO's investigation was through and legitimate;

  3. student was not entitled to trial de novo;

  4. university substantially complied with its own published policies and did not act arbitrarily, unreasonably, or in abuse of discretion;

  5. university complied with academic due process in dismissing student; and

  6. university complied with substantive due process in dismissing student. Affirmed.


101. Reasner v. State Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

Supreme Court of Alaska. May 19, 2017 394 P.3d 610 2017 WL 2209883


TORTS Negligence. Fact issue as to whether foster parents completed training precluded summary judgment in negligence case against Office of Children's Services.

Synopsis

Background: Alleged victim of sexual abuse by her foster brother brought action against Office of Children's Services (OCS), alleging that OCS was negligent in investigating reports of harm occurring


while OCS had legal custody of her, in supervising and monitoring her foster home, and in failing to investigate reports of harm after she was adopted by foster parents. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, 2014 WL 11191026, granted OCS summary judgment. Following denial of her motion for reconsideration, 2015 WL 10527223, alleged victim appealed, and OCS cross-appealed. Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

  1. fact issue as to when victim discovered information suggesting that OCS played role in allowing her to be abused precluded summary judgment on statute of limitations grounds;

  2. victim's action against OCS was not for conduct that amounted to felony sexual abuse of a minor, within meaning of statute allowing person to bring suit any time for certain conduct;

  3. OCS was not protected by discretionary function immunity, under Tort Claims Act, from victim's negligent investigation claim; and

  4. fact issue as to whether victim's foster parents completed required training precluded summary judgment on victim's claim against OCS for negligent monitoring of foster home.

Reversed in part and remanded.


  1. Todeschi v. Sumitomo Metal Mining Pogo, LLC

    Supreme Court of Alaska. April 28, 2017 394 P.3d 562 2017 WL 1534545


    LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT Discrimination. Reasonable jury could find breach of covenant of good faith and fair dealing and also find, consistently, that supervisor did not prove claim for disability discrimination.

    Synopsis

    Background: Former supervisor sued his employer, alleging breach of the covenant of good faith and fair dealing and unlawful discrimination based both on a disability and on his assertion of workers' compensation claim. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, William F. Morse, J., entered judgment on jury's verdict finding the employer liable for breach of the covenant of good faith and fair dealing, but finding in the employer's favor on the supervisor's other claims. Supervisor appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

    1. issue as to whether supervisor had disability was for jury;

    2. jury could find a breach of the covenant of good faith and fair dealing and also find, consistently, that supervisor did not prove the elements of a claim for disability discrimination;

    3. superior court did not abuse its discretion by refusing to give burden shifting instruction as remedy for negligent spoliation of records;

    4. any error in trial court's failing to give permissible adverse inference instruction as remedy for spoliation of evidence was harmless; and

    5. jury instruction arguably raising an untimely statute of limitations defense did not affect jury's verdict. Affirmed.


  2. Alex H. v. State Department of Health & Social Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. February 10, 2017 389 P.3d 35 2017 WL 541393


    FAMILY LAW Child Protection. Incarcerated father's due process rights were not violated by denial of his request for transportation to attend termination of parental rights trial.



    Synopsis

    Background: Office of Children's Services (OCS) petitioned to terminate incarcerated father's parental rights. Father sought order requiring the Department of Public Safety (DPS) to transport him from jail to the courthouse so that he could attend the termination trial in person. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Michael P. McConahy, J., denied father's request and terminated father's parental rights. Father appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

    1. trial court did not abuse its discretion by denying father's statutory request for transportation to attend in person his termination of parental rights trial;

    2. trial court's failure to sua sponte address all eight factors in conducting its prisoner transport analysis was not plain error;

    3. trial court did not exact penalty for father's assertion of his right against self-incrimination by considering father's decision not to testify in determining whether to grant father's request for transportation; and

    4. father's due process rights were not violated by trial court's denial of his request for transportation. Affirmed.


  3. Wright v. Anding

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 17, 2017 390 P.3d 1162 2017 WL 1033960


    CIVIL RIGHTS Prisons. Corrections officials did not show deliberate indifference to inmate's complaints of hearing loss by failing to provide him with hearing aids.

    Synopsis

    Background: Inmate, who was released from confinement at some point in the proceedings, brought action against operator of private correctional facility that contracted with the Department of Corrections, one of its employees, and an employee of the department alleging medical malpractice and deliberate indifference to his medical needs under 1983 during his incarceration both at the private facility and in a facility operated by the Department. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No. 3AN-13-08114 CI, Patrick J. McKay, J., awarded summary judgment to defendants and denied inmate's motion for reconsideration. Inmate appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, C.J., held that:

    1. judge who presided over inmate's criminal trial was not disqualified from presiding over inmate's medical malpractice and 1983 action;

    2. inmate's medical malpractice claims accrued, for purposes of the two-year statute of limitations, no later than when inmate underwent a hearing examination that he alleged confirmed that he had sustained damage to his hearing; and

    3. corrections officials did not show deliberate indifference to inmate's complaints of hearing loss by failing to provide him with hearing aids.

    Affirmed.


  4. Daggett v. Feeney

Supreme Court of Alaska. June 16, 2017 397 P.3d 297 2017 WL 2609223


ENERGY AND UTILITIES Alternate Energy. Renewable energy limited liability company (LLC)



that installed wind turbines was required to register as steel erection contractor.

Synopsis

Background: Property owner brought action against renewable energy limited liability company (LLC), seeking rescission of contract to install wind turbine and to recover his down payment. LLC counterclaimed for breach of contract. Following bench trial, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Homer, No. 3HO-11-00359 CI, Charles T. Huguelet, J., ordered contract rescinded and return of down payment less setoff, and after LLC failed to pay, amended judgment to add LLC's members and successor company. Members appealed, and property owner cross-appealed.

Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carney, J., held that:

  1. wind turbine installation did not qualify for finished product exemption under contractor registration statutes, and, thus, LLC was required to register as steel erection contractor;

  2. trial court's finding that members knew that LLC needed to be registered under contractor registration statutes was not clear error;

  3. statute requiring contractors to be registered to bring certain claims barred LLC's breach-of-contract claim;

  4. statute requiring contractors to be registered to bring certain claims barred LLC's claim for remedies for wrongful rejection under Uniform Commercial Code (UCC);

  5. trial court did not abuse its discretion when it awarded LLC equitable setoff based on costs incurred by LLC, rather than on any benefits received by property owner;

  6. trial court failed to consider actual amount of profit made by LLC on resale of wind turbine, when calculating equitable setoff, warranting remand; and

  7. trial court did not abuse its discretion when it extended deadline for property owner to move to amend judgment.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.


106. Douglas Indian Association v. Central Council of Tlingit and Haida Indian Tribes of Alaska

Supreme Court of Alaska. September 08, 2017 403 P.3d 1172 2017 WL 3928701


NATIVE AMERICANS Sovereign Immunity. Tribal sovereign immunity is jurisdictional bar properly raised in motion to dismiss for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.

Synopsis

Background: First Indian tribe brought action against second Indian tribe and two of its tribal officials after first tribe withdrew from consortium formed by second tribe to administer tribal transportation funds from federal government but second tribe failed to remit first tribe's funds as required by agreement. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, No. 1JU-15-00625 Ci, Louis J. Menendez, J., granted second tribe's motion to dismiss based on sovereign immunity. First tribe appealed.

Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

  1. tribal sovereign immunity is jurisdictional bar properly raised in motion to dismiss for lack of subject matter jurisdiction;

  2. trial court did not abuse its discretion by denying jurisdictional discovery to first tribe;

  3. Ex parte Young doctrine does not allow suit to proceed against tribal official based on contract claim merely because plaintiff seeks declaratory and injunctive relief; and

  4. trial court did not have jurisdiction over first tribe's claims that officials were not protected by sovereign immunity because their actions were ultra vires.


Affirmed.


  1. Jack C. v. State , Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. April 21, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 1423177


    FAMILY LAW Child Protection. Evidence supported finding that the Office of Children's Services (OCS) made reasonable efforts to reunite father with child.

    Synopsis

    Background: The Office of Children's Services (OCS) petitioned to terminate parental rights. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No. 3AN1400484 CN, Gregory Miller, J., terminated mother and father's parental rights. Father appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. the trial court's denial of father's motion for a continuance of termination of parental rights trial, in order to access services that were unavailable while he was incarcerated, was not an abuse of discretion, and

    2. Evidence supported finding that the OCS made reasonable efforts to reunite father with child. Affirmed.


  2. Brandner v. Providence Health & ServicesWashington

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 19, 2017 394 P.3d 581 2017 WL 2209878


    HEALTH Discipline. Hospital violated physician's procedural due process rights by terminating his hospital privileges without a pre-termination opportunity to be heard.

    Synopsis

    Background: After hospital terminated physician's hospital privileges for failing to report State Medical Board order requiring him to undergo a fitness evaluation, physician brought action against hospital and members of hospital's executive committee and fair hearing panel, alleging due process violations, defamation, breach of contract, and other contract claims. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Patrick J. McKay, J., 2014 WL 8396238, granted summary judgment in favor of the committee and panel members, and the Supreme Court, Bolger, J., 349 P.3d 1068, affirmed that decision. Following a non-jury trial on the due process claims against hospital, the Superior Court, McKay, J., 2015 WL 4610241, entered judgment in favor of hospital. Physician appealed.

    Holdings: On rehearing, the Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

    1. physician did not waive his due process right to a pre-termination opportunity to be heard;

    2. hospital violated physician's procedural due process rights by terminating his hospital privileges without a pre-termination opportunity to be heard;

    3. hospital's reporting policy was not impermissibly vague or ambiguous as applied to physician;

    4. hospital did not apply its reporting policy arbitrarily or capriciously and, thus, did not violate physician's substantive due process rights; and

    5. hospital was not entitled to Health Care Quality Improvement Act (HCQIA) immunity on physician's pre-termination due process claim.

    Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded. Opinion, 384 P.3d 773, superseded.



  3. Hodari v. State, Department of Corrections

    Supreme Court of Alaska. October 27, 2017 407 P.3d 468 2017 WL 4855403


    CRIMINAL JUSTICE Prisons. Request for fee itemization was sufficient to require inmate as prevailing party on appeal to submit itemization of attorney's fees.

    Synopsis

    Background: Inmate appealed decision by the Department of Corrections finding him guilty of disciplinary infraction for planning an escape from correctional center. While appeal was pending, the Department reversed its decision. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No. 3AN-14-09035 CI, Charles W. Ray, Jr., J., determined that inmate had effectively prevailed on his appeal and awarded inmate attorney's fees. Inmate appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carney, J., held that:

    1. Department's request for fee itemization in its opposition to inmate's motion for attorney's fees was sufficiently specific and cognizable to require inmate to submit fee itemization, and

    2. any abuse of discretion in Superior Court's decision to award attorney's fees to inmate without fee itemization was harmless.

    Affirmed.


  4. Dara v. Gish

    Supreme Court of Alaska. September 22, 2017 404 P.3d 154 2017 WL 4185401


    FAMILY LAW Child Custody. Clear and convincing evidence supported finding child would suffer clear detriment if mother was given sole custody, in custody dispute with grandparents.

    Synopsis

    Background: Maternal grandmother and step-grandfather filed a petition for custody of grandchild. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No. 3AN-14-04479 CI, Erin B. Marston, J., granted joint legal of child to mother and maternal grandmother and step-grandfather, primary physical custody of child to maternal grandmother and step-grandfather, and awarded mother visitation. Mother appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

    1. mother was not entitled to appointed counsel in child custody dispute;

    2. mother's due process right to direct the upbringing and education of her child was not violated by the trial court's order granting maternal grandmother and step-grandfather primary physical custody of child; and

    3. clear and convincing evidence supported finding that child would suffer clear detriment if mother was given sole custody of child.

    Affirmed.


  5. Jude M. v. State Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services


    Supreme Court of Alaska. April 28, 2017 394 P.3d 543 2017 WL 1533373


    NATIVE AMERICANS Child Welfare. Evidence did not support findings that father posed risk of sexually re-offending and that risk included child, as basis for foster care placement under ICWA.

    Synopsis

    Background: Office of Children's Services (OCS) filed petition to terminate father's parental rights to Native American child adjudicated as child in need of aid. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Andrew Guidi, J., declined to terminate parental rights, but instead established long-term guardianship over child placed with foster family out-of-state. Father appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

    1. superior court had statutory authority to establish long-term guardianship over child after it declined to terminate father's parental rights;

    2. regulation prohibiting agency from placing child in guardianship without evidence that parental rights have been terminated or suspended did not apply;

    3. long-term guardianship was not de facto termination of father's parental rights that failed to comply with Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA);

    4. active efforts were made to provide remedial and rehabilitative services designed to prevent breakup of family, as prerequisite to foster care placement/guardianship under ICWA;

    5. determination that father, who was convicted sex offender, posed significant risk of re-offending and that risk encompassed child, was not supported by expert testimony;

    6. evidence supported finding that father was unable to meet child's caregiving needs, and thus, that father's continued custody of child was likely to result in serious emotional or physical harm;

    7. evidence supported finding that long-term guardianship under current foster family placement was in child's best interest.

    Vacated; remanded.

    Stowers, C.J., filed opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part, in which Winfree, J., joined.


  6. Schaeffer-Mathis v. Mathis

    Supreme Court of Alaska. October 27, 2017 407 P.3d 485 2017 WL 4855445


    FAMILY LAW Child Custody. Trial court did not abuse discretion by failing to explicitly discuss children's preferences when making child custody determination.

    Synopsis

    Background: Wife instituted divorce proceedings. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, No. 3PA-11-02658 Cl, Vanessa White, J., granted divorce, distributed marital estate equally, and granted husband sole legal custody of children while affording parties shared physical custody of children. Wife appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, C.J., held that:

    1. trial court did not abuse its discretion by denying wife's request for update to court's initial child custody investigation;

    2. trial court did not abuse its discretion by failing to explicitly discuss children's preferences when making child custody determination;

    3. trial court did not clearly err in finding, as factor in determining child custody, that husband was more motivated than wife to focus on children's needs; and

    4. trial court clearly erred in determining that student loan debt incurred by wife during parties' marriage was not marital debt.

    Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.



  7. Nicholas H. v. State

    Supreme Court of Alaska. February 06, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 477770


    FAMILY LAW Child Protection. Evidence supported finding that the Office of Children's Services had made active, but unsuccessful, efforts to prevent the breakup of Indian family.

    Synopsis

    Background: The Office of Children's Services (OCS) petitioned to terminate mother and father's parental rights to Indian child. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eric A. Aarseth, J., terminated parental rights. Father appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. evidence supported finding that father was not meaningfully engaged in his case plan;

    2. the trial court's failure to credit the testimony of father's witnesses over the testimony of the OCS witnesses was not clearly erroneous; and

    3. evidence supported finding that the OCS had made active, but unsuccessful, efforts to prevent the breakup of Indian family.

    Affirmed.


  8. Whittenton v. Peter Pan Seafoods, Inc.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. September 22, 2017 421 P.3d 1133 2017 WL 4211497


    LITIGATION Costs. Mother, who failed to beat defendant's offer of judgment in personal injury case, was subject to cost penalties under the offer of judgment rule.

    Synopsis

    Background: Mother and daughter who were involved in car accident brought action against employer of other vehicle's driver, seeking damages for pain and suffering, and father brought loss of consortium claim. Following a jury trial, in which all three plaintiffs were awarded damages, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Valdez, Daniel Schally, J., awarded partial attorney fees to employer because mother's award was less than 95% of an offer of judgment. Mother appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carney, J., held that:

    1. employer's offer of judgment to mother was sufficient to trigger cost penalties against mother under the offer of judgment rule, and

    2. because mother failed to beat the offer of judgment, she was subject to cost penalties under the rule.

    Affirmed.


  9. Haines v. Comfort Keepers, Inc.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 24, 2017 393 P.3d 422 2017 WL 1102813


    TORTS Jury. Representative did not waive his right to jury trial by applying for default judgment on condition that jury determine damages in conversion action.



    Synopsis

    Background: Elderly woman brought action against in-home care company and in-home assistant, alleging claims for negligent hiring, conversion, assault and battery, breach of contract, and unjust enrichment. After woman died, the personal representative of her estate was substituted as plaintiff. Personal representative accepted offer of judgment from company, and applied for entry of default against assistant. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No. 3AN-11-12882 CI, Paul E. Olson, J., 2015 WL 12020710, entered default judgment against assistant and following bench trial awarded no damages. Personal representative appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

    1. personal representative had adequate remedy at law for recovering value of woman's medication that assistant converted, and thus, restitution was not available as equitable alternative;

    2. trial court did not abuse its discretion in declining to hold that assistant waived any objections to written discovery as sanction for her failure to timely respond;

    3. jury trial on damages following entry of default in civil action was not required by state constitution;

    4. personal representative did not waive his right to jury trial by applying for entry of default against assistant on the condition that damages be determined by jury;

    5. trial court abused its discretion in granting personal representative's application for entry of default without giving effect to representative's express condition that damages be decided by jury upon which the application was made;

    6. testimony by elderly woman's daughters and son-in-law put in controversy questioned allegation in complaint that assistant caused woman physical injuries and harm, and thus, trial court in default proceeding was required to accept as proven the allegation and award noneconomic damages; and

    7. well-pleaded allegations satisfied elements of assault in the fourth-degree, and thus, trial court in default proceeding was required to award attorney's fees to representative under statute allowing injured person to recover attorney's fees if injury resulted from serious criminal offense.

    Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.


  10. Judd v. Burns

Supreme Court of Alaska. July 07, 2017 397 P.3d 331 2017 WL 2884382


FAMILY LAW Child Custody. Evidence supported finding that modifying custody to grant mother physical custody of child to move out of state was in child's best interests.

Synopsis

Background: Mother moved for modification of child custody agreement, pursuant to which parties had equal shared custody of child, seeking primary physical custody to allow her to move out of state. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Michael P. McConahy, J., granted primary physical custody to mother and modified legal custody to allow mother final decision-making authority. Father appealed.

Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

  1. trial court did not clearly err in finding that mother's out-of-state move was legitimate;

  2. trial court did not abuse its discretion in declining to appoint custody investigator in response to mother's modification motion;

  3. trial court did not abuse its discretion in limiting modification hearing to two hours;

  4. trial court did not abuse its discretion in determining that modification of custody agreement to grant mother primary physical custody of child was in child's best interests; and

  5. trial court abused its discretion by modifying legal custody to grant mother final decision-making authority, subject to later court ratification.

Affirmed in part and vacated in part.



117. Government Employees Insurance Company v. Gonzalez

Supreme Court of Alaska. August 25, 2017 403 P.3d 1153 2017 WL 3666576


INSURANCE Bad Faith and Unfair Practices. Punitive damages award of $450,000 for underinsured motorist carrier's delay in paying benefits did not violate due process.

Synopsis

Background: Insured brought action against underinsured motorist (UIM) carrier to recover for breach of contract and bad faith and against adjuster to recover for negligence in handling claim. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Sen. K. Tan, J., No. 3AN-00-12188 CI, 2013 WL 10408626, entered judgment on jury verdict against insurer and in favor of adjuster, required carrier to pay nominal and punitive damages, required it to pay costs and attorney fees, required insured to pay adjuster's fees, and refused insured's request for entry of judgment nunc pro tunc. Carrier appealed, and insured filed cross-appeal.

Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

  1. insured was entitled to nominal damages;

  2. $450,000 punitive damages award complied with due process;

  3. pre-judgment interest began to run at least as of date of letter from insured's attorney threatening bad faith suit;

  4. evidence created jury question on damages for financial and emotional distress;

  5. amending judgment nunc pro tunc would not be correct procedural device for attempting to alter accrual date for post-judgment interest;

  6. treating insured as prevailing party and awarding attorney fees and costs was not abuse of discretion;

  7. adjuster did not waive right to attorney fees; but

  8. adjuster failed to satisfy burden to show attorney fees related to his defense. Affirmed in part and remanded.


118. Alaska Airlines, Inc. v. Darrow

Supreme Court of Alaska. August 25, 2017 403 P.3d 1116 2017 WL 3666550


LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT Workers' Compensation. Statute that allowed reduction to PTD benefits by amount of previously paid PPD benefits did not authorize any offset for previously paid PPI.

Synopsis

Background: Employer appealed and claimant, who suffered job-related knee injury, cross-appealed decision by Workers' Compensation Appeals Commission that allowed offset to employer's payment of permanent total disability (PTD) compensation for employer's earlier permanent partial impairment (PPI) payments, but denied offset for social security disability benefits.

Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carney, J., held that:

  1. phrase average weekly wages at the time of injury used in workers' compensation statute governing offset for social security disability benefits against PTD payments was not limited to claimant's actual wage at time of injury;

  2. statute that allowed reduction to PTD benefits by amount of previously paid permanent partial


    disability (PPD) benefits did not authorize any offset for previously paid PPI benefits; and

  3. regulation stating that PPD benefits included PPI benefits was invalid. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.


  1. Timothy W. v. Julia M.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 25, 2017 403 P.3d 1095 2017 WL 3662468


    FAMILY LAW Visitation. Father's criminal trespass and coercion offenses against girlfriend were qualifying offenses under statute employing presumption against unsupervised visitation.

    Synopsis

    Background: Mother filed a postdissolution motion to modify visitation. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No. 3AN-12-06387 CI, Frank A. Pfiffner, J., ordered father to have supervised visitation until he completed a parenting class and a batterer intervention program. Father appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

    1. the trial court's determination that there was no bias or appearance of bias warranting recusal of judge was not an abuse of discretion;

    2. the trial court's decision declining to close the hearing to the public was not an abuse of discretion;

    3. evidence supported finding that father committed the offense of coercion against his girlfriend;

    4. father's commission of criminal trespass and coercion against his girlfriend constituted qualifying offenses under statute employing a presumption against unsupervised visitation if a party committed three or more domestic violence offenses; and

    5. remand for additional findings was required to determine whether father and his girlfriend were domestic living partners when father's three crimes of domestic violence occurred.

    Affirmed in part; vacated and remanded in part.


  2. Scott v. Gaines

    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 14, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 2610503


    FAMILY LAW Child Custody. Court did not abuse its discretion in finding substantial change in circumstances so as to warrant modifying custody.

    Synopsis

    Background: Ex-husband filed a motion to modify custody. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Gregory Miller, J., awarded primary physical custody to ex-husband and liberal visitation to ex-wife and awarded ex-husband a portion of his attorney fees. Ex-wife appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. superior court did not abuse its discretion in finding a substantial change in circumstances so as to warrant modifying custody;

    2. trial court's best interests findings were not clearly erroneous; and

    3. superior court did not abuse its discretion by awarding attorneys fees to ex-husband. Affirmed.


  3. Bibi v. Elfrink

    Supreme Court of Alaska. September 22, 2017 408 P.3d 809 2017 WL 4211490


    REAL PROPERTY Interest. Value generated by foreclosure sale constituted payment under usury statute and, thus, borrower was entitled to recover double amount of usurious interest paid.

    Synopsis

    Background: Lender of $10,000 for purchase of home brought action for forcible entry and detainer to remove husband and wife following their default, lender's foreclosure proceedings, and lender's purchase of home at foreclosure sale. Wife filed counterclaim for usury, quiet title, and possession. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Gregory Miller, J., No. 3AN-14-05970 Ci, found for lender on his claim for title and possession and denied wife's counterclaims. Wife appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, C.J., held that:

    1. wife had standing to bring counterclaim for usury;

    2. finding fee charged by lender was disguised interest and, thus, interest he charged was usurious;

    3. modifications to original loan did not constitute separate loans but, brought loan principal over

      $25,000 and, thus, 12 percent interest established by modification was not usurious;

    4. debtor may only recover under usury statute after she has paid sum greater than principal plus lawful interest;

    5. value generated by foreclosure sale constituted payment under usury statute;

    6. counterclaim for usury accrued following foreclosure sale;

    7. wife was entitled to recover double amount of usurious interest paid to lender; but

    8. wife could not recover on her counterclaim for clear title and possession of home. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.


  4. Wielechowski v. State

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 25, 2017 403 P.3d 1141 2017 WL 3666557


    GOVERNMENT States. Alaska Permanent Fund income is not exempt from constraints of state constitution's anti-dedication clause.

    Synopsis

    Background: Current and former legislators brought action against State and Alaska Permanent Fund Corporation, seeking a declaration that the dividend program statutes automatically transferred revenues without the need for a legislative appropriation and not subject to the governor's veto. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No. 3AN-16-08940 CI, William F. Morse, J., 2016 WL 8411733, granted summary judgment to State and Corporation. Legislators appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

    1. Permanent Fund income is not exempt from the constraints of the anti-dedication clause, and

    2. Governor validly exercised veto authority when reducing transfer amount from earnings reserve account to dividend fund.

    Affirmed.


  5. State Department of Administration, Division of Retirement & Benefits v. Shea

    Supreme Court of Alaska. April 21, 2017 394 P.3d 524 2017 WL 1422475



    LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT Public Employment. Substantial evidence supported ALJ's finding that prolonged sitting at work was not proximate cause of public employee's disability.

    Synopsis

    Background: Former state employee applied for occupational disability benefits, claiming that prolonged sitting at work aggravated pre-existing medical condition. Department of Administration, Division of Retirement and Benefits, denied the claim. Employee sought review. An ALJ affirmed Department's decision. Employee appealed. The Superior Court, 2010 WL 8747457, affirmed the ALJ's decision. Employee appealed. The Supreme Court, 267 P.3d 624, reversed and remanded. On remand, the ALJ determined that employee had not proven that prolonged sitting at work was a substantial factor in causing her disability, and again denied claim. Employee appealed. The Superior Court, 2014 WL 8396280, reversed ALJ's decision. State appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

    1. substantial evidence supported ALJ's finding that employee's diagnosis was disputed;

    2. substantial evidence supported ALJ's finding that ordinary activities aggravated employee's pain;

    3. substantial evidence supported ALJ's finding that psychological factors might have contributed to employee's disabling pain; and

    4. substantial evidence supported ALJ's finding that prolonged sitting at work was not proximate cause of employee's disability.

    Reversed.

    Fabe, J., filed dissenting opinion.


  6. Rosales v. Icicle Seafoods, Inc.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 19, 2017 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2017 WL 3122390


    LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT Workers' Compensation. Claims following Workers' Compensation Board's second refusal to set aside claimant's global settlement were barred by res judicata.

    Synopsis

    Background: Workers' compensation claimant, who entered into global settlement of his workers' compensation claim and maritime lawsuit, appealed decision by Workers' Compensation Appeals Commission, which affirmed Workers' Compensation Board's refusal to set aside claimant's settlement. Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. claim that Board did not follow statutory and regulatory requirements was barred by res judicata;

    2. offset of $108,000 from claimant's settlement of maritime lawsuit was proper;

    3. Board made adequate findings supporting determination that claimant's settlement of workers' compensation claim was in his best interest;

    4. claim that employer misrepresented that it had filed all medical records and records of reemployment benefits in its possession was barred by res judicata;

    5. rule permitting relief from judgment or order based on fraud did not apply;

    6. equal protection claims were barred by res judicata; and

    7. there was no due process violation. Affirmed.

    See also 316 P.3d 580.


  7. Recreational Data Services, Inc. v. Trimble Navigation Limited

Supreme Court of Alaska. March 24, 2017 404 P.3d 120 2017 WL 2951450


TORTS Damages. Even though software developer proved element of damages by preponderance of evidence, evidence was too speculative to award lost profits.

Synopsis

Background: Mobile telephone software developer brought action against hardware developer, alleging misrepresentation, breach of contract, and breach of fiduciary duty arising out of failed project for outdoor-oriented telephone and subsequent launch of similar product by a different division of hardware developer's company. Following jury trial, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No. 3AN-11-10519, Catherine M. Easter, J., granted judgment notwithstanding the verdict and entered judgment in favor of hardware developer. Software developer appealed.

Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

  1. issue of whether mobile telephone software developer relied on hardware developer's misrepresentations was jury question;

  2. software developer's profit and loss statements were confidential and thus protected by nondisclosure agreement signed by hardware developer;

  3. issue of whether software developer and hardware developer were partners was jury question;

  4. issue of whether hardware developer breached its fiduciary duty of loyalty as software developer's partner was jury question;

  5. issue of whether hardware developer's actions caused software developer to lose profits was jury question; and

  6. under reasonable certainty standard, evidence was too speculative to support award of lost profit damages to software developer.

Reversed and remanded; remittitur granted.


126. Hockema v. Hockema

Supreme Court of Alaska. August 25, 2017 403 P.3d 1080 2017 WL 3662463


FAMILY LAW Spousal Support. Trial court's decision to award spousal support to wife instead of a larger share of marital estate was not sufficiently supported by court's findings.

Synopsis

Background: Husband filed for divorce from wife. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Kodiak, No. 3KO-12-00458 CI, Steve W. Cole, J., entered order divorcing parties, dividing marital estate equally, and awarding wife spousal support for six years. Husband appealed.

Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carney, J., held that:

  1. trial court was entitled to credit certified construction equipment appraiser's testimony regarding the valuation of excavation equipment owned by husband and wife, and thus court's adoption of appraiser's valuation was not clearly erroneous in dividing marital property;

  2. trial court acted within its discretion in refusing to offset valuation of marital home by estimated cost to perform needed septic system repairs in dividing marital assets;

  3. husband was not entitled to credit on his spousal support obligation to wife for mortgage payments that husband made on marital home after wife moved out of marital home;

  4. husband was entitled to credit for $510.18 in property tax payments that he made on out-of-state marital property in division of marital assets;

  5. trial court miscalculated value of husband's retirement account when it calculated the account twice


    in dividing marital assets;

  6. trial court's decision to award spousal support to wife instead of a larger share of marital estate was not sufficiently supported by trial court's findings; and

  7. trial court was not required to find that wife had significant health issues prior to awarding her extended spousal support.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.


127. Merdes & Merdes, P.C. v. Leisnoi, Inc.

Supreme Court of Alaska. November 09, 2017 410 P.3d 398 2017 WL 5181610


COMMERCIAL LAW Fraudulent Transfers. Law firm's transfer of assets to newly formed law firm in order to avoid repaying attorney's fees to corporation was a violation of UTPA.

Synopsis

Background: Corporation sued original law firm that had represented corporation, successor law firm, and son of attorney who originally represented corporation, after firm failed to repay attorney's fees to corporation following corporation's successful appeal of a writ of execution. Firm counterclaimed seeking recovery in quantum meruit for attorney's fees it claimed were still owed for its original representation of the corporation. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eric A. Aarseth, J., granted summary judgment for the corporation on the law firm's quantum meruit claim and, following trial, found that the son and both law firms fraudulently conveyed assets and were liable for treble damages under the Unfair Trade Practices Act (UTPA). Son and law firms appealed.

Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

  1. quantum meruit claim brought by law firm was barred by res judicata;

  2. exceptions to res judicata did not apply to firm's quantum meruit claim;

  3. corporation was entitled to bring fraudulent conveyance claim against firm;

  4. award of $643,760 to corporation was not erroneously awarded in fraudulent conveyance claim;

  5. firm was engaged in a trade or business that was subject to UTPA;

  6. firm's transfer of assets was a violation of UTPA;

  7. court properly trebled corporation's damages; and

  8. firm had actual notice of corporation's claim of injury, for purposes of awarding prejudgment interest, at the time corporation paid money to law firm.

Affirmed in part and remanded.


128. State v. Wright

Supreme Court of Alaska. September 22, 2017 404 P.3d 166 2017 WL 4185705


CRIMINAL JUSTICE Speedy Trial. State's filing of an information starts the state constitutional speedy trial clock.

Synopsis

Background: Defendant was convicted in the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No. 3AN-99-09867 CR, Philip R. Volland and Michael Spaan, JJ., of sexual abuse of a minor. Defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, 347 P.3d 1000, remanded for reassessment of defendant's speedy trial claim. State filed petition for review.

Holdings: The Supreme Court, Matthews, Senior Justice, held that:


  1. a defendant is formally accused for state constitutional speedy trial purposes when the State files an information charging the defendant with a crime, and

  2. defendant fled from state to avoid prosecution, thus supporting determination that defendant bore primary responsibility for pretrial delay.

Reversed and remanded with directions. Bolger, J., concurred and filed opinion.

Carney, J., concurred in part, dissented in part, and filed opinion.


  1. Baer V Alyeska East Condominium Association

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 11, 1974 519 P.2d 461


    Appeal from State of Alaska Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks District; Warren Wm. Taylor, Judge.

    Synopsis

    Appeal from State of Alaska Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks District; Warren Wm. Taylor, Judge.


  2. Brown v. State

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 13, 1974 522 P.2d 534


    Defendant was convicted in Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Kodiak, Edmond W. Burke, J., of selling lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD), and he appealed. The Supreme Court held that indictment charging unlawful and felonious sale of LSD in language of statute was sufficient to apprise defendant of charge against him even though it did not...

    Synopsis

    Defendant was convicted in Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Kodiak, Edmond W. Burke, J., of selling lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD), and he appealed. The Supreme Court held that indictment charging unlawful and felonious sale of LSD in language of statute was sufficient to apprise defendant of charge against him even though it did not contain a provision stating that defendant knew he was selling an hallucinogenic drug.

    Affirmed.

    Connor, J., did not participate.


  3. Morrison v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. June 17, 1974 523 P.2d 427


Proceeding on application for postconviction relief. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Edward V. Davis, J., denied the application and the defendant appealed. The Supreme Court held that the defendant was not denied effective assistance of counsel where the trial counsel possessed and utilized the customary skill and knowledge...

Synopsis

Proceeding on application for postconviction relief. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Edward V. Davis, J., denied the application and the defendant appealed. The Supreme Court held that the defendant was not denied effective assistance of counsel where the trial counsel possessed and utilized the customary skill and knowledge of attorneys fairly skill in the criminal law. Affirmed.



4. Simmons v. Simmons

Supreme Court of Alaska. May 17, 1974 522 P.2d 171


Appeal and cross appeal from a judgment of the Superior Court Third Judicial District, Edward V. Davis, J., dividing property owned by parties following their divorce. The Supreme Court held that record established that trial court did not abuse its discretion in dividing parties' property. Affirmed.

Synopsis

Appeal and cross appeal from a judgment of the Superior Court Third Judicial District, Edward V. Davis, J., dividing property owned by parties following their divorce. The Supreme Court held that record established that trial court did not abuse its discretion in dividing parties' property.

Affirmed.


5. In re Cornelius

Supreme Court of Alaska. April 22, 1974 521 P.2d 497


In a disciplinary proceeding, suspension was ordered, 520 P.2d 76. On petition for rehearing, the Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that a condition of reinstatement, as expressed in an opinion and order suspending an attorney, that the attorney must make full restitution to whom it may be owing as a result of misconduct for which suspension has been...

Synopsis

In a disciplinary proceeding, suspension was ordered, 520 P.2d 76. On petition for rehearing, the Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that a condition of reinstatement, as expressed in an opinion and order suspending an attorney, that the attorney must make full restitution to whom it may be owing as a result of misconduct for which suspension has been ordered, is not objectionable as vague.

Order in accordance with opinion.

Erwin and Boochever, JJ., did not participate.


6. White v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. June 17, 1974 523 P.2d 428


Defendant was convicted in Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, C. J. Occhipinti, J., of possession of heroin, and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., following reinstatement of appeal, 514 P.2d 814, held that indictment charging defendant with unlawful and felonious possession of heroin was suffcient to apprise defendant of...

Synopsis

Defendant was convicted in Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, C. J. Occhipinti, J., of possession of heroin, and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., following reinstatement of appeal, 514 P.2d 814, held that indictment charging defendant with unlawful and felonious possession


of heroin was suffcient to apprise defendant of charge against him notwithstanding absence of provision stating defendant knew he was in possession of a narcotic drug and that where a mistrial was declared because of incurably prejudicial impact of tenuous evidence of addiction elicited from unqualified witness by the prosecutor, double jeopardy was not a bar to retrial of defendant on charge of unlawful and felonious possession of heroin an absence of proof of deliberate prosecutorial misconduct made in attempt to force a mistrial and prevent acquittal.

Affirmed in part and remanded with instruction.


7. Thomas v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. July 19, 1974 524 P.2d 664


The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, C. J. Occhipinti, J., found defendant guilty of assault with dangerous weapon, and defendant appealed. The Supreme Court held that telephone could be considered a dangerous weapon, and that where sentence was made to run concurrent with another sentence which was twice as long, review of...

Synopsis

The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, C. J. Occhipinti, J., found defendant guilty of assault with dangerous weapon, and defendant appealed. The Supreme Court held that telephone could be considered a dangerous weapon, and that where sentence was made to run concurrent with another sentence which was twice as long, review of sentence was superfluous.

Affirmed.


8. McKenzie v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. April 12, 1974 520 P.2d 791


Appeal from a judgment of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Ralph E. Moody, J., affirming a conviction of negligent driving rendered by the District Court, John Mason, J. The Supreme Court held that error, if any, which occurred because of trial court's consideration of two moving violations in determining sentence to be imposed upon...

Synopsis

Appeal from a judgment of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Ralph E. Moody, J., affirming a conviction of negligent driving rendered by the District Court, John Mason, J. The Supreme Court held that error, if any, which occurred because of trial court's consideration of two moving violations in determining sentence to be imposed upon defendant was harmless.

Affirmed.

Connor, J., did not participate.


9. Webb v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. October 14, 1974 527 P.2d 35



Following mistrial, accused renewed motion to dismiss indictment alleging that it was based on improperly admitted hearsay testimony. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Thomas Schulz, J., denied motion, and accused filed petition for review. The Supreme Court held that sound policy behind requirement that appeals be taken only...

Synopsis

Following mistrial, accused renewed motion to dismiss indictment alleging that it was based on improperly admitted hearsay testimony. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Thomas Schulz, J., denied motion, and accused filed petition for review. The Supreme Court held that sound policy behind requirement that appeals be taken only from final judgments was outweighed by demands of justice where a present and immediate review of particular nonappealable order might prevent accused and state from having to undergo second lengthy trial; and that record which indicated that hearsay testimony produced before grand jury was either peripheral or cumulative to direct testimony did not require dismissal of indictment against accused.

Petition granted and order denying motion to dismiss affirmed.


10. Nizinski v. Currington

Supreme Court of Alaska. January 02, 1974 517 P.2d 754


Libel suit against arbitrator by employee whose claim against employer was denied by arbitrator. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Everett W. Hepp, J., granted arbitrator's motion to dismiss the complaint, and employee appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that order dismissing complaint on ground that it failed to state...

Synopsis

Libel suit against arbitrator by employee whose claim against employer was denied by arbitrator. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Everett W. Hepp, J., granted arbitrator's motion to dismiss the complaint, and employee appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that order dismissing complaint on ground that it failed to state claim for which relief could be granted was final and appealable and that arbitrator's affidavit detailing the rationale for his denial of employee's claim was pertinent to subject matter of arbitration proceedings and was absolutely privileged and could not be basis for employee's claim for defamation.

Affirmed.


11. State v. Beckley

Supreme Court of Alaska. October 14, 1974 527 P.2d 33


Petition by State for review of orders of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Peter

J. Kalamarides, J., granting defendant's motion to suppress admission into evidence of narcotic drugs on ground that drugs had been illegally seized under invalid search warrant and granting motion to dismiss indictment based on presentation of...

Synopsis


Petition by State for review of orders of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Peter J. Kalamarides, J., granting defendant's motion to suppress admission into evidence of narcotic drugs on ground that drugs had been illegally seized under invalid search warrant and granting motion to dismiss indictment based on presentation of allegedly illegally seized evidence before grand jury. The Supreme Court held that there was probable cause to search defendant's residence and that search warrant was properly issued for search of defendant's premises.

Orders overruled; case remanded.


12. Northern Corp. v. Chugach Elec. Ass'n

Supreme Court of Alaska. June 28, 1974 523 P.2d 1243


Action by contractor against electric association for costs incurred in attempted completion of contract for repair and protection of upstream face of dam. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, James K. Singleton, J., discharged parties from contract on ground of impossibility, denying claim for damages and attorney fees, and...

Synopsis

Action by contractor against electric association for costs incurred in attempted completion of contract for repair and protection of upstream face of dam. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, James K. Singleton, J., discharged parties from contract on ground of impossibility, denying claim for damages and attorney fees, and appeals were taken. The Supreme Court, 518 P.2d 76, affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded, holding that the contractor was entitled to certain damages, and, on petition for rehearing, held that where owner, by unilateral insistence on performance in manner prescribed in contract, impliedly represented that method was feasible, contractor was entitled to recover extra costs thereafter incurred by reason of breach of that implied warranty, but could not recover for damages incurred after contractor acquired actual knowledge or should have known that method was impossible.

Remanded.

Erwin and Fitzgerald, JJ., did not participate.


  1. Gonzales v. State

    Supreme Court of Alaska. April 12, 1974 521 P.2d 512


    Defendant was convicted in the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Ralph E. Moody, J., of sale of narcotics, and appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that where the prosecution was for sale to a purchaser who had been the subject of juvenile adjudications, it was not error to preclude the defense from cross-examining...

    Synopsis

    Defendant was convicted in the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Ralph E. Moody, J., of sale of narcotics, and appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that where the prosecution was for sale to a purchaser who had been the subject of juvenile adjudications, it was not error to preclude the defense from cross-examining the purchaser as to such prior adjudications for the purpose of attacking credibility where such prior adjudications were more than five years old and where such evidence would have been cumulative because the adjudications concerned forgeries and the


    purchaser had already admitted recent forgeries totaling $8,000. Remanded for resentence.

    Connor, J., did not participate.


  2. R. J. C. v. State

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 26, 1974 520 P.2d 806


    The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Warren W. Taylor, J., entered a decision waiving juvenile jurisdiction, and an appeal was taken. The Supreme Court held that hearing with respect to waiver of juvenile jurisdiction was insufficient, in the absence of an adeauate evaluation of existing children's treatment programs or...

    Synopsis

    The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Warren W. Taylor, J., entered a decision waiving juvenile jurisdiction, and an appeal was taken. The Supreme Court held that hearing with respect to waiver of juvenile jurisdiction was insufficient, in the absence of an adeauate evaluation of existing children's treatment programs or facilities which might be suitable for child and in the absence of evidence concerning probable cause that offense charged was in fact committed; and that emancipation proceedings which permitted defendant to live separate and apart from legal guardians did not affect his statutory right to be treated as a juvenile in proceedings for crimes committed by him before his 18th birthday.

    Decision of superior court vacated and case remanded to children's court. Connor, J., did not participate.


  3. Roehl v. State

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 13, 1974 521 P.2d 1240


    Defendant pleaded guilty to two counts of robbery, and the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Edmond H.
