Burke, J., imposed concurrent six-year sentences with eligibility for parole fixed after service of two years' imprisonment, and defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that the sentences were not excessive...

    Synopsis

    Defendant pleaded guilty to two counts of robbery, and the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Edmond H. Burke, J., imposed concurrent six-year sentences with eligibility for parole fixed after service of two years' imprisonment, and defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that the sentences were not excessive in light of the seriousness of the crimes committed and the sentencing data which was provided to the trial court.

    Affirmed.


  4. Brown v. State

    Supreme Court of Alaska. February 04, 1974 518 P.2d 770



    Persons under indictment in Nevada filed habeas corpus proceedings after their arrest on fugitive warrants. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Eben H. Lewis, J., ordered indictees returned to Nevada and they appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that the necessary probable cause determination for extradition was made in Nevada...

    Synopsis

    Persons under indictment in Nevada filed habeas corpus proceedings after their arrest on fugitive warrants. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Eben H. Lewis, J., ordered indictees returned to Nevada and they appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that the necessary probable cause determination for extradition was made in Nevada when the matter was considered by the grand jury, and accompanying affidavits were not necessary to supplement the indictment; that governor's investigation was confined to determining the adequacy of the documents forwarded to him, not to investigating the commission of the crime; and that it is not necessary that a person be fleeing from a jurisdiction where criminal proceedings are pending against him before he can be considered a fugitive from justice.

    Affirmed.

    Boochever, J., filed concurring opinion.


  5. Darling v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. April 08, 1974 520 P.2d 793


Defendant was convicted in Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Gerald J. Van Hoomissen, J., of two separate offenses involving the sale and dispensing of cocaine, and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that in the circumstances prosecutor's comments during final argument were not improper; and that trial court...

Synopsis

Defendant was convicted in Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Gerald J. Van Hoomissen, J., of two separate offenses involving the sale and dispensing of cocaine, and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that in the circumstances prosecutor's comments during final argument were not improper; and that trial court did not abuse its discretion in refusing to declare a mistrial because of answer of prospective juror, who was prosecutor's wife, regarding honesty of State's chief witness, where immediately after exchange trial judge asked prospective juror, as well as entire jury panel, whether they understood that any verdict they reached must be based on evidence produced in courtroom and that they may not take into account evidence or things that they may have heard outside of courtroom.

Affirmed.


18. Torres v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. April 19, 1974 521 P.2d 386


By a judgment of the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Edmond W. Burke, J., the defendant was convicted of rape and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that in view of



other evidence relating to age of defendant and jury's observation of defendant, any error in admitting in evidence his driver's license, seized without a...

Synopsis

By a judgment of the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Edmond W. Burke, J., the defendant was convicted of rape and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that in view of other evidence relating to age of defendant and jury's observation of defendant, any error in admitting in evidence his driver's license, seized without a warrant from personal property held for defendant at jail, to show that defendant was over the age of 16 was harmless, and there was no clear mistake in imposing 20-year sentence.

Affirmed.


19. Donlun v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. October 21, 1974 527 P.2d 472


Defendant was convicted in the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, C. J. Occhipinti, J., of burglary and sentenced to ten years' imprisonment, and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that where aggravating circumstances of burglary occurring at night and in an occupied dwelling were not set forth in indictment and proven...

Synopsis

Defendant was convicted in the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, C. J. Occhipinti, J., of burglary and sentenced to ten years' imprisonment, and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that where aggravating circumstances of burglary occurring at night and in an occupied dwelling were not set forth in indictment and proven at trial, the maximum sentence prescribed in such aggravated circumstances could not be considered in sentencing defendant.

Remanded for resentencing with directions. Rabinowitz, C. J., filed concurring opinion.


  1. Dunbar v. State

    Supreme Court of Alaska. September 09, 1974 526 P.2d 1


    Petition for review of an order of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Peter J. Kalamarides, J., denying motions to dismiss three criminal cases. The Supreme Court held that defendant was not entitled to review of order denying motion to dismiss under rule relating to speedy trial where the case was not unusual, and where defendant simply...

    Synopsis

    Petition for review of an order of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Peter J. Kalamarides, J., denying motions to dismiss three criminal cases. The Supreme Court held that defendant was not entitled to review of order denying motion to dismiss under rule relating to speedy trial where the case was not unusual, and where defendant simply disagreed with trial court's manner of counting the excluded days under rule, since such pretrial review would necessarily result in extensive delay which would frustrate the manifest purpose of the rule.


    Petition denied.


  2. Coger v. State

    Supreme Court of Alaska. January 16, 1974 517 P.2d 1403


    Defendant was convicted in the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks District, Warren Wm. Taylor, J., of selling hallucinogenic drugs and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that where district attorney was not sworn witness but was acting as counsel when he summarized police report in context of questioning grand jury...

    Synopsis

    Defendant was convicted in the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks District, Warren Wm. Taylor, J., of selling hallucinogenic drugs and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that where district attorney was not sworn witness but was acting as counsel when he summarized police report in context of questioning grand jury witness, a policeman whose undercover activities were basis of grand jury convening to consider series of drug cases, district attorney's summary was not hearsay and the defect in form of district attorney's question did not render evidence of the sale of marijuana inadmissible before grand jury. The Court held, however, that future indictments would be defective when based solely upon narrative statements read to a grand jury witness, rather than upon testimony elicited by means of question and answer method.

    Affirmed.


  3. Graybill v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. May 20, 1974 522 P.2d 539


Defendant was convicted before the Superior Court, Anchorage District, C. J. Occhipinti, J., of unlawful transportation of a bear hide by airplane. Defendant appealed after such court amended judgment by identifying airplane ordered forfeited as condition of probation. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that issue whether Superior Court had power...

Synopsis

Defendant was convicted before the Superior Court, Anchorage District, C. J. Occhipinti, J., of unlawful transportation of a bear hide by airplane. Defendant appealed after such court amended judgment by identifying airplane ordered forfeited as condition of probation. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that issue whether Superior Court had power to forfeit airplane was not timely raised, that such issue was abandoned and that identification of airplane ordered forfeited, as a condition of probation, was a proper modification under rule pertaining to correction of clerical mistakes.

Appeal dismissed.

Fitzgerald, J., not participating.


23. Hutchings v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. February 01, 1974 518 P.2d 767



Defendant was convicted in State of Alaska Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks District, Warren Wm. Taylor, J., of selling a stimulant drug and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that undue restriction of investigation of bias was an abuse of discretion; that defendant should have been allowed to explore possibility...

Synopsis

Defendant was convicted in State of Alaska Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks District, Warren Wm. Taylor, J., of selling a stimulant drug and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that undue restriction of investigation of bias was an abuse of discretion; that defendant should have been allowed to explore possibility of bias presented by fact that undercover agent who arrested him had been discharged by police force and was attempting to be reinstated; that there were no special rules of proper impeachment for bias; that the credibility of a witness was a material issue; and that where only other person who could have identified defendant as the purveyor of illicit drugs testified that defendant was not the seller, exclusion of evidence tending to impugn undercover agent's testimony was not harmless.

Reversed and remanded.


24. Brown v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. October 07, 1974 526 P.2d 1365 1974 WL 451374


Action by passenger on state ferry against State and other passengers arising out of an alleged assault by defendant passengers on plaintiff. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Edward V. Davis, J., dismissed without prejudice for failure to prosecute, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that where plaintiff had...

Synopsis

Action by passenger on state ferry against State and other passengers arising out of an alleged assault by defendant passengers on plaintiff. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Edward V. Davis, J., dismissed without prejudice for failure to prosecute, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that where plaintiff had been an inmate in a Canadian prison for most of the period since filing the action, was thus unavailable for deposition and unable to obtain another attorney when his original counsel requested to withdraw, and plaintiff made diligent efforts to prosecute his complaint, dismissal for failure to prosecute was an abuse of discretion.

Reversed and remanded. Boochever, J., did not participate.


  1. Bayly, Martin & Fay, Inc., of Alaska v. Arctic Auto Rental, Inc.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. January 21, 1974 517 P.2d 1406


    Following plaintiff's acceptance of an offer of judgment, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, James K. Singleton, J., awarded costs and attorneys' fees to the plaintiff and made offsetting award of costs and attorneys' fees to the defendant from the date of the offer of judgment until the date of acceptance of the offer. The...



    Synopsis

    Following plaintiff's acceptance of an offer of judgment, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, James K. Singleton, J., awarded costs and attorneys' fees to the plaintiff and made offsetting award of costs and attorneys' fees to the defendant from the date of the offer of judgment until the date of acceptance of the offer. The plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court held that the award of costs and attorneys' fees should have been computed for both parties as of the date the offer was made and not at the later time when accepted.

    Award reversed and remanded with directions. Rabinowitz, C. J., not participating.


  2. Alaska Rent-A-Car, Inc. v. Ford Motor Co.

Supreme Court of Alaska. October 04, 1974 526 P.2d 1136 1974 WL 451241


Third-party action to recover against manufacturer of leased vehicle involved in rear-end collision. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Hubert A. Gilbert, J., entered summary judgment in favor of manufacturer, and lessor appealed. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that issue as to whether it might be inferred from evidence that...

Synopsis

Third-party action to recover against manufacturer of leased vehicle involved in rear-end collision. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Hubert A. Gilbert, J., entered summary judgment in favor of manufacturer, and lessor appealed. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that issue as to whether it might be inferred from evidence that defect existed in leased vehicle when it left hands of manufacturer and prior to time vehicle was involved in rear-end collision upon failure of brake pedal was question of fact precluding summary judgment in third-party action wherein lessor sought to recover against manufacturer on a theory of breach of implied warranty or strict liability.

Reversed and remanded. Boochever, J., did not participate.


27. Otton v. Zaborac

Supreme Court of Alaska. August 19, 1974 525 P.2d 537


Habeas corpus proceedings in which relator sought to obtain release from incarceration for civil contempt of court for failure to make child support payments contending that, as an indigent person, relator was intitled to court-appointed counsel to assist in his defense. The Third Judicial district Superior Court, Anchorage District, Victor D....

Synopsis

Habeas corpus proceedings in which relator sought to obtain release from incarceration for civil contempt of court for failure to make child support payments contending that, as an indigent person, relator was intitled to court-appointed counsel to assist in his defense. The Third Judicial district Superior Court, Anchorage District, Victor D. Carlson, J., denied relief sought, and relator appealed. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that due process of law required that assistance of counsel be provided an indigent facing contempt proceedings for failure to make child support payments in accordance with divorce decree.


Reversed and remanded.


  1. Davenport v. State

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 08, 1974 519 P.2d 452


    The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Edmond W. Burke, J., found defendant guilty of receiving and concealing stolen property, and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Connor J., held that (1) allowing the prosecution to introduce, for the purpose of impeaching defendant's testimony that he had never seen gold cuff link prior to its...

    Synopsis

    The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Edmond W. Burke, J., found defendant guilty of receiving and concealing stolen property, and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Connor J., held that

    (1) allowing the prosecution to introduce, for the purpose of impeaching defendant's testimony that he had never seen gold cuff link prior to its being pawned on July 1, 1971, testimony linking the cuff link with defendant's prior burglary conviction was proper, since the testimony went to the essence of the critical transaction, not to a mere collateral matter, and (2) instruction which used the phrase moral certainty in the context of defining the reasonable doubt standard was not fatally defective, although the preferable form of instrution is to define reasonable doubt as a doubt that would cause prudent men to hesitate before acting in matters of importance to themselves.

    Affirmed.


  2. Lemon v. State

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 10, 1974 522 P.2d 160


    Defendant was convicted in the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Warren Wm. Taylor, J., of escape, and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Dimond, J. pro tem., held that where trial judge in escape prosecution indicated for record that he was taking judicial notice of lawful commitment of defendant in criminal case bearing specified file...

    Synopsis

    Defendant was convicted in the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Warren Wm. Taylor, J., of escape, and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Dimond, J. pro tem., held that where trial judge in escape prosecution indicated for record that he was taking judicial notice of lawful commitment of defendant in criminal case bearing specified file number, there was sufficient compliance with requirement of rule that judge indicated for record matter which is judicially noticed, and it was unnecessary that judge identify prior commitment by stating what it concerned or when it was dated; and that two-year sentence was not excessive.

    Affirmed.

    CONNOR, J., not participating.


  3. Hunnicutt v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. November 15, 1974 527 P.2d 1292



Probation revocation proceedings. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, P. J. Kalamarides, J., revoked defendant's probation, and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that where the trial court did not consider the particular legal arguments regarding illegal search and seizure advanced by the defendant on appeal, the case must be...

Synopsis

Probation revocation proceedings. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, P. J. Kalamarides, J., revoked defendant's probation, and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that where the trial court did not consider the particular legal arguments regarding illegal search and seizure advanced by the defendant on appeal, the case must be remanded for further consideration.

Remanded.


31. Horton v. Horton

Supreme Court of Alaska. March 18, 1974 519 P.2d 1131


Appeal from a postdivorce custody order of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Victor D. Carlson, J., changing custody of parties' ten-year-old son from mother to father. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that neither passage of two years' time since last incident involving father's sexual abuse of his older children nor...

Synopsis

Appeal from a postdivorce custody order of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Victor

D. Carlson, J., changing custody of parties' ten-year-old son from mother to father. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that neither passage of two years' time since last incident involving father's sexual abuse of his older children nor father's remarriage operated to serve as protection against recurrence of father's problem, and absent evidence of rehabilitation or evidence that father had sought to correct his malady or that his malady had disappeared, it was not in best interests of ten-year-old son that he be placed in custody of father.

Reversed.

Erwin, J., did not participate.


32. State v. Thomas

Supreme Court of Alaska. September 03, 1974 525 P.2d 1092


Appeal by the State from a judgment of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, P. J. Kalamarides, J., dismissing indictment charging crime of attempted rape. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that indictment charging attempted rape and citing only rape statute was sufficient, that criminal rule governing nature and contents of...

Synopsis

Appeal by the State from a judgment of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, P. J. Kalamarides, J., dismissing indictment charging crime of attempted rape. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that indictment charging attempted rape and citing only rape statute was sufficient, that criminal


rule governing nature and contents of indictments does not require absolute precision of citation of statute allegedly violated for the indictment to be valid when it is clear from its language that a crime had been charged, and that a charge of attempt to commit a specific crime clearly advised the defendant of the offense with which he was charged even though specific intent was not mentioned. Reversed and remanded.


33. Thomas v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. May 13, 1974 522 P.2d 528


The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, C. J. Occhipinti, J., found defendants guilty on a joint indictment charging illegal sale of heroin, and they appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that (1) the indictment which charged that defendants did unlawfully and feloniously sell and transfer a narcotic drug, to wit,...

Synopsis

The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, C. J. Occhipinti, J., found defendants guilty on a joint indictment charging illegal sale of heroin, and they appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that (1) the indictment which charged that defendants did unlawfully and feloniously sell and transfer a narcotic drug, to wit, heroin was sufficient to alert defendants to the elements of the offense charged, notwithstanding their claim that the indictment failed to meet the scienter requirement, (2) trial court's failure, not objected to by defendants, to instruct the jury that knowledge of the nature of the drug was a necessary element of the offense did not constitute plain error, where knowledge of the nature of the substance was not an issue and where there was thus no possibility of prejudice, and (3) defendant was not denied his constitutional right of confrontation when the court allowed an undercover officer to refuse to answer a question because it might incriminate him on a charge he was facing.

Judgments affirmed.

Connor, J., did not participate.


34. Poole v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. July 15, 1974 524 P.2d 286


The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Ralph E. Moody, J., affirmed defendant's conviction of disorderly conduct after trial by jury in the District Court, Paul B. Jones, J. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that disorderly conduct statute, which made it unlawful to engage in certain conduct to the...

Synopsis

The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Ralph E. Moody, J., affirmed defendant's conviction of disorderly conduct after trial by jury in the District Court, Paul B. Jones, J. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that disorderly conduct statute, which made it unlawful to engage in certain conduct to the disturbance or annoyance of another, was unconstitutionally vague.

Reversed.


35. City of Fairbanks v. Smith

Supreme Court of Alaska. August 26, 1974 525 P.2d 1095


Action by automobile passenger and his wife for injuries and loss of consortium arising out of automobile-truck collision. The defendants, city-truck owner and its employee-driver conceded liability. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Edward V. Davis, J., rendered judgment on a jury verdict in the of $77,154.06 for the...

Synopsis

Action by automobile passenger and his wife for injuries and loss of consortium arising out of automobile-truck collision. The defendants, city-truck owner and its employee-driver conceded liability. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Edward V. Davis, J., rendered judgment on a jury verdict in the of $77,154.06 for the passenger, and a verdict of zero dollars in regard to his wife's claim for loss of consortium. Parties cross-appealed. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that the award to the passenger was not excessive; that the city waived its contention that the verdicts were inconsistent by its failure to object in the trial court; and that the award to the passenger's wife on her loss of consortium claim was not inadequate.

Affirmed.


36. Gray v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. August 12, 1974 525 P.2d 524


Defendant was convicted before the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Warren W. Taylor, J., of selling marijuana and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that State was properly permitted to impeach State's witness with witness' prior inconsistent sworn statement; that question of defendant's guilt was for jury; and...

Synopsis

Defendant was convicted before the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Warren W. Taylor, J., of selling marijuana and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that State was properly permitted to impeach State's witness with witness' prior inconsistent sworn statement; that question of defendant's guilt was for jury; and that defendant's failure to assert constitutional challenge to statute prohibiting sale of marijuana prior to trial or at pretrial omnibus hearing did not constitute waiver of the issue. However, no final disposition of issue could be made without first holding evidentiary hearing at which State would be entitled to opportunity to present evidence that compelling state interest justified intrusion on right of privacy represented by the statute.

Affirmed in part and remanded. Erwin, J., did not participate.


37. Slaymaker v. Peterkin

Supreme Court of Alaska. February 04, 1974 518 P.2d 763 1974 WL 448752


Assignee of promissory note brought action against makers to accelerate payment on note after default. The State of Alaska Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage District, Ralph E.



Moody, J., granted assignee's motion for summary judgment. Makers appealed from the award of summary judgment and assignee appealed from the alleged...

Synopsis

Assignee of promissory note brought action against makers to accelerate payment on note after default. The State of Alaska Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage District, Ralph E. Moody, J., granted assignee's motion for summary judgment. Makers appealed from the award of summary judgment and assignee appealed from the alleged inadequacy of award of attorneys' fees. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that earnest money agreement was sufficiently complete and enforceable to constitute a loan commitment or contract for purposes of determining whether interest called for was usurious; that interest called for in the contract would be compared to the legal maximum as of the date that the earnest money contract was signed, not as of the date transaction was closed; that facts as alleged by makers, if established, would afford a valid defense to suit to accelerate collection of the note; that the affidavits and depositions raised a conflict which could only be reliably determined at trial; and that in view of disposition, it was unnecessary to rule on appeal from the award of attorneys' fees.

Vacated and remanded.


38. Kvasnikoff v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. May 03, 1974 521 P.2d 903


Defendant was convicted before the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, James A. Hanson, J., of manslaughter and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that evidence, inter alia, that death of defendant's wife was caused by hemorrhage from abdominal wounds, that it was unlikely that fatal blow was caused accidentally due to...

Synopsis

Defendant was convicted before the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, James A. Hanson, J., of manslaughter and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that evidence, inter alia, that death of defendant's wife was caused by hemorrhage from abdominal wounds, that it was unlikely that fatal blow was caused accidentally due to amount of force necessary to cause the injury inflicted, that fatal injury was inflicted in hotel where defendant and wife were staying and that defendant had previously assaulted wife was sufficient to sustain conviction.

Affirmed.

Connor, J., did not participate.


39. Dolchok v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. March 08, 1974 519 P.2d 457


Defendant was convicted by the State of Alaska Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage District, Ralph E. Moody, J., of first-degree murder and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Dimond,

J. pro tem., held that testimony of psychiatrist was sufficient to place burden on state of proving defendant's sanity beyond a reasonable doubt; that...



Synopsis

Defendant was convicted by the State of Alaska Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage District, Ralph E. Moody, J., of first-degree murder and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Dimond, J. pro tem., held that testimony of psychiatrist was sufficient to place burden on state of proving defendant's sanity beyond a reasonable doubt; that evidence sustained finding that defendant's mental illness did not substantially incapacitate him from conforming his conduct to law; and that trial court properly applied the insanity test.

Affirmed.

Fitzgerald, J., did not participate.


40. Adams v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. April 22, 1974 521 P.2d 516


Defendant was given consecutive sentences, totalling 11 years' imprisonment, by the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, P. J. Kalamarides, J., on various burglary and larceny charges. Defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that in view of the sentencing judge's knowledge of defendant's prior record, his...

Synopsis

Defendant was given consecutive sentences, totalling 11 years' imprisonment, by the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, P. J. Kalamarides, J., on various burglary and larceny charges.

Defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that in view of the sentencing judge's knowledge of defendant's prior record, his psychological background, his drug addiction and his previous rehabilitative failures, the absence of presentence report and psychiatric evaluation did not require vacation of the sentences, imposition of which had previously been deferred. Alleged uncertainty as to when defendant would be eligible for parole when not a ground for vacating sentence. Where defendant admitted to the lower court that he had committed felonies while on probation, and where the prosecutor informed the court he was ready and willing to support allegations of additional offenses with witnesses in the courtroom, and neither defendant nor his counsel objected to the prosecutor's references to such other offenses, such reference was not error.

Affirmed.

Fitzgerald, J., did not participate.


41. B. A. M. v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. November 29, 1974 528 P.2d 437


Juvenile was adjudged delinquent in the State of Alaska Superior Court, First Judicial District, Ketchikan District, Victor D. Carlson, J., and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that where juvenile was under the age of 18 at the time the acts of delinquency were committed, court had no authority to direct his placement for fixed...

Synopsis

Juvenile was adjudged delinquent in the State of Alaska Superior Court, First Judicial District, Ketchikan District, Victor D. Carlson, J., and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that where juvenile was under the age of 18 at the time the acts of delinquency were committed, court had


no authority to direct his placement for fixed period of time in an adult institution; that where no waiver hearing had been held, court erred in sentencing juvenile as an adult; and that court had no authority to place juvenile on probation beyond his 19th birthday.

Remanded with instructions.


  1. McClain v. State

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 15, 1974 519 P.2d 811


    Defendant, after plea of guilty, was convicted in the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, James A. Hanson, J., of manufacturing and selling heroin, and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that sentencing standards enunciated by the Supreme Court are applicable in sentencing heroin addicts, and that imposition of...

    Synopsis

    Defendant, after plea of guilty, was convicted in the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, James A. Hanson, J., of manufacturing and selling heroin, and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that sentencing standards enunciated by the Supreme Court are applicable in sentencing heroin addicts, and that imposition of four-year sentences, to run concurrently, was not unreasonable.

    Appeal dismissed.

    Connor, J., did not participate.


  2. Park v. State

    Supreme Court of Alaska. November 25, 1974 528 P.2d 785


    Appeal by alien who was a permanent state resident and who was admitted to practice of law in 1971, from judgment of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, James K. Singleton, J., precluding alien from voting in state elections. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that the State Constitution limited voting privileges to citizens of...

    Synopsis

    Appeal by alien who was a permanent state resident and who was admitted to practice of law in 1971, from judgment of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, James K. Singleton, J., precluding alien from voting in state elections. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that the State Constitution limited voting privileges to citizens of United States and that federal constitutional voting rights are applied expressly only to citizens, and thus right to vote was not available to alien.

    Affirmed.

    Erwin, J., did not participate.


  3. Wernberg v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. February 27, 1974 519 P.2d 801



In suit in inverse condemnation based, inter alia, on obstruction of riparian proprietor's access from creek to inlet, plaintiff appealed from dismissal of the complaint by the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, James K. Singleton, J. Following reversal by the Supreme Court, 516 P.2d 1191, the State petitioned for rehearing. The...

Synopsis

In suit in inverse condemnation based, inter alia, on obstruction of riparian proprietor's access from creek to inlet, plaintiff appealed from dismissal of the complaint by the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, James K. Singleton, J. Following reversal by the Supreme Court, 516 P.2d 1191, the State petitioned for rehearing. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that under the facts of the case, limiting access from creek to inlet to vessels able to pass through a culvert six feet in diameter was, in effect, a taking of such access for which the riparian proprietor was entitled to compensation.

Petition for rehearing denied.

Connor and Fitzgerald, JJ., did not participate.


45. Bell v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. March 01, 1974 519 P.2d 804


Defendant was convicted in the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks District, Everett

W. Hepp, J., of possession of hallucinogenic drugs with intent to sell, and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that initial inspection by cargo handler of air carrier did not violate defendant's rights, that actions of airport...

Synopsis

Defendant was convicted in the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks District, Everett W. Hepp, J., of possession of hallucinogenic drugs with intent to sell, and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that initial inspection by cargo handler of air carrier did not violate defendant's rights, that actions of airport security officer were not unlawful, that conduct of state troopers was not unlawful, and that evidence was sufficient to establish that defendant knowingly possessed a prohibited drug.

Affirmed.

Rabinowitz, C. J., dissented and filed opinion.


46. Kostic v. Smedley

Supreme Court of Alaska. May 10, 1974 522 P.2d 535


Proceeding on petition for writ of habeas corpus testing validity of extradition proceeding. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Edmond W. Burke, J., entered order denying habeas corpus relief and the petitioner appealed. The Supreme Court, Dimond, J. pro tem., held that case would be remanded for determination of whether a...

Synopsis

Proceeding on petition for writ of habeas corpus testing validity of extradition proceeding. The Superior


Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Edmond W. Burke, J., entered order denying habeas corpus relief and the petitioner appealed. The Supreme Court, Dimond, J. pro tem., held that case would be remanded for determination of whether a petitioner was mentally competent to aid counsel and comprehend the nature of the habeas corpus-extradition proceeding and if incompetent then extradition must be stayed until the competency had been restored.

Remanded.

Connor, J., did not participate.


47. Pennington v. Employer's Liability Assur. Corp.

Supreme Court of Alaska. March 26, 1974 520 P.2d 96


Judgment creditor brought garnishment proceedings against tort-feasor's liability insurer to recover balance of $30,000 obtained in personal injury and wrongful death suit. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Eben H. Lewis, J., dismissed proceeding, and garnishor appealed. The Supreme Court held that once a valid judgment is extinguished...

Synopsis

Judgment creditor brought garnishment proceedings against tort-feasor's liability insurer to recover balance of $30,000 obtained in personal injury and wrongful death suit. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Eben H. Lewis, J., dismissed proceeding, and garnishor appealed. The Supreme Court held that once a valid judgment is extinguished as result of reversal, vacation, or dismissal, garnishment proceedings pertaining to that judgment are precluded, that an ambiguous judgment is to be construed according to rules of construction that applied to all written instruments and that judgment, which dismissed suit with prejudice after parties agreed to settle for $10,000 but which reserve to garnishor the judgment creditor's right to enforce $20,000 balance against tort-feasor's liability insurer, had preserved balance of $30,000 judgment since continued exercise of underlying judgment was implied and that garnishment proceedings could be brought even though garnishee Reversed and remanded.

Erversed and remanded. Erwin, J., not participating.


48. In re Adoption of A. J. N.

Supreme Court of Alaska. August 16, 1974 525 P.2d 520


Stepfather filed petition for adoption of child, and natural father filed objections. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Harold J. Butcher, J., entered decree allowing the adoption, and natural father appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held, inter alia, that natural father's consent to adoption could not be dispensed...

Synopsis

Stepfather filed petition for adoption of child, and natural father filed objections. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Harold J. Butcher, J., entered decree allowing the adoption, and natural father appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held, inter alia, that natural father's consent to adoption could not be dispensed with on theory that mother was awarded full and exclusive custody of child in her divorce from the natural father, where natural father was given substantial visitation


rights; and that evidence would not support findings that natural father had abandoned child or that he was unfit parent for purposes of adoption statute.

Remanded with directions.

Rabinowitz, C. J., filed opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part.


49. Alaska Public Emp. Ass'n v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. July 29, 1974 525 P.2d 12 1974 WL 450553


From an adverse summary judgment of the Alaska Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Thomas B. Stewart, J., state employees suing on their own behalf and on behalf of all others similarly situated appealed. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that a statute making provision for pay increments for longevity in state service is not...

Synopsis

From an adverse summary judgment of the Alaska Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Thomas B. Stewart, J., state employees suing on their own behalf and on behalf of all others similarly situated appealed. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that a statute making provision for pay increments for longevity in state service is not prospective only but affords pay increments for state employees who, as of the effective date of the statute, otherwise met statutory eligibility requirements and had been in the last step of their pay range for four, nine or 13 years.

Reversed.

Boochever, J., did not participate.


50. McCarrey v. Commissioner of Natural Resources

Supreme Court of Alaska. October 07, 1974 526 P.2d 1353


Appeal from decision of Division of Lands, Department of Natural Resources, terminating state grazing lease. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eben H. Lewis, J., entered summary judgment in favor of Division and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that Superior Court was not bound by strict time...

Synopsis

Appeal from decision of Division of Lands, Department of Natural Resources, terminating state grazing lease. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eben H. Lewis, J., entered summary judgment in favor of Division and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that Superior Court was not bound by strict time limitations provided by statute for seeking review of administrative action, where at the time a great deal of confusion existed concerning method and procedures by which appeals from administrative decision might be taken to Superior Court, and that, before termination of state grazing lease for non-compliance, lessee was entitled to notice and to opportunity to be heard in some meaningful way and to present mitigating circumstances and the hearing must be consistent with fair trial and conducted in manner providing an opportunity for reviewing court to determine if applicable rules of law and procedure were observed.

Remanded.


51. Gellert v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. June 03, 1974 522 P.2d 1120


Action was brought challenging constitutionality of act providing for issuance of bonds for purpose of paying cost, capital improvements for flood control and small boat harbor projects. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, James K. Singleton, J., held that bonds proposition and statute pursuant to which it was presented dealt with a single...

Synopsis

Action was brought challenging constitutionality of act providing for issuance of bonds for purpose of paying cost, capital improvements for flood control and small boat harbor projects. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, James K. Singleton, J., held that bonds proposition and statute pursuant to which it was presented dealt with a single subject and appeal was taken. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that it was permissible to classify boat harbors and flood control projects as being within the confines of one subject.

Affirmed.

Fitzgerald, J., filed dissenting opinion.


52. Frontier Saloon, Inc. v. Alcoholic Beverage Control Bd.

Supreme Court of Alaska. July 15, 1974 524 P.2d 657


Holder of beverage dispensary license filed a complaint against the Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, seeking a temporary restraining order and an injunction against further enforcement of Board's ten-day closure order. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Ketchikan, Hubert A. Gilbert, J., granted Board's motion to dismiss, and the licensee...

Synopsis

Holder of beverage dispensary license filed a complaint against the Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, seeking a temporary restraining order and an injunction against further enforcement of Board's ten-day closure order. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Ketchikan, Hubert A. Gilbert, J., granted Board's motion to dismiss, and the licensee appealed. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that absent an emergency situation in which the public health, safety or welfare requires summary action, due process requires that adequate notice and a meaningful opportunity to be heard must be afforded to liquor licensees before their licenses can be suspended; however, the required hearing need not be an elaborate one and it is not necessary for the Board to make written findings or to file a written opinion explaining its action, so long as it reaches a decision after hearing the licensee's presentation.

Reversed and remanded.


53. Alaska State Housing Authority v. Sullivan

Supreme Court of Alaska. January 28, 1974 518 P.2d 759


Appeal by employer from a judgment of the Superior Court, First Judicial District, Victor D. Carlson, J., affirming decision of Workmen's Compensation Board awarding compensation. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that evidence supported Board's finding that employee's failure to



give employer notice of knee injury was excusable. Affirmed.

Synopsis

Appeal by employer from a judgment of the Superior Court, First Judicial District, Victor D. Carlson, J., affirming decision of Workmen's Compensation Board awarding compensation. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that evidence supported Board's finding that employee's failure to give employer notice of knee injury was excusable.

Affirmed.


54. Moran v. Kenai Towing & Salvage, Inc.

Supreme Court of Alaska. June 26, 1974 523 P.2d 1237


Mortgagor under sale and lease-back with option to purchase brought action against mortgagee to determine right to proceeds of fire policy on the premises. From a judgment of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, James A. Hanson, J., both parties appealed. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that mortgagee was entitled to satisfy...

Synopsis

Mortgagor under sale and lease-back with option to purchase brought action against mortgagee to determine right to proceeds of fire policy on the premises. From a judgment of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, James A. Hanson, J., both parties appealed. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that mortgagee was entitled to satisfy his secured debt from the proceeds, with the remainder of the proceeds going to the mortgagor; that trial court's entries of findings of fact and conclusions of law complied with rules; that mortgagee's attorney was properly permitted to withdraw; and that transaction was subject to usury laws and usurious on its face, requiring forfeiture of entire interest on the debt.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded.


55. Martin v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. January 18, 1974 517 P.2d 1399


Proceeding for revocation of probation. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Ralph E. Moody, J., revoked the probation, and the probationer appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that the evidence supported finding that the probationer violated a condition of the probation order by passing a forged check; that failure to...

Synopsis

Proceeding for revocation of probation. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Ralph E. Moody, J., revoked the probation, and the probationer appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that the evidence supported finding that the probationer violated a condition of the probation order by passing a forged check; that failure to notify probationer, prior to revocation hearing, of an allegation that he has violated a condition of probation is a denial of procedural due process; that denial of constitutional right affects substantial rights and hence plain error will result unless defect is harmless; that finding probationer in violation of condition requiring him to maintain an approved residence was


not plain error because he received no notice of such charge prior to hearing, where trial court did not consider such condition in revoking the probation; that the imposition of a condition requiring probationer, an avowed alcoholic, to abstain from alcohol was not unreasonable; and that the reinstating of the full four years of original sentence of imprisonment was not excessive punishment. Affirmed.

Rabinowitz, C. J., and Fitzgerald, J., did not participate.


56. Davis v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. August 16, 1974 525 P.2d 541


Defendant was convicted in the State of Alaska Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Edmond W. Burke, J., of possession and sale of heroin and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that forcible entry made by police 30 seconds to one minute after they had announced their presence and their purpose and the fact that they had a warrant...

Synopsis

Defendant was convicted in the State of Alaska Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Edmond W. Burke, J., of possession and sale of heroin and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that forcible entry made by police 30 seconds to one minute after they had announced their presence and their purpose and the fact that they had a warrant was not unreasonable under either Federal or State Constitution; and that police officers who waited 30 seconds to one minute, during which time they heard no response to their announcement, had been refused admittance within meaning of statute allowing forcible entry where police are refused admittance.

Affirmed.


57. Mullaly v. Mullaly

Supreme Court of Alaska. February 25, 1974 518 P.2d 1395


Divorce action. An appeal was taken by husband from property division made by the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Harold J. Butcher, J. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that the division of property was not clearly unjust, where husband was relieved of approximately

$435 in monthly expenses and had a fully secured interest in...

Synopsis

Divorce action. An appeal was taken by husband from property division made by the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Harold J. Butcher, J. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that the division of property was not clearly unjust, where husband was relieved of approximately $435 in monthly expenses and had a fully secured interest in property to which he had contributed, along with the prospect of substantial monthly additions to his income in the future, and where wife was in possession of the business which had been built up primarily through the time and efforts of her and a third party, accompanied by the necessary lands and buildings through which she could conduct that business.

Affirmed.


58. G & A Contractors, Inc. v. Alaska Greenhouses, Inc.

Supreme Court of Alaska. January 16, 1974 517 P.2d 1379


Suit was brought by property owner against upstream property owners seeking to enjoin from future trespasses, future siltation of creek, and future impairment of plaintiff's riparian rights, and also seeking damages stemming from diversion of creek. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eben C. Lewis, J., entered judgment in favor...

Synopsis

Suit was brought by property owner against upstream property owners seeking to enjoin from future trespasses, future siltation of creek, and future impairment of plaintiff's riparian rights, and also seeking damages stemming from diversion of creek. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eben C. Lewis, J., entered judgment in favor of plaintiff, and defendants appealed. The Superme Court, Connor, J., held that (1) the facts militated against resort to the administrative law doctrine of primary jurisdiction, (2) reasonable use of defendants' land did not include siltation, (3) the evidence was sufficient to establish that plaintiff was harmed by siltation of the creek, (4) the cost of restoration rather than reduction in value of the land was proper measure of measure of damages, and (5) it was not error to allow damages for the corporate plaintiff's owner's lost time in attempting to solve the siltation and trespass problems.

Order in accordance with opinion.

Erwin and Fitzgerald, jj., did not participate.


59. Schreiner v. Fruit

Supreme Court of Alaska. February 25, 1974 519 P.2d 462


Action by wife for loss of consortium as result of permanent and personal disability of the husband as result of alleged negligence of defendants. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eben H. Lewis, J., granted motion for judgment on the pleadings and rendered judgment for the defendants. The plaintiff wife appealed. The Supreme...

Synopsis

Action by wife for loss of consortium as result of permanent and personal disability of the husband as result of alleged negligence of defendants. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eben

H. Lewis, J., granted motion for judgment on the pleadings and rendered judgment for the defendants. The plaintiff wife appealed. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that both husband and wife have right to sue for loss of consortium due to negligently inflicted injury to the other spouse. The Court further held that joinder of the claim for loss of consortium with the other spouse's claim for injuries was mandatory and that requirement for joinder was retroactive.

Affirmed.

Erwin, J., not participating.


  1. Sumner Development Corp. v. Shivers

    Supreme Court of Alaska. January 02, 1974 517 P.2d 757 1974 WL 448334



    Action to recover for site work done on construction project. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Victor Carlson, J., denied a motion for summary judgment as against a mechanic's lien claim and petition to review was granted. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that the claim was barred because of plaintiff's lack of...

    Synopsis

    Action to recover for site work done on construction project. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Victor Carlson, J., denied a motion for summary judgment as against a mechanic's lien claim and petition to review was granted. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that the claim was barred because of plaintiff's lack of registration and that defendants were not estopped to rely on the licensing statute but that plaintiff could assert his claim as a setoff.

    Reversed and remanded with instructions.


  2. Spruce Equipment Co. v. Maloney

    Supreme Court of Alaska. November 08, 1974 527 P.2d 1295


    Action by truck driver for damages for injuries sustained when his truck struck a pile of gravel which had been placed on roadway by defendant corporation. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Gerald J. VanHoomissen, J., entered judgment for driver, and corporation appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that instruction which did...

    Synopsis

    Action by truck driver for damages for injuries sustained when his truck struck a pile of gravel which had been placed on roadway by defendant corporation. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Gerald J. VanHoomissen, J., entered judgment for driver, and corporation appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that instruction which did not make clear to jury the fact that truck driver had an obligation to minimize his damages was erroneous where evidence clearly indicated that during portions of period when truck driver was not working after the accident he chose not to seek employment, but engaged in personal activities such as vacationing, tending to his private properties, supervising work on such properties, and taking extensive trips.

    Reversed and remanded for new trial on issue of damages.


  3. Snyder v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. July 15, 1974 524 P.2d 661


Defendant was convicted in the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage District, C. J. Occhipinti, J., of burglary not in a dwelling and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz C. J., held that entire 111-day period between time that defendant moved for examination to determine his competency to stand trial and date on which Superior...

Synopsis

Defendant was convicted in the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage District, C. J. Occhipinti, J., of burglary not in a dwelling and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz C. J., held


that entire 111-day period between time that defendant moved for examination to determine his competency to stand trial and date on which Superior Court held competency hearing and determined that defendant was competent would be excluded from 120-day period within which criminal rule required that defendant be brought to trial.

Affirmed.


63. Wester v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. December 06, 1974 528 P.2d 1179


Defendant was convicted in the Third Judicial District Court, Ralph E. Moody, Superior Court Judge, and John D. Mason, J., of driving while under the influence of an intoxicating beverage, and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that ampule certification and breathalyzer calibration need not be the subject of personal testimony in a...

Synopsis

Defendant was convicted in the Third Judicial District Court, Ralph E. Moody, Superior Court Judge, and John D. Mason, J., of driving while under the influence of an intoxicating beverage, and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that ampule certification and breathalyzer calibration need not be the subject of personal testimony in a prosecution for driving while intoxicated, and are clearly admissible under official records exception to the hearsay rule.

Affirmed.


64. Modrok v. Marshall

Supreme Court of Alaska. February 25, 1974 523 P.2d 172


Forcible entry and detainer action. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Victor D. Carlson, J., entered judgment in favor of plaintiffs, and defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that there may exist a cause of action for forcible entry and detainer where, without entry by force, one in quiet possession withholds...

Synopsis

Forcible entry and detainer action. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Victor D. Carlson, J., entered judgment in favor of plaintiffs, and defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that there may exist a cause of action for forcible entry and detainer where, without entry by force, one in quiet possession withholds property from another entitled to possession after a demand to relinquish it, that it is not essential that person alleging detainer ever have been in possession of premises, that plaintiffs were not chargealbe with notice of a possible claim of fraud by defendant against his wife, and that claim was to be brought against wife, not against plaintiffs in forcible detainer action. It was further held that the state may protect a property owner against loss during an appeal by requiring an appeal bond and payment on affirmance which are related to actual rent accrued or specific damage suffered, but that an automatic doubling of the rental over the period of the appeal is not reasonably tailored to achieve such ends.

Affirmed as modified and remanded. Boochever, J., did not participate.


  1. Dunbar v. State

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 13, 1974 522 P.2d 158


    Defendant, who had been convicted of incest, moved for new trial on basis of newly discovered evidence. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Everett W. Hepp. J., denied motion and movant appealed. The Supreme Court, Dimond, J. pro tem., held that evidentiary hearing was required in view of recantations of defendant's three...

    Synopsis

    Defendant, who had been convicted of incest, moved for new trial on basis of newly discovered evidence. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Everett W. Hepp. J., denied motion and movant appealed. The Supreme Court, Dimond, J. pro tem., held that evidentiary hearing was required in view of recantations of defendant's three children of their testimony against him at trial.

    Order denying motion for new trial reversed and case remanded. Fitzgerald, J., did not participate.


  2. Wortham v. State

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 11, 1974 519 P.2d 797


    Parolee sought habeas corpus to preclude his extradition to demanding state for parole violations. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Ralph E. Moody, J., denied writ, and parolee appealed. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that determination as to whether conditions of parole had been violated was one that was to be made by...

    Synopsis

    Parolee sought habeas corpus to preclude his extradition to demanding state for parole violations. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Ralph E. Moody, J., denied writ, and parolee appealed. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that determination as to whether conditions of parole had been violated was one that was to be made by officials of demanding state, that certification of parole was sufficient to support conclusion by governor of demanding state that conditions of parole had been violated, and that a sufficient basis for issuance of extradition warrant was established.

    Affirmed.


  3. Grasle Elec. Co. v. Clark

Supreme Court of Alaska. August 26, 1974 525 P.2d 1081


Action for injuries and loss of consortium resulting from collision between automobile occupied by plaintiffs and truck driven by an employee of defendant. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Everett W. Hepp, J., rendered summary judgment for plaintiffs as to liability, a jury returned verdicts in amounts of $83,244.50 in favor...

Synopsis

Action for injuries and loss of consortium resulting from collision between automobile occupied by plaintiffs and truck driven by an employee of defendant. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District,


Fairbanks, Everett W. Hepp, J., rendered summary judgment for plaintiffs as to liability, a jury returned verdicts in amounts of $83,244.50 in favor of plaintiff husband and $44,018.30 in favor of plaintiff wife, and defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that the awards were not excessive; that defendant was not entitled to have admitted into evidence a prior inconsistent written statement of defendant, where defendant admitted making such statement; and that the award of attorney's fees was not excessive.

Affirmed.


68. Jakoski v. Holland

Supreme Court of Alaska. March 11, 1974 520 P.2d 569


Action was instituted by motorist for injuries arising out of rear-end automobile collision. The husband made a consortium claim. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Edward

V. Davis, J., entered judgment on a verdict for plaintiffs, and plaintiffs appealed, and defendant cross-appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held...

Synopsis

Action was instituted by motorist for injuries arising out of rear-end automobile collision. The husband made a consortium claim. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Edward V. Davis, J., entered judgment on a verdict for plaintiffs, and plaintiffs appealed, and defendant cross-appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that testimony pertaining to indictment of plaintiff's son was relevant on question of plaintiff's mental and physical disabilities, and medical testimony to establish causal connection between plaintiff's condition and indictment were not necessary; and that amendment adding husband's consortium claim to wife's claim arising out of automobile accident related back to date of complaint so that expiration of limitation prior to amendment did not bar consortium claim.

Affirmed.

Connor, J., dissented and filed an opinion. Erwin and Fitzgerald, JJ., did not participate.


69. State v. Johnson

Supreme Court of Alaska. August 16, 1974 525 P.2d 532


Defendant charged with grand larceny moved to dismiss indictment because of insufficiency of evidence presented to grand jury. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks District, Gerald, J. Van Hoomissen, J., granted motion for dismissal and denied motion for rehearing and the State appealed. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that,...

Synopsis

Defendant charged with grand larceny moved to dismiss indictment because of insufficiency of evidence presented to grand jury. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks District, Gerald, J. Van Hoomissen, J., granted motion for dismissal and denied motion for rehearing and the State appealed. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that, although actual basis for trial court's decision to dismiss indictment was insufficiency of State's opposition to the motion to dismiss, effect of decision was to dismiss indictment on ground of insufficient evidence; thus Supreme Court had


jurisdiction to review the dismissal, and that where employee of store, in which larceny had allegedly taken place, testified that store's security guard was a trained police officer and that he observed guard and defendant with unwrapped, unpaid for items outside store and guard was out of state because her father was dying, it was not improper to allow employee to describe to grand jury what he said the security guard had told him, even though it was hearsay.

Reversed and remanded.


70. Hendricks v. Knik Supply, Inc.

Supreme Court of Alaska. May 22, 1974 522 P.2d 543


Claims were made against wife's estate by her former husband and an assignee of an heir to estate. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Edward V. Davis, J., disallowed husband's claim in its entirety, and upheld assignee's claim to real property, and husband appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that word...

Synopsis

Claims were made against wife's estate by her former husband and an assignee of an heir to estate. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Edward V. Davis, J., disallowed husband's claim in its entirety, and upheld assignee's claim to real property, and husband appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that word personalty, within property settlement agreement wherein wife specifically disclaimed any interest in cash and other personalty owned by either or both of parties, could not be interpreted literally and, absent evidence that wife was relinquishing ownership of every item of her personal property, including her utensils, her jewelry and even the very garments she was wearing at time she signed agreement, could not be interpreted as meaning savings bonds and that wife was disclaiming her interest in same; hence, husband's claim against her estate for bonds was invalid and was improperly disallowed.

Affirmed.

Erwin, J., dissented and filed opinion. Fitzgerald, J., not participating.


71. W. R. Grasle Co. v. Alaska Workmen's Compensation Bd.

Supreme Court of Alaska. January 07, 1974 517 P.2d 999


Workmen's Compensation Board award to claimant was affirmed by the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks District, Warren W. Taylor, J., and employer and its insurer appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that amendment to statute of limitations allowing claimant to file for latent injury as determined by the Board, time...

Synopsis

Workmen's Compensation Board award to claimant was affirmed by the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks District, Warren W. Taylor, J., and employer and its insurer appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that amendment to statute of limitations allowing claimant to file for latent injury as determined by the Board, time limitations notwithstanding, repealed provision that the claim be filed within four years of the accident; and that evidence supported finding that the injury was latent.

Affirmed.



72. Hill v. Vetter

Supreme Court of Alaska. August 12, 1974 525 P.2d 529


Defendant brought action for assault and battery. The State of Alaska Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks District, Gerald J. Van Hoomissen, J., entered judgment in favor of plaintiff and defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that trial court should not have imposed the sanction of entering judgment in the...

Synopsis

Defendant brought action for assault and battery. The State of Alaska Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks District, Gerald J. Van Hoomissen, J., entered judgment in favor of plaintiff and defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that trial court should not have imposed the sanction of entering judgment in the amount prayed for, $150,000, against defendant who failed to appear where the failure was due to a misunderstanding as to whether date set for trial was actually date for trial or merely for hearing of motion for continuance; that trial court erred in allowing motion to withdraw demand for jury; and that defendant did not waive his right to jury trial by his failure to appear at trial.

Reversed and remanded. Erwin, J., did not participate.


73. Aguchak v. Montgomery Ward Co., Inc.

Supreme Court of Alaska. April 01, 1974 520 P.2d 1352 1974 WL 449434


Appeal from a judgment of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, James A. Hanson, J., affirming denial by District Court of motion for relief from default judgment rendered against debtors in small claims action. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that small claims actions were subject to change of venue and that summons which failed to...

Synopsis

Appeal from a judgment of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, James A. Hanson, J., affirming denial by District Court of motion for relief from default judgment rendered against debtors in small claims action. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that small claims actions were subject to change of venue and that summons which failed to inform rural indigent debtors of option of filing written pleadings was constitutionally defective.

Reversed and remanded.


74. Adoption of V. M. C.

Supreme Court of Alaska. November 29, 1974 528 P.2d 788


Proceeding on petition for adoption of child by its paternal grandparents. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Gerald J. VanHoomissen, J., denied petition, and grandparents



appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that evidence supported finding that father had not consciously abandoned his parental role, that such finding...

Synopsis

Proceeding on petition for adoption of child by its paternal grandparents. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Gerald J. VanHoomissen, J., denied petition, and grandparents appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that evidence supported finding that father had not consciously abandoned his parental role, that such finding was not excessively influenced by evidence of father's objective intent, that even if exclusion of psychiatrist's testimony that it would not be in best interests of child to be taken from grandparents and returned to live with father was error, such error was harmless, that award of costs of $2,462.28 and attorney fees of $2,000 to father was not abuse of discretion and that such an award was not precluded on theory that it created chilling effect on legitimate assertion of rights by both parties in contested adoption proceedings.

Affirmed.


75. Adkins v. Lester

Supreme Court of Alaska. December 16, 1974 530 P.2d 11


Police officer brought action against motorist for injuries sustained in collision involving unmarked city police vehicle and motorist's automobile, and motorist's wife who was a passenger in motorist's vehicle brought action against motorist, police officer and city. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks District, Warren William...

Synopsis

Police officer brought action against motorist for injuries sustained in collision involving unmarked city police vehicle and motorist's automobile, and motorist's wife who was a passenger in motorist's vehicle brought action against motorist, police officer and city. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks District, Warren William Taylor, J., rendered judgment in favor of the police officer and city and the motorist and his wife appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that state traffic regulation permitting driver of authorized emergency vehicle to avoid use of audible signals and warning lights under certain circumstances when responding to an emergency call was applicable rather than city ordinance which required use of audible signals at all times; that instruction properly stated effect of the state regulation; and that officer who investigated accident should have been permitted to testify as to his opinion as to causes which contributed to the accident if he was qualified as an expert.

Reversed.

Rabinowitz, C. J., dissented in part and filed opinion.


76. Gilbert v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. September 30, 1974 526 P.2d 1131 1974 WL 451238


Action for declaratory judgment by potential candidate for state senator, seeking declaration that requirement of three-year residency in state and one-year residency in election district for election to legislative office violated the candidate's equal protection rights. The Superior Court, Third



Judicial District, Anchorage District, P. J....

Synopsis

Action for declaratory judgment by potential candidate for state senator, seeking declaration that requirement of three-year residency in state and one-year residency in election district for election to legislative office violated the candidate's equal protection rights. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage District, P. J. Kalamarides, J., denied the petition, awarded attorney's fees to the state, and candidate appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that the residency requirement served a compelling state interest and thus did not deny candidate equal protection; but that it was an abuse of discretion to award attorneys' fees against the candidate who had in good faith raised a question of genuine public interest before the courts.

Affirmed in part and reversed in part.


  1. Continental Ins. Co. v. U. S. Fidelity & Guar. Co.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. November 29, 1974 528 P.2d 430


    Action for declaratory judgment was brought against subcontractor's insurer by general contractor's insurer to determine liability for costs of defense and actual recovery in wrongful death actions. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Victor D. Carlson, J., entered judgment denying recovery, and an appeal was taken. The Supreme...

    Synopsis

    Action for declaratory judgment was brought against subcontractor's insurer by general contractor's insurer to determine liability for costs of defense and actual recovery in wrongful death actions. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Victor D. Carlson, J., entered judgment denying recovery, and an appeal was taken. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that general contractor which did no more than prepare ice road over lake was not a user of subcontractor's trucks within omnibus clause of subcontractor's standard automobile policy covering trucks; that wrongful death actions against general contractor, wherein an allegation placed subcontractor's insurer on notice of contention that general contractor was a user of subcontractor's vehicles within omnibus clause, were at least potentially within coverage of subcontractor's standard automobile policy covering subcontractor's trucks so that subcontractor's insurer should have undertaken general contractor's defense.

    Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded. Rabinowitz, C. J., dissented and filed an opinion. Erwin and Fitzgerald, JJ., did not participate.


  2. Urban Development Co. v. Dekreon

    Supreme Court of Alaska. September 13, 1974 526 P.2d 325


    Appeal by landowner from a judgment of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Eben H. Lewis, J., ordering foreclosure of a lien for services rendered in improvement of property and contracted for by prospective purchaser of property. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that agreement



    between prospective purchaser and construction supervisor...

    Synopsis

    Appeal by landowner from a judgment of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Eben H. Lewis, J., ordering foreclosure of a lien for services rendered in improvement of property and contracted for by prospective purchaser of property. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that agreement between prospective purchaser and construction supervisor in establishing a partnership whereby supervisor would take monthly draw against the profits did not affect supervisor's standing to file lien against land, that case should be reversed and remanded so that necessary additional findings to support trial court's conclusion could be made, and that failure to hold hearing on objections to proposed findings and conclusions was not error.

    Reversed and remanded.


  3. Union Oil Co. of California v. State, Dept. of Natural Resources

Supreme Court of Alaska. October 04, 1974 526 P.2d 1357


Oil company appealed from an order of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Ralph E. Moody, J., which dismissed proceeding for review of a determination of the Commissioner of the Department of Natural Resources that the oil company was not entitled to a discovery royalty certification. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that the...

Synopsis

Oil company appealed from an order of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Ralph E. Moody, J., which dismissed proceeding for review of a determination of the Commissioner of the Department of Natural Resources that the oil company was not entitled to a discovery royalty certification. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that the Commissioner had authority to review denials of discovery certification separate from that of the Director of Division of Lands which was not limited by the 60-day limitations period of the Administrative Procedure Act.

Reversed and remanded.


80. McCracken v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. January 11, 1974 518 P.2d 85


A proceeding for postconviction relief. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Victor D. Carlson, J., issued an order denying the petitioner's motion to represent himself, and the petitioner appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that a court rule must be interpreted so as to conform to the United States and Alaska...

Synopsis

A proceeding for postconviction relief. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Victor D. Carlson, J., issued an order denying the petitioner's motion to represent himself, and the petitioner appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that a court rule must be interpreted so as to conform to the United States and Alaska Constitutions; that the petitioner has a right to self-representation in such a proceeding but that the right is not absolute; that where court is not satisfied


that prisoner is capable of self representation, it is within court's discretion to insist that prisoner accept consultative assistance by appointed counsel; and that where pleadings filed by petitioner demonstrated a certain knowledge of the merits of his allegation, his rights could best be vindicated by an order permitting him to represent himself with assistance of counsel from public defender's office appointed by the court.

Reversed in part and remanded. Erwin, J., did not participate.


81. Prokopis v. Prokopis

Supreme Court of Alaska. March 08, 1974 519 P.2d 814


Suit for specific performance of alleged oral contract which would give plaintiff an undivided one-half ownership in duplex and surrounding land which was in name of defendant. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Edmond W. Burke, J., denied specific performance and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that where...

Synopsis
