Suit for specific performance of alleged oral contract which would give plaintiff an undivided one-half ownership in duplex and surrounding land which was in name of defendant. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Edmond W. Burke, J., denied specific performance and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that where defendant purchased duplex in his own name by assuming 20-year trust deed note, making down payment and becoming obligated to perform improvements of stated value, he offered to convey one-half to plaintiff, who was to assume half of defendant's obligations, and plaintiff's later oral offer incorporated those terms, even though there was no written agreement, terms of agreement were definite enough to permit specific performance on part of defendant.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded for further proceedings. Ervin and Fitzgerald, JJ., did not participate.


82. Concerned Citizens of South Kenai Peninsula v. Kenai Peninsula Borough

Supreme Court of Alaska. October 21, 1974 527 P.2d 447


Action by taxpayers seeking dissolution of hospital service district. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage District, Ralph E. Moody, J., granted summary judgment for the defendants, and taxpayers appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., hald that the creation of the service district was not an arbitrary act denying due process of...

Synopsis

Action by taxpayers seeking dissolution of hospital service district. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage District, Ralph E. Moody, J., granted summary judgment for the defendants, and taxpayers appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., hald that the creation of the service district was not an arbitrary act denying due process of law; that the description set out in the ordinance creating the hospital district adequately designated the district's boundaries; and that laches barred taxpayer's other claims that organization of the hospital district violated state statutes and constitutional provisions.

Affirmed.


Boocheever, J., joined by Rabinowtz, C. J., concurred and filed opinion.


83. Williams v. Safeway Stores

Supreme Court of Alaska. September 03, 1974 525 P.2d 1087


Workman filed letter on April 20, 1972 asking State Workmen's Compensation Board to open his case wherein Board had filed order on January 31, 1968 awarding him compensation for continuing temporary total disability and stating that he suffered permanent partial disability of an undetermined degree; Board granted...

Synopsis

Workman filed letter on April 20, 1972 asking State Workmen's Compensation Board to open his case wherein Board had filed order on January 31, 1968 awarding him compensation for continuing temporary total disability and stating that he suffered permanent partial disability of an undetermined degree; Board granted workmen's claim for permanent total disability after hearing, and employer appealed. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage District, Eben H. Lewis, J., granted employer's motion for summary judgment on basis that claim was time barred, and workman appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that State Workmen's Compensation Board's 1968 order impliedly reserved jurisdiction to decide issue of workman's permanent disability so that statutory limitation period did not apply to workman's claim.

Reversed and remanded. Erwin, J., did not participate.


84. Davenport v. McGinnis

Supreme Court of Alaska. May 31, 1974 522 P.2d 1140


Action against Commissioner of Health and Social Services, Superintendent of Youth Center and other employees of Department of Health and Social Services brought by plaintiff who alleged that he had been wrongfully placed in facility with adults and wrongfully imprisoned past his 19th birthday. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District,...

Synopsis

Action against Commissioner of Health and Social Services, Superintendent of Youth Center and other employees of Department of Health and Social Services brought by plaintiff who alleged that he had been wrongfully placed in facility with adults and wrongfully imprisoned past his 19th birthday. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Edmond W. Burke, J., granted summary judgment for defendants on one issue and entered judgment on verdict for defendants and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that where at time minor committed act which conferred jurisdiction upon juvenile court and at time he was sentenced the applicable statute required that minor found to be delinquent be committed to Department for indeterminate period to end not later than day he became 21 years of age, fact that, shortly after he was committed, statute reducing age for release to 19 became effective did not mandate his release on day he attained age of 19; thus he was not wronged by incarceration beyond that day and that where plaintiff had attained age of 18 at time of his commitment to facility for young offenders up to 27 years of age, such placement did not violate statute requiring juveniles to be held in custody in place separate from adults.


Affirmed.

Erwin, J., with whom Rabinowitz, C. J., joined, concurred in part and dissented in part and filed opinion.


85. Holiday Inns of America, Inc. v. Peck

Supreme Court of Alaska. March 26, 1974 520 P.2d 87


Suit by franchisee against franchisor for alleged wrongful breach of franchise agreement. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eben H. Lewis, J., found for franchisee, and franchisor appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that submission of compound interrogatories to jury was not plain error, and that evidence...

Synopsis

Suit by franchisee against franchisor for alleged wrongful breach of franchise agreement. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eben H. Lewis, J., found for franchisee, and franchisor appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that submission of compound interrogatories to jury was not plain error, and that evidence sustained jury's findings relating to franchisee not knowing or being bound by date specified in commitment letter for commencement of construction.

Affirmed.


86. University of Alaska v. Chauvin

Supreme Court of Alaska. May 01, 1974 521 P.2d 1234


Former employee of state university brought action against university for breach of contract of employment. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Gerald J. Van Hoomissen, J., awarded employee damages, and university appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that tenured employee was entitled to a hearing before termination of...

Synopsis

Former employee of state university brought action against university for breach of contract of employment. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Gerald J. Van Hoomissen, J., awarded employee damages, and university appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that tenured employee was entitled to a hearing before termination of employment, that employee's discharge was improper and that employee was not required to mitigate his damages by taking another untenured position which was not suitable alternative to former job.

Affirmed.


87. Roderick v. Sullivan

Supreme Court of Alaska. November 22, 1974 528 P.2d 450


Action by borough against city to determine whether voters of borough must ratify ordinance altering manner of selecting borough assemblymen. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage District, James K. Singleton, J., rendered judgment for the city, and borough appealed.



The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that a borough...

Synopsis

Action by borough against city to determine whether voters of borough must ratify ordinance altering manner of selecting borough assemblymen. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage District, James K. Singleton, J., rendered judgment for the city, and borough appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that a borough reapportionment ordinance held that a borough reapportionment ordinance even where the assembly had not made a determination of existing unconstitutionality.

Affirmed.

Fitzgerald, J., did not participate.


88. Employers Commercial Union Ins. Group v. Schoen

Supreme Court of Alaska. March 08, 1974 519 P.2d 819


Workmen's compensation case. The Workmen's Compensation Board issued an order in favor of claimant, and compensation insurer filed a complaint in the superior court in the nature of an appeal. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Ralph E. Moody, J., vacated the Board's order and remanded the claim to the Board with directions....

Synopsis

Workmen's compensation case. The Workmen's Compensation Board issued an order in favor of claimant, and compensation insurer filed a complaint in the superior court in the nature of an appeal. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Ralph E. Moody, J., vacated the Board's order and remanded the claim to the Board with directions. Upon an appeal and cross appeal, the Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that (1) denying the compensation insurer an opportunity to cross-examine claimant's physician, whose medical reports were admitted in evidence at hearing before thte Board, constituted prejudicial error, unwaived by the insurer on its appeal to the superior court, requiring remand to the Board, and (2) where the causal relationship between the employment and disability was disputable and where the sufficiency of evidence question was close, it was appropriate for the superior court to remand the case after determining that vital evidence had erroneously been excluded.

Affirmed.

Erwin, J., did not participate.


89. State v. Marathon Oil Co.

Supreme Court of Alaska. November 18, 1974 528 P.2d 293 1974-1975 O.S.H.D. (CCH) P 19,174


Oil company was convicted in the Third Judicial District Court, Anchorage, John D. Mason, J., of violating safety code regulation, and oil company appealed. The Superior Court, Edmond W. Burke, J., reversed the conviction, and State Appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that statutory limitation proscribing State appeals in criminal...

Synopsis

Oil company was convicted in the Third Judicial District Court, Anchorage, John D. Mason, J., of


violating safety code regulation, and oil company appealed. The Superior Court, Edmond W. Burke, J., reversed the conviction, and State Appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that statutory limitation proscribing State appeals in criminal cases applied to appeals from judgments of acquittal in trial court, that State was not precluded from appealing the order of the Superior Court, that safety code regulation, requiring employer to furnish and maintain safe place of employment and to do everything reasonably necessary to protect life and safety of employees, was applicable to situation where employee of independent contractor who was injured on oil company's premises, that the regulation was not void as unconstitutionally vague, and that evidence supported the conviction.

District court judgment affirmed.

Fitzgerald, J., with whom Connor, J., concurred, dissented on basis that evidence was insufficient to support conviction.


90. McKinnon v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. August 30, 1974 526 P.2d 18 1974 WL 451075


Defendant was convicted before the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage District, Ralph E. Moody, J., for the sale of narcotics and his probation was revoked before the same court,

C. J. Occhipinti, J. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that dismissal of defendant's counsel, over defendant's protest, and appointment of substitute...

Synopsis

Defendant was convicted before the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage District, Ralph E. Moody, J., for the sale of narcotics and his probation was revoked before the same court, C. J. Occhipinti, J. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that dismissal of defendant's counsel, over defendant's protest, and appointment of substitute counsel for defendant deprived him of his right to counsel of his choice, that the defendant's subsequent entry of a plea of nolo contendere did not shield the conviction from challenge, that since the probation revocation was based upon the conviction it too must be vacated, that it was error for the presiding judge, to whom the criminal case was assigned, to transfer the criminal case to the judge assigned to the probation revocation hearing and to take the probation revocation hearing himself in the face of defendant's per-emptory challenge to both judges, that the defendant could not attack the legality of the conviction which led to his probation status except in the court in which the conviction occurred, that the evidence was sufficient to allow the grand jury to return indictment, and that the findings of a professional laboratory technician could be introduced at the grand jury proceedings in the technician's absence.

Reversed and remanded. Fitzgerald, J., did not participate.


91. Schandelmeier v. Winchester Western

Supreme Court of Alaska. March 11, 1974 520 P.2d 70


The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, James K. Singleton, J., denied plaintiff relief from judgment of dismissal, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that in view of harshness of dismissal with prejudice, case was proper one for dispensing with procedural rule regarding timely appeals, and that...



Synopsis

The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, James K. Singleton, J., denied plaintiff relief from judgment of dismissal, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that in view of harshness of dismissal with prejudice, case was proper one for dispensing with procedural rule regarding timely appeals, and that dismissal with prejudice for failure of plaintiff's son who was only witness to accident to appear for deposition was improper.

Reversed and remanded.

Connor, J., filed dissenting opinion.

Erwin and Fitzgerald, JJ., not participating.


92. In re Cornelius

Supreme Court of Alaska. March 15, 1974 520 P.2d 76


Petition for review of recommendations of board of governors of Alaska Bar Association. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that where two attorneys shared office, the one who was in charge of office in the other's absence could effectively consent to search of office and any evidence disclosed could properly be used against the absent attorney,...

Synopsis

Petition for review of recommendations of board of governors of Alaska Bar Association. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that where two attorneys shared office, the one who was in charge of office in the other's absence could effectively consent to search of office and any evidence disclosed could properly be used against the absent attorney, that soliciting at least one offeror in connection with law-related business, in which attorney is partner of nonlawyers, accepting business of other offerors solicited by partners and participating in organization of prospective litigants, thus creating litigation, warrants suspension for four months, and that sending letters to original offerors informing them that they retained an interest in certain oil lease applications, with knowledge that original offerors were not named as offerors or interested parties in any lease applications, warrants suspension for 42 months. Suspension ordered.

Erwin and Boochever, JJ., not participating.


93. State v. I'Anson

Supreme Court of Alaska. November 29, 1974 529 P.2d 188


Petition for review by state arising out of a bifurcated superior court trial in which issue of state's liability for alleged negligent failure to post a warning sign in advance of entrance road to campground and in failure to place no-passing striping on portion of highway was tried with assistance of an advisory jury. The Superior Court, Third...

Synopsis

Petition for review by state arising out of a bifurcated superior court trial in which issue of state's liability for alleged negligent failure to post a warning sign in advance of entrance road to campground and in failure to place no-passing striping on portion of highway was tried with assistance of an advisory jury. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eben H. Lewis, J., rejected verdict of advisory jury and rendered judgment for injured motorist and passengers, and state appealed. The Supreme


Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that where record as barren of data surrounding possibility that trial judge conducted an impermissible experiment at site of accident, case would be remanded; that discretionary acts include only those made at planning level, while decisions made at operational or ministerial level are actionable in regard to discretionary function exception under the Tort Claims Act; that superior court did not err in refusing to extend discretionary function exception to state; and that where placement of traffic signs and striping were operational functions rather than planning functions for purposes of discretionary function exception to Tort Claims Act, the appropriate standard of care required of state and its agents was to use reasonable care to keep the highway in a safe condition for reasonably prudent traveler.

Affirmed in part, and remanded with directions. Boochever, J., did not participate.


94. Jefferson v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. September 27, 1974 527 P.2d 37


Suit by city resident against city, borough and state to enjoin transfer of control over city's sewer system to borough. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, James K. Singleton, J., rendered summary judgment in favor of defendants, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that defect in proportional representation...

Synopsis

Suit by city resident against city, borough and state to enjoin transfer of control over city's sewer system to borough. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, James K. Singleton, J., rendered summary judgment in favor of defendants, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that defect in proportional representation scheme of statute under which borough assembly was established did not render incorporation of borough invalid, and that statute providing that no city, may exercise any area wide power exercised by borough overrides city utility assets without voter approval thus utility asserts without voter approval thus city could transfer its sewer system to borough without voter approval.

Affirmed.

Connor, J., filed a concurring opinion.


95. Anthony v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. April 01, 1974 521 P.2d 486


Defendant was convicted before the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Everett W. Hepp, J., of first-degree murder and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that where the only evidence which placed defendant at scene of murder or which demonstrated motive or guilty knowledge was the testimony of the victim's widow,...

Synopsis

Defendant was convicted before the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Everett W. Hepp, J., of first-degree murder and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that where the only evidence which placed defendant at scene of murder or which demonstrated motive or guilty knowledge was the testimony of the victim's widow, an accomplice, and the conviction was


substantially procured by the accomplice's testimony, the failure to give cautionary instruction that testimony of an accomplice ought to be viewed with distrust constituted reversible error.

Reversed and remanded.

Erwin, J., dissented and filed opinion in which Fitzgerald, J., joined.


96. Interior Paint Co. v. Rodgers

Supreme Court of Alaska. May 13, 1974 522 P.2d 164


Proceedings on application for workmen's compensation benefits for permanent and total disability. The Supreme Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Everett W. Hepp, J., reversed the compensation board's denial of benefits, and employer appealed. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that substantial evidence standard applied to review of...

Synopsis

Proceedings on application for workmen's compensation benefits for permanent and total disability. The Supreme Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Everett W. Hepp, J., reversed the compensation board's denial of benefits, and employer appealed. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that substantial evidence standard applied to review of compensation board's determinations, and that evidence sustained denial of permanent and total disability benefits.

Reversed and remanded.


97. Golden Val. Elec. Ass'n, Inc. v. City Elec. Service, Inc.

Supreme Court of Alaska. January 21, 1974 518 P.2d 65


Third-party action for indemnification. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks. Everett W. Hepp, J., dismissed third-party complaint and rendered judgment for third-party defendant, and third-party plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that third party, although found liable in tort to injured workman, could...

Synopsis

Third-party action for indemnification. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks. Everett W. Hepp, J., dismissed third-party complaint and rendered judgment for third-party defendant, and third-party plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that third party, although found liable in tort to injured workman, could not recover indemnity from workman's employer, considering that no covenant of indemnity could be implied in agreement between parties, and that parties, having entered into a written contract, could have allocated risk expressly amongst themselves in that they were on notice of exclusive remedy provision of Workmen's Compensation Act.

Affirmed.

Erwin, J., dissented and filed opinion, in which Fitzgerald, J., concurred.


98. State v. Adams

Supreme Court of Alaska. May 23, 1974 522 P.2d 1125



From a final judgment of the State of Alaska Superior Court, First Judicial District, Sitka District, Victor D. Carlson, J., holding a statutory residency requirement for divorce unconstitutional, the attorney general appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that the statute violates equal protection clauses of state and federal constitutions....

Synopsis

From a final judgment of the State of Alaska Superior Court, First Judicial District, Sitka District, Victor

D. Carlson, J., holding a statutory residency requirement for divorce unconstitutional, the attorney general appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that the statute violates equal protection clauses of state and federal constitutions.

Affirmed.


99. United Services Auto. Ass'n v. Werley

Supreme Court of Alaska. September 09, 1974 526 P.2d 28


An order of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Ralph E. Moody, J., directed the production of various documents in a discovery order, and a petition for review was filed. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that an allegation that plaintiff's insurer breached its duty of good faith and fair dealing with plaintiff by...

Synopsis

An order of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Ralph E. Moody, J., directed the production of various documents in a discovery order, and a petition for review was filed. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that an allegation that plaintiff's insurer breached its duty of good faith and fair dealing with plaintiff by refusing, without proper cause, to compensate him for loss and that such tortious conduct took the form of the insurer offering bad-faith defenses to a legitimate claim satisfied the civil fraud pleading requirement of exception to attorney-client privilege, and evidence was such as to satisfy also the prima facie evidence requirement for exception.

Order affirmed.

Erwin, J., did not participate.


100. Stock v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. August 30, 1974 526 P.2d 3 7 ERC 1131


Defendant was convicted in the District Court, First Judicial District, Juneau District, Bruce Monroe, J., of Willfully violating the State Environmental Conservation Act, and he appealed. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau District, Victor D. Carlson, J., affirmed and held that case should be remanded for sentencing under another...

Synopsis

Defendant was convicted in the District Court, First Judicial District, Juneau District, Bruce Monroe, J., of Willfully violating the State Environmental Conservation Act, and he appealed. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau District, Victor D. Carlson, J., affirmed and held that case should be


remanded for sentencing under another provision of the Act in the absence of an allegation of willfullness, and the defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that definition of term pollution contained in State Environmental Conservation Act was not unconstitutionally vague as applied to defendant; that Department of Environmental Conservation was not required to exhaust the compliance-order procedure before instituting prosecuting of defendant for pollution violation; that defendant's right to due process was not violated by commencement of civil action without completion of administrative proceedings where record indicated that no administrative hearings were held; that evidence was sufficient to sustain defendant's conviction on basis that defendant had consented to pollution violation by trailer court owned by corporation of which he was president and principal stockholder; and that punishment provisions of State Environmental Conservation Act providing

$25,000 fine for negligent violators and $1,000 fine per day for each willful violation did not transgress equal protection and due process clauses of Federal and State Constitutions.

Affirmed.


101. Day v. A & G Const. Co., Inc.

Supreme Court of Alaska. November 29, 1974 528 P.2d 440


Action for accounting was brought for purpose of proper allocation of costs under contract whereby defendant promised to pay plaintiff 50% of net profits from resale of land after defendant's exercise of option to purchase land from plaintiff. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, at Anchorage, Ralph E. Moody, J., entered a judgment from...

Synopsis

Action for accounting was brought for purpose of proper allocation of costs under contract whereby defendant promised to pay plaintiff 50% of net profits from resale of land after defendant's exercise of option to purchase land from plaintiff. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, at Anchorage, Ralph

E. Moody, J., entered a judgment from which the defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that, inter alia, the term cost as used in contract providing for sharing of net profits after deduction of cost incurred in connection with the acquisition and development of land should be understood in the broad common sense rather than the technical tax accounting context.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded.

Connor, J., filed an opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part.


102. Risher v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. June 17, 1974 523 P.2d 421


Defendant was convicted before the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, William H. Sanders, J., of obtaining money by false pretenses from the Department of Health and Social Services and she appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that in order for a defendant to receive effective assistance of counsel, defense counsel...

Synopsis

Defendant was convicted before the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, William H. Sanders, J., of obtaining money by false pretenses from the Department of Health and Social Services and she appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that in order for a defendant to receive


effective assistance of counsel, defense counsel must perform at least as well as the lawyer with ordinary training and skill in the criminal law and must conscientiously protect his client's interest, undeflected by conflicting consideration; that in order to establish ineffective assistance of counsel a defendant must show that counsel did not meet that standard and that the ineffective assistance of counsel contributed to the conviction; and that in view of the magnitude of the case against defendant and the unlikelihood of a different result, defendant was not deprived of the effective assistance of counsel.

Affirmed.

Rabinowitz, C. J., concurred and filed opinion in which Erwin, J., joined. Fitzgerald, J., did not participate.


103. North State Tel. Co., Inc. v. Alaska Public Utilities Com'n

Supreme Court of Alaska. May 03, 1974 522 P.2d 711 1974 WL 333605


Appeal by telephone compamy from a judgment of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, James

M. Fitzgerald, J., affirming a decision of the Public Utilities Commission relieving telephone company of authority to provide telephone exchange service in particular area. The Supreme Court, Commor, J., held that admission of evidence concerning...

Synopsis

Appeal by telephone compamy from a judgment of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, James M. Fitzgerald, J., affirming a decision of the Public Utilities Commission relieving telephone company of authority to provide telephone exchange service in particular area. The Supreme Court, Commor, J., held that admission of evidence concerning telephone company's technical ability to provide the required service and need for service was harmless error and did not convert proceeding into a decertification inquiry and that evidence supported Commission's action.

Affirmed.

Boochever and Fitzgerald, JJ., did not participate.


104. Fajeriak v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. March 18, 1974 520 P.2d 795


Proceedings on application for postconviction relief. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, C. J. Occhipinti, J., summarily dismissed the application, and defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that genuine issues of material fact requiring evidentiary hearing were presented. Reversed and remanded. Erwin and...

Synopsis

Proceedings on application for postconviction relief. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, C. J. Occhipinti, J., summarily dismissed the application, and defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that genuine issues of material fact requiring evidentiary hearing were presented.

Reversed and remanded.

Erwin and Fitzgerald, JJ., did not participate.


105. Northern Corp. v. Chugach Elec. Ass'n

Supreme Court of Alaska. January 16, 1974 518 P.2d 76


Action by contractor against owner to recover costs incurred in attempted completion of contract for repair and protection of upstream face of a dam. Owner counterclaimed. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, James K. Singleton, J., discharged parties from contract on ground of impossibility of performance, but denied both...

Synopsis

Action by contractor against owner to recover costs incurred in attempted completion of contract for repair and protection of upstream face of a dam. Owner counterclaimed. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, James K. Singleton, J., discharged parties from contract on ground of impossibility of performance, but denied both parties' claims for damages and attorney's fees, and contractor appealed and owner cross-appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that contractor's repeated efforts to perform contract by transporting rock across frozen lake by truck, culminating in tragic loss of life, supported finding that contract was impossible of performance by this method, and that when owner was reasonably placed on notice that it was not feasible to perform contract by means of ice haul method, owner should either have agreed to termination of the contract or issued a change order providing for some other method of hauling the rock, and owner, which instead implacably insisted on performance of contract as agreed, was liable for contractor's increased cost incurred after such time as it was reasonably placed on notice that it was not feasible to perform the contract by means of ice haul method.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded. Erwin and Fitzgerald, JJ., did not participate.


106. ERA Helicopters, Inc. v. Digicon Alaska, Inc.

Supreme Court of Alaska. February 11, 1974 518 P.2d 1057


Survey company brought action for losses suffered when helicopter company damaged a gravity meter. The State of Alaska Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage District, Edward V. Davis, J., entered judgment on the verdict in favor of survey company and helicopter company appealed from the award of damages. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz,...

Synopsis

Survey company brought action for losses suffered when helicopter company damaged a gravity meter. The State of Alaska Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage District, Edward V. Davis, J., entered judgment on the verdict in favor of survey company and helicopter company appealed from the award of damages. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that instruction on determination of damages for business interruption furnished adequate guidelines to the jury; that damages for business interruption were not limited to the value of the gravity meter; that even though relationship of the parties was defined by contract, the case was litigated in tort and damages were not limited to those which helicopter company knew or should have contemplated it would be exposed to at the time it entered into the contract; that award of damages for business interruption and damage to the gravity meter were not excessive, were supported by evidence and were properly computed; and that prejudgment interest was properly included in the money judgment on which attorneys' fees were computed; but that prejudgment interest should have been awarded from the date on which the loss of use damages ended rather than from the date of loss of the gravity meter.

Affirmed and remanded for modification.



107. Vetter v. Alaska Workmen's Compensation Bd.

Supreme Court of Alaska. July 12, 1974 524 P.2d 264


Workmen's compensation case. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Warren W. Taylor, J., affirmed a denial of compensation and claimant appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that disability compensation may be denied to claimant who does not desire to work but that evidence did not support finding that claimant was...

Synopsis

Workmen's compensation case. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Warren W. Taylor, J., affirmed a denial of compensation and claimant appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that disability compensation may be denied to claimant who does not desire to work but that evidence did not support finding that claimant was unwilling to find suitable employment, and thus not entitled to disability compensation, either because her husband opposed her working or because she did not desire to work.

Reversed and remanded with instructions.

Connor, J., dissented and filed opinion in which Fitzgerald, J., joined.


108. City of Valdez v. Valdez Development Co.

Supreme Court of Alaska. June 05, 1974 523 P.2d 177


Development partnership brought action in which it was claimed that city's counterclaim for forfeiture of lots recently conveyed to partnership in conjunction with carrying out urban renewal project constituted a cloud on partnership's titles, prevented it from obtaining financing and was an act of malicious prosecution. City subsequently brought...

Synopsis

Development partnership brought action in which it was claimed that city's counterclaim for forfeiture of lots recently conveyed to partnership in conjunction with carrying out urban renewal project constituted a cloud on partnership's titles, prevented it from obtaining financing and was an act of malicious prosecution. City subsequently brought suit to have title to lots revested in it due to partnership's failure to meet its contractual construction deadlines. The Superior Court, Anchorage, Third Judicial District, Eben H. Lewis, J., refused to grant city foreclosure, extended construction deadlines, denied partnership damages for malicious prosecution and ordered city to convey four lots to partnership, and both parties appealed. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that period during which securing of financing for construction of housing in city was impossible due to federal injunction preventing construction of trans-Alaska pipeline was an excused period of enforced delay within contract provision, that failure of partnership to comply with contractual provision requiring party seeking benefit of provision pertaining to excused delays to give notice to other party as to cause of such delay within ten days after delay began was excused, that city was not contractually required to convey such four lots to partnership, that evidence supported finding that no damages were established with regard to claim of malicious prosecution and that refusal to award either party attorney fees was not abuse of discretion.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded.


Connor, J., dissented and filed opinion. Erwin, J., not participating.


109. Peters v. Juneau-Douglas Girl Scout Council

Supreme Court of Alaska. March 15, 1974 519 P.2d 826


Action was brought to establish adverse title to land. The Superior Court, First Judicial, Juneau District, Thomas B. Stewart, J., entered a judgment adverse to the claimant and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that evidence did establish that the claimant's possession of land in semiwilderness area had the requisite exclusivity and...

Synopsis

Action was brought to establish adverse title to land. The Superior Court, First Judicial, Juneau District, Thomas B. Stewart, J., entered a judgment adverse to the claimant and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that evidence did establish that the claimant's possession of land in semiwilderness area had the requisite exclusivity and hostility.

Reversed and remanded.

Erwin and Boochever, JJ., did not participate.


110. Talbot's Inc. v. Cessnun Enterprises, Inc.

Supreme Court of Alaska. February 08, 1974 518 P.2d 1064


Action to establish an easement over a tidelands parcel. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Ketchikan, Hubert A. Gilbert, J., issued an injunction against interference with alleged easement, and defendant appealed. The Supreme Court Erwin, J., held that there were sufficient interests established by both parties holding deeds to tidelands...

Synopsis

Action to establish an easement over a tidelands parcel. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Ketchikan, Hubert A. Gilbert, J., issued an injunction against interference with alleged easement, and defendant appealed. The Supreme Court Erwin, J., held that there were sufficient interests established by both parties holding deeds to tidelands property from city to call for city engineer to decide, in an adversary adjudicatory proceeding held pursuant to statute, whether an easement over property held by defendant was reasonable and necessary to use of adjoining property held by plaintiffs, but while there was sufficient evidence for city engineer to make a decision on question of conflicting uses, where record did not reflect what he decided, and designation of an easement on plat was not sufficient to reflect nature of use, or purpose of easement, or what it was for, and no mention was made in either deed of easement, case would be remanded for a determination as to what was found by city engineer, and parties would be permitted to introduce evidence bearing upon existence of easement and type of easement contemplated.

Judgment vacated, and case remanded.


111. Petition of Moody


Supreme Court of Alaska. July 22, 1974 524 P.2d 1261


Law clerk for superior court instituted proceeding challenging refusal of bar association to enroll him as an inactive rather than active member. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that determination of bar association that law clerk, who had been admitted to practice, was engaged in the practice of law and, therefore, was not entitled to...

Synopsis

Law clerk for superior court instituted proceeding challenging refusal of bar association to enroll him as an inactive rather than active member. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that determination of bar association that law clerk, who had been admitted to practice, was engaged in the practice of law and, therefore, was not entitled to enrollment in bar association as an inactive member was reasonable and within the association's authority even though court rule precluded clerk from engaging directly or indirectly in the practice of law and membership in the bar association was not a prerequisite to his employment.

Order accordingly.


112. Stewart & Grindle, Inc. v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. June 12, 1974 524 P.2d 1242 1974 WL 450820


Motion by landowners to tax condemnor state with interest from date eminent domain proceedings were instituted to date of payment of compensation into court registry, appraisal costs and attorney fees. The Third Judicial District Court, Edmond W. Burke, J., denied the motion, and landowners appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that...

Synopsis

Motion by landowners to tax condemnor state with interest from date eminent domain proceedings were instituted to date of payment of compensation into court registry, appraisal costs and attorney fees. The Third Judicial District Court, Edmond W. Burke, J., denied the motion, and landowners appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that institution of condemnation proceedings constitutes compensable appropriation entitling landowner to interest dating from institution of proceeding, that landowners were entitled to interest, and that landowners were entitled to appraisal costs and attorney fees which were necessarily incurred in order to obtain just compensation for taking of land.

Reversed and remanded. Fitzgerald, J., did not participate.


  1. Martens v. Metzgar

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 12, 1974 524 P.2d 666


    Subdivider brought action against purchaser of lots to recover sum which allegedly represented purchaser's purported liability to pay costs of utilities which were installed. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage District, Edmond W. Burke, J., entered judgment in favor of defendant, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court,...



    Synopsis

    Subdivider brought action against purchaser of lots to recover sum which allegedly represented purchaser's purported liability to pay costs of utilities which were installed. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage District, Edmond W. Burke, J., entered judgment in favor of defendant, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that plaintiff failed to establish requisite elements to recover under an implied-in-fact contract theory, but that ruling that plaintiff was not entitled to use realtor's deposition was erroneous, and case would be remanded for limited purpose of taking realtor's testimony so far as the same was relevant to resolution of quasi-contract issue.

    Affirmed in part, and reversed in part.

    Erwin and Fitzgerald, JJ., did not participate.


  2. University of Alaska v. Modern Const., Inc.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 31, 1974 522 P.2d 1132


    Proceeding on motions by university to vacate arbitrators' award to prime contractor under contract for construction of building on university and for clarification of award. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Warren W. Taylor, J., ruled that it had no authority to order aggregation of award, denied motion to vacate and...

    Synopsis

    Proceeding on motions by university to vacate arbitrators' award to prime contractor under contract for construction of building on university and for clarification of award. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Warren W. Taylor, J., ruled that it had no authority to order aggregation of award, denied motion to vacate and confirmed award, and university appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that superior court had statutory authority to compel arbitrators to clarify award, that arbitrators had power to interpret contract, that arbitrators' dermination that contractor's claims against university for impach damages due to delays were arbitrable was not based on an unreasonable interpretation of contract, that presumption did not arise that award was based in part on unverified claims of subcontractors who were not parties to construction contract, that arbitrators' acceptance into evidence of claims of such subcontractors was not reversible error and that arbitrators could determine merits of claims under their own notions of fairness without considering legal precedent of issues involved.

    Judgment affirmed.


  3. Mobil Oil Corp. v. Local Boundary Commission

Supreme Court of Alaska. January 16, 1974 518 P.2d 92


Corporations and individuals holding surface leases and owners of interests in oil and gas wells and other property in the area of Prudhoe Bay petitioned for declaratory judgment against local boundary commission, the lieutenant governor and state holding incorporation of North Slope Borough invalid. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District,...

Synopsis

Corporations and individuals holding surface leases and owners of interests in oil and gas wells and other property in the area of Prudhoe Bay petitioned for declaratory judgment against local boundary commission, the lieutenant governor and state holding incorporation of North Slope Borough invalid.


The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Eben H. Lewis, J., upheld acceptance of the petition for incorporation and plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that the geography standard was satisfied even though borough boundaries encompassed naval petroleum reserve No. 4, in view of the reserves importance to the subsistent life style of area residents; that the availability of travel by charter air craft and surface transportation limited to dog teams and snow machines satisfied the transportation requirements; that inclusion of plaintiffs' property at Prudhoe Bay within the borough did not deny substantive due process; that local boundary commission was not required to submit the incorporation petition to the legislature; and that award of $20,000 attorney fees to the prevailing parties was not improper inasmuch as Superior Court could have concluded that plaintiffs were acting in their private interests and not in behalf of the public.

Affirmed.

Boochever, J., did not participate.


116. Scott v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. March 01, 1974 519 P.2d 774


The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Ralph E. Moody, J., issued a pretrial discovery order which required accused to disclose certain information, and petition for review was granted. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that requiring accused to disclose names and addresses of witnesses, statements of witnesses, and evidence...

Synopsis

The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Ralph E. Moody, J., issued a pretrial discovery order which required accused to disclose certain information, and petition for review was granted. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that requiring accused to disclose names and addresses of witnesses, statements of witnesses, and evidence relating to alibi defense violated accused's privilege against self-incrimination under the State Constitution, but that requiring accused to give notice of alibi defense was proper.

Vacated and remanded.


  1. Ficke v. Alaska Airlines, Inc.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 12, 1974 524 P.2d 271


    Action by airline and its subsidiary for specific performance of contract for sale of resort property. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Ralph E. Moody, J., granted specific performance and vendor appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that, generally, evidence sustained findings adverse to vendor and favorable to...

    Synopsis

    Action by airline and its subsidiary for specific performance of contract for sale of resort property. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Ralph E. Moody, J., granted specific performance and vendor appealed. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that, generally, evidence sustained findings adverse to vendor and favorable to purchasers, including finding that provision that deposit might be retained by vendor as advance rent should prior lease be reinstated was a penalty and that, accordingly, vendor's retention of deposit operated to estop vendor from relying on purchasers' delay in


    performance. Affirmed.

    Connor, Fitzgerald and Boochever, JJ., did not participate.


  2. Morrison-Knudsen Co., Inc. v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. March 11, 1974 519 P.2d 834 1974 WL 448986


Action against the state to recover additional compensation arising out of a contract. From a judgment of the Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Thomas B. Stewart, J., the plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that the state was under no duty to reveal information it had received from other bidders bearing on...

Synopsis

Action against the state to recover additional compensation arising out of a contract. From a judgment of the Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Thomas B. Stewart, J., the plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that the state was under no duty to reveal information it had received from other bidders bearing on feasibility of hydraulic dredging at construction site; that the state was not guilty of any misrepresentations in contract documents; and that the award to the state of attorney fees in amount of $22,633.91 was not an abuse of discretion.

Affirmed.

Fitzgerald, J., did not participate, and Boochever, J., dissented and filed opinion in which Erwin, J., joined.


119. Cooksey v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. July 19, 1974 524 P.2d 1251


Defendant entered plea of nolo contendere before the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Peter

J. Kalamarides, J., to charge of assault with a dangerous weapon, and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that appeal would be entertained since integral part of plea was stipulation that defendant retained right to appeal speedy...

Synopsis

Defendant entered plea of nolo contendere before the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Peter J. Kalamarides, J., to charge of assault with a dangerous weapon, and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that appeal would be entertained since integral part of plea was stipulation that defendant retained right to appeal speedy trial issue and such issue had been fully litigated at pretrial hearing on motion to dismiss, that a defendant's waiver of speedy trial right may extend a period of exclusion beyond that provided by statute but it cannot shorten such excluded periods, that four-month speedy trial period began running as of date of arrest, that presumption of court's receipt of psychiatric report was rebutted and that 16-day delay between receipt of report by the district attorney and by the superior court was not to be included in computing speedy trial period since public defender has requested delay in trial date so as to conduct psychiatric evaluation and had also received copy of report on same day as the district attorney.

Affirmed.

Erwin, J., concurred and filed opinion.



120. Redman v. Department of Ed.

Supreme Court of Alaska. March 08, 1974 519 P.2d 760


Tenured school teacher, who was not reemployed at end of 1969-1970 school year, brought action seeking damages. Determination that teacher was tenured and had been improperly dismissed was affirmed, 491 P.2d 157. In a subsequent trial on the damage issue, the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Warren W. Taylor, J., awarded teacher...

Synopsis

Tenured school teacher, who was not reemployed at end of 1969-1970 school year, brought action seeking damages. Determination that teacher was tenured and had been improperly dismissed was affirmed, 491 P.2d 157. In a subsequent trial on the damage issue, the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Warren W. Taylor, J., awarded teacher approximately $17,000, and cross appeals were taken. The Supreme Court, Erwin, J., held that statute providing that absent agreement on a new contract the prior contract continues where a teacher has not been given timely notice of nonretention does not automatically continue a teacher's contract of employment for the following school year, that a teacher who has not been given proper notice of nonretention may enforce her statutory right to be given a new contract and may then sue for breach of that contract but cannot base an action for damages on a prior contract that has expired, that teacher was required to mitigate damages, that teacher was not required to accept alternate employment as a school social worker if acceptance would result in compromising her claims to reinstatement in her former position and damages for wrongful dismissal, that teacher was not obligated to return to work if her reemployment was conditional on accepting a contract to which she did not agree, that amounts which teacher earned during summer months by working for department of highways was not required to be deducted in mitigation, that claims not raised in original or amended complaints could not properly be considered in awarding damages and that teacher was entitled to attorneys' fees.

Affirmed in part and reversed in part and remanded. Connor and Boochever, JJ., not participating.


121. Boucher v. Engstrom

Supreme Court of Alaska. November 15, 1974 528 P.2d 456 1974 WL 451941


Appeal by Lieutenant Governor and state from judgment of the Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Victor D. Carlson, J., enjoining placement by primary ballot of an initiative proposal to relocate the state capital to a location other than Anchorage or Fairbanks. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that action was not barred by...

Synopsis

Appeal by Lieutenant Governor and state from judgment of the Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Victor D. Carlson, J., enjoining placement by primary ballot of an initiative proposal to relocate the state capital to a location other than Anchorage or Fairbanks. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that action was not barred by 30-day period specified as time to bring an action to review determination of lieutenant governor regarding an initiative where notice was only given to the sponsors, that action was not prematurely brought, that after the lieutenant governor determines that


an initiative is not in conflict with constitutional provision prohibiting use of an initiative to enact local or special legislation the initiative can be challenged by anyone, and that exclusion of Anchorage and Fairbanks was not arbitrary and thus did not render the initiative local or special legislation.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part. Boochever, J., did not participate.


122. Torres v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. March 15, 1974 519 P.2d 788


Defendant was convicted before the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Gerald J. VanHoomissen, J., of lewd and lascivious conduct upon the person of an eight-year-old girl and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that defendant's right not to be placed twice in jeopardy was not violated because he was retried...

Synopsis

Defendant was convicted before the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Gerald J. VanHoomissen, J., of lewd and lascivious conduct upon the person of an eight-year-old girl and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that defendant's right not to be placed twice in jeopardy was not violated because he was retried following a mistrial, that prosecutrix's mother's testimony concerning prosecutrix's statement approximately ten minutes following the incident was admissible under the spontaneous exclamation exception to the hearsay rule, that the admission of testimony concerning physical evidence negligently destroyed by the police was not plain error and that the negligent destruction of the physical evidence did not constitute a denial of due process.

Affirmed.


123. McCracken v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. April 08, 1974 521 P.2d 499


By judgment of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Ralph E. Moody, J., the defendant was convicted on two counts of shooting with intent to kill and two counts of use of a firearm during assault and was sentenced on all four counts and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that the allegedly improper postindictment...

Synopsis

By judgment of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Ralph E. Moody, J., the defendant was convicted on two counts of shooting with intent to kill and two counts of use of a firearm during assault and was sentenced on all four counts and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that the allegedly improper postindictment identification of defendant at parole revocation hearing by victims of shooting did not require exclusion of victim's in-court identification of defendant from an independent source, but that the sentencing of the defendant on counts charging use of firearm during assault violated prohibition against double jeopardy.

Affirmed and remanded for modification of sentences. Erwin and Fitzgerald, JJ., did not participate.

See also Alaska, 518 P.2d 85.


124. Stafford v. Westchester Fire Ins. Co. of New York, Inc.

Supreme Court of Alaska. September 13, 1974 526 P.2d 37


Employer's workmen's compensation carrier intervened in action by injured employee against manufacturer of shredder which caused injury to the employee and attempted to obtain judgment for the amount of workmen's compensation it had paid to the employee. The employee settled his suit against the manufacturer and answered the carrier's complaint by...

Synopsis

Employer's workmen's compensation carrier intervened in action by injured employee against manufacturer of shredder which caused injury to the employee and attempted to obtain judgment for the amount of workmen's compensation it had paid to the employee. The employee settled his suit against the manufacturer and answered the carrier's complaint by alleging that the carrier willfully and maliciously withheld compensation benefits resulting in infliction of mental distress. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage District, James K. Singleton, J., granted the carrier's motion for summary judgment. The employee appealed and the carrier cross-appealed from the denial of attorney fees. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that statute requiring reimbursement of total amounts paid by compensation carrier when damages are recovered by employee from third party does not allow for pro rata deduction of attorney fees, that intentional misconduct by an employer or its compensation carrier will destroy its immunity from suit for delay in making compensation payments, and that the carrier should have been awarded attorney fees to the extent that it prevailed on the reimbursement issue.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

Erwin, J., filed an opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part and in which Connor, J., joined. Boochever, J., did not participate.


125. Port Valdez Co., Inc. v. City of Valdez

Supreme Court of Alaska. May 20, 1974 522 P.2d 1147


An annexation by a city was challenged but upheld by the State of Alaska Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Ralph E. Moody, J. The challenging corporation appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that under evidence, the city exercised sufficient municipal powers under the annexation order in the annexed area to satisfy the...

Synopsis

An annexation by a city was challenged but upheld by the State of Alaska Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Ralph E. Moody, J. The challenging corporation appealed. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that under evidence, the city exercised sufficient municipal powers under the annexation order in the annexed area to satisfy the doctrine of de facto municipal incorporation.

Affirmed.

Erwin, J., did not participate.


126. Koehler v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. February 22, 1974 519 P.2d 442



Prosecution for assault with a dangerous weapon and assault with intent to commit rape. The first trial resulted in declaration of a mistrial on ground of a hung jury. After the case was set for retrial defendant moved to dismiss the indictment on ground that reprosecution would unconstitutionally place him twice in jeopardy for the same offense...

Synopsis

Prosecution for assault with a dangerous weapon and assault with intent to commit rape. The first trial resulted in declaration of a mistrial on ground of a hung jury. After the case was set for retrial defendant moved to dismiss the indictment on ground that reprosecution would unconstitutionally place him twice in jeopardy for the same offense because no manifest necessity justified declaration of mistrial. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, James K. Singleton, J., denied the motion. On petition for review, the Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, C. J., held that defendant had not been voluntarily absent from proceedings culminating in discharge of the jury so as to constitute a waiver of his right to be present, that such proceedings constituted a stage of the trial at which defendant was entitled to be present, that defendant's substantial rights were affected and that principle of double jeopardy barred retrial since no manifest necessity existed for discharge of the jury.

Reversed.

Erwin, J., dissented and filed opinion.


127. Galauska v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. October 25, 1974 527 P.2d 459


Defendant was convicted in the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Edward V. Davis, J., of manslaughter, and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that the indictment was not fatally flawed by presentation of hearsay evidence to the grand jury; that the evidence was sufficient to sustain the conviction; that the...

Synopsis

Defendant was convicted in the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Edward V. Davis, J., of manslaughter, and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that the indictment was not fatally flawed by presentation of hearsay evidence to the grand jury; that the evidence was sufficient to sustain the conviction; that the trial court did not err in limiting evidence as to the prosecution's chief witness' violent character to general reputation evidence, and excluding evidence of particular assaults perpetrated by witness; and that the trial court did not err in refusing to instruct the jury that said witness' testimony was to be viewed as that of an accomplice.

Affirmed.

Boochever, J., dissented and filed opinion. Connor, J., did not participate.


128. Groh v. Egan

Supreme Court of Alaska. September 13, 1974 526 P.2d 863


Action was brought challenging validity of plan for reapportionment of the Alaska legislature. The



Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage District, James K. Singleton, J., dismissed and appeal was taken. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that use of 1970 census data as basis for reapportionment plan adopted in 1973 was not...

Synopsis

Action was brought challenging validity of plan for reapportionment of the Alaska legislature. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage District, James K. Singleton, J., dismissed and appeal was taken. The Supreme Court, Boochever, J., held that use of 1970 census data as basis for reapportionment plan adopted in 1973 was not unreasonable; that formula used to exclude transient military personnel from data base did not discriminate against military personnel; that State failed to demonstrate that individual variances from the mean in certain districts were based on legitimate considerations incident to the implementation of a rational state policy; that division of Greater Anchorage area into six election districts was not improper; and that it was within governor's discretionary authority to require mid-term elections in Greater Anchorage area following adoption of the plan, Fitzgerald, J., concurred in part, dissented in part and filed opinion.

Affirmed in part and reversed in part. Erwin, J., dissented and filed opinion.


129. Martin v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. January 02, 1974 517 P.2d 1389 75 A.L.R.3d 941


Proceedings on consolidated appeals from orders of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, C. J. Occhipinti, J., denying defendants' request for release on bail. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that although it could well be argued that issues arising on applications for bail had been mooted by either a subsequent dismissal,...

Synopsis

Proceedings on consolidated appeals from orders of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, C. J. Occhipinti, J., denying defendants' request for release on bail. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that although it could well be argued that issues arising on applications for bail had been mooted by either a subsequent dismissal, a conviction or a revocation of probation, matters would be decided on the merits since they involved important recurring issues of law, that the Constitution guarantees an accused, except an accused charged with a capital offense, the right to be released on bail, that 1967 amendment to Bail Reform Act did not permit detention of persons without bail, that the legislature cannot infringe the constitutional right to bail and that Constitution does not guarantee right to bail prior to probation revocation hearing but that bail should not usually be denied in such case.

Order accordingly.


1. State, Dept. of Commerce, Community & Economic Development v. Alyeska Pipeline Service Co.

Supreme Court of Alaska. January 21, 2011 Not Reported in P.3d 2011 WL 193592


INSURANCE - Industry Regulation. Oil pipeline operator's owner-controlled insurance program (OCIP) was not prohibited by statute limiting construction OCIPs to major construction projects.



2. Stone v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. April 22, 2011 Not Reported in P.3d 2011 WL 1519382


CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Counsel. Defendant had right to first-tier appellate review of sentence for which defendant had Sixth Amendment right to counsel.



3. David S. v. State, Dept. of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

Supreme Court of Alaska. December 16, 2011 Not Reported in P.3d 2011 WL 6347722


NATIVE AMERICANS - Child Welfare. Father's mother was not an Indian custodian pursuant to the Indian Child Welfare Act.



4. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co. v. Houle

Supreme Court of Alaska. August 26, 2011 258 P.3d 833 2011 WL 4012417


INSURANCE - Automobile. Individual family members were not in accident so as to trigger per-person UIM coverage for emotional distress claims.

Synopsis

Editor's Note: The opinion of the Supreme Court of Alaska, in State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co. v. Houle, published in the advance sheet at this citation, 258 P.3d 833, was withdrawn from the bound volume because rehearing is pending.


  1. In re Shea

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 18, 2011 251 P.3d 357 2011 WL 1966958


    The Disciplinary Board of the Alaska Bar Association, based on its adoption of an area hearing committee's findings of fact and conclusions of law and a final report of recommended sanctions, recommended that attorney Wevley William Shea be suspended from the practice of law for 25



    months and be subject to certain conditions for reinstatement....


  2. Gray v. Gray

    Supreme Court of Alaska. December 07, 2011 Not Reported in P.3d 2011 WL 6116482


    FAMILY LAW - Judgment. Allegedly wrong dates on settlement agreement signatures did not entitle ex-husband to relief from divorce decree.

    Synopsis

    Background: Divorce action was brought. The Superior Court entered judgment. Husband moved for relief from judgment. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Randy M. Olsen, J., denied relief. Husband appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. allegedly erroneous dates on the parties' respective signature lines and/or the date the settlement agreement was notarized did not entitle ex-husband to relief from divorce decree;

    2. any period tolling ex-husband's time to move for relief from judgment of divorce due to incompetence from alcoholism began to run when ex-husband was no longer incompetent; and

    3. motion for relief from judgment of divorce was not timely made. Affirmed.


  3. Schug v. Josephson

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 18, 2011 Not Reported in P.3d 2011 WL 1955055


    1. Franklin Schug claimed he was injured during a flight from Alaska to Arizona while in the custody of the State of Alaska, Department of Corrections. Schug retained attorney Joe P. Josephson to represent him and sued the State. After trial a jury returned a verdict in the State's favor. 2. Schug then sued Josephson pro se. In July 2008 Josephson...



  4. Provost v. Nevitt

    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 01, 2011 Not Reported in P.3d 2011 WL 2175984


    FAMILY LAW - Child Custody. Court's decision to modify custody before wife had opportunity to present her case violated her procedural due process rights.

    Synopsis

    Background: Husband brought custody modification action. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Mark Rindner, J., granted husband custody, and wife appealed.

    Holding: The Supreme Court held that trial court's decision to modify custody before wife had an opportunity to present her case violated her procedural due process rights.

    Reversed and remanded.


  5. Tillmon v. Tillmon

    Supreme Court of Alaska. April 27, 2011 Not Reported in P.3d 2011 WL 1599732


    1. This is the second appeal arising from Susan and Clifton Tillmon's divorce proceedings. The first appeal was resolved in an opinion reported at 189 P.3d 1022 (Tillmon I ). Both before and after this court resolved the issues raised in Tillmon I, the superior court faced a steady stream of disputes about child custody and support. These disputes...



  6. Olson v. State, Dept. of Natural Resources

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 20, 2011 Not Reported in P.3d 2011 WL 2937228


    1. On January 26, 2009, Dana Olson sent a four-page handwritten document titled Request and/or Appeal to the Alaska Department of Natural Resources (DNR) Commissioner, Thomas Irwin. The document did not identify any decision made by DNR that Olson wished to appeal. 2. On February 4, 2009, Irwin responded to Olson with a letter...



  7. Alaska Spine Institute Surgery Center, LLC v. State, Dept. of Health & Social Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. October 28, 2011 266 P.3d 1043 2011 WL 5116410


    LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Potential competitor's appeal of denial of hearing to contest decision to issue certificate of need was moot.

    Synopsis

    Background: Potential competitor appealed State's decision to deny evidentiary hearing to dispute issuance of certificate of need (CON) to ambulatory surgery center. The Superior Court granted surgery center's and State's motion to dismiss. Potential competitor appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. potential competitor's appeal was moot, and

    2. public interest exception to mootness doctrine did not apply. Appeal dismissed as moot.


  8. Varilek v. Burke

    Supreme Court of Alaska. April 13, 2011 Not Reported in P.3d 2011 WL 1441854


    TAXATION - Real Property. Board of Equalization had reasonable basis to affirm valuation of deceased taxpayer's real property as conducted by municipality's assessor.

    Synopsis

    Background: Personal representative of taxpayer's estate sought judicial review of decision by city's Board of Equalization that upheld assessor's valuation of real property, for purposes of property tax. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Craig Stowers, J., affirmed, and personal representative appealed.


    [Holding:] The Supreme Court adopted the opinion of the Superior Court, and held that Board of Equalization had reasonable basis to affirm valuation of deceased taxpayer's real property as conducted by municipality's assessor.

    Affirmed.


  9. Taylor v. Moutrie-Pelham

Supreme Court of Alaska. February 11, 2011 246 P.3d 927 2011 WL 488903


REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Court did not abuse its discretion in declining to name either landlord or tenant as prevailing party for attorney fee purposes,

Synopsis

Background: Tenant filed suit against landlord, asserting breach of lease agreement and a claim for conversion in connection with a down payment on a home he had given to landlord. Landlord filed counterclaim for breach of lease agreement. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Sen K. Tan, J., ruled that landlord converted $23,000 received from tenant, but that tenant owed

$10,574 in damages to landlord for breach of lease agreement, and made no award of attorney fees. Tenant appealed.

[Holding:] The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that trial court did not abuse its discretion in declining to name either landlord or tenant as the prevailing party, for attorney fee purposes.

Affirmed.


14. Roberson v. Southwood Manor Associates, LLC

Supreme Court of Alaska. April 08, 2011 249 P.3d 1059 2011 WL 1330800


REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. UTPA does not apply to residential leases.

Synopsis

Background: Mobile home park owner brought action against tenant for back rent and late charges, and tenant filed class action counterclaims, asserting in part that late charges violated Alaska's Unfair Trade Practices and Consumer Protection Act (UTPA). The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Patrick J. McKay, J., granted owner's motion to dismiss UTPA counterclaim, and tenant appealed.

[Holding:] The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that UTPA does not apply to residential leases. Affirmed.


  1. Hora v. Smith

    Supreme Court of Alaska. December 07, 2011 Not Reported in P.3d 2011 WL 6116477


    FAMILY LAW - Judgment. The doctrine of res judicata barred the trial court from considering former husband's claim for reimbursement of medical expenses.

    Synopsis


    Background: After the parties divorced, former wife filed a second motion against former husband seeking reimbursement of the children's medical expenses, and former husband filed a motion seeking reimbursement of the children's medical expenses. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Stephanie E. Joannides, J., granted former wife's motion and granted former husband's motion. Former wife appealed.

    Holding: The Supreme Court held that the doctrine of res judicata barred the trial court from considering former husband's claim for reimbursement of the children's medical expenses. Reversed and remanded.


  2. Bagby v. Bagby

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 13, 2011 250 P.3d 1127 2011 WL 1814244


    FAMILY LAW - Child Custody. Father's relocation out of state was substantial change in circumstances requiring best interests hearing as to modification.

    Synopsis

    Background: Mother filed motion to modify child custody after father, who had been awarded primary physical custody of child upon divorce, relocated with the child out of state. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Sitka, David V. George, J., denied motion. Mother appealed.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Christen, J., held that father's relocation with child out of state was a substantial change in circumstances warranting determination of whether modification of child custody served child's best interests.

    Reversed and remanded for hearing.


  3. Henash v. Fairbanks North Star Borough

    Supreme Court of Alaska. November 10, 2011 265 P.3d 302 2011 WL 5428967


    TAXATION - Real Property. Wedding receptions did not disqualify taxpayer's use of tribal hall as a charitable use.

    Synopsis

    Background: Taxpayer, a Native nonprofit corporation that applied to borough assessor for charitable-purpose tax exemptions on several of its properties, appealed decision of the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Raymond Funk, Judge pro tem, affirming denial as to four properties, and ordering taxpayer to pay borough $38,416 in attorney fees.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carpeneti, C.J., held that:

    1. tribal hall met exclusive use requirement of charitable-purpose tax exemption statute, and

    2. taxpayer was entitled to charitable-purpose tax exemptions for properties it rented to other nonprofit organizations.

    Reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.


  4. State, Dept. of Commerce, Community & Economic Development, Div. of Ins.

    v. Alyeska Pipeline Service Co.


    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 10, 2011 262 P.3d 593 2011 WL 2274221


    INSURANCE - Industry Regulation. Oil pipeline operator's owner-controlled insurance program (OCIP) was not prohibited by statute limiting construction OCIPs to major construction projects.

    Synopsis

    Background: Oil pipeline operator appealed decision of the Department of Commerce, Division of Insurance, determining that owner-controlled insurance program (OCIP) issued to oil pipeline operator was prohibited by statute providing that owner-controlled insurance programs shall be allowed only for major construction projects. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Peter A. Michalski, J., reversed, and Department appealed.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that statute did not apply to operator's OCIP. Affirmed.

    Opinion, 2011 WL 193592, superseded.


  5. Pebble Ltd. Partnership ex rel. Pebble Mines Corp. v. Lake and Peninsula Borough

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 17, 2011 262 P.3d 598 2011 WL 3628864


    On consideration of Pebble Limited Partnership's Emergency Petition for Review filed on August 1, 2011, and responses filed by Lake and Peninsula Borough, George Jacko and Jackie Hobson, Sr., and amici curiae Nunamta Aulukestai and the State of Alaska, It is Ordered: The Petition for Review is Denied. Entered by direction of the court. Clerk of the...



  6. Sutliff v. Sutliff

    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 22, 2011 Not Reported in P.3d 2011 WL 2505559


    FAMILY LAW - Settlements. Settlement agreement was reached between spouses as to how marital assets and personal property were to be divided.

    Synopsis

    Background: Wife filed for divorce from husband. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, John Suddock, J., entered divorce decree that incorporated terms of parties' property settlement agreement. Wife appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. settlement agreement was reached between parties as to how marital assets and personal property were to be divided;

    2. wife was entitled to a $300,000 equalization payment from husband pursuant to terms of their settlement agreement, not an equal share of parties' marital assets in addition to the $300,000 payment; and
