    3. trial court did not abuse its discretion in ordering sale of certain financial assets of the parties, or in giving husband a nominal monthly payment and survivorship right from wife's state retirement account. Affirmed and remanded.


  7. Latham v. Palin

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 18, 2011 251 P.3d 341 2011 WL 923187


    CIVIL RIGHTS - Prisons. Prisoner was collaterally estopped from bringing claim for damages based on modification of jurisdiction to hear sentencing appeals.

    Synopsis

    Background: Former prisoner brought third lawsuit relating to legislation that modified the jurisdiction of the Court of Appeals to hear excessive sentence appeals. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Sharon L. Gleason, J., dismissed the action, and prisoner appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Fabe, J., held that:

    1. issue in prior actions regarding injury was identical to issue in current action, as required for collateral estoppel to apply, and

    2. discretionary immunity barred claims against Governor and Attorney General for declaratory judgment.

    Affirmed.

    See also 2006 WL 1667661.


  8. McCrary v. Ivanof Bay Village

    Supreme Court of Alaska. December 09, 2011 265 P.3d 337 2011 WL 6116492


    NATIVE AMERICANS - Alaska Natives. Alaska Native village was federally recognized Indian tribe entitled to sovereign immunity in contract action.

    Synopsis

    Background: Developer brought action against Indian tribe alleging breaches of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing arising out of development contracts. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Peter A. Michalski, J., dismissed the suit based on sovereign immunity. Developer appealed.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that tribe was federally recognized tribe entitled to sovereign immunity.

    Affirmed.


  9. Thomas v. Thomas

    Supreme Court of Alaska. April 06, 2011 Not Reported in P.3d 2011 WL 1330803


    FAMILY LAW - Settlements. Marital property settlement agreement was entered into knowingly and voluntarily by husband in divorce proceeding.

    Synopsis

    Background: Wife filed a complaint for divorce. Following remand from the Supreme Court, 171 P.3d 98, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Peter A. Michalski, J., adopted parties' settlement as amended judgment and decree. Husband filed motion to set aside judgment, which was denied. Husband appealed.

    Holding: The Supreme Court held that settlement agreement was entered into voluntarily and


    knowingly by husband. Affirmed.


  10. Patrick C. v. State, Dept. of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 18, 2011 Not Reported in P.3d 2011 WL 1954795


    FAMILY LAW - Child Protection. Clear and convincing evidence supported conclusion that father failed to remedy conduct or conditions that placed children at risk.

    Synopsis

    Background: Department of Health and Social Services filed petition seeking termination of father's parental rights to children. The Superior Court Third Judicial District, Palmer, Eric Smith, J., granted petition. Father appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. clear and convincing evidence supported conclusion that Department made reasonable efforts to provide family support services to father to enable children's safe return to him, and

    2. clear and convincing evidence supported conclusion that father failed to remedy the conduct or conditions that placed his children at risk.

    Affirmed.


  11. Larson v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. June 10, 2011 254 P.3d 1073 2011 WL 2274442


LITIGATION - Declaratory Judgment. Res judicata barred declaratory judgment claim challenging acts of appellate court in reviewing denial of postconviction relief.

Synopsis

Background: Following affirmance, 2000 WL 19199, of his convictions on two counts of first-degree murder and one count of burglary, defendant sought postconviction relief, relying on affidavits from jurors and alternate jurors alleging juror misconduct. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Niesje J. Steinkruger, J., dismissed petition. Defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, 79 P.3d 650, Mannheimer, J., affirmed, and the Supreme Court denied defendant's petition for hearing.

Later, defendant filed pro se civil complaint against state based on allegations that Court of Appeals violated its duties on defendant's appeal from postconviction ruling. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Frank A. Pfiffner, J. granted state's motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim. Defendant appealed.

Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

  1. act of Court of Appeals, in assuming that evidence rule governing questioning of jurors concerning possible juror misconduct also governed testimony or affidavits of alternate jurors, was judicial in nature, such that Court of Appeals had absolute judicial immunity on present claim;

  2. present claim was barred by res judicata; and

  3. claim was dismissable for lack of an actual dispute between parties, to the extent that defendant sought a determination for use in some future unspecified action.

Affirmed.


26. Olson v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. September 23, 2011 260 P.3d 1056 2011 WL 4435849


CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Driving While Intoxicated. Defendant had burden of showing prejudice from incorrect information provided about penalties for chemical-test refusal.

Synopsis

Background: Defendant entered a Cooksey plea in the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Michael L. Wolverton, J., to class C felony refusal to submit to a chemical test and other offenses. He appealed. The Court of Appeals affirmed, 2006 WL 306907. Defendant filed a petition for hearing, which the Supreme Court granted.

Holdings: The Supreme Court, Christen, J., held that:

  1. incorrect information provided in an implied-consent form about the penalties for defendant's refusal to submit to a chemical test raised due process concerns;

  2. as a matter of first impression, defendant had the burden of showing that he was prejudiced by the incorrect information; and

  3. remand was appropriate to allow defendant an opportunity to show prejudice. Reversed and remanded.


  1. Sarah G. v. State, Dept. of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. December 02, 2011 264 P.3d 831 2011 WL 6004354


    FAMILY LAW - Child Protection. Children were children in need of aid based on conduct by mother that placed the children at substantial risk of mental injury.

    Synopsis

    Background: The Office of Children's Services (OCS) filed a petition for custody of mother's four children. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, Gregory Heath, J., found the children were children in need of aid. Mother appealed.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Carpeneti, C.J., held that evidence supported finding that mother's four children were children in need of aid based on conduct by mother that placed the children at substantial risk of mental injury as a result of exposure to conduct by a household member against another household member that was a crime.

    Affirmed.


    28. Marathon Oil Co. v. State, Dept. of Natural Resources

    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 10, 2011 254 P.3d 1078 2011 WL 2274215


    ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Oil and Gas. Department of Natural Resources' interpretation of statute governing contract pricing was reasonable and entitled to deference.

    Synopsis

    Background: Company that leased land from State for the purpose of producing natural gas appealed Department of Natural Resources' (DNR's) denial of its request for retroactive application of contract


    pricing. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, John Suddock, J., affirmed. Company appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Fabe, J., held that:

    1. reasonable basis standard of review applied to DNR's interpretation of statute governing contract pricing;

    2. DNR's interpretation of statute as permitting DNR to approve contract pricing only for future production was longstanding and reasonable, and thus Supreme Court would defer to it;

    3. DNR's interpretation of statute was a rule of internal agency procedure, and thus DNR was not required to promulgate its interpretation in a regulation; and

    4. company's due process rights were not violated. Affirmed.


    29. Varilek v. Burke

    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 10, 2011 254 P.3d 1068 2011 WL 2274300


    TAXATION - Real Property. Board of equalization did not lack reasonable basis for its valuation assessment of real property.

    Synopsis

    Background: Personal representative of deceased property owner's estate sought review of board of equalization's decision to uphold city's assessment of the value of the property, for taxation purposes, claiming it was overstated. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eric A. Aarseth, J., affirmed the Board's decision. Personal representative appealed.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Christen, J., held that the board of equalization did not lack reasonable basis for its valuation assessment.

    Affirmed.


    30. Nelson v. Municipality of Anchorage

    Supreme Court of Alaska. December 23, 2011 267 P.3d 636 2011 WL 6450910


    LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Municipality could be a project owner pursuant to the Workers' Compensation Act.

    Synopsis

    Background: Injured worker brought negligence action against municipality and contractor for injuries he sustained in fall through hole in municipal building floor. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Sen K. Tan, J., granted defendants summary judgment. Worker appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Christen, J., held that:

    1. municipality could be a project owner pursuant to the Workers' Compensation Act, and

    2. worker's claims were not ripe for adjudication. Affirmed and remanded.


    1. Holmes v. Wolf

      Supreme Court of Alaska. November 30, 2011 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2011 WL 6046407



      NATIVE AMERICANS - Alaska Natives. Directors of corporation were entitled to award of enhanced attorney fees.

      Synopsis

      Background: Shareholders brought action against members of an Alaska native corporation's board of directors for failure to hold annual shareholder meetings, failure to prepare and distribute annual shareholder reports, failure to obtain and send out annual audited financial reports, and failure to reasonably inquire into a mediated settlement agreement. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Sen K. Tan, J., entered judgment in favor of directors. Shareholders appealed. The Supreme Court, 243 P.3d 584, affirmed. Directors filed motion for enhanced attorney fees. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Sen K. Tan, J., found that directors were prevailing parties and awarded enhanced attorney fees. Shareholders appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

      1. for purposes of rule providing for award of attorney fees to prevailing parties in civil cases, directors were prevailing parties, and

      2. directors were entitled to award of enhanced attorney fees. Affirmed.


    2. Trask v. Ketchikan Gateway Borough

      Supreme Court of Alaska. June 17, 2011 253 P.3d 616 2011 WL 2437670


      CIVIL RIGHTS - Free Speech. Homeowner had interest-injury standing to bring 1983 claim against borough which sought removal of religious message on home's roof.

      Synopsis

      Background: Borough filed complaint seeking to enjoin homeowner from displaying religious message painted on the roof of her home. Homeowner filed counterclaim for relief under 1983. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Ketchikan, Trevor N. Stephens, J., entered judgment for homeowner on injunction claim, but dismissed homeowner's 1983 claim and awarded attorney's fees. Homeowner appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

      1. Homeowner had interest-injury standing;

      2. allegations were sufficient to state a 1983 claim; and

      3. homeowner was not required to allege any specific damages or injury. Reversed and remanded.


    3. Koeneman v. Boersma

      Supreme Court of Alaska. December 07, 2011 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2011 WL 6116480


      FAMILY LAW - Child Support. Father was not entitled to an income deduction or child support reimbursement for his claimed work-related childcare expenses

      Synopsis

      Background: Father sought a reduction in his child support obligation to mother Matter was referred to


      master. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Stephanie E. Joannides, J., ordered master to recalculate father's support obligation to account for the three oldest of parties' seven children attaining the age of majority during the calculation period, and, once master made this change, approved master's report. Father appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court of Alaska held that:

      1. master's method of determining father's income for one year over a three-year base was reasonable;

      2. master did not abuse his discretion by finding good cause to deny father reimbursement for children's medical expenses in calculating support;

      3. father was not entitled to an income deduction or child support reimbursement for his claimed work-related childcare expenses;

      4. father was not entitled to an income deduction for support purposes for truck depreciation and expenses allegedly related to his business;

      5. trial court's calculation of father's support obligation was properly based on child custody order, rather than on actual physical custody father exercised; and

      6. father failed to establish judicial bias on part of master or trial court. Affirmed.


    4. Stevens v. State, Alcoholic Beverage Control Bd.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. August 12, 2011 257 P.3d 1154 2011 WL 3558422


      GOVERNMENT - Liquor. Placing burden of persuasion on bar owner to retain liquor license in light of municipal protest did not violate due process.

      Synopsis

      Background: Bar owner, who had been convicted of violating borough noise and adult entertainment ordinances, appealed decision of Alcoholic Beverage Control Board (ABC Board) to deny owner's continued operation under his liquor license. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Sen K. Tan, J., affirmed. Owner appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

      1. borough's participation at every procedural level was sufficient to cure any deficiencies in authority of director to file protest, and

      2. placing burden of persuasion on owner to retain liquor license in light of municipal protest did not violate due process.

      Affirmed.


    5. Smith v. State, Dept. of Transp. and Public Facilities

      Supreme Court of Alaska. July 01, 2011 253 P.3d 1233 2011 WL 2610956


      LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Former employee failed to establish prima facie case of employment discrimination based on race.

      Synopsis

      Background: Former employee brought action against his former employer, the Department of Transportation and Public Facilities (DOTPF), arising out of termination of employment. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Frank A. Pfiffner, J., granted summary judgment in favor of


      DOTPF. Employee appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Fabe, J., held that:

      1. former employee failed to establish prima facie case of employment discrimination, and

      2. DOTPF did not violate implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing by terminating employment. Affirmed.


    6. Shaffer v. Bellows

    Supreme Court of Alaska. September 23, 2011 260 P.3d 1064 2011 WL 4435848


    REAL PROPERTY - Judgment. Issues of material fact precluded summary judgment on claim for fraudulent conveyance of island to grantor's sister as gift.

    Synopsis

    Background: Former joint owner of island brought action against grantor of island for fraudulent conveyance, breach of option agreement, and related claims arising out of grantor's conveyance of island to his sister as gift. The First Judicial District Superior Court, Sitka, David V. George, J., entered summary judgment in grantor's favor, and former owner appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carpeneti, C.J., held that:

    1. badges of fraud in claim for fraudulent conveyance include inadequate consideration, transfer in anticipation of pending suit, insolvency of transferor, failure to record, transfer encompasses substantially all transferor's property, transferor retains possession of transferred premises, transfer completely depletes transferor's assets, and relationship of parties, abrogating Asher v. Alkan Shelter, LLC, 212 P.3d 772;

    2. fact issue remained whether grantor conveyed island to his sister for inadequate consideration, precluding summary judgment on fraudulent conveyance claim;

    3. fact issue remained whether transfer of island to sister as gift was undertaken while grantor was in or approaching insolvency;

    4. fact issue remained whether grantor retained possession of island following conveyance of island as gift; and

    5. grantor's election to sell island was condition precedent to former owner's option to purchase island. Affirmed in part; reversed in part; remanded.


    37. State, Dept. of Corrections v. Hendricks-Pearce

    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 24, 2011 254 P.3d 1088 2011 WL 2505560


    CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Prisons. Prisoner, as used in statute on responsibility for costs of medical care provided to prisoner, includes former prisoner.

    Synopsis

    Background: The state filed an action for declaratory judgment against former prisoner who had won a medical-malpractice judgment against the state around the time of his release from custody, seeking a declaration that it was entitled to reimbursement of the cost of outside medical care provided to former prisoner for conditions unrelated to the malpractice claim. The state moved for summary judgment, and former prisoner filed a cross motion for summary judgment. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Craig F. Stowers, J., denied the state's motion and granted former prisoner's cross motion. The state appealed.


    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

    1. prisoner, as used in the statute providing that liability for payment of the costs of medical care provided to a prisoner is the responsibility of the prisoner and, if applicable, certain funding sources, includes a former prisoner, but

    2. the Supreme Court would remand to trial court a question of whether the statute allowed the state to seek reimbursement of the cost of the outside medical care provided to former prisoner, who did not have such funding sources.

    Reversed, vacated, and remanded.


    1. Iris R. v. State, Dept. of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

      Supreme Court of Alaska. October 05, 2011 Not Reported in P.3d 2011 WL 4715212


      NATIVE AMERICANS - Child Welfare. Evidence supported termination of parental rights of mother of Indian children.

      Synopsis

      Background: Office of Children's Services (OCS) petitioned for a termination of parental rights of mother of Indian children within the meaning of the Indian Child Welfare Act. The First Judicial District Superior Court, Juneau, Patricia A. Collins, J., entered judgment terminating mother's parental rights. Mother appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

      1. evidence supported finding that OCS made reasonable and active efforts to prevent the break up of the family, and

      2. evidence supported finding that return of the children to mother's care would likely result in serious damage to the children.

      Affirmed.


    2. McAlpine v. Pacarro

      Supreme Court of Alaska. October 21, 2011 262 P.3d 622 2011 WL 5009381


      FAMILY LAW - Child Custody. Mother's motion to modify child custody was not barred by res judicata or the finality principle.

      Synopsis

      Background: Mother sought to modify child custody and requested an evidentiary hearing on her motion. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eric A. Aarseth, J., denied mother's motion without a hearing, finding mother barred by res judicata and collateral estoppel from attempting to relitigate legal and factual matters that existed prior to a previous child-custody hearing. Mother appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

      1. mother's motion to modify child custody was not barred by res judicata or the finality principle, and

      2. prior incidents of domestic violence by father were sufficiently serious to provide a prima facie case for modification, and therefore a hearing was required on mother's motion to modify child custody. Remanded.


    3. Lot 04B & 5C Block 83 Townsite v. Fairbanks North Star Borough

    Supreme Court of Alaska. October 07, 2011 261 P.3d 422 2011 WL 4715208


    TAXATION - Liens. Borough correctly included property owner on foreclosure list for certain tax year.

    Synopsis

    Background: Property owner appealed from judgment of the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Paul R. Lyle, J., foreclosing a borough property tax lien.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

    1. borough correctly included property owner on foreclosure list for certain tax year even though owner owed no new taxes in year prior to certain tax year, and

    2. trial court did not abuse its discretion in declining to impose sanctions against borough attorney. Affirmed.


    41. Sheffield v. Sheffield

    Supreme Court of Alaska. December 09, 2011 265 P.3d 332 2011 WL 6116493


    FAMILY LAW - Child Custody. Statutory child custody modification factors favored father's request to relocate with children out of state.

    Synopsis

    Background: Father filed post-dissolution motion to modify physical custody of children, seeking permission to relocate with children to state of Virginia. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Sharon Gleason, J., granted motion. Mother appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Fabe, J., held that:

    1. child's stated preference to relocate with father was reliable such that trial court could afford it significant weight when ruling on father's post-dissolution motion to modify custody, and

    2. trial court adequately considered geographic stability as a factor prior to granting father's motion. Affirmed.


    42. Cox v. Haines

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 13, 2011 Not Reported in P.3d 2011 WL 2750724


    FAMILY LAW - Marital Property. Court did not clearly err in finding the rental value of the marital residence to be $850 per month.

    Synopsis

    Background: Wife filed for divorce. After trial, the Superior Court ordered wife to transfer ownership of the marital residence to husband and husband was ordered to pay wife for her share of the value of the home. Wife appealed. The Supreme Court, 182 P.3d 1140, affirmed in part and remanded. On remand, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Homer, Margaret L. Murphy, Judge pro tem, recalculated wife's share of the residence's value, and husband appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. husband's claim that superior court erred in finding that the parties agreed that wife's annuity was


      her separate property was waived for purposes of appeal; and

    2. superior court did not clearly err in finding the rental value of the marital residence to be $850 per month.

    Affirmed.


    43. Pfeifer v. State, Dept. of Health & Social Services, Div. of Public Assistance

    Supreme Court of Alaska. September 23, 2011 260 P.3d 1072 2011 WL 4435846


    HEALTH - Medical Assistance. Retroactive application of Medicaid statute providing a penalty period of ineligibility for certain asset transfers was not an unlawful taking.

    Synopsis

    Background: Applicant sought Medicaid benefits. The State denied the application. Applicant appealed. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Patrick J. McKay, J., affirmed. Applicant appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carpeneti, C.J., held that:

    1. retroactive application of Medicaid statute provision governing the imposition of a penalty period of ineligibility for the transfer of assets for less than fair market value by an applicant did not constitute an unlawful taking;

    2. retroactive application of Medicaid statute provision governing the imposition of a penalty period of ineligibility for the transfer of assets for less than fair market value by an applicant did not violate ex post facto laws; and

    3. the State did not violate Medicaid applicant's equal protection rights when it temporarily denied her application for benefits.

    Affirmed.


    44. William P. v. Taunya P.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 26, 2011 258 P.3d 812 2011 WL 3795530


    FAMILY LAW - Child Custody. Modification of shared legal and physical custody of children by awarding sole legal and physical custody to mother was justified.

    Synopsis

    Background: Parents, who shared legal and physical custody of children, filed cross-motions for modification of custody, each seeking to be awarded sole legal and physical custody. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Michael A. MacDonald, J., granted mother's motion and reduced father's visitation with children. Father appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Fabe, J., held that:

    1. trial court did not abuse its discretion in modifying parties' shared legal and physical custody of children by awarding sole legal and physical custody of children to mother, and

    2. trial court did not abuse its discretion in reducing father's visitation with children. Affirmed.


    45. Stone v. State

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 01, 2011 255 P.3d 979 2011 WL 2610807


    CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Counsel. Defendant had right to first-tier appellate review of sentence for which defendant had Sixth Amendment right to counsel.

    Synopsis

    Background: Defendant convicted on negotiated no contest plea to criminally negligent homicide and violations of probation filed application for post-conviction relief. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer County, Beverly W. Cutler, J., denied application, and defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, 2009 WL 795211, affirmed. Defendant then filed petition for discretionary first-tier appellate review.

    [Holding:] On grant of rehearing in part, the Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that defendant had right to first-tier appellate review of sentence for which defendant had Sixth Amendment right to counsel.

    Leave to file petition for first-tier appellate review granted.


    46. Victor B. v. State, Dept. of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. November 30, 2011 Not Reported in P.3d 2011 WL 6004329


    FAMILY LAW - Child Protection. Termination of father's parental rights was in children's best interests, although mother's rights remained intact.

    Synopsis

    Background: Office of Children's Services (OCS), which had custody of two Indian children since their births, filed a petition to terminate both mother and father's parental rights to the children. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Sen K. Tan, J., found the children were in need of aid, denied termination petition as to mother's rights, and granted petition as to father's rights. Father appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. the trial court acted within its discretion in finding that father failed to remedy the conduct and conditions that posed a substantial risk of harm to the children, and

    2. termination of father's parental rights was in children's best interests, although mother's rights remained intact.

    Affirmed.


    47. Henrichs v. Chugach Alaska Corp.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. April 22, 2011 250 P.3d 531 2011 WL 1519386


    BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Evidence was sufficient to impose a bar against chairman of corporate board from serving on the board.

    Synopsis

    Background: Corporation brought action against chairman for conversion, misrepresentation, a general breach of fiduciary duty, and a specific breach of fiduciary duty for authorizing a false and


    misleading proxy solicitation letter. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Sen K. Tan, J., entered judgment on a jury verdict in favor of corporation and entered an order banning chairman from serving on the corporation's board of directors for five years. Chairman appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Christen, J., held that:

    1. chairman was not entitled to have the jury instructed on the reliance of counsel defense in instruction on breach of fiduciary duty for authorizing a misleading proxy solicitation letter;

    2. business judgment rule did not protect chairman; and

    3. evidence was sufficient to impose a bar against chairman of corporate board from serving on the board.

    Affirmed.

    Winfree, J., filed a concurring opinion.


    48. Yvonne S. v. Wesley H.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. January 14, 2011 245 P.3d 430 2011 WL 116833


    FAMILY LAW - Child Custody. Mother's allegations that child's health and grades had deteriorated in father's care did not warrant hearing on motion to modify custody.

    Synopsis

    Background: Mother filed motion to modify prior order granting father physical custody of child. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Mark Rindner, J., denied the motion without a hearing, and mother appealed.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Carpeneti, C.J., held that mother's allegations, even if true, did not show a change in circumstances warranting modification of custody.

    Affirmed.


    1. Whitney v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. August 19, 2011 258 P.3d 113 2011 WL 3630486


      INSURANCE - Settlements. Automobile insurer did not breach legal duty to insured to settle claim brought by injured bicyclist.

      Synopsis

      Background: Automobile insured filed suit against insurer, alleging various claims of bad faith, based in part on alleged breach of duty to settle claim brought by injured bicyclist. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District Court, Anchorage, Peter A. Michalski, J., entered partial summary judgment dismissing insured's bad faith claims, and insured appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carpeneti, C.J., held that:

      1. partial summary judgment which resulted in dismissal of all of insured's claims for bad faith exceeded scope of motion limited to precise issue of whether insurer breached legal duty to tender policy limits to bicyclist, and

      2. insurer did not breach legal duty to settle with injured bicyclist when it rejected bicyclist's offer to settle for amounts that exceeded policy limits.

      Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.


    2. Horan v. Kenai Peninsula Borough Bd. of Equalization

      Supreme Court of Alaska. March 11, 2011 247 P.3d 990 2011 WL 832805


      TAXATION - Real Property. Board could consider low income housing rental restrictions when valuing apartment complex.

      Synopsis

      Background: Borough assessor appealed decision of the Board of Equalization which determined that low-income housing apartment complex was overvalued, and apartment complex owner cross-appealed. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Kenai, Anna M. Moran, J., affirmed. Assessor appealed, and complex owner cross-appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

      1. Board could use cost approach, rather than income approach, when assessing full and true value;

      2. Board could consider low income housing rental restrictions when valuing apartment complex;

      3. Remand was required for clarification as to whether or why Board considered low income housing tax credits when adjusting assessor's valuation of apartment complex;

      4. Board could reasonably determine that assessor's valuation was excessive because it failed to account for economic obsolescence;

      5. remand was required for Board to clarify reason for application of 40% obsolescence factor; and

      6. remand was required for clarification as to why Board determined that assessment was grossly disproportionate.

      Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.


    3. Alaska Exchange Carriers Ass'n, Inc. v. Regulatory Com'n of Alaska

      Supreme Court of Alaska. October 07, 2011 262 P.3d 204 2011 WL 4715209


      ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Telecommunications. Remand to RCA was required for determination as to whether corrected access charge rate was correction of procedural error.

      Synopsis

      Background: Association of local telephone companies sought retroactive application of adjusted access charge rates long distance telephone companies paid to local telephone companies. The Regulatory Commission of Alaska (RCA) denied retroactive application. Local telephone companies appealed. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Jack Smith, J., affirmed. Local telephone companies appealed.

      [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Christen, J., held that remand to RCA was required for determination as to whether error was procedural error.

      Vacated and remanded.

      Stowers, J., concurred in part, dissented in part, and filed opinion. Winfree, J., dissented in part and filed opinion.


    4. Handle Const. Co., Inc. v. Norcon, Inc.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. October 28, 2011 264 P.3d 367 2011 WL 5107129


      COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Subcontractor bore risk of unilateral mistake in submitting



      inadvertently low bid to general contractor.

      Synopsis

      Background: Subcontractor brought suit against general contractor, alleging that subcontractor's inadvertent error in bid for concrete foundation construction project was attributable to information sent by general contractor. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Eric A. Aarseth, J., entered judgment for general contractor. Subcontractor appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carpeneti, C.J., held that:

      1. subcontractor bore risk of unilateral mistake in bid, and

      2. subcontractor's submission of bid that was 35 percent lower than next-lowest bidder did not impose obligation on general contractor to inquire into whether subcontractor committed mistake.

      Affirmed.


    5. Darcy F. v. State, Dept. of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

      Supreme Court of Alaska. April 22, 2011 252 P.3d 992 2011 WL 1522442


      NATIVE AMERICANS - Child Welfare. Evidence supported finding that the State made active efforts to provide services and programs designed to prevent the breakup of the Indian family.

      Synopsis

      Background: A petition was filed to terminate mother's parental rights to Indian child. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Philip M. Pallenberg, J., terminated parental rights. Mother appealed.

      [Holding:] The Supreme Court held that the State made active efforts, as required by the Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA), to provide remedial services and rehabilitative programs designed to prevent the breakup of the Indian family.

      Affirmed.


    6. Crowley v. State, Dept. of Health & Social Services

      Supreme Court of Alaska. July 01, 2011 253 P.3d 1226 2011 WL 2610953


      LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Contracts. Investigation into employee's work performance was not conduct in a bad faith manner.

      Synopsis

      Background: Terminated state employee brought breach of implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing action against her former employer, the Office of Children's Services (OCS). Following remand from the Supreme Court, 2008 WL 5352309, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, William F. Morse, J., dismissed action. Employee appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carpeneti, C.J., held that:

      1. supervisor did not conduct investigation in bad faith;

      2. employee failed to prove immediate supervisor treated her in a bad-faith manner; and

      3. employee failed to prove that immediate supervisor was permitted to be present during interviews


      during investigation. Affirmed.


    7. Fraternal Order of Eagles v. City and Borough of Juneau

      Supreme Court of Alaska. July 01, 2011 254 P.3d 348 2011 WL 2610954


      GOVERNMENT - Tobacco. Ordinance prohibiting smoking in private clubs offering food or alcoholic beverages for sale did not violate right to privacy.

      Synopsis

      Background: Private club brought action alleging that city and borough's ordinance prohibiting smoking in private clubs offering food or alcoholic beverages for sale violated club's freedom of association under First Amendment and club's right to privacy under State Constitution. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Philip M. Pallenberg, J., granted summary judgment to city and borough. Club appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Fabe, J., held that:

      1. ordinance did not implicate the right to intimate association under the First Amendment, and

      2. ordinance did not violate private club's right to privacy under the State Constitution. Affirmed.


    8. Coppe v. Bleicher

      Supreme Court of Alaska. March 09, 2011 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2011 WL 832807


      LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Judgment. Employee was not entitled to relief from court's judgment for employer on employee's wrongful discharge claim on ground of excusable neglect.

      Synopsis

      Background: Employee sued her former employer for wrongful termination. After employee lost at trial, she failed to file an appeal from trial court's judgment or the denial of her motion for new trial, and instead, she filed a motion for relief from judgment. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, John Suddock, J., denied her motion, and she appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

      1. employee was not entitled to relief from trial court's judgment for employer on employee's wrongful discharge claim on ground of excusable neglect; and

      2. employee was not entitled to relief from judgment on ground of newly discovered evidence. Affirmed.


    9. Gillis v. Aleutians East Borough

      Supreme Court of Alaska. August 19, 2011 258 P.3d 118 2011 WL 3652429


      GOVERNMENT - States. Alaska Land Act required applicant to enter land while it was under federal ownership to qualify for preference right.



      Synopsis

      Background: Borough, after Department of Natural Resources (DNR) conveyed lands, filed declaratory judgment action, asking for determination whether lessee qualified for a preference right to purchase land. Lessee counterclaimed against borough, filed third-party complaint against DNR, and moved for partial summary judgment against both parties. Borough and DNR cross-moved for summary judgment. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, John Suddock, J, entered summary judgment in favor of borough and DNR. Lessee appealed.

      [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that provision of Alaska Land Act required applicant to enter land while it was under federal ownership to qualify for preference right.

      Affirmed.


    10. Erkins v. Alaska Trustee, LLC

      Supreme Court of Alaska. October 21, 2011 265 P.3d 292 2011 WL 5009383


      REAL PROPERTY - Mortgages and Deeds of Trust. Assignee of loan originator could not be held liable for loan originator's alleged torts associated with origination of loan.

      Synopsis

      Background: After borrower defaulted on loan and foreclosure proceedings were initiated, borrower filed suit against foreclosure trustee and the current holder of the loan, alleging 12 causes of action chiefly related to fraud and misrepresentation associated with the origination of the loan. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, John Suddock, J., granted defendants' motion for summary judgment, finding that defendants were not liable for any tort of loan originator and that borrower released his claims in a forbearance agreement. Borrower appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

      1. defendants could not be held liable for loan originator's alleged torts associated with the origination of the loan, and

      2. fact issues precluded summary judgment on remaining claims. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.


    11. In re Alaska Network on Domestic Violence and Sexual Assault

      Supreme Court of Alaska. December 02, 2011 264 P.3d 835 2011 WL 6062049


      GOVERNMENT - Public Bodies. Nonprofit corporation representing party constituted public agency so as to trigger opposing party's right to appointed counsel.

      Synopsis

      Background: In child custody dispute, the Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Philip M. Pallenberg, J., determined sua sponte that Court was obligated to appoint counsel for father through the Office of Public Advocacy (OPA). Domestic violence and sexual assault nonprofit corporation petitioned for review, which was granted.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Christen, J., held that:

      1. termpublic agency referred to organization's funding sources, rather than status as government agency, and

      2. corporation constituted public agency.


      Affirmed.

      Stowers, J., dissented and filed opinion.


    12. Thomas v. Thomas

      Supreme Court of Alaska. July 27, 2011 Not Reported in P.3d 2011 WL 3241844


      FAMILY LAW - Visitation. Trial court considered mother's admitted child abuse when entering order awarding her limited visitation with children.

      Synopsis

      Background: More than a year after her arrest for striking two of the children, which resulted in father being awarded interim custody, mother filed a motion to permit her to have limited and temporary supervised visits with the parties' six children in a therapeutic setting. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Peter A. Michalski, J., granted motion. After his motion for reconsideration was denied, father appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

      1. entry of deferred sentencing agreement in mother's criminal case constituted a material change in circumstances that allowed trial court to make best interests determination relative to mother's request for visitation;

      2. father was afforded opportunity to be heard in proceedings on mother's motion;

      3. trial court's findings were sufficient to support best interests conclusion;

      4. trial court acted within its discretion in declining to have the children interviewed for another child custody investigation;

      5. trial court acted within its discretion in making best interests determination for each of the six individual children when ruling on mother's motion; and

      6. trial court considered mother's admitted child abuse when entering order awarding her limited visitation with children.

      Affirmed.


    13. McGahuey v. Whitestone Logging, Inc.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. October 21, 2011 262 P.3d 613 2011 WL 5009382


      LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Substantial evidence supported conclusion that claimant did not prove his benefits claim.

      Synopsis

      Background: Claimant sought workers' compensation benefits after he allegedly injured his hip, lower back, and ear in a fight at work. Employer controverted benefits. The Workers' Compensation Board dismissed the benefits claim. Claimant appealed, and the Workers' Compensation Appeals Commission, Kristin S. Knudsen, Commission Chair, reversed and remanded. On remand, the board determined that the claim was barred because claimant did not give employer timely written notice of the injuries and that, even if he had, the injuries were not compensable. Claimant appealed. The commission affirmed. Claimant appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

      1. start of the 30-day period for claimant to give employer written notice of his alleged injuries was required to be determined by the board and the commission in deciding whether claimant provided the


        required notice;

      2. error in the failures of the board and the commission to determine the start of the 30-day period was harmless;

      3. any erroneous consideration of claimant's credibility by the board in determining whether claimant established a link between his employment and his alleged injuries was harmless;

      4. evidence was sufficient to rebut a presumption that claimant's alleged injuries were compensable; and

      5. substantial evidence supported a conclusion that claimant did not prove his claim. Affirmed.


    14. Renaissance Alaska, LLC v. Rutter and Wilbanks Corp.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. October 28, 2011 263 P.3d 35 2011 WL 5107093


      COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Member of LLC did not forfeit share of ORRI in oil field by failing to contribute required share of capital.

      Synopsis

      Background: Member of limited liability company (LLC) that had acquired lease to working interest of oil field brought declaratory judgment action seeking determination that it was entitled to half of overriding royalty interest (ORRI) following its failure to contribute all of required capital. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, John Suddock, J., determined that member was entitled to half of ORRI. Other member appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Fabe, J., held that:

      1. member owned half of ORRI, and

      2. member did not forfeit interest by failing to contribute required share of capital. Affirmed.


    15. Monzulla v. Voorhees Concrete Cutting

      Supreme Court of Alaska. June 24, 2011 254 P.3d 341 2011 WL 2515504


      LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Workers' Compensation Appeals Commission has implied jurisdiction to review interlocutory Workers' Compensation Board orders.

      Synopsis

      Background: Employer filed a motion for extraordinary review of Workers' Compensation Board's interlocutory order denying employer's petition to change venue. The Workers' Compensation Appeals Commission, Kristin S. Knudsen, Commission Chair, reversed the Board's venue decision. Claimant appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carpeneti, C.J., held that:

      1. claimant's challenge to Commission's subject matter jurisdiction to review Board's interlocutory order denying employer's petition to change venue was not untimely;

      2. Commission has implied jurisdiction to review interlocutory Board orders; and

      3. Commission had jurisdiction to stay Board's decision denying employer's petition to change venue while Commission reviewed the decision.

      Affirmed.


    16. Rivera v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. February 11, 2011 247 P.3d 957 2011 WL 488902


    LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Workers' Compensation Board was permitted to give less weight to claimant's physician's testimony than other medical evidence.

    Synopsis

    Background: Workers' compensation claimant appealed decision of the Workers' Compensation Appeals Commission, Kristin Knudsen, Commission Chair, affirming Workers' Compensation Board's denial of her claim for temporary total disability (TTD) benefits.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Fabe, J., held that:

    1. Board properly relied on independent medical evaluation physician's testimony in rejecting claim;

    2. Board was permitted to give less weight to claimant's family practice physician's testimony than the other medical evidence; and

    3. Workers' Compensation Board was not required to make findings about the lay testimony. Affirmed.


    65. Hoendermis v. Advanced Physical Therapy, Inc.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. April 29, 2011 251 P.3d 346 2011 WL 1600172


    LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Wrongful Discharge. Fact issues precluded summary judgment on breach of covenant of good faith and fair dealing claim.

    Synopsis

    Background: Former employee brought action against employer for wrongful termination in violation of employer's policy manual and covenant of good faith and fair dealing and for failure to provide overtime compensation in violation of state and federal law. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, John Suddock, J., granted employer's motion for summary judgment. Employee appealed. Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

    1. fact issues precluded summary judgment on overtime compensation claim;

    2. Department of Labor and Workforce Development's decision in unemployment compensation proceeding that employee committed misconduct did not preclude superior court from examining employee's breach of covenant of good faith and fair dealing claim;

    3. employer's policy manual did not create a reasonable expectation that employee was guaranteed progressive discipline; and

    4. fact issues precluded summary judgment on claim of breach of the covenant of good faith and fair dealing.

    Reversed and remanded.


    1. Burts v. Burts

      Supreme Court of Alaska. December 02, 2011 266 P.3d 337 2011 WL 6046441


      FAMILY LAW - Equitable Distribution. Husband's post-retirement military health insurance benefit was a marital asset for purposes of property division.



      Synopsis

      Background: Husband filed complaint for divorce against wife. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Mark Rindner, J., dissolved parties' marriage and divided the marital estate between the parties. Husband appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Christen, J., held that:

      1. in a matter of first impression, husband's post-retirement military health insurance benefit, earned during parties' marriage, was a marital asset for purposes of property division;

      2. Former Spouses' Protection Act did not preempt trial court from considering husband's post-retirement military health insurance benefit as a marital asset for purposes of property division;

      3. trial court was not justified in adopting the valuation of husband's post-retirement military health insurance benefit included in written report of wife's expert, rather than the figure that expert testified to at trial;

      4. evidence supported trial court's unequal distribution of the marital estate. Affirmed and remanded.


    2. Kalenka v. Infinity Ins. Companies

      Supreme Court of Alaska. October 14, 2011 262 P.3d 602 2011 WL 4862938


      INSURANCE - Automobile. Insured's stabbing death did not arise out of use of an uninsured vehicle within meaning of UM coverage provision.

      Synopsis

      Background: Automobile insurer filed action against insured's estate for a declaration that insured's policy did not provide uninsured motorist (UM) liability coverage for insured's death when he was stabbed and killed by driver of uninsured vehicle after minor collision. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, 2009 WL 8473851, Peter G. Ashman, Judge pro tempore, granted summary judgment to insurer. Estate appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Fabe, J., held that:

      1. fatal stabbing did not arise out of the use, ownership, or maintenance of uninsured vehicle, as necessary for UM coverage to apply; and

      2. trial court did not abuse its discretion in deciding tort issues of alleged negligent entrustment and maintenance by owner of uninsured vehicle.

      Affirmed.

      See also, 2009 WL 8473850; 2005 WL 6731666.


    3. Chambers v. Scofield

      Supreme Court of Alaska. March 04, 2011 247 P.3d 982 2011 WL 745988


      REAL PROPERTY - Settlements. Purchaser was not entitled to profit and overhead on repairs to triplex, under agreement settling vendor's fraud action.

      Synopsis

      Background: Vendor's guardian brought fraudulent inducement action against purchaser seeking return of vendor's triplex. Vendor's guardian filed motion to enforce settlement agreement. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Morgan B. Christen, J., granted the motion after appointing a


      new remodel appraiser, and denied purchaser's argument that he was the prevailing party. Purchaser appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

      1. under the settlement agreement purchaser was not entitled to profit and overhead on his repairs and maintenance to triplex, and

      2. trial court did not abuse its discretion by finding that purchaser was not the prevailing party for purposes of an attorney fees award.

      Affirmed.


    4. Miller v. Handle Const. Co.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. July 22, 2011 255 P.3d 984 2011 WL 2937217


      LITIGATION - Settlements. Offer was judgment was not required to be reduced by other amount received by plaintiff in order to avoid double recovery.

      Synopsis

      Background: After landowner made offer of judgment in action by construction company seeking unanticipated costs company incurred due to manufacturing defects in hangar company erected on landowner's property, landowner refused to pay full amount after company received payment from manufacturer. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, William F. Morse, J., ordered landowner to pay full amount. Landowner appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

      1. payment of full amount of offer of judgment did not constitute double recover;

      2. post-offer extrinsic evidence was irrelevant; and

      3. disputed issue of material fact existed regarding whether amount received from manufacturer rightfully belonged to landowner.

      Reversed and remanded.

      Christen, J., dissented and filed opinion in which Carpeneti, C.J., joined.


    5. O'Connell v. Will

    Supreme Court of Alaska. October 28, 2011 263 P.3d 41 2011 WL 5107105


    LITIGATION - Process. Judgment creditor lacked standing to object to judgment debtor's defective service on his ex-wife.

    Synopsis

    Background: Judgment creditor sought post-judgment attorney fees. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Sharon Gleason, J., denied creditor's motion, and he appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

    1. in a matter of first impression, judgment creditor lacked standing to object to judgment debtor's defective service on his ex-wife;

    2. Superior Court's consideration of judgment debtor's motion for entry of a satisfaction of judgment before debtor's ex-wife, a co-defendant in the underlying action, had been served, did not constitute an abuse of discretion; and

    3. judgment creditor was entitled to recover reasonable post-judgment attorney fees and costs under his contract with judgment debtor.


    Order vacated, reversed and remanded.

    Fabe, J., filed dissenting opinion, joined by Christen, J.


    71. Pravat P. v. State, Dept. of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. February 18, 2011 249 P.3d 264 2011 WL 563184


    FAMILY LAW - Child Protection. Evidence supported finding that the Office of Children's Services made active efforts to prevent the breakup of Indian family.

    Synopsis

    Background: The Office of Children's Services (OCS) filed a petition to terminate father's parental rights to his three children. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Sharon Gleason, J., terminated parental rights. Father appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carpeneti, C.J., held that:

    1. evidence supported finding that the OCS made active efforts to prevent the breakup of father's Indian family;

    2. evidence supported finding that father failed to remedy the conduct that placed his children at substantial risk;

    3. evidence supported finding that returning the children to father would likely result in serious emotional or physical injury; and

    4. evidence supported finding that termination of father's parental rights was in the best interests of the children.

    Affirmed.


    72. In re Tracy C.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. April 22, 2011 249 P.3d 1085 2011 WL 1519379


    HEALTH - Mental Health. An order granting petition for involuntary commitment must be based on patient's condition at time of commitment hearing.

    Synopsis

    Background: Involuntary committee appealed order of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Stephanie E. Joannides, J., granting petition for involuntary commitment.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Fabe, J., held that:

    1. appeal fell within the public interest exception to the mootness doctrine;

    2. an order granting a petition for involuntary commitment must be based on the patient's condition at the time of the commitment hearing;

    3. in determining the patient's condition at the time of the involuntary commitment hearing the trial court can consider the patient's recent conduct and conditions; and

    4. superior court properly applied involuntary commitment statute in determining that committee was gravely disabled on the day of the commitment hearing.

    Affirmed.


    73. Lewis-Walunga v. Municipality of Anchorage

    Supreme Court of Alaska. April 15, 2011 249 P.3d 1063 2011 WL 1441883


    LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Claimant was a successful party on appeal from Workers' Compensation Board's order and, thus, was entitled to attorney fees.

    Synopsis

    Background: A successful workers' compensation claimant requested an attorney fee award. The Workers' Compensation Board reduced the requested fee award by 30 percent. Claimant appealed. The Workers' Compensation Appeals Commission reversed and remanded to the Board for further consideration of a fee award. The claimant then requested an attorney fee award from the Commission for her appeal. The Commission refused to award claimant attorney fees, finding she was not the successful party on appeal. Claimant petitioned for review.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

    1. a claimant is a successful party in an appeal to the Commission when the claimant prevails on a significant issue in the appeal;

    2. claimant was a successful party on appeal and, thus, was entitled to attorney fees for work done before the Commission; and

    3. Commission's finding that the essential element of the relief claimant requested on appeal was a remand with instructions to award full reasonable attorney fees was not supported by substantial evidence.

    Reversed and remanded.


    74. Henrichs v. Chugach Alaska Corp.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 26, 2011 260 P.3d 1036 2011 WL 3795531


    BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Corporation was not required to deliver shareholder information to directors and shareholders.

    Synopsis

    Background: Former directors of corporation brought action against corporation alleging that their names were excluded from the board's corporate proxy materials and that corporation did not provide them with shareholder information for their own proxy campaigns within the time frame they demanded. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Craig F. Stowers, J., granted summary judgment in favor of corporation. Former directors appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, Justice Pro Tem., held that:

    1. corporation was not required to deliver shareholder information to directors and shareholders;

    2. trial court's failure to inform directors of its treatment of motion to dismiss as summary judgment motion did not prejudice directors;

    3. failure to include names of former directors in proxy literature for shareholder meeting did not constitute a material misrepresentation;

    4. proxy statement for shareholder meeting complied with disclosure of financial information requirements;

    5. proxy statement for shareholder meeting complied with disclosure of net value per share requirements; and

    6. offer of early-bird prizes for early return of proxies did not constitute impermissible distributions. Affirmed.


    75. Sengul v. CMS Franklin, Inc.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. December 09, 2011 265 P.3d 320 2011 WL 6116695


    REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Landlord padlocking door to property constituted constructive eviction of commercial tenant.

    Synopsis

    Background: Following vacation of property, landlord brought action against tenant for unpaid rent. The Superior Court, Alaska, First Judicial District, Juneau, Patricia A. Collins, J., found that tenant had waived right to rent abatement but that landlord's actions constituted constructive eviction. Landlord appealed and tenant cross-appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Fabe, J., held that:

    1. landlord was not permitted to lock tenant out of property;

    2. landlord constructively evicted tenant;

    3. tenant did not impliedly waive rent abatement; and

    4. amount of unpaid rent was to be calculated based on monthly rental amount, rather than yearly rental value.

    Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded. Christen, J., dissented and filed opinion.


    1. Stephen H. v. State, Dept. of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

      Supreme Court of Alaska. November 30, 2011 Not Reported in P.3d 2011 WL 6004352


      FAMILY LAW - Child Protection. Evidence was sufficient to support order terminating father's parental rights.

      Synopsis

      Background: State moved to terminate father's parental rights. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, John Suddock, J., granted motion. Father appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

      1. evidence was sufficient to establish that father's drinking impaired his ability to parent and caused a substantial risk of harm to both his children;

      2. evidence was sufficient to establish that father failed to remedy the conduct that placed his children at substantial risk of harm;

      3. evidence was sufficient to establish that State had made active efforts to prevent the breakup of the Indian family;

      4. evidence was sufficient to establish that children would likely have suffered serious harm if they had been returned to father's care; and

      5. evidence was sufficient to establish that termination of father's parental rights served his children's best interests.

      Affirmed.


    2. Williams v. Russell

      Supreme Court of Alaska. June 15, 2011 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2011 WL 2437688



      FAMILY LAW - Child Support. Mother provided sufficient support as to amount of daycare expenses.

      Synopsis

      Background: Mother of non-marital child filed motion for reimbursement for daycare expenses. Father filed motion for contempt. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Peter A. Michalski, J., entered judgment in favor of mother. Father appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

      1. under law-of-the-case doctrine, father's failure to appeal trial court's previous rulings precluded father from challenging those rulings in current appeal;

      2. remand was warranted to consider recalculating father's child-support obligation based on adjusted annual income figure that accounted for reasonable child care expenses;

      3. mother provided sufficient support as to amount of daycare expenses;

      4. father was not entitled to have child-support obligation retroactively reduced; and

      5. father's allegation that mother had arranged for child to travel independently with escort of flight attendant, standing alone, was insufficient factual support to prove that mother violated court order governing transfer of child.

      Affirmed and remanded.


    3. Foster v. Professional Guardian Services Corp.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. August 19, 2011 258 P.3d 102 2011 WL 3652417


      FAMILY LAW - Attorney Fees. Conservator could not recover attorney's fees incurred in defending actions which harmed ward's estate.

      Synopsis

      Background: Conservator for mother, who suffered from dementia, filed final accounting after mother's death. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, John Suddock, J., approved the accounting, and daughter appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carpeneti, C.J., held that:

      1. apparent inconsistency in trial court's factual findings regarding the value of ward's property;

      2. inventory which listed only items valued in excess of $400 was insufficient;

      3. conservator's error in failing to timely correct mis-sent monthly pension payments caused only

        $1,323.91 in damages to estate;

      4. conservator did not breach any fiduciary duty in the manner in which it sold ward's house; and

      5. as a matter of first impression, conservator could not recover attorney's fees incurred in defending actions which harmed ward's estate.

      Remanded in part; otherwise affirmed.


    4. Griswold v. City of Homer

      Supreme Court of Alaska. June 10, 2011 252 P.3d 1020 2011 WL 2274553


      REAL PROPERTY - Appeals. Superior court's initial Decision on Appeal in land use action, rather than later final judgment, triggered period for appeal.



      Synopsis

      Background: City resident appealed city clerk's determination that he lacked standing to appeal advisory planning commission's grant of a conditional-use permit to a mariculture association. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Homer County, Carl Bauman, J., affirmed, and resident appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

      1. superior court's Decision on Appeal, rather than its later, separate Final Judgment, was the relevant judgment which triggered 30-day time period for appeal;

      2. Supreme Court would consider pro se resident's untimely appeal;

      3. city code's standing provisions did not violate statute statutes;

      4. standing requirements did not violate due process;

      5. city had a legitimate reason for standing requirements;

      6. resident did not have standing as a person aggrieved; and

      7. city could delegate to city clerk the authority to reject appeals for lack of standing. Affirmed.


    5. Worthington v. Worthington

      Supreme Court of Alaska. August 24, 2011 Not Reported in P.3d 2011 WL 3795532


      FAMILY LAW - Child Custody. Evidence supported finding it was in two youngest children's best interests for mother to retain primary physical custody.

      Synopsis

      Background: Mother and father both filed motions to modify child custody. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eric A. Aarseth, J., denied father's motion for custody of the two youngest children, granted father's motion to temporarily reduce child support payments for one child who, by agreement of the parties, was temporarily living with him, and sanctioned mother for interfering with father's visitation with another child. Father appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

      1. evidence supported determination that a change in primary physical custody of the parties' two youngest children from mother to father was not in children's best interests;

      2. superior court acted well within its discretion in providing guidance to mother and father, as pro se litigants;

      3. child's move to live with father was not a material change in circumstances, and thus superior court did not abuse its discretion by granting father extended visitation credits rather than modifying child support; and

      4. superior court did not abuse its discretion by sanctioning mother only $1,000 for interfering with father's visitation with child.

      Affirmed.


      81. Kingery v. Barrett

      Supreme Court of Alaska. March 04, 2011 249 P.3d 275 2011 WL 833258


      TRANSPORTATION - Motor Vehicles. Any error in instruction which charged jury with determining whether second motorist had acted negligently was not plain error.



      Synopsis

      Background: First motorist brought personal injury action against second and third motorists arising out of consecutive accidents less than five minutes apart. After settlement between first motorist and third motorist, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, Beverly W. Cutler, J., entered judgment on jury verdict for second motorist, denied first motorist's motion for examination or change of judge, and awarded second motorist attorney's fees and costs. First motorist appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

      1. first motorist waived argument that second motorist was the cause of at least some of first motorist's injuries as a matter of law;

      2. second motorist's statements in trial brief were not binding judicial admissions;

      3. any error in jury instruction which charged the jury with determining whether second motorist had acted negligently was not plain error;

      4. evidence was sufficient to support jury finding that second collision caused injuries; and

      5. prejudicial effect of information in insurer's claim file outweighed probative value. Affirmed.


      82. Philip J. v. State, Dept. of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

      Supreme Court of Alaska. December 02, 2011 264 P.3d 842 2011 WL 6046446


      FAMILY LAW - Child Protection. Entry of adjudication findings in CINA case after contested probable cause hearing did not violate father's right to due process.

      Synopsis

      Background: State filed petition for adjudication of children in need of aid (CINA). The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Bethel, Leonard Devaney III, J., issued order finding that children were in need of aid. Father appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Christen, J., held that:

      1. trial court's entry of adjudication findings in CINA proceeding after contested probable cause hearing did not violate father's right to due process, and

      2. father waived his right to present a closing argument at end of contested probable cause hearing. Affirmed.

      Winfree, J., dissented, with opinion.


      83. Ralph H. v. State, Dept. of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

      Supreme Court of Alaska. February 04, 2011 246 P.3d 916 2011 WL 338044


      FAMILY LAW - Child Protection. Evidence supported finding that child was in need of aid based on parental abandonment, an element in support of termination of parental rights.

      Synopsis

      Background: The Office of Children's Services (OCS) petitioned to terminate parental rights to child. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, Beverly Cutler, J., terminated parental rights. Father appealed.


      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

      1. evidence supported finding that child was in need of aid based on parental abandonment;

      2. evidence supported finding that child was in need of aid based on child suffering substantial physical harm;

      3. evidence supported finding that child was in need of aid based on a mental injury;

      4. evidence supported finding that child was in need of aid based on a parent having a mental illness, serious emotional disturbance, or mental deficiency;

      5. evidence supported finding that parents failed to remedy the conduct or conditions that made child a child in need of aid (CINA); and

      6. evidence supported finding that the OCS made reasonable efforts to reunify family. Affirmed.


      84. Cowan v. Yeisley

      Supreme Court of Alaska. May 27, 2011 255 P.3d 966 2011 WL 2084008


      REAL PROPERTY - Adverse Possession. Revised limitations statute did not apply to landowners who were vested with title well before statute was changed.

      Synopsis

      Background: Landowners brought action against borough, neighbors, and other parties to quiet title to right of way. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Ketchikan, Michael A. Thompson, J., entered summary judgment in defendants' favor. Landowners appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

      1. deed that granted perpetual right of way granted landowners an easement, not a fee interest;

      2. revised version of statute did not apply to landowners who were vested with title to the disputed land well before the statute was changed;

      3. material fact issue precluded summary judgment; and

      4. landowners were not estopped from making claim for adverse possession of right away. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.


      1. Stefanski v. Municipality of Anchorage

        Supreme Court of Alaska. August 17, 2011 Not Reported in P.3d 2011 WL 3903388


        When the Municipality of Anchorage invited bid proposals for contractors to perform tree trimming services, it specified as one condition of the contract that the successful contractor had to have a current collective bargaining agreement or a letter of assent with the IBEW Local No. 1547.

        Skookum Construction and Tree Service did not have a...



      2. J.P. v. Anchorage School Dist.

        Supreme Court of Alaska. September 16, 2011 260 P.3d 285 2011 WL 4435897


        EDUCATION - Disabled Students. Reimbursement by school district for parents' cost of obtaining private eligibility evaluation was appropriate.



        Synopsis

        Background: Parents of an elementary-school student requested a due-process hearing pursuant to the federal Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) after school district did not assess student's eligibility for special-education services within the required time after they requested an assessment, seeking reimbursement for the costs of private tutoring and a private eligibility evaluation that they had arranged. School district ultimately determined that student was ineligible for services. An independent hearing officer agreed with the school district that student was ineligible for services but ordered school district to pay the cost of the private evaluation and to partially pay the costs of the private tutoring. School district appealed. Parents also appealed but later dismissed their appeal. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Peter G. Ashman, J., upheld the award for the private evaluation and reversed the award for the private tutoring. School district and parents appealed.

        Holdings: The Supreme Court, Christen, J., held that:

        1. appropriate standard for trial court's review of the hearing officer's decision was de novo;

        2. learning disability of student did not entitle him to private tutoring at school district's expense;

        3. failure of school district to timely assess the student's eligibility for special-education services did not give rise to a remedy under the IDEA; but

        4. reimbursement by school district for parents' cost of obtaining a private eligibility evaluation was appropriate.

        Affirmed.


      3. Schneider v. Schneider

        Supreme Court of Alaska. September 07, 2011 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2011 WL 3925260


        FAMILY LAW - Witnesses. Trial court acted within its discretion in excluding witness who had remained in courtroom prior to being called to testify.

        Synopsis

        Background: Husband brought action for divorce. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, Kari Kristiansen, J., entered judgment of divorce, which included an equitable distribution order that awarded husband marital land and unfinished home while requiring him to make offsetting equalization payments to wife totaling $50,668. Husband appealed.

        Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

        1. husband waived for appellate review any claim that real property and unfinished home was his separate property and thus exempt from equitable distribution;

        2. real property and unfinished home on the property was marital property and thus subject to equitable distribution;

        3. trial court acted within its discretion in valuing real property and unfinished home on the property at

          $146,000;

        4. husband waived for appellate review challenge against trial court's refusal to consider appraisal of real property and unfinished home on property that contemplated an unfinanced quick sale for cash;

        5. trial court acted within its discretion in refusing to treat the marital property division as an action for rescission;

        6. trial court acted within its discretion in excluding husband's proposed character witness; and

        7. trial court acted within its discretion in excluding witness who had remained in courtroom prior to being called to testify.

        Affirmed.


      4. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co. v. Houle

      Supreme Court of Alaska. August 26, 2011 269 P.3d 654 2011 WL 6957589


      INSURANCE - Automobile. Individual family members were not in accident so as to trigger per-person UIM coverage for emotional distress claims.

      Synopsis

      Background: Insureds brought action against their automobile insurer seeking further coverage under underinsured motorist (UIM) provisions of policies following automobile accident. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, William F. Morse, J., concluded that the insureds had not exhausted their UIM coverage under insurance statutes and reformed the insurance policies to allow emotional distress claims to proceed to arbitration. Insurer appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carpeneti, C.J., held that:

      1. individual family members were not in accident so as to trigger per-person UIM coverage, and

      2. insurance statutes did not require per-person UIM coverage in such situations. Reversed and remanded; rehearing denied.

      Opinion, 258 P.3d 833, withdrawn.

      Editor's Note: The opinion of the Supreme Court of Alaska, in State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co. v. Houle, published in the advance sheet at this citation, 258 P.3d 833, was withdrawn from the bound volume because rehearing was pending.


      89. ASRC Energy Services Power and Communications, LLC v. Golden Valley Elec. Ass'n, Inc.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. November 04, 2011 267 P.3d 1151 2011 WL 5288786


      COMMERCIAL LAW - Consumer Protection. Standards under Unfair Trade Practices and Consumer Protection Act were not required to conform to analogous federal law.

      Synopsis

      Background: Contractor brought suit against electrical association alleging claims including breach of contract and violation of Unfair Trade Practices and Consumer Protection Act (UTPA), and electrical association asserted counterclaims alleging misrepresentation and violation of UTPA by contractor.
