    BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Sale of corporate asset to self-interested directors was just and reasonable as to the corporation at the time it was authorized.

    Synopsis

    Background: First shareholder in closely held corporation brought action, individually and on behalf of corporation, against second and third shareholders to void sale of corporate asset and to re-convey asset in the form of mining claims to corporation, and alleging breach of fiduciary duty. Following a bench trial, the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Paul R. Lyle, J., found in favor of defendants, and plaintiff shareholder appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

    1. evidence was sufficient to support a finding that April meeting, at which only bid for the claims was opened, was a directors' meeting, rather than a shareholders' meeting, for purposes of determining whether the sale of the asset was just and reasonable as to the corporation;

    2. Superior Court did not clearly err in finding first shareholder had knowledge of all facts material to the sale of corporate asset;

    3. first shareholder waived notice of special meeting of the board by attending the directors' meeting without protest as to lack of notice;

    4. first shareholder had the authority to vote to approve the sale of corporate asset at April 2010 directors' meeting; and

    5. in an apparent matter of first impression, the Superior Court did not clearly err in deciding that, under the business judgment rule, the sale of corporate asset to self-interested directors was just and


    reasonable as to the corporation at the time it was authorized. Affirmed.


  7. Rowan B. v. State, Dept. of Health & Social Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. November 25, 2015 361 P.3d 910 2015 WL 7709456


    FAMILY LAW - Child Protection. Father failed to establish good cause to warrant a continuance of termination of parental rights hearing.

    Synopsis

    Background: The Office of Children's Services (OCS) petitioned to terminate father's parental rights to his three children. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, Kari Kristiansen, J., terminated father's parental rights. Father appealed.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Fabe, J., held that father failed to establish good cause to warrant the continuance.

    Affirmed.


  8. Goldsbury v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. February 13, 2015 342 P.3d 834 2015 WL 630289


CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Privileges. Prosecutor's violation of defendant's right against self-incrimination was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt.

Synopsis

Background: Defendant was convicted in the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer County, Kari Kristiansen, J., of attempted murder in the first degree. Defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, 2012 WL 2203055, affirmed.

Holdings: On petition for review, the Supreme Court, Fabe, C.J., held that:

  1. prosecutor's comment violated defendant's right against self-incrimination, but

  2. violation of defendant's right against self-incrimination was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt. Affirmed.


35. Horne v. Touhakis

Supreme Court of Alaska. August 14, 2015 356 P.3d 280 2015 WL 4774231


FAMILY LAW - Child Support. Evidence in child support modification case did not support court's imputed income determination with respect to psychological parent.

Synopsis

Background: Psychological parent, who, pursuant to parties' settlement, had established a psychological parent relationship with mother's adoptive child and had visitation rights with child, filed motion to modify his child support obligation. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, William F. Morse, J., reduced psychological parent's child support obligation from $1,750 to $1,050 a


month, and psychological parent appealed.

[Holding:] The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that evidence did not support trial court's imputed income determination with respect to psychological parent.

Vacated and remanded.


  1. Ace Delivery & Moving, Inc. v. State

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 15, 2015 350 P.3d 776 2015 WL 2328726


    LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Attorney Fees. Prevailing employer in hostile work environment proceeding could not recover attorney fees.

    Synopsis

    Background: Executive director of State Commission for Human Rights brought action on behalf of employee who alleged that her employer's racist and insensitive remarks created a hostile work environment. Commission found that employee did not suffer a hostile work environment, but it denied employer's request for attorney fees, and employer appealed. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Frank A. Pfiffner, J., affirmed, and employer appealed.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that reasonable basis existed for State Commission for Human Rights' conclusion that statute, authorizing Commission to order payment of attorney fees, did not require an award of fees to employer.

    Affirmed.


  2. Dirk H. v. State, Dept. of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 25, 2015 Not Reported in P.3d 2015 WL 1394581


    FAMILY LAW - Child Protection. Court did not clearly err in finding that father failed to remedy the conduct that placed Indian child at substantial risk of harm.

    Synopsis

    Background: Office of Children's Services (OCS) filed a petition to terminate both parents' rights to child pursuant to the Child in Need of Aid (CINA) statute and the Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA). The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, John Suddock, J., terminated father's parental rights, and he appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. trial court did not clearly err in finding that father failed to remedy the conduct that placed Indian child at substantial risk of harm, and

    2. trial court did not clearly err in finding that OCS made active, but unsuccessful efforts to prevent the breakup of an Indian family, as required by CINA statute and ICWA.

    Affirmed.


  3. McCormick v. McCormick

    Supreme Court of Alaska. September 16, 2015 Not Reported in P.3d 2015 WL 5478150



    FAMILY LAW - Marital Property. Court did not abuse its discretion by equally dividing marital estate.

    Synopsis

    Background: Divorce action was brought. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Gregory Miller, J., found that a construction business the husband had started before the marriage was marital property, as was all equipment used or owned by the company, and decided that it was equitable to split the marital assets 50/50. Husband appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. equipment that husband purchased before marriage that his business used before, during, and after the marriage was marital property, and

    2. superior court did not abuse its discretion by equally dividing marital estate. Affirmed.


  4. Alaska Police Standards Council v. Parcell

    Supreme Court of Alaska. April 17, 2015 348 P.3d 882 2015 WL 1743217


    GOVERNMENT - Public Safety. Council reasonably determined police officer was not of good moral character, and was dishonest, as a basis for revoking his police certificate.

    Synopsis

    Background: Police officer sought review of the Alaska Police Standards Council's decision to revoke officer's police certificate. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Louis J. Menendez, J., reversed, and the Council appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

    1. the rational basis test, rather than the substitution of judgment, was the proper standard of review for the Council's decision to revoke officer's police certificate, and

    2. the Council reasonably determined police officer was not of good moral character, and was dishonest, as a basis for revoking his police certificate.

    Superior Court judgment reversed.

    Police Standards Council's revocation of officer's police certificate affirmed.


  5. Jennifer L. v. State, Dept. of Health and Social Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 28, 2015 357 P.3d 110 2015 WL 5062023


    FAMILY LAW - Child Protection. Standing master's order that children should be returned to parents was not effective until judicially reviewed.

    Synopsis

    Background: After Office of Children's Services (OCS) took three minor children into emergency custody, a standing master determined that no probable cause existed and recommended that children be returned to mother's custody. Following remand from the Supreme Court, 2014 WL 1888190, the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Aniak, Douglas Blankenship, J., rejected recommendation and determined that probable cause existed. Mother appealed and Superior Court dismissed underlying case before State could file brief.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:


    1. public interest exception to mootness doctrine applied, and

    2. standing master's order that children should be returned to parents was not effective until judicially reviewed.

    Affirmed.


  6. Hertz v. Schmidt

    Supreme Court of Alaska. December 23, 2015 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2015 WL 9393564


    LITIGATION - Limitations. Res judicata barred parolee's civil claims against the Department of Corrections, the Executive Director of the Board of Parole, and the Board.

    Synopsis

    Background: Parolee brought action against the Commissioner of the Department of Corrections, the Executive Director of the Board of Parole, and the Board, seeking injunctive relief and damages. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Patrick J. McKay, J., granted the State's motion to dismiss, and parolee appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. the two-year statute of limitations that applied to parolee's claims began to run on the date parolee was released subject to the mandatory parole conditions the board had placed on him;

    2. the continuing violations doctrine did not operate to extend the two year statute of limitations;

    3. parolee's claim was barred by res judicata;

    4. parolee's claim that his post-conviction relief counsel was allegedly ineffective did not operate to bar the application of res judicata; and

    5. the Superior Court did not abuse its discretion in awarding state attorney fees. Affirmed.


  7. Duenas-Rendon v. Wells Fargo Bank, N.A.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 14, 2015 354 P.3d 1037 2015 WL 4774463


    REAL PROPERTY - Mortgages and Deeds of Trust. Mortgagee did not waive right to foreclose by accepting monthly payments after notice of mortgagor's default was recorded.

    Synopsis

    Background: Mortgagor brought breach of contract action against mortgagee, alleging that its foreclosure on her home violated terms of contract. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, John Suddock, J., granted summary judgment for mortgagee. Mortgagor appealed. Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

    1. mortgagee did not waive its right to foreclose, and

    2. mortgagor's pending discovery motion was moot. Affirmed.


  8. Bulger-Post v. Post

Supreme Court of Alaska. April 08, 2015 Not Reported in P.3d 2015 WL 1605163



FAMILY LAW - Spousal Support. An award of spousal support to wife was necessary to fairly allocate the economic impact of the parties' divorce.

Synopsis

Background: After the parties separated, and property division was filed in legal separation proceeding, husband filed a complaint for divorce. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Mark Rindner, J., denied wife's motion for relief from property division judgment. Wife appealed.

Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

  1. res judicata barred wife's motion for relief from property distribution judgment, and

  2. an award of spousal support to wife was necessary to fairly allocate the economic impact of the parties' divorce.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded. Winfree, J., filed a dissenting opinion.


44. Hutton v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. June 05, 2015 350 P.3d 793 2015 WL 3535199


CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Jury. Defendant's waiver of his right to a jury trial on the charge of weapons misconduct in the third degree was constitutionally invalid.

Synopsis

Background: Defendant was convicted in the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Patrick J. McKay and Jack W. Smith, JJ., of weapons misconduct. Defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, Bolger, J., 305 P.3d 364, affirmed, and defendant petitioned for further review.

Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

  1. the Court of Appeals should have applied the standard for mixed questions of law and fact when reviewing whether defendant made a constitutionally valid waiver of his right to a jury trial, and

  2. defendant's jury waiver was invalid.

Court of Appeals' decision reversed, and remanded to the Superior Court.


  1. McGee v. Alaska Bar Ass'n

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 24, 2015 353 P.3d 350 2015 WL 4497958


    LEGAL SERVICES - Discipline. Bar counsel's decision to close complainant's grievance without a formal investigation was not arbitrary or capricious.

    Synopsis

    Background: After ethics grievance was filed against lawyer, and bar counsel determined that a formal investigation was unwarranted and closed the file, the complainant sought review of the decision. [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that bar counsel's decision to close complainant's grievance without a formal investigation was not arbitrary or capricious.

    Relief denied.


  2. Remy M. v. State, Dept. of Health and Social Services

Supreme Court of Alaska. August 14, 2015 356 P.3d 285 2015 WL 4774390


FAMILY LAW - Child Protection. Even if father had same right as criminal defendant to make the final decision whether to testify, he did not establish any violation of that right in termination of parental rights action.

Synopsis

Background: Father appealed from decision of the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Bethel, Beverly Cutler, Judge pro tem, terminating his parental rights.

[Holding:] The Supreme Court held that , even if father had the same right as a criminal defendant to make the final decision whether to testify, he did not establish any violation of that right.

Affirmed.


47. In re Ivy

Supreme Court of Alaska. May 01, 2015 350 P.3d 758 2015 WL 1958531


LEGAL SERVICES - Discipline. Rules relating to conduct of a lawyer serving as an advocate did not apply to attorney's misconduct in her personal capacity.

Synopsis

Background: Attorney disciplinary proceeding was brought.

Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

  1. sufficient circumstantial evidence established that attorney knew her testimony at deposition and disciplinary hearing was false, and

  2. rules of professional conduct relating to conduct of a lawyer serving as an advocate did not apply to attorney's misconduct in her personal capacity.

Remanded for reconsideration of sanctions.


  1. Becky H. v. Martin G.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 15, 2015 Not Reported in P.3d 2015 WL 4387736


    FAMILY LAW - Adoption. Existence of protective order restricting mother's visitation with child did not lead to conclusion that mother's failure to communicate was not willful for purposes of adoption statute.

    Synopsis

    Background: Paternal grandparents filed adoption petition. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Sen K. Tan and William F. Morse, JJ., granted adoption over mother's objection, and mother appealed.

    Holding: The Supreme Court held that existence of domestic violence protective order restricting mother's visitation with child did not, as a matter of law, lead to the conclusion that mother's resulting failure to communicate with child was not willful and was justified for purposes of adoption statute.

    Affirmed.


  2. Jay W. v. Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. September 28, 2015 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2015 WL 13951383


    Jay W. appeals the superior court's termination of his parental rights to his two Indian children. First, he argues that the superior court erred in finding that the children were in need of aid due to abandonment. Second, he argues that the superior court erred in finding beyond a reasonable doubt that Jay's continued custody of the...



  3. Alaska Commercial Fishermen's Memorial in Juneau v. City and Borough of Juneau

    Supreme Court of Alaska. September 25, 2015 357 P.3d 1172 2015 WL 5655710


    LITIGATION - Declaratory Judgment. Nonprofit's' contention that city could not legally construct dock on state-owned land was not ripe for adjudication under declaratory judgment statute.

    Synopsis

    Background: Nonprofit organization filed suit to enjoin construction of dock before state-owned submerged lands were transferred to city. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Louis J. Menendez, J., denied nonprofit's motions for injunctive and declaratory relief, denied motions to amend and for a continuance to conduct discovery, and granted city's motion to dismiss nonprofit's claims.

    Nonprofit appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

    1. nonprofit's' contention that city could not legally construct the dock was not ripe for adjudication under declaratory judgment statute;

    2. city's alleged failure to own the land was not actionable as trespass; and

    3. nonprofit's' proposed amendment to complaint was futile. Affirmed.


  4. Thomas G. v. Sonya G.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 24, 2015 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2015 WL 3935903


    FAMILY LAW - Child Custody. Court did not abuse its discretion in awarding wife sole legal custody and primary physical custody of child.

    Synopsis

    Background: Parties filed a petition for dissolution of their marriage. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Kenai, Carl Bauman, J., granted wife's request for sole legal custody and primary physical custody of the couple's minor child, and husband appealed.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court held that superior court did not abuse its discretion in awarding wife sole legal custody and primary physical custody of child.

    Affirmed.


  5. Courtenay V. v. State, Dept. of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. November 18, 2015 Not Reported in P.3d 2015 WL 7360079


    FAMILY LAW - Child Protection. Trial court did not plainly err in failing to consider Indian child's aunt as potential Indian custodian.

    Synopsis

    Background: In child protection proceeding involving Indian child under the Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA), the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Bethany Harbison, J., terminated mother's parental rights. Mother appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. mother waived challenge to termination of her parental rights on basis of child's alleged placement with Indian custodian, and

    2. trial court did not plainly err in failing to consider child's aunt as potential Indian custodian for child. Affirmed.


  6. Beals v. Beals

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 25, 2015 Not Reported in P.3d 2015 WL 1394674


    FAMILY LAW - Child Custody. Court did not abuse its discretion in allowing the children to relocate to Anchorage with ex-wife.

    Synopsis

    Background: Ex-wife, who wished to relocate to Anchorage for employment-related reasons, filed motion to modify the physical custody arrangement so the children could move with her to Anchorage. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eric A. Aarseth, J., ruled that the children could move to Anchorage with ex-wife, and ex-husband appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. trial court did not clearly err by finding that ex-wife's move to Anchorage had proper motive, and

    2. superior court did not abuse its discretion in allowing the children to relocate to Anchorage with ex-wife.

    Affirmed.


  7. Provost v. Dooley

Supreme Court of Alaska. February 18, 2015 Not Reported in P.3d 2015 WL 731450


FAMILY LAW - Child Custody. Custody modification case would be remanded to trial court for findings on child's best interests.

Synopsis

Background: Ex-husband moved to modify custody, seeking primary physical custody of children. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Valdez, Daniel Schally, Judge pro tem, granted ex-husband's request for custody modification, gave him primary custody of daughter, and ex-wife retained primary physical custody of son. Ex-wife appealed pro se.


[Holding:] The Supreme Court held that custody modification case would be remanded to trial court for findings on child's best interests.

Remanded.


55. Wagner v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. April 24, 2015 347 P.3d 109 2015 WL 1874583


CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Confessions. Defendant was required to testify before being entitled to claim improper impeachment on appeal.

Synopsis

Background: Defendant was convicted in the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Michael L. Wolverton, J., of first degree murder. The Court of Appeals, Coats, J., 2013 WL 6576741, affirmed. Defendant filed petition for hearing in the Supreme Court.

Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

  1. defendant was required to testify before being entitled to claim improper impeachment on appeal, and

  2. the Superior Court's denial of defendant's in limine motion to suppress the use of statement did not preclude him from vindicating his constitutional claims with regard to his right to testify, his right to due process, or the privilege against self-incrimination.

Affirmed.


56. DeVilbiss v. Matanuska-Susitna Borough

Supreme Court of Alaska. August 28, 2015 356 P.3d 290 2015 WL 5061501


GOVERNMENT - Public Improvements. Validity of a tax does not depend on whether a taxpayer receives a special benefit.

Synopsis

Background: Following borough assembly's denial of property owner's request that they remove his property from road service area, property owner filed a complaint against borough, contesting validity of road service tax. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer County, Eric Smith, J., granted borough's cross-motion for summary judgment. Property owner appealed.

Holdings: The Supreme Court, Fabe, C.J., held that:

  1. borough was not required to exclude owner's property from road service area;

  2. road service tax was not an invalid special assessment;

  3. borough was authorized to provide special services within road service area, thus it could levy taxes to finance those services;

  4. validity of a tax does not depend on whether a taxpayer receives a special benefit; and

  5. property owner had sufficient economic incentive to bring his claim, entitling borough to attorney fees.

Affirmed.


57. George v. State


Supreme Court of Alaska. December 18, 2015 362 P.3d 1026 2015 WL 9257675


CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Sex Offenses. Evidence was not sufficient for sexual abuse of a minor conviction related to digital penetration of a child during victim's third-grade year.

Synopsis

Background: Defendant was convicted following jury trial in the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Glenallen, Eric Smith, J., of sexual abuse of a minor, among other charges. Defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, 2014 WL 2937874, affirmed. Defendant appealed and petitioned for hearing regarding sufficiency of the evidence supporting the conviction for one of the counts. The Supreme Court granted the petition.

Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, C.J., held that:

  1. evidence was not sufficient for sexual abuse of a minor conviction related to digital penetration of victim child during her third-grade year, and

  2. evidence did not support sexual abuse of a minor conviction based on an alleged continuing course of conduct theory.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.


58. Caroline J. v. Theodore J.

Supreme Court of Alaska. August 28, 2015 354 P.3d 1085 2015 WL 5062047


FAMILY LAW - Child Custody. Shared physical and joint legal custody of minor children was in best interest of children.

Synopsis

Background: Following parties' divorce, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, Vanessa White, J., awarded mother and father shared physical and joint legal custody of minor children. Mother appealed.

Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

  1. father rebutted statutory domestic violence presumption;

  2. trial court was permitted to consider mother's parental alienation conduct; and

  3. shared custody was in best interest of children. Affirmed.


  1. Yould v. Yould

    Supreme Court of Alaska. November 12, 2015 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2015 WL 7201238


    FAMILY LAW - Judgment. Court's did not violate imprisoned wife's due process rights by entering default judgment after she refused to attend divorce trial telephonically.

    Synopsis

    Background: Husband filed for divorce after wife pled guilty to a number of federal crimes involving fraud, and wife received several continuances to allow her to prepare for trial from prison. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Patrick J. McKay, J., granted husband's motion for default when wife refused to come to telephone at time of trial, and entered divorce decree and property


    division. Wife appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. the Superior Court did not violate wife's due process rights, and

    2. the trial judge was not biased against wife. Affirmed.


  2. In re Reid K.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. September 25, 2015 357 P.3d 776 2015 WL 5655619


    CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Mental Commitment. Public interest exception to mootness doctrine did not apply to permit appellate review of expired civil commitment order.

    Synopsis

    Background: After holding a contested evidentiary hearing, the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Paul R. Lyle, J., entered 30day involuntary commitment order. Committee appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Fabe, C.J., held that:

    1. public interest exception to mootness doctrine did not apply;

    2. collateral consequences exception to mootness doctrine did not apply; and

    3. best practice was for state to move to dismiss based on mootness before proceeding to appellate briefing.

    Appeal dismissed.


    61. Oakly Enterprises, LLC v. NPI, LLC

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 28, 2015 354 P.3d 1073 2015 WL 5061944


    ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - Hazardous Substances. Court properly granted construction company's post-trial motion for contribution, in landowner's action to recover hazardous waste cleanup costs.

    Synopsis

    Background: Landowners sued construction company seeking damages in excess of $150,000 for the contamination of their properties, costs of cleanup, and rent. Following a jury trial on company's liability, the company filed a post-trial motion for contribution, which the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, Kari Kristiansen, J., granted. Landowners appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

    1. jury's finding that landowner could have avoided certain damages with reasonable effort was not an apportionment of damages;

    2. court acted within its authority when it made equitable findings during contribution phase;

    3. court did not abuse its discretion by excluding a consultant's report on environmental condition of company's property three years after diesel spill at issue; and

    4. court did not abuse its discretion in its award of attorney fees against landowner. Affirmed.


    1. Faye H. v. James B.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. April 17, 2015 348 P.3d 876 2015 WL 1743199



      FAMILY LAW - Child Custody. Court failed to make sufficient findings regarding whether domestic violence triggered statutory rebuttable presumption.

      Synopsis

      Background: Father filed complaint seeking sole legal and primary physical custody of minor child. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Kenai, Charles T. Huguelet, J., awarded parents joint physical custody. Mother appealed.

      [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that trial court failed to make sufficient findings regarding whether father's domestic violence triggered statutory rebuttable presumption.

      Remanded.


    2. Devine v. Great Divide Ins. Co.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. May 15, 2015 350 P.3d 782 2015 WL 2328729


      INSURANCE - Liability. Employer engendered, exacerbated, or facilitated worker's assault on another worker at job site and thus employee exclusion precluded coverage for injuries.

      Synopsis

      Background: Insurer brought action against worker who was injured when he was assaulted by another worker at a job site, seeking a declaratory judgment that commercial general liability (CGL) insurance policy's employee exclusion clause precluded coverage for worker's personal injury suit for negligence against its insured, a concrete-pouring company. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Patrick J. McKay, J., 2013 WL 7206850, entered summary judgment in favor of insurer.

      Worker appealed.

      [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that company engendered, exacerbated, or facilitated worker's assault, and thus injuries arose out of and in the course of worker's employment within meaning of exclusion.

      Affirmed.


    3. Wells v. Barile

      Supreme Court of Alaska. October 16, 2015 358 P.3d 583 2015 WL 6087203


      FAMILY LAW - Child Custody. Modification of child custody order from shared physical custody to sole legal and primary custody to father was in child's best interests.

      Synopsis

      Background: Divorced father moved to modify child custody order, alleging substantial change in circumstances and seeking sole legal and primary physical custody of child. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, Vanessa White, J., granted motion and ordered divorced mother to reimburse father for half of their child's Permanent Fund Dividends (PFDs). Mother appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

      1. modification of custody order was in child's best interests;

      2. father was entitled to child support; but

      3. trial court's determination that child's orthodontics expenses were ineligible for reimbursement by


      father was abuse of discretion.

      Affirmed in part; reversed and remanded in part.


    4. Sylvia L. v. State, Dept. of Health and Social Services, Office of Children's Services

      Supreme Court of Alaska. February 20, 2015 343 P.3d 425 2015 WL 720524


      FAMILY LAW - Child Protection. The Office of Children's Services (OCS) made reasonable efforts to reunify mother with two of her children.

      Synopsis

      Background: Office of Children's Services (OCS) petitioned to terminate mother's parental rights with regard to one Indian and two non-Indian children. Following a bench trial, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Patrick J. McKay, J., terminated mother's parental rights with regard to the three children, and she appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

      1. any error in allowing the OCS's tardy amendment of its petition to terminate mother's parental rights with regard to one Indian and two non Indian children to include allegations of mother's mental illness, was harmless;

      2. the OCS made reasonable efforts to reunify mother with two of her non-Indian children;

      3. the OCS made active, but unsuccessful, efforts to provide remedial services and rehabilitative programs designed to prevent the breakup of the Indian family;

      4. the Superior Court's decision to allow the testimony of the OCS's expert on substance abuse and mental health did not constitute an abuse of discretion; and

      5. the OCS's Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 (ICWA)-qualified expert's testimony was sufficiently grounded in the facts and issues of the case to be admissible.

      Affirmed.


    5. Susan M. v. Paul H.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. December 11, 2015 362 P.3d 460 2015 WL 8521295


      FAMILY LAW - Visitation. Trial court, in denying motion for sanctions, properly found that father had not acted willfully and without just excuse in refusing visitation.

      Synopsis

      Background: Following parties' divorce, they entered into a settlement agreement whereby father retained sole legal and physical custody of children, with mother having supervised visitation only, and allowing father to relocate to California with the children. Mother moved to sanction father for wrongfully denying her visitation and to enjoin father from relocating. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Frank A. Pfiffner, J., denied both motions. Mother appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

      1. trial court, in denying motion for sanctions, properly found that father had not acted willfully and without just excuse, and

      2. trial court was not required to conduct a best-interest analysis in denying mother's motion to enjoin father from relocating.

      Affirmed.



    6. Andrea C. v. Marcus K.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. August 07, 2015 355 P.3d 521 2015 WL 4708478


      FAMILY LAW - Child Custody. Best interests of children warranted grant of primary physical and sole legal custody to father.

      Synopsis

      Background: Mother filed child custody modification request based on impending relocation. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Patrick J. McKay, J., awarded father primary physical and sole legal custody of two minor children. Mother appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

      1. offensive collateral estoppel did not apply to preclude father from asserting that he had not recently committed new crime of domestic violence, and

      2. best interests of children warranted grant of primary physical and sole legal custody to father. Affirmed.


    7. RBG Bush Planes, LLC v. Kirk

    Supreme Court of Alaska. January 09, 2015 340 P.3d 1056 2015 WL 122340


    GOVERNMENT - Elections. Plaintiff challenging campaign finance investigation failed to show that exhaustion of administrative remedies was certain to be futile.

    Synopsis

    Background: Plaintiff brought action against chairperson and executive director of the Alaska Public Offices Commission, alleging his constitutional rights were being violated with regard to a campaign finance complaint due to bias on the part of the Commission. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Kevin M. Saxby, J., 2013 WL 3288053, granted summary judgment in favor of defendants, and plaintiff appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

    1. while plaintiff was not required to exhaust his state administrative remedies before filing a federal 1983 claim in state court, he was required to exhaust his administrative remedies with respect to his state constitutional claims;

    2. plaintiff was required to first exhaust his administrative remedies by pursuing the Administrative Procedure Act's (APA) procedure for disqualification before seeking to enjoin the Commission from proceeding with its investigation;

    3. the Superior Court did not abuse its discretion when it held plaintiff failed to show that exhaustion of administrative remedies was certain to be futile;

    4. plaintiff's federal due process claim was not ripe; and

    5. the Superior Court did not abuse its discretion by failing to consider and grant plaintiff's request to conduct additional discovery.

    Affirmed.


    69. Jordan J. v. State, Dept. of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. April 29, 2015 Not Reported in P.3d 2015 WL 1985060


    FAMILY LAW - Child Protection. Termination of mother's parental rights was in children's best interests.

    Synopsis

    Background: Office of Children's Services (OCS) sought to terminate parental rights of parents of minor children in OCS custody. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Paul E. Olson, J., terminated parental rights. Mother appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. evidence supported findings that mother did not adequately address her behaviors that placed children at risk of harm;

    2. evidence was sufficient to support finding that OCS made reasonable efforts to reunite mother with her children;

    3. termination of mother's parental rights was in children's best interests;

    4. failure of mother's attorney to present comprehensive closing argument did not amount to deficient performance; and

    5. failure of mother's attorney to present closing argument did not prejudice mother. Affirmed.


    1. Manning v. State, Dept. of Fish & Game

      Supreme Court of Alaska. August 28, 2015 355 P.3d 530 2015 WL 5061353


      ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - Game. Board of Game's calculations of amount of caribou reasonably necessary for subsistence was not unconstitutional.

      Synopsis

      Background: Hunter challenged Board of Game regulations concerning subsistence caribou hunting in a game management unit and sought a judicially imposed public reprimand of an assistant attorney general representing the Board. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Kenai, Anna Moran and Charles T. Huguelet, JJ., dismissed claim against assistant attorney general, entered summary judgment upholding the regulations, and awarded partial attorney fees to State and an intervenor defendant. Hunter appealed.

      Holdings: On rehearing, the Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

      1. Board's calculations of amount of caribou reasonably necessary for subsistence was not unconstitutional;

      2. managing caribou hunt under Tier I of statute was consistent with statute, reasonable, and not arbitrary; and

      3. remand was required for determination of attorney fees. Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.


    2. Stavenjord v. Schmidt

      Supreme Court of Alaska. March 20, 2015 344 P.3d 826 2015 WL 1268091



      CIVIL RIGHTS - Religion. Inmate was not required to prove elements of Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act claim to defeat summary judgment motion.

      Synopsis

      Background: Inmate brought action against Department of Corrections and various officials, alleging violations of Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act (RLUIPA). The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Mark Rindner, J., granted summary judgment in favor of Department and officials, and inmate appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

      1. inmate was not required to prove elements of his RLUIPA claim to defeat Department's motion for summary judgment;

      2. genuine issue of material fact existed as to sincerity of inmate's religious beliefs and whether he had ulterior, non-religious motives for his requests for religious accommodations, precluding summary judgment on the RLUIPA claim; and

      3. inmate was not required to show that his personal religious beliefs were consistent with beliefs of other Buddhists, or that prayer shawl and Kosher diet he had requested were necessary for practice of his religion.

      Reversed and remanded.


    3. Trask v. Borough

      Supreme Court of Alaska. April 01, 2015 Not Reported in P.3d 2015 WL 1509772


      LITIGATION - Appeals. Homeowner who brought 1983 claim in connection with borough's enforcement of local ordinance waived appellate review of ordinance's constitutionality.

      Synopsis

      Background: Borough brought action against homeowner to enforce a local ordinance regulating roof signs in connection with a biblical message painted on her roof, and homeowner counterclaimed for relief under 1983. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Ketchikan, Trevor N. Stephens, J., dismissed homeowner's claim. Homeowner appealed. The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., 253 P.3d 616, reversed and remanded. On remand, the Superior Court denied homeowner's summary judgment motion and dismissed her claim. Homeowner appealed.

      Holding: The Supreme Court held that homeowner waived appellate review of constitutionality of ordinance.

      Affirmed.

      Stowers, J. dissented and filed opinion in which Winfree, J., joined.


    4. Diana P. v. State, Dept. of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

      Supreme Court of Alaska. September 01, 2015 355 P.3d 541 2015 WL 5247084


      NATIVE AMERICANS - Child Welfare. Substantial-harm requirement to support termination of parental rights may be met by a combination of lay testimony and other evidence.



      Synopsis

      Background: Office of Children's Services (OCS) petitioned to terminate mother's parental rights to her four daughters, all Native children, under the Indian Child Welfare Act. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Bethany S. Harbison, J., terminated mother's parental rights, and mother appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

      1. evidence was sufficient to establish beyond a reasonable doubt that placing the children in mother's custody would likely put the children at risk of serious harm, and

      2. as a matter of first impression, under the Act, when the basis for termination is culturally neutral, the substantial-harm requirement may be met by a combination of lay testimony and other evidence that the parent's conduct is harmful to the child, as well as expert testimony that the conduct is likely to continue.

      Affirmed.


    5. Crawford v. Avila

      Supreme Court of Alaska. May 27, 2015 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2015 WL 3477237


      COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Developer could not maintain second breach of contract claim against owner on behalf of LLC after first action in his personal capacity was dismissed.

      Synopsis

      Background: Real estate developer, on behalf of limited liability company (LLC) that signed development contract, filed breach of contract action against property owner, and sought to vacate settlement agreement from earlier lawsuit brought in developer's personal capacity. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Andrew Guidi, J., upheld settlement agreement, entered judgment in favor of property owner, and assessed enhanced attorney's fees against LLC. Developer appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

      1. execution and sale proceedings could not be collaterally attacked;

      2. developer was not entitled to maintain second claim for breach of contract against property owner on behalf of LLC; and

      3. trial court acted within its discretion in awarding enhanced attorney fees to property owner. Affirmed.


    6. Norris v. Norris

      Supreme Court of Alaska. March 27, 2015 345 P.3d 924 2015 WL 1393384


      FAMILY LAW - Child Custody. Evidence was sufficient to support a finding that Mississippi, rather than Alaska, had subject matter jurisdiction over child custody matter.

      Synopsis

      Background: Wife brought divorce action against husband. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Paul R. Lyle, J., dismissed the action, concluding Mississippi had exclusive jurisdiction under the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement Act (UCCJEA). Wife appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:


      1. evidence was sufficient to support a finding that child did not have a home state for purposes of establishing jurisdiction in a child custody proceeding;

      2. evidence was sufficient to support a finding that Mississippi, rather than Alaska, had subject matter jurisdiction; and

      3. with regard to wife's motion for reconsideration, the Superior Court did not abuse its discretion in holding an evidentiary hearing or ruling on the motion more than 30 days after wife filed her response brief.

      Affirmed.


    7. Municipality of Anchorage v. Stenseth

      Supreme Court of Alaska. November 25, 2015 361 P.3d 898 2015 WL 7709448


      LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Substantial evidence existed to support finding that a binding settlement contract was formed between claimant and former employer

      Synopsis

      Background: Former employer, a municipality, appealed dismissal of its fraud petition against workers' compensation claimant. The Workers' Compensation Appeals Commission, Laurence Keyes, Commission Chair, affirmed the Workers' Compensation Board's decision, and former employer appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

      1. substantial evidence existed to support the Board's finding that a binding settlement contract was formed;

      2. an e-mail was insufficient to demonstrate an unequivocal acceptance of claimant's offer, as required to form a new contract, and to abrogate an existing settlement agreement;

      3. statutory provision that permitted a claimant and his employer to settle a claim for injury or death and required the parties to an agreement to file it with the Board in a form prescribed by the director did not apply to a settlement agreement entered into by claimant and his former employer; and

      4. equitable estoppel applied to bar former employer from denying the authority of its agents to settle its fraud case.

      Affirmed.


    8. Novak v. Novak

      Supreme Court of Alaska. August 26, 2015 Not Reported in P.3d 2015 WL 5086385


      FAMILY LAW - Spousal Support. Court did not abuse its discretion by awarding wife spousal support.

      Synopsis

      Background: Wife filed for divorce. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Patrick J. McKay, J., awarded wife the family home and temporary spousal support and ordered husband to pay child support, and he appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

      1. trial court's classification of wife's second loan as marital debt was clearly erroneous;

      2. trial court did not abuse its discretion by awarding wife spousal support; and

      3. trial court did not abuse its discretion by awarding wife attorney fees.


      Affirmed in part, reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.


    9. Rodriguez v. Alaska State Com'n For Human Rights

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 14, 2015 354 P.3d 380 2015 WL 4774430


    LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Airline employee alleging race discrimination failed to rebut employer's legitimate reason for hiring less-senior employee.

    Synopsis

    Background: Complainant, a Hispanic airline employee, filed complaint with Alaska State Commission for Human Rights (ASCHR), alleging race-based employment discrimination. Commission dismissed the complaint without a hearing, upon finding that allegations were not supported by substantial evidence. Complainant appealed pro se. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Gregory Miller, J., affirmed. Complainant appealed pro se.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

    1. complainant waived any challenge to ASCHR's conclusion regarding untimeliness of his complaint with respect to employer's purported deletion of his position as basis for discrimination claim;

    2. employer met burden of providing evidence of legitimate, nondiscriminatory reason for hiring less-senior Caucasian employee over complainant for temporary assignment after complainant and others were furloughed; and

    3. complainant failed to meet burden of rebutting employer's legitimate non-discriminatory reason for hiring less-senior Caucasian employee for temporary assignment.

    Affirmed.


    79. Payton S. v. State, Dept. of Health and Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 01, 2015 349 P.3d 162 2015 WL 1958674


    FAMILY LAW - Child Protection. Even though the court erred by entering adjudication and disposition order when parents lacked proper notice of the hearing, the error did not violate parents' due process rights.

    Synopsis

    Background: The Office of Children's Services (OCS) sought to terminate parental rights to Indian children. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Bethel, Dwayne W. McConnell, J., terminated parental rights. Parents appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

    1. even though the trial court erred by entering an adjudication and disposition order when the parents lacked proper notice of the hearing, the error did not violate parents' due process rights as it did not affect the outcome of the case;

    2. evidence supported finding that children were children in need of aid (CINA);

    3. evidence supported finding that parents had failed to remedy the conduct that placed the children at substantial risk of harm;

    4. evidence supported finding that Indian children were likely to suffer serious emotional or physical harm if returned to their parents' custody; and

    5. the trial court's determination that termination of mother and father's parental rights was in the best


    interests of their Indian children was not clearly erroneous. Affirmed.


    80. City of Hooper Bay v. Bunyan

    Supreme Court of Alaska. September 11, 2015 359 P.3d 972 2015 WL 5306203


    TORTS - Negligence. Intoxicated prisoner's suicide while in police custody was reasonably foreseeable.

    Synopsis

    Background: Mother of intoxicated detainee who committed suicide while detained in a holding cell brought wrongful death action against city. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Bethel, Charles

    W. Ray, Jr., J., entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of mother. City appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Fabe, C.J., held that:

    1. city owed duty to protect detainee from unreasonable risks of harm;

    2. city was not entitled to qualified immunity for implementation of operational protocols;

    3. detainee's suicide was reasonably foreseeable;

    4. mother was financially dependent on detainee;

    5. expert testimony concerning economic loss was not subject to heightened admissibility requirements for scientific evidence;

    6. protective custody statutes did not require gross negligence in order to establish city's liability;

    7. jury instruction adequately included reasonable foreseeability requirement; and

    8. jury instructions impermissibly precluded possibility of allocation of fault. Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.


    1. McGlinchy v. State, Dept. of Natural Resources

      Supreme Court of Alaska. August 07, 2015 354 P.3d 1025 2015 WL 4708854


      REAL PROPERTY - Mineral Rights and Interests. Construction rock was not locatable and thus could not be permitted through mining law's location process.

      Synopsis

      Background: Construction company sought judicial review of Department of Natural Resources' denial of its permit application to mine a mineral deposit for use as construction rock. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Michael A. MacDonald, J., affirmed. Company appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

      1. constituent-minerals exception under Common Varieties Act did not apply;

      2. comparison mineral deposit sites used were reasonable;

      3. hearing officer had a reasonable basis to determine that the construction rock was a common variety stone under Common Varieties Act; and

      4. company received ample procedural due process. Affirmed.


    2. Haar v. State, Dept. of Admin., Div. of Motor Vehicles


      Supreme Court of Alaska. May 01, 2015 349 P.3d 173 2015 WL 1958696


      TRANSPORTATION - Motor Vehicles. Reasonable basis existed for agency's refusal to register vehicle described as electric car or customized golf cart as a low-speed vehicle.

      Synopsis

      Background: Owner sought to title and register vehicle described as an electric car or customized golf cart as a low-speed vehicle. The Department of Administration, Division of Motor Vehicles (DMV) refused to title or register vehicle. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Patrick S. Hammers, Judge pro tem., affirmed. Owner appealed.

      [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that substantial evidence supported DMV's finding that vehicle was not roadworthy as a low-speed vehicle, and thus a reasonable basis existed for DMV's refusal to issue title to or register vehicle.

      Affirmed.


    3. Bush v. Elkins

      Supreme Court of Alaska. January 23, 2015 342 P.3d 1245 2015 WL 302961


      TORTS - Tortious Interference. Injured automobile passenger's father could not maintain contractual interference claim against automobile insurer.

      Synopsis

      Background: Injured automobile passenger and his family brought action against, among others, driver of the automobile and automobile insurer arising out of a single-vehicle accident. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Kenai, Anna Moran, J., dismissed the intentional infliction of emotional distress claim asserted by passenger's father against insurer, then awarded summary judgment against father and removed him from the caption of the case. The Superior Court subsequently rejected father's proposed amended complaint and, after dismissal of the remaining claims in the action pursuant to a settlement, entered final judgment against father and awarded insurer prevailing party attorney fees against him. Father appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Fabe, C.J., held that:

      1. father could not maintain a contractual interference claim against insurer, and thus proposed amendment to complaint to assert such a claim was futile, but

      2. trial court could not award insurer prevailing party attorney fees without informing father that he was permitted to respond to insurer's motion.

      Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.


    4. Brandner v. Bateman

      Supreme Court of Alaska. May 15, 2015 349 P.3d 1068 2015 WL 2328730


      HEALTH - Peer Review. Physicians on executive committee and hearing panel who recommended termination of a physician's hospital privileges were immune from suit.

      Synopsis

      Background: Following termination of his hospital privileges, physician brought action against


      physicians on medical staff executive committee and fair hearing panel that recommended termination, claiming breach of contract and denial of due process. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage County, Patrick J. McKay, J., 2014 WL 8396238, entered summary judgment in favor of physicians on committee and panel. Physician appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

      1. as a matter of first impression, committee and panel made reasonable efforts to ascertain facts upon which recommendation was based, as factor in determining whether physicians were immune from suit;

      2. committee and panel acted in the reasonable belief that recommendation was warranted by the facts, as factor in determining immunity; and

      3. actions of committee and panel were not motivated by malice, and thus physicians were immune from suit.

      Affirmed.


    5. Jacko v. State, Pebble Ltd. Partnership

      Supreme Court of Alaska. July 17, 2015 353 P.3d 337 2015 WL 4381086


      GOVERNMENT - Municipalities. Borough's clean water initiative was impliedly preempted by state law conferring gatekeeper permitting authority to DNR.

      Synopsis

      Background: State and copper mining company sued borough for declaratory and injunctive relief, contending that borough's clean water initiative exceeded its power to legislate on matters governing land use permit requirements. Initiative sponsors intervened. The Superior Court, 2014 WL 8396243, John Suddock, J., granted summary judgment for state and company and enjoined borough from enforcing the initiative. Initiative sponsors appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

      1. matter was ripe for review, and

      2. initiative was impliedly preempted by state law conferring gatekeeper permitting authority to DNR. Affirmed.


    6. Theresa L. v. State, Dept. of Health & Social Services

      Supreme Court of Alaska. August 07, 2015 353 P.3d 831 2015 WL 4708858


      FAMILY LAW - Child Protection. Finding that children were in need of aid on the basis of mental injury was clearly erroneous.

      Synopsis

      Background: Office of Children's Services petitioned to terminate mother's parental rights. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Eric Smith, J., terminated mother's parental rights. Mother appealed.

      [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that finding that children were in need of aid on the basis of mental injury was clearly erroneous.

      Reversed and remanded.


    7. Kinnan v. Sitka Counseling

      Supreme Court of Alaska. April 17, 2015 349 P.3d 153 2015 WL 1743210


      LEGAL SERVICES - Attorney-Client Relationship. Pro se plaintiff was not entitled to a continuance for the purposed of finding and obtaining counsel to represent him.

      Synopsis

      Background: Participant in substance abuse treatment program who was asked to vacate residence operated by counseling service after program funding ended brought action against the service and two of its staff members, alleging several torts based on defendants' conduct when attempting to remove him from the premises, violations of the Landlord Tenant Act, and civil rights violations, and the counseling service counterclaimed for forcible entry and detainer. Following a bench trial, the Superior Court, First Judicial District, Sitka, David V. George, J., ruled in favor of defendants, and participant appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

      1. participant, a pro se plaintiff, was not entitled to a continuance for the purpose of finding and obtaining counsel to represent him;

      2. any error by the Superior Court in excluding the testimony of any witnesses other than the parties as a discovery sanction was harmless;

      3. affidavits offered by participant at bench trial concerning his mental health and the use of the residence as supportive housing for the chronically mentally ill constituted inadmissible hearsay evidence;

      4. the Superior Court did not commit plain error in allowing and facilitating cross-examination regarding participant's mental disability; and

      5. neither the judge's rulings nor his conduct created an appearance of bias. Affirmed.


    8. Ackels v. Krause

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 01, 2015 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2015 WL 4064710


    LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Trial court did not lose subject-matter jurisdiction upon filing of administrative appeal in a related case.

    Synopsis

    Background: Recorder of four mining claims appealed Department of Natural Resources' (DNR) rejection of recorder's four amendments to the claims after being contacted by competing claimant involved in other litigation with recorder, and recorder named competing claimant in the appeal. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Paul R. Lyle, J., dismissed recorder's claims against competing claimant as barred by res judicata, and dismissed recorder's claims against DNR as moot. Recorder appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. the Superior Court could rely on previous decision in related case;

    2. res judicata barred recorder's claims against competing claimant;

    3. administrative appeal against DNR was moot; and

    4. public interest exception to mootness did not apply. Affirmed.

    See also 299 P.3d 148


    89. Richardson v. Municipality of Anchorage

    Supreme Court of Alaska. October 30, 2015 360 P.3d 79 2015 WL 6597852


    CIVIL RIGHTS - Arrest and Detention. Separation from legal documents while incarcerated did not equitably toll two-year statute of limitations for unlawful arrest and other claims.

    Synopsis

    Background: Arrestee brought actions against retail store employee who reported his alleged theft and police officers for obstruction of justice, extortion, trespass, unlawful arrest, and false imprisonment in connection with his arrest and alleged injuries from a police dog. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Catherine M. Easter and Mark Rindner, JJ., entered judgment in favor of employee and officers. Arrestee appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

    1. Supreme Court would review decision on motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim as having been converted to a summary judgment motion;

    2. discovery rule did not apply to toll two-year statute of limitations;

    3. genuine issues of material fact existed as to whether trial court effectively received complaint prior to date that limitations period ran;

    4. limitations period was not tolled due to arrestee's alleged mental incompetency;

    5. arrestee was not mentally incompetent at the time limitations period ran; and

    6. arrestee's separation from legal documents while incarcerated did not equitably toll limitations period.

    Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.


    90. State, Dept. of Health and Social Services, Div. of Public Assistance v. Gross


    Supreme Court of Alaska. April 24, 2015 347 P.3d 116 2015 WL 1874584


    GOVERNMENT - Public Assistance. Persons eligible for federal disability benefits who cannot perform other work in national economy could not be excluded from receipt of state interim assistance.

    Synopsis

    Background: Applicant for state benefits, which provided basic assistance while federal application for disability benefits was pending, sought review of denial of application for state benefits by Department of Health and Social Services. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Erin B. Marston, J., reversed. Department petitioned for review, which was granted.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

    1. substitution-of-judgment rather than reasonable basis standard applied in determining whether Department may definitionally exclude persons who are eligible for federal Supplemental Security Income (SSI) from eligibility for state benefits, and

    2. Department may not exclude from eligibility for state benefits entire category of persons eligible for SSI who cannot perform other work in the national economy.

    Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.


    91. Shirley M. v. State

    Supreme Court of Alaska. January 09, 2015 342 P.3d 1233 2015 WL 122378


    FAMILY LAW - Child Protection. Record in termination of parental rights case supported finding that mother failed to timely remedy her conduct.

    Synopsis

    Background: Office of Children's Services brought termination of parental rights proceedings against mother. Following trial, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Erin B. Marston, J., terminated mother's parental rights. Mother appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

    1. record supported trial court's findings that mother failed to timely remedy her conduct within a reasonable time;

    2. Office made reasonable efforts to reunite mother and child;

    3. termination of mother's parental rights was in the child's best interests; and

    4. record supported decision to place child with foster family, rather than with her great grandmother. Affirmed.


    92. Lieutenant Governor of State v. Alaska Fisheries Conservation Alliance, Inc.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. December 31, 2015 363 P.3d 105 2015 WL 9587544


    AGRICULTURE - Animals. Initiative to prohibit use of commercial set nets in nonsubsistence areas was a prohibited appropriation of state assets.

    Synopsis

    Background: Sponsors of initiative to prohibit use of commercial set net fishing in nonsubsistence areas filed complaint for declaratory judgment and injunctive relief after Lieutenant Governor declined to certify initiative. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Catherine M. Easter, J., 2014 WL 5782298, granted summary judgment in favor of sponsors. Lieutenant Governor appealed. [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that proposed initiative was a prohibited appropriation of public assets.

    Reversed.


    93. Geotek Alaska, Inc. v. Jacobs Engineering Group, Inc.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 14, 2015 354 P.3d 368 2015 WL 4774257


    TORTS - Negligence. General contractor did not owe sub-subcontractor a duty of care in tort to ensure it was paid by subcontractor.

    Synopsis

    Background: Sub-subcontractor sought payment directly from general contractor, after insolvent subcontractor failed to pay it for work performed, through a demand for arbitration. General contractor declined to participate. An arbitrator awarded damages to sub-subcontractor, who filed an action to confirm the award in superior court, and also brought a negligence claim against general contractor. The Superior Court, 2013 WL 10408620, Erin B. Marston, J., granted summary judgment to general


    contractor on both claims. Sub-subcontractor appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

    1. issue of general contractor's consent to arbitrate presented a question of arbitrability, properly decided by court, and

    2. general contractor did not owe sub-subcontractor a duty of care in tort to ensure it was paid by subcontractor.

    Affirmed.


    1. Matthew P. v. Gail S.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. August 28, 2015 354 P.3d 1044 2015 WL 5061439


      FAMILY LAW - Visitation. Superior Court adequately articulated a plan through which father could achieve unsupervised visitation with daughter.

      Synopsis

      Background: Father moved to modify child custody. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Louis J. Menendez, J., denied the request, and father appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

      1. Superior Court's evaluation of child's emotional needs, as a factor in determining whether shared physical custody was in child's best interests, was not an abuse of discretion;

      2. willingness and ability of each parent to facilitate and encourage a close and continuing relationship between the other parent and child favored mother, as factor in determining that a return to shared custody was not in child's best interest; and

      3. Superior Court adequately articulated a plan through which father could achieve unsupervised visitation with daughter.

      Affirmed.

      Fabe, C.J., filed dissenting opinion, joined by Maassen, J.


    2. Tagaban v. City of Pelican

      Supreme Court of Alaska. September 18, 2015 358 P.3d 571 2015 WL 5474352


      TAXATION - Collection. Statute governing enforcement of tax liens did not violate lienholder's due process interests by limiting its foreclosure notice requirement to property owners.

      Synopsis

      Background: Lienholder filed suit to challenge city's tax foreclosure sale on property in which he claimed an interest. Lienholder moved for summary judgment and city cross-moved. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Petersburg, William B. Carey, J., denied lienholder's motion and granted city's motion. Lienholder appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Fabe, C.J., held that:

      1. statute governing municipalities' enforcement of tax liens did not violate lienholder's due process interests by limiting its foreclosure notice requirement to property owners;

      2. because lienholder had actual knowledge of tax foreclosure during redemption period, and did not seek to redeem the property, he was precluded from raising a due process challenge to the redemption notice statute;

      3. prevailing party fees should not have been awarded for time city spent litigating lienholder's standing


        to sue as a class representative; and

      4. city could recover attorney fees under offer-of-judgment rule. Affirmed.


    3. Cooper v. Thompson

    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 26, 2015 353 P.3d 782 2015 WL 3930085


    TORTS - Evidence. Injured driver was not entitled to wholly exclude evidence of former girlfriend's domestic assaults, in action against at-fault driver for injuries.

    Synopsis

    Background: Injured driver filed suit against driver who caused accident and his employer for injuries allegedly sustained in accident. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Sen K. Tan, J., entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of injured driver. Parties appealed. The Supreme Court, 290 P.3d 393, affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded for new trial on compensatory damages.

    Following new trial, the Superior Court entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of injured driver. Employer appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Fabe, C.J., held that:

    1. employer was not required to join injured driver's former girlfriend to present evidence of domestic assault as alleged cause of injuries;

    2. evidence of domestic assaults was relevant;

    3. injured driver was not entitled to wholly exclude evidence of domestic assaults;

    4. trial court acted within its discretion in limiting biomechanics expert's testimony;

    5. any error in additional harm instruction did not prejudice employer; and

    6. trial court acted within its discretion in awarding injured driver attorney's fees and costs for continuance requested by employer.

    Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.


    97. Moore v. Moore

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 29, 2015 349 P.3d 1076 2015 WL 3452474


    FAMILY LAW - Visitation. Court acted within its discretion in declining to limit father's international visitation with child to Hague Convention signatories.

    Synopsis

    Background: Divorce proceedings involving child custody were instituted. Following bench trial, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Gregory Miller, J., granted sole legal and primary physical custody to mother, and awarded father unrestricted visitation, including visitation to foreign countries. Mother appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Fabe, C.J., held that:

    1. record supported finding that father posed no flight risk with child, and

    2. trial court acted within its discretion in declining to restrict international visitation. Affirmed.


    1. Moore v. Olson

      Supreme Court of Alaska. July 02, 2015 351 P.3d 1066 2015 WL 4031624


      LITIGATION - Alternative Dispute Resolution. Court was not statutorily required to sua sponte conduct an evidentiary hearing in confirming arbitration award.

      Synopsis

      Background: Former business partner applied to confirm arbitration award, and his former business partner sought to vacate the award. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Andrew Guidi, J., confirmed the arbitration award and awarded attorney fees. Unsuccessful former business partner appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

      1. court did not abuse its discretion by refusing to disqualify opposing counsel;

      2. denial of request to disqualify was not gross error;

      3. arbitrator's decision not to grant postponement was not gross error;

      4. court was not statutorily required to sua sponte conduct an evidentiary hearing;

      5. court did not violate unsuccessful former business partner's due process rights; and

      6. court properly awarded full attorney fees to prevailing party. Affirmed.


    2. Hope P. v. Flynn G.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. September 04, 2015 355 P.3d 559 2015 WL 5167283


      FAMILY LAW - Child Support. Superior Court's decision not to impute income to father for purposes of calculating child support did not constitute an abuse of discretion.

      Synopsis

      Background: Mother and father moved to modify existing child custody arrangement. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, Eric Smith, J., granted father's motion for temporary modification, and then made order permanent. Mother appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

      1. mother failed to make a prima facie case for a permanent modification of custody, as required to trigger a right to an evidentiary hearing;

      2. mother waived any right she might otherwise have had to a hearing on trial court's order making interim custody order granting father shared custody a final order; and

      3. Superior Court's decision not to impute income to father for purposes of calculating child support did not constitute an abuse of discretion.

      Affirmed.


    3. Fernandez v. Fernandez

      Supreme Court of Alaska. August 28, 2015 358 P.3d 562 2015 WL 5061754


      FAMILY LAW - Child Support. Trial court had the authority to set aside 1986 child support judgment based upon a fraud upon the court.



      Synopsis

      Background: Former husband moved for judicial relief from child support order. Parties reached a settlement agreement under which former wife agreed to pay former husband $33,000 and would get a second mortgage to fund settlement. After former wife reported that she was unable to obtain a second mortgage, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, John Suddock, J., ordered her to pay

      $33,000 to former husband at a rate of $250 per month. Former wife moved for relief from judgment which was denied. Former wife appealed. The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., 312 P.3d 1098, reversed. The Superior Court subsequently set aside 1986 decree of dissolution, child support judgments, and property judgments, finding there was a fraud on the court based on parties' participation in a sham dissolution, and then divided property and determined child support as of date of parties' final separation in 2007. Wife appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Fabe, C.J., held that:

      1. District Court did not abuse its discretion in determining that husband and wife's attempt to shield assets from bankruptcy creditors through 1986 sham dissolution was a fraud on the court;

      2. District Court had authority to set aside 1986 decree of dissolution, child support judgments, and property judgments, based on parties' fraud upon the court;

      3. District Court did not abuse its discretion in granting husband relief from 1986 child support judgment;

      4. doctrine of in pari delicto did not preclude District Court from granting husband relief from 1986 child support judgment; and

      5. statutory bar on retroactive modification of child support judgments did not preclude District Court from setting aside child support arrears and ordering child support from date the parties actually separated.

      Affirmed.


    4. City & Borough of Juneau v. State

      Supreme Court of Alaska. December 04, 2015 361 P.3d 926 2015 WL 7873718


      GOVERNMENT - Municipalities. Head-to-head analysis as between dissolving city and neighbor borough was not needed when granting petition for new borough.

      Synopsis

      Background: Neighboring borough petitioned for review of decision of local Boundary Commission granting city's petition to dissolve itself and incorporate a new borough, over objection of neighboring borough, which had sought to annex some of area included in new borough. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Louis J. Menendez, J., affirmed. Neighboring borough appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

      1. Commission was not required to conduct head-to-head analysis as between dissolving city and neighboring borough to determine whether city had superior common interests to contested area, in order to satisfy its constitutional obligation to make borough decisions from a statewide perspective prior to granting city's petition, and

      2. trial court's decision to award less than 30% portion of city's requested attorney fees was not manifestly unreasonable.

      Affirmed.


    5. Alaskasland.Com, LLC v. Cross


      Supreme Court of Alaska. September 25, 2015 357 P.3d 805 2015 WL 5655881


      COPYRIGHTS - Art and Architecture. Copyright Act preempted claim of misappropriation of photographs.

      Synopsis

      Background: Developer brought action against real estate agency, agents, and owners of neighboring property for misappropriation of advertising materials, trademark and trade name infringement, and defamation, among other claims, arising from defendants' use of photographs contained in developer's marketing materials. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Frank A. Pfiffner, J., 2013 WL 6839799, granted summary judgment to defendants and awarded attorney fees to defendants.

      Developer appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

      1. Copyright Act preempted claim for misappropriation;

      2. agency did not commit torts of misappropriation or passing off;

      3. statements contained in appraisal posted to real estate multiple listing service were not defamatory; and

      4. trial court acted within its discretion in awarding enhanced attorney fees to defendants. Affirmed.


    6. Kenneth S. v. Beulah E.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. August 26, 2015 Not Reported in P.3d 2015 WL 5086386


      FAMILY LAW - Child Custody. Accusations of domestic violence that occurred prior to settlement agreement for shared custody could be considered on request to modify custody.

      Synopsis

      Background: Following parents' entry into settlement agreement for shared custody of child, mother sought primary physical custody of child, alleging multiple instances of pre-settlement domestic violence by father. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Frank A. Pfiffner, J., granted custody to mother. Father appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

      1. trial court acted within its discretion in declining to appoint independent expert;

      2. father was not entitled to have trial court explain substantive law to him;

      3. evidence supported finding that father had committed domestic violence against mother;

      4. accusations of domestic violence that occurred prior to settlement agreement could be considered by trial court;

      5. trial court acted within its discretion in ordering that father complete batterers' intervention program;

      6. trial court acted within its discretion in giving mother authority to move child to any place of her choosing; and

      7. trial court acted within its discretion in setting limitations on father's communications with mother and child.

      Affirmed.


    7. Castle Properties, Inc. v. Wasilla Lake Church of the Nazarene

      Supreme Court of Alaska. April 10, 2015 347 P.3d 990 2015 WL 1592112



      REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Alleged holder of right of first refusal had reasonable opportunity to exercise its right after discovering offer to purchase property.

      Synopsis
