      Background: Alleged holder of right of first refusal on future sale of property filed suit against property owner seeking specific performance of right of first refusal. Property owner counterclaimed, seeking declaratory judgment quieting title to property. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, Eric Smith, J., quieted title in favor of property owner. Alleged holder appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

      1. ordinance provided alleged holder adequate notice of terms of city's offer to purchase property;

      2. alleged holder had reasonable opportunity to exercise its right of first refusal; and

      3. owner did not violate implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing. Affirmed.


    8. Snider v. Snider

      Supreme Court of Alaska. September 25, 2015 357 P.3d 1180 2015 WL 5655720


      FAMILY LAW - Evidence. Trial court abused discretion in refusing to reopen divorce proceedings to allow for presentation of additional evidence.

      Synopsis

      Background: In divorce proceedings, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Paul E. Olson, J., divided property and made child custody determination, denying husband's motion for reconsideration. Husband appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

      1. trial court abused its discretion in refusing to reopen evidence, on husband's request, to allow for presentation of additional evidence;

      2. trial judge did not abuse his discretion in denying husband's motion for recusal for bias;

      3. trial court did not abuse its discretion in finding, when making child custody determination, that length of time the child had lived in a stable, satisfactory environment and the desirability of maintaining continuity was factor that was equal between parties; and

      4. trial court did not abuse its discretion in determining that willingness and ability of each parent to facilitate and encourage a close and continuing relationship between the other parent and the child, as factor to be considered in making child custody determination, weighed in favor of wife.

      Vacated and remanded.


    9. Engstrom v. Engstrom

      Supreme Court of Alaska. May 15, 2015 350 P.3d 766 2015 WL 2328723


      FAMILY LAW - Equitable Distribution. Determining marital part of retirement health insurance benefits required using marriage years as fraction of years of work.

      Synopsis

      Background: In divorce action, the Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Philip M. Pallenberg,


      J., divided marital property. Husband appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

      1. determining marital portion of wife's retirement health insurance benefits required using years of marriage as a fraction of wife's total years of employment, rather than considering such benefits marital to the extent they vested during marriage, overruling Sparks v. Sparks, 233 P.3d 1091;

      2. individual rate rather than composite rate was appropriately applied to calculating value of wife's retirement health insurance benefits;

      3. trial court abused its discretion in relying on husband's receipt of income-producing businesses to justify unequal property division;

      4. trial court abused its discretion in relying on wife's childcare costs to justify unequal property division without first finding that child support was inadequate to meet child's needs; and

      5. trial court did not clearly err in valuing husband's tax liability for year based on husband's trial estimates rather than his actual return.

      Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded. Winfree, J., filed opinion dissenting in part.


    10. Moreno v. State

      Supreme Court of Alaska. January 30, 2015 341 P.3d 1134 2015 WL 404251


      CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Counsel. Defendants did not have burden to disprove that their attorneys made tactical decisions not to object to error.

      Synopsis

      Background: Defendant was convicted in the Superior Court, Second Judicial District, Barrow, Michael

      I. Jeffery, J., of possession and delivery of methamphetamine and illegal sale of alcohol in local option community. He appealed. The Court of Appeals, Bolger, J., 2013 WL 120907, affirmed. Defendant petitioned for hearing, arguing that burden of proof should be on state to show that his counsel's failure to object was the result of tactical decision. Petition for hearing was granted. A second defendant was convicted in the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Glennallen, Daniel Schally, J., of driving under the influence. She appealed. The Court of Appeals, Bolger, J., 2013 WL 203264, affirmed. Defendant petitioned for hearing on same grounds as first defendant. Petition was granted, and cases were consolidated.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

      1. defendants did not have burden to prove that their attorneys did not make tactical decisions not to object to errors, and

      2. any error in admitting arresting officer's statement in trial for possession and delivery of methamphetamine and illegal sale of alcohol was harmless.

      Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.


    11. Pacifica Marine, Inc. v. Solomon Gold, Inc.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. August 21, 2015 356 P.3d 780 2015 WL 4965989


      REAL PROPERTY - Mineral Rights and Interests. Failure of bidder to supply statement of qualifications to acquire and hold mineral rights was material and not result of excusable inadvertence.



      Synopsis

      Background: Bidder for mining leases sought judicial review of the determination of the Commissioner of the Department of Natural Resources (DNR) that bidder's failure to supply a statement of qualifications to acquire and hold mineral rights before submitting bids was material and was not the result of excusable inadvertence. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Jack Smith, J., affirmed the Commissioner's decision. Bidder appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Fabe, C.J., held that:

      1. substantial evidence supported finding that bidder had ample notice of the requirement;

      2. bidder's failure to provide statement was not result of excusable inadvertence, within meaning of regulation governing incomplete bids;

      3. bidder's failure to provide statement was material and, thus, did not fall within immateriality exception to the regulation;

      4. Commissioner's decision was not arbitrary, unreasonable, or an abuse of discretion; and

      5. trial court was not required to hold a trial de novo on appeal from Commissioner's decision. Affirmed.


    12. Alaska Fish and Wildlife Conservation Fund v. State

      Supreme Court of Alaska. March 27, 2015 347 P.3d 97 2015 WL 1393374


      ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - Game. Regulations promulgated by Board of Game establishing community system of subsistence hunting for moose and caribou were not unconstitutional.

      Synopsis

      Background: Nonprofit private outdoors group brought action against the State, alleging that regulations promulgated by the Board of Game establishing community and individual systems of subsistence hunting for moose and caribou violated the State Constitution and were not authorized by statute. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks North Star Borough, Michael P. McConahy, J., 2011 WL 11557897, entered summary judgment in favor of State. Group appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

      1. regulations did not violate equal access clauses of State Constitution;

      2. statute and regulation governing community subsistence harvest hunt permits was not facially invalid under State Constitution Article governing natural resources;

      3. Board had statutory authority to promulgate regulations;

      4. permit allowing community harvest subsistence moose hunters a longer hunting season with fewer size restrictions than permits allowed to individual subsistence hunters was not arbitrary or unreasonable;

      5. permit allowing community hunters to take one caribou per group member up to 300 caribou was not arbitrary or unreasonable;

      6. regulations did not conflict with regulation providing that total bag limit for community harvest permit was equal to sum of individual participants' bag limits; and

      7. Board's amendment to regulation to give itself authority to assign different hunting season lengths to community permit holders and individual permit holders was properly noticed.

      Affirmed.


    13. Pister v. State, Dept. of Revenue

      Supreme Court of Alaska. July 24, 2015 354 P.3d 357 2015 WL 4496281



      BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Taxpayer's sole shareholder manipulated corporate form in order to commit tax evasion, as justification for piercing corporate veil.

      Synopsis

      Background: After judgment establishing tax liability of corporate taxpayer that had been administratively dissolved was affirmed, 151 P.3d 434, Director of Revenue brought separate action against taxpayer, taxpayer's sole shareholder, and taxpayer's successor to pierce corporate veil in order to collect tax debt, and for fraudulent conveyance and successor liability. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Louis J. Menendez, J., pierced corporate veil, set aside conveyances of two contracts, and held successor liable for taxpayer's tax debt. Taxpayer and shareholder appealed. Holdings: The Supreme Court, Fabe, C.J., held that:

      1. instant suit to pierce corporate veil was not barred by res judicata;

      2. shareholder manipulated taxpayer's corporate form in order to evade payment of state and federal taxes, as justification for piercing corporate veil, under both Alaska and Washington law; and

      3. trial court's finding that contract shareholder fraudulently conveyed to himself, without consideration, contract worth $1.4 million, was clearly erroneous; and

      4. trial court's finding that shareholder conveyed to taxpayer's successor taxpayer's three-year contract worth $648,000 was clearly erroneous.

      Affirmed in part; reversed in part; remanded.


    14. Red Elk v. McBride

      Supreme Court of Alaska. March 13, 2015 344 P.3d 818 2015 WL 1119536


      FAMILY LAW - Visitation. Trial court was precluded from making visitation decision based on father's litigation conduct in tribal court.

      Synopsis

      Background: Mother of child born out of wedlock brought custody action. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Homer, Charles T. Huguelet, J., awarded primary physical and sole legal custody to mother, ordered unsupervised visitation between Indian father and child in Alaska, but prohibited visitation on the reservation until child turned eight. Father appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

      1. the Superior Court did not abuse its discretion in denying father's motion to amend the pleadings;

      2. the Superior Court was precluded from weighing father's litigation conduct in tribal court against him, and to make a visitation decision with regard to child born out of wedlock on that basis;

      3. the Superior Court did not abuse its discretion when it awarded sole legal custody to mother, and in ordering mother to begin educating the child about her Indian heritage;

      4. the Superior Court's failure to explain why father should bear the full burden of visitation costs, or consider or conduct an analysis regarding the parties' finances in the context of allocating visitation expenses, constituted an abuse of discretion, and necessitated remand for further consideration; and

      5. the Superior Court's imposition of a tiered visitation plan did not constitute an abuse of discretion. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.


    15. Laybourn v. City of Wasilla

    Supreme Court of Alaska. December 11, 2015 362 P.3d 447 2015 WL 8521290



    REAL PROPERTY - Easements. City's obligation to build access road in exchange for easement was unambiguously conditioned upon available funding and permitting approval.

    Synopsis

    Background: After city failed to fulfill its promise to build access road across property owners' land in exchange for property owners' grant of utility easement to city, subject to obtaining permits and funding, property owners sued city, claiming that city had fraudulently induced them to sign the easement agreement, breached the agreement, and breached the covenant of good faith and fair dealing.

    Following a bench trial, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, Kari Kristiansen, J., ruled against property owners and they appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

    1. city's obligation to build the road was unambiguously conditioned upon available funding and permitting approval;

    2. evidence supported finding that city had made no misrepresentations of material fact to property owners;

    3. city did not breach the agreement; and

    4. city did not breach covenant of good faith and fair dealing. Affirmed.


    113. Cook Inlet Fisherman's Fund v. State, Dept. of Fish & Game

    Supreme Court of Alaska. September 25, 2015 357 P.3d 789 2015 WL 5655814


    ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - Industry Regulation. Decision by Department of Fish and Game to curb and then close set net fishery was not fishery mismanagement.

    Synopsis

    Background: Set net commercial fishers brought action against state Department of Fish and Game, after Department's Commissioner used her emergency authority to limit time for and then close set net fishery in effort to protect king salmon run, seeking declaratory judgment recognizing validity of Board of Fisheries' salmon management plans and permanent injunction directing Department to follow those plans. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, 2014 WL 8396298, Andrew Guidi, J., granted Department summary judgment, and assessed an attorney fee award against fishers, 2014 WL 8396279. Fishers appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

    1. trial court did not abuse its discretion by failing to expressly address, and implicitly denying, fishers' motion for additional discovery prior to ruling on summary judgment motion;

    2. discretionary in-season management decisions made by Commissioner were all within range of discretion permitted by Board's salmon management plans, such that Commissioner's actions did not amount to fishery mismanagement;

    3. Commissioner's emergency order did not deprive set net fishers of equal protection under state constitution's uniform application clause; and

    4. fishers' request for injunctive relief lacked specificity required for granting of such relief. Affirmed.


    1. Wilson v. State, Dept. of Law


      Supreme Court of Alaska. September 04, 2015 355 P.3d 549 2015 WL 5167269


      HEALTH - Mental Health. Court's finding that elderly mother was incapacitated and required partial public guardianship was supported by substantial evidence.

      Synopsis

      Background: Adult Protective Services (APS) filed petition seeking appointment of public guardian for elderly mother. Following appointment of temporary emergency guardian, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, Eric Smith, J., adopted report of Craig S. Condie, Magistrate Judge, recommending appointment of partial public guardian and full conservator and sale of home. Mother appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

      1. trial court's finding that mother was incapacitated and required partial public guardianship was supported by substantial evidence, and

      2. evidence supported trial court's finding that mother was unable to manage her financial affairs, so as to support appointment of public conservator.

      Affirmed.


    2. Alaska Conservation Foundation v. Pebble Ltd. Partnership

      Supreme Court of Alaska. May 29, 2015 350 P.3d 273 2015 WL 3452471


      LITIGATION - Costs. Constitutional claimants did not have sufficient economic incentive to bring action as would bar them from recovering full attorney fees.

      Synopsis

      Background: Four local residents and non-profit organization whose members were village corporations in bay region, sued the state Department of Natural Resources, for alleged constitutional violations related to land and water use permits issued to mineral exploration project operator.

      Following a bench trial, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eric A. Aarseth, J., resolved the case in favor the state and operator, which had intervened, and issued an order allowing discovery into plaintiffs' economic incentive in bringing the action.

      [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that plaintiffs did not have sufficient economic incentive to bring action as would bar them from recovering full attorney fees.

      Vacated and remanded.


    3. Ranes & Shine, LLC v. MacDonald Miller Alaska, Inc.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 01, 2015 355 P.3d 503 2015 WL 1958657


    COMMERCIAL LAW - Limitations. UCC financing statements did not provide constructive notice of fraud claim as would trigger statute of limitations.

    Synopsis

    Background: Bank brought action against buyer of equipment, claiming security interest in the equipment and seeking possession. Buyer brought third-party claim against seller, a limited liability company (LLC), and its former managing member, asserting breach of warranty of title,


    misrepresentation, unfair trade practices, and common law contract claims. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, John Suddock, J., held seller liable for breach of contract and misrepresentation, and dismissed claims asserted against managing member individually. Seller appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

    1. publicly-filed financing statements did not provide constructive notice of fraud claim as would result in accrual of buyer's cause of action under statute of limitations;

    2. buyer's claims accrued, for statute of limitations purposes, when bank contacted buyer;

    3. former managing member could be individually liable for tortious acts he individually committed while acting as an agent for LLC;

    4. trial court acted within its discretion when it sua sponte amended pleadings to substitute buyer's corporation as third-party plaintiff; and

    5. trial court acted within its discretion when it permitted incarcerated third-party defendant to testify telephonically.

    Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.


    117. State, Dept. of Revenue v. BP Pipelines (Alaska) Inc.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 28, 2015 354 P.3d 1053 2015 WL 5061652


    TAXATION - Energy and Utilities. Court properly applied the use value standard to value oil pipeline system for property tax purposes.

    Synopsis

    Background: Oil pipeline owners and municipalities sought review of decision of the State Assessment Review Board valuing pipeline for property tax purposes. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Sharon Gleason and Andrew Guidi, JJs., valued the pipeline system and the parties appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

    1. court properly applied the use value standard to value pipeline;

    2. court was not required to treat tariff regulations as a form of economic obsolescence;

    3. court did not improperly consider one expert's production forecasts in calculating total proven oil reserves and estimating economic life of pipeline; and

    4. evidence was sufficient to support ruling that a scaling deduction in value of pipeline for economic obsolescence was appropriate based upon superadequacy of the pipeline.

    Affirmed.


    118. Patterson v. GEICO General Ins. Co.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. April 03, 2015 347 P.3d 562 2015 WL 1509747


    LITIGATION - Trial. Rulings against plaintiff on evidentiary matters and limits on opening statement and closing argument did not deprive him of due process.

    Synopsis

    Background: Insured brought action against automobile insurer to recover uninsured motorist (UM) benefits. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, John Suddock, J., denied insured's motion to amend complaint, entered judgment on jury verdict for insured, but reduced award based on


    insurer's payment of medical expenses and its attorney fees and costs. Insured appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

    1. insured was not entitled to amend complaint to include racketeering, embezzlement, mail fraud, and bad faith claims;

    2. insured was not entitled to disqualification of trial judge;

    3. portions of defense expert's deposition could be admitted;

    4. restrictions on insured's opening statement and closing arguments did not violate free speech rights;

    5. rulings against insured on evidentiary matters and limits on opening statement and closing argument did not deprive him of due process;

    6. trial court acted reasonably by ordering insured to end opening statement and closing arguments before his time had expired; and

    7. any error in special verdict form asking jury for decision on uncontested issue did not prejudice insured.

    Affirmed.


    1. Kacher v. Kacher

      Supreme Court of Alaska. July 22, 2015 Not Reported in P.3d 2015 WL 4503988


      FAMILY LAW - Marital Property. Court did not clearly err by finding that parties intended residence, which wife owned prior to marriage, but which was held in joint title, to remain her property.

      Synopsis

      Background: Husband filed for divorce. After bench trial, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Kenai, Charles T. Huguelet, J., concluded that the Alaska residence was wife's separate property and the California residence was husband's separate property, and he appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

      1. superior court did not clearly err by finding that the parties intended the Alaska residence, which wife owned prior to marriage, but which was held in joint title during marriage, to remain wife's separate property;

      2. superior court did not clearly err by finding that the California residence, which husband owned prior to marriage, but which was held in joint title during marriage, remained husband's separate property; and

      3. superior court did not abuse its discretion by ordering husband to prepare and file amended tax returns in order to address and correct husband's unreported earnings.

      Affirmed and remanded.

      Winfree, J., dissented in part and filed opinion.


    2. Ray v. Draeger

      Supreme Court of Alaska. July 17, 2015 353 P.3d 806 2015 WL 4381087


      INSURANCE - Evidence. Courts apply substantial connection analysis to determine whether probative value of witness's insurance ties outweighs danger of unfair prejudice.

      Synopsis

      Background: Automobile passenger brought personal injury action against driver responsible for rear-end collision, and driver made a motion in limine to preclude reference at trial to the fact that driver was


      covered by liability insurance, which limited passenger's ability to cross-examine the ties driver's expert had with the insurance industry to show bias. The District Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, David Wallace, J., 2012 WL 9506265, granted driver's motion in limine, and the jury awarded passenger damages for past, but not future, damages. Passenger appealed. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, John Suddock, J., 2013 WL 6063433, reversed and remanded for a new trial. Driver petitioned for review.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Fabe, C.J., held that:

      1. as a matter of first impression, trial courts should apply substantial connection analysis to determine whether probative value of witness's ties to insurance industry outweighs danger of prejudice;

      2. the trial court abused its discretion in excluding evidence of substantial connection between driver's expert and insurance industry; but

      3. the trial court's error in excluding expert's insurance connection was harmless.

      Superior Court's order affirmed in part, reversed in part, and vacated, and District Court's judgment reinstated.


    3. Hughes v. Treadwell

      Supreme Court of Alaska. January 30, 2015 341 P.3d 1121 2015 WL 404235


      ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - Mines. Initiative requiring legislative approval of certain mines in bay watershed was not unconstitutional appropriation or local or special legislation.

      Synopsis

      Background: Mining engineer and associations filed suit challenging lieutenant governor's certification of ballot initiative that would require final legislative approval for any large-scale metallic sulfide mining operation located within bay watershed. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Paul R. Lyle, J., granted summary judgment in favor of State and initiative sponsors, declining to enjoin placement of initiative on ballot. Mining engineer and associations appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

      1. initiative did not make unconstitutional appropriation of state assets, and

      2. initiative did not violate constitutional prohibition against local or special legislation. Affirmed.


    4. Guerrero v. Guerrero

      Supreme Court of Alaska. September 18, 2015 362 P.3d 432 2015 WL 5474348


      FAMILY LAW - Marital Property. Husband's military benefits were not a divisible marital asset.

      Synopsis

      Background: In dissolution proceeding, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Catherine M. Easter, J., refused to divide husband's military retirement pay and forced sale of marital home, which wife had received pursuant to property settlement agreement. Wife appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

      1. husband's military benefits were not a divisible marital asset;

      2. wife was entitled to reopening of property settlement agreement;

      3. trial court acted within its discretion in refusing to require husband to sign quitclaim deed; and

      4. forced sale of marital home was warranted.


      Affirmed in part, reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.


    5. Nunamta Aulukestai v. State, Dept. of Natural Resources

      Supreme Court of Alaska. May 29, 2015 351 P.3d 1041 2015 WL 3452438


      REAL PROPERTY - Mineral Rights and Interests. Miscellaneous land use permit issued to mining company was functionally irrevocable, thus public notice was required.

      Synopsis

      Background: Objectors brought declaratory judgment action challenging denial by Department of Natural Resources (DNR) of objectors' request to stay permit allowing intensive mineral exploration on state land. After trial, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eric A. Aarseth, J., entered judgment in favor of DNR. Objectors appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Matthews, Senior Justice, held that:

      1. licenses that are functionally irrevocable are interests in land for which public notice is required by state constitution prior to disposal of such interests;

      2. any revocation of miscellaneous land use permit (MLUP) issued to applicant, a mining company, would have resulted in destruction of sizeable investments, supporting finding that MLUP was functionally irrevocable and thus a disposal of an interest in state land for which prior public notice was required by state constitution;

      3. applicant's activities under MLUP were potential source of environmental harm, also supporting finding that MLUP was functionally irrevocable; but

      4. temporary water use permits (TWUPs) issued to applicant were not functionally irrevocable. Reversed and remanded.

      Winfree, J., filed concurring opinion.


    6. RBG Bush Planes, LLC v. Alaska Public Offices Com'n

      Supreme Court of Alaska. November 25, 2015 361 P.3d 886 2015 WL 7709446


      GOVERNMENT - Elections. Fine of $25,500 against air carrier for violation of campaign finance laws was not excessive.

      Synopsis

      Background: Air carrier sought review of decision of the Public Offices Commission imposing fine for carrier's violation of campaign finance laws. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Catherine M. Easter, J., affirmed. Carrier appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

      1. Commission's use of rate for seat fares was a reasonable interpretation of term commercially reasonable rate for air travel, and

      2. fine of $25,500 was not unconstitutionally excessive. Affirmed.


    7. Ruppe v. Ruppe

    Supreme Court of Alaska. September 25, 2015 358 P.3d 1284 2015 WL 5655628



    FAMILY LAW - Child Support. Husband was not entitled to credit alleged overpayments of child support in interim period against his post-divorce support obligations.

    Synopsis

    Background: Husband filed for divorce from wife, and wife counterclaimed. The Superior Court, Frank

    A. Pfiffner, J., entered judgment granting divorce, determining custody, distributing marital property, and setting husband's child support obligations. Wife appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Fabe, C.J., held that:

    1. trial court acted within its discretion in granting spouses joint legal custody of children;

    2. spouses' living situation provided good cause to vary interim child support award;

    3. husband satisfied interim child support obligation;

    4. husband was not entitled to credit alleged overpayments in interim period against post-divorce obligations;

    5. Supreme Court would not read strict end-date into support order;

    6. trial court acted within its discretion in crediting husband's estimate of his future income to set support obligations;

    7. trial court did not err in crediting wife's withdrawals against her share of marital estate; and

    8. trial court acted within its discretion in declining to award spousal support. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.


    126. Sarah D. v. John D.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 12, 2015 352 P.3d 419 2015 WL 3645554


    FAMILY LAW - Costs. Trial court did not abuse its discretion in declining to award wife interim attorney fees in divorce case.

    Synopsis

    Background: In custody portion of divorce proceedings, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Patrick J. McKay, J., awarded parties shared physical custody, sole legal custody to husband, and unspecific visitation to paternal grandfather during husband's custodial time. Wife appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

    1. trial court did not abuse its discretion in declining to award wife interim attorney fees;

    2. trial court did not abuse its discretion in denying wife's continuance motions;

    3. evidence was insufficient to establish that paternal grandfather had ever truly been denied visitation with child, such that trial court had no reason to formally award him visitation;

    4. trial court's award of physical custody to husband, as part of joint physical custody order, was not a de facto award of physical custody to paternal grandparents which warranted clear and convincing evidentiary findings under Evans v. McTaggart; and

    5. trial court's failure to make more specific findings of fact regarding all of domestic violence allegations, including violations of protective orders, prior to making child custody determination, warranted remand.

    Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.


    1. Baker v. Ryan Air, Inc.


      Supreme Court of Alaska. March 27, 2015 345 P.3d 101 2015 WL 1393314


      REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Sublessee's increased monthly payments constituted prepayments to be applied to final purchase price, rather than reflect intent to modify contract.

      Synopsis

      Background: Sublessee sought a declaration that purchase and sublease agreements had remained in full force and effect. Sublessor counterclaimed for breach of contract. Following a bench trial, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Frank A. Pfiffner, J., ordered that the sale should proceed. Sublessor appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

      1. sublessor had waived his right to object to sublessee's building renovations on leasehold;

      2. sublessor had failed to provide a valid notice of default;

      3. sublessee's increased monthly payments constituted prepayments to be applied to final purchase price; and

      4. warranties contained in conveyance documents drafted by sublessee were not inconsistent with the statutory quitclaim deed specified by the agreement.

      Affirmed and remanded.


    2. Dundas v. Dundas

      Supreme Court of Alaska. December 11, 2015 362 P.3d 468 2015 WL 8521499


      FAMILY LAW - Visitation. Wife was not liable for full visitation expenses after she moved out of state.

      Synopsis

      Background: In divorce proceeding, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, Eric Smith, J., issued equitable division of property and required wife to pay all visitation expenses. Wife appealed. Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

      1. trial court acted within its discretion in determining that parties ceased functioning as a joint marital unit on date of their mediated agreement;

      2. income earned by husband in year following date of parties' economic separation was separate income;

      3. tax consequences of sale of equipment and real property were marital debt; and

      4. trial court was required to allocate visitation expenses between husband and wife. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.


    3. Alaska Fur Gallery, Inc. v. First Nat. Bank Alaska

      Supreme Court of Alaska. March 13, 2015 345 P.3d 76 2015 WL 1119535


      FINANCE AND BANKING - Judgment. Borrowers failed to establish sufficiently egregious conduct to prove fraud upon the court in action against lender.

      Synopsis

      Background: Corporate borrowers brought action against lender, a bank, alleging common law tort


      claims and Alaska Securities Act violations, in connection with alleged inducing by lender's loan officer of unwise investments in hotel project. Verdict from that trial was vacated, and borrowers brought second action alleging same claims, as well as asserting fraud upon the court. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, 2011 WL 12524968, Stephanie E. Joannides and Patrick J. McKay, JJ., awarded damages to borrowers on their common law negligence claim, as well as enhanced attorney's fees for first trial. Borrowers appealed, and lender cross-appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

      1. direct discrepancies between testimony of lender's general counsel in two different trials, in actions by two different borrowers for allegedly fraudulent conduct of lender's loan officer, were not sufficiently egregious to establish fraud upon the court in first action;

      2. even if in-court testimony of lenders' officials misrepresented quality of loan officer's history with lender, such misrepresentation was not sufficiently egregious to constitute fraud upon the court in first action;

      3. trial court did not abuse its discretion in concluding that testimony from lender's corporate officers was bad faith attempt to minimize loan officer's misconduct, warranting award of enhanced attorney's fees in borrowers' first, but not second, action;

      4. borrowers failed to establish sufficiently egregious conduct to prove fraud upon the court in borrowers' second action against lender; and

      5. trial court did not clearly err in concluding that reassurances made by lender's loan officer were misrepresentations, rather than promises that were never performed, such that they could be used to support borrowers' claim of equitable estoppel with respect to lender's statute of limitations defense. Affirmed.


    4. Brandner v. Pease

      Supreme Court of Alaska. November 25, 2015 361 P.3d 915 2015 WL 7709465


      HEALTH - Malpractice. Patient failed to establish that failure to use working TEE probe during open heart surgery caused his alleged injuries.

      Synopsis

      Background: Patient brought medical malpractice action against anesthesiologist and medical providers involved in his open heart surgery. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Patrick J. McKay, J., granted summary judgment for anesthesiologist and providers and awarded them attorney fees and costs. Patient appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, J., held that:

      1. patient failed to provide expert testimony that standard of care had been breached with regard to use of drug and second intubation attempt;

      2. patient failed to establish that failure to use working transesophageal echo (TEE) probe caused his alleged injuries;

      3. trial court did not abuse its discretion by denying patient's request for additional time to depose experts;

      4. patient was required to reimburse $24,878 in costs incurred as result of his motion to continue trial; and

      5. anesthesiologist and providers were entitled to attorney fees. Affirmed.


    5. Sanders v. State


      Supreme Court of Alaska. October 09, 2015 364 P.3d 412 2015 WL 5917057


      CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Evidence. Extrinsic corroborating evidence can be used to show that statement offered under residual hearsay exception has circumstantial trustworthiness guarantees.

      Synopsis

      Background: Defendant was convicted in the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Michael Spaan, J., of first degree murder and second degree murder. The Court of Appeals, 2013 WL 6229377, affirmed. Defendant filed a petition for hearing with the Supreme Court.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Fabe, C.J., granted the petition and held that:

      1. one victim's statement to witness, that both victims were conspiring to attack and rob defendant, should have been admitted as evidence of victim's then existing state of mind;

      2. statement should have been admitted as evidence of other victim's conduct;

      3. extrinsic corroborating evidence may be considered in determining whether a statement proffered under residual unavailable declarant hearsay exception exhibits circumstantial guarantees of trustworthiness;

      4. witness' statement to detective about victim's statement satisfied requirements for exception; and

      5. trial court's exclusion of victim's statement and witness's statement was not harmless. Reversed and remanded.

      Bolger, J., dissented in part, with opinion, in which Stowers, J., joined.


    6. Ross v. Bauman

      Supreme Court of Alaska. July 24, 2015 353 P.3d 816 2015 WL 4497962


      FAMILY LAW - Visitation. Order requiring reasonable visitation of children with grandfather violated parents' due process rights.

      Synopsis

      Background: Children's grandfather filed petition for restriction-free visitation. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Kenai, William F. Morse, J., entered order requiring reasonable visitation. Parents appealed.

      [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that visitation order violated parents' due process rights.

      Order vacated; petition dismissed.


    7. Hunter v. Philip Morris USA Inc.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. December 18, 2015 364 P.3d 439 2015 WL 9257673


      TORTS - Trial. Trial court was not bound by its original order granting a new trial following verdict in favor of cigarette manufacturer.

      Synopsis

      Background: Personal representative of smoker's estate brought action against cigarette manufacturer for wrongful death, products liability, and fraud. Following jury trial in which the verdict was in favor of manufacturer, estate's motion for a new trial was initially granted. Subsequently, the


      Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Bethel, Eric Smith, J., granted manufacturer's motion for reconsideration, granted a new trial, and denied estate's motion for reconsideration. Estate appealed. Holdings: The Supreme Court, Fabe, C.J., held that:

      1. a trial court may order a new trial if the verdict is against the weight of the evidence;

      2. trial court was not bound by its original order granting a new trial; and

      3. new trial was not warranted on the basis of exclusion of federal judge's findings that cigarette manufacturers violated the federal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations (RICO) Act. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.


    8. Municipality of Anchorage v. State, Dept. of Revenue

    Supreme Court of Alaska. November 12, 2015 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2015 WL 7188569


    ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Oil and Gas. Substantial evidence supported finding that utility failed to establish that it had used purchased gas to satisfy supply contracts.

    Synopsis

    Background: Electric utility sought judicial review of decision by Office of Administrative Hearing (OAH) that utility had not provided sufficient evidence to disturb Department of Revenue's determination that utility was not entitled to refund on gas-production taxes for seven-year period. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Mark Rindner, J., 2014 WL 5782321, affirmed. Utility appealed, and Department filed cross-appeal.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court held that substantial evidence supported OAH's finding that utility failed to establish that it had used purchased gas to satisfy supply contracts.

    Affirmed.

    FAMILY LAW - Visitation. Trial court's refusal to allow father to relitigate the court's prior sexual abuse finding was not an abuse of discretion.

    Synopsis

    Editor's Note: Opinion withdrawn and superseded. For superseding opinion, see 2020 WL 6252917.

    13. Jackson E. v. Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    14. Schindler v. Schindler

      Supreme Court of Alaska. October 23, 2020 474 P.3d 648 2020 WL 6252373


      FAMILY LAW Equitable Distribution. Offer to purchase home was not a fact in existence at time of divorce, and thus was not newly discovered evidence warranting relief from judgment.

      Synopsis

      Background: Following denial of husband's motion to modify divorce judgment, which awarded him the marital home and ordered him to make a corresponding equalization payment to former wife, husband filed motion for relief from judgment, arguing that newly discovered evidence showed the court had mis-valued the home. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, John C. Cagle, J., denied the requested relief, and husband appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

      1. offer to purchase marital home was not a fact in existence at time of original divorce trial, and thus could not constitute newly discovered evidence warranting relief from judgment, and

      2. mis-valuing of marital home did not constitute extraordinary circumstances warranting relief from judgment.

      Affirmed.

    24. Carr v. Alaska Bar Association

      Supreme Court of Alaska. November 06, 2020 475 P.3d 269 2020 WL 6533456


      LEGAL SERVICES Bar Admission. Health concerns related to COVID-19 pandemic did not warrant allowing applicants to practice law without taking and passing bar examination.

      Synopsis

      Background: Applicants sought to be admitted to practice law without taking and passing bar examination during COVID-19 pandemic.

      [Holding:] The Supreme Court held that health concerns related to COVID-19 pandemic did not warrant allowing applicants to practice law without taking and passing bar examination.

      Application denied.

    33. Sampson v. Alaska Airlines, Inc.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. July 24, 2020 467 P.3d 1072 2020 WL 4249423


      TORTS Damages. Any inconsistency between special verdict form and instructions as to future non-economic damages was not plain error.

      Synopsis

      Background: Airport patron brought negligence action against airline arising out of slip and fall on ice outside terminal. Following jury trial, the Superior Court, Kotzebue, Paul A. Roetman, J., entered judgment in favor of patron. Patron appealed as to damages.

      [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that any inconsistency between special verdict form, asking if patron had proven to a reasonable degree of certainty that she would incur future noneconomic losses, and instructions directing jury to award future non-economic damages that were reasonably probable to occur, was not plain error.

      Affirmed.


    34. Matter of Necessity for Hospitalization of Mason J.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. June 10, 2020 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2020 WL 3071426


      A young man appeals a 30-day involuntary commitment order for mental health treatment. He argues that the superior court erred when it found that he was likely to cause harm to himself or others due to mental illness and that there was no less restrictive treatment alternative.     35. Belk v. Belk

      Supreme Court of Alaska. March 18, 2020 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2020 WL 1289814


      A divorced father moved from Alaska to Utah to be near his child and sought a modification of custody reflecting his move that would give him primary physical custody. Following an evidentiary hearing, the superior court increased the amount of the father's visitation but left primary physical custody with the mother, as well as the right to make...



    36. Matter of Tiffany O.


      Supreme Court of Alaska. July 24, 2020 467 P.3d 1076 2020 WL 4249427


      FAMILY LAW Guardians. State's actions in removing ward's adult daughter, who relied on faith-based medicine, were justified by compelling state interest.

      Synopsis

      Background: Ward's adult daughter appealed from decision of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eric A. Aarseth, J., removing ward's daughter as guardian for ward, who suffered from epilepsy.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, C.J., held that:

      1. record supported superior court's determinations that there was change in circumstances and that existing appointment of ward's adult daughter as her guardian was not in ward's best interests;

      2. ward's adult daughter, who argued that it was religious discrimination to replace her as guardian, met the three requirements for invoking religious exemption from facially neutral state laws, namely guardianship statutes, under State Constitution;

      3. State's actions in removing ward's adult daughter as her guardian were justified by a compelling state interest.

      Affirmed.


    37. Vogus v. Vogus

      Supreme Court of Alaska. April 03, 2020 460 P.3d 1220 2020 WL 1647839


      FAMILY LAW Child Support. Trial court could not impute income to mother by utilizing an hourly rate that exceeded the average hourly rate mother had previously worked.

      Synopsis

      Background: After the parties divorced, child custody of modified, with father obtaining primary physical custody of the children, and the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Jennifer S. Henderson, J., imputed income to mother and set child support order. Mother appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

      1. evidence supported finding that mother was voluntarily underemployed, and

      2. trial court could not impute income to mother by utilizing an hourly rate and number of weekly hours that exceeded the average hourly rate and number of hours per week mother had previously worked. Vacated and remanded.


    38. Darrell N. v. Jolina N.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. May 13, 2020 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2020 WL 2464848


      Divorcing parents disputed custody of their minor child. Following trial, the superior court found that the father had committed acts of domestic violence, and it granted the mother sole legal custody and primary physical custody of the child; the father was given supervised visitation pending his satisfaction of certain conditions. The custody...

      Supreme Court of Alaska. November 18, 2020 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2020 WL 6778391


      A father challenges the superior court's child custody determination. He argues that the court abused its discretion or otherwise erred in its consideration of the statutory best interest factors set out in AS 25.24.150(c). He also argues that the court erred when it awarded the mother primary physical custody because the amount of...



    40. Viviane K. v. State

      Supreme Court of Alaska. June 03, 2020 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2020 WL 2904031


      A mother appeals the termination of her parental rights to her infant daughter. She argues that the Office of Children's Services (OCS), by not doing more to help her obtain substance abuse treatment, violated the Indian Child Welfare Act's requirement that OCS make active efforts to provide remedial and rehabilitative services designed to prevent...



    41. Matter of Duane M.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. March 11, 2020 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2020 WL 1165853


      A man appeals a 30-day order committing him involuntarily for mental health treatment at Alaska Psychiatric Institute (API). He argues that his right to due process was violated because the commitment order states that the superior court's findings were based in part on the initial petition for evaluation and its attachments, which had not been...



    42. Norman S. v. Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

      Supreme Court of Alaska. March 13, 2020 459 P.3d 464 2020 WL 1223498


      FAMILY LAW Trial. Trial court's acceptance of offer of proof by Office of Children's Services (OCS), without his approval, was reversible error as matter of law.

      Synopsis

      Background: Father's parental rights were terminated by the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Thomas I. Temple, J., and father appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

      1. father did not waive objection to offer of proof submitted in his absence, and

      2. trial court's acceptance of offer of proof by Office of Children's Services (OCS), in father's absence and without father's approval, was reversible error as matter of law.

      Vacated; remanded.


    43. Hardy v. Nix


      Supreme Court of Alaska. May 27, 2020 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2020 WL 2745816


      A father appeals the superior court's custody decision, arguing that the court erred by awarding the father and mother shared legal and physical custody of their daughter. Seeing no abuse of discretion or other error, we affirm the court's decision. Daniel Hardy Jr. and Cassandra Nix are the parents of a daughter, who was born in August 2006. The...



    44. Harmon v. Office of Governor

We have affirmed the Commission's decisions in each previous appeal; we do...

He argues that the superior court erred when it valued his medical benefits and in its distribution of the marital estate. Because the...



    47. Matter of Margo T.

      A patient appeals the superior court's 30-day involuntary commitment order, arguing that the court lacked sufficient evidence to find she was gravely disabled. We conclude that there was no clear error in the superior court's findings and affirm the commitment order. At the time of the relevant proceedings Margo T. was a 59-year-old woman who had...

    49. Matter of Naomi B.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. May 20, 2020 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2020 WL 2551862


      Naomi B. was admitted to Alaska Psychiatric Institute (API) for a 30-day involuntary commitment in October 2017. The magistrate judge concluded that Naomi met both statutory definitions of gravely disabled, and the superior court adopted that recommendation without specifying which definition it relied on.     50. Arnoult v. Webster

      Supreme Court of Alaska. June 12, 2020 480 P.3d 592 2020 WL 3118229


      TORTS Limitations. Patient was on inquiry notice of malpractice claim, for purposes of limitations period, when patient knew that his periodontist was surprised that infection had not been treated.

      Synopsis

      Background: Patient, who received treatment for periodontal disease, brought dental malpractice claim against his periodontist. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Douglas L. Blankenship, J., entered summary judgment for periodontist, and patient appealed.

      [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that patient was on inquiry notice of dental malpractice claim, for purposes of two year limitations period, when patient knew that his new periodontist was surprised that patient's bacterial infection had not been treated sooner.

      Affirmed.


    51. Marks v. Plunkett

      Supreme Court of Alaska. October 14, 2020 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2020 WL 6055264


      A woman injured her shoulder when she slipped and fell in the parking lot of her Anchorage apartment complex. Surgery and physical therapy allowed her to regain most of the functioning in her arm and shoulder. She sued her landlord, arguing that his negligence caused her injury. A jury awarded medical expenses and past noneconomic damages, but...



    52. Addy S. v. Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's


      Services

      An Indian child's mother appeals termination of her parental rights. She contends that, because the superior court relied on testimony provided by an improperly qualified expert witness, the court erred in concluding that returning the child to her custody would result in serious harm. She also contends that the court erred by adopting the guardian...



    53. Louisa M. v. Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

      Supreme Court of Alaska. November 12, 2020 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2020 WL 6606348


      A mother appeals the termination of her parental rights to her two daughters, who are Indian children as defined by the Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA). The Office of Children's Services (OCS) took custody of the children for over a year because of concerns with the mother's substance abuse, then returned the children to the home after the mother...



    54. Maalah v. Trident Seafoods

    Supreme Court of Alaska. December 16, 2020 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2020 WL 7384948


    A worker filed a workers' compensation claim for several benefits related to separate injuries that three doctors initially agreed likely were work related, although one doctor later changed his opinion about whether an injury was work related. The Alaska Workers' Compensation Board denied all the worker's claims based in part on the doctor's...



    56. Matter of Meredith B.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. April 24, 2020 462 P.3d 522 2020 WL 1969397


    HEALTH Mental Health. Any error arising from superior court's failure to interview patient during screening investigation was harmless.

    Synopsis

    Background: Sister of patient, who had bipolar disorder with delusions, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), and unspecified psychotic disorder, petitioned for order authorizing patient's hospitalization for evaluation. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No. 3AN-18-00302 PR, Dani Crosby, J., entered ex parte order authorizing patient's 30-day commitment at psychiatric institute. Patient appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, C.J., held that:

    1. there was clear and convincing evidence that patient was gravely disabled;

    2. there was clear and convincing evidence that mental condition of patient could improve with treatment; and

    3. any error arising from superior court's failure to interview patient during screening investigation was harmless.


    Affirmed.


    1. Manns v. Department of Natural Resources, Division of Mining, Land and Water

      Supreme Court of Alaska. August 07, 2020 468 P.3d 1171 2020 WL 4557115


      GOVERNMENT Property. Applicants failed to establish their business use of land for five years prior to state selection, as required for a preference right to purchase state land.

      Synopsis

      Background: Applicants filed applications for preference rights to purchase certain state land. The Department of Natural Resources (DNR) Division of Mining, Land and Water denied the application and the DNR Commissioner affirmed. Applicants appealed. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Jane F. Kauvar, J., affirmed and applicants appealed.

      [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Bolger, C.J., held that applicants failed to provide evidence that established their business use of land for five years prior to state selection, as required to qualify for a preference right to purchase state land.

      Affirmed.


    2. Steve K. v. Department of Health and Social Services, Office of Children's Services

      Supreme Court of Alaska. March 18, 2020 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2020 WL 1289844


      A father appeals the termination of his parental rights, arguing that the superior court clearly erred when it found that he had abandoned his daughter and neglected her and that his substance abuse had placed her at substantial risk of harm. Because the record supports the superior court's finding that his daughter was a child in...



    3. Cavitt v. D&D Services, LLC

      Supreme Court of Alaska. June 19, 2020 466 P.3d 345 2020 WL 3396003


      LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT Workers' Compensation. Board acted within its discretion when it awarded claimant future medical costs in accordance with the Act.

      Synopsis

      Background: Workers' compensation claimant appealed decision of the Workers' Compensation Appeals Board, which awarded future medical benefits in form of periodic surveillance examinations of claimant's elbow until another cause displaced the work injury, claiming he was entitled to lifetime medical care.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

      1. Board acted within its discretion when it awarded claimant future medical costs in accordance with the Act, and

      2. periodic follow-up exams of claimant's elbow were reasonable and necessary, and therefore part of


      his compensable medical treatment. Affirmed.


    4. Zwiacher v. Capstone Family Medical Clinic, LLC

      Supreme Court of Alaska. December 04, 2020 476 P.3d 1139 2020 WL 7088498


      LITIGATION Estoppel. Positions taken in counterclaim and in affidavit seeking relief from default were not clearly inconsistent, thus counterclaim was not estopped.

      Synopsis

      Background: Lessor of medical office building brought forcible entry and detainer action against lessee. After default judgment was entered against lessee, the District Court, Palmer, William L. Estelle, J., denied lessee's motion for relief from judgment. Lessee appealed. The Superior Court, Palmer, Kari Kristiansen, J., affirmed. Petition for hearing was granted.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

      1. as a matter of apparent first impression, whether two positions are actually contradictory, as would support application of judicial estoppel, is a question of law which Supreme Court considers on appeal using Court's independent judgment, but once the judicial estoppel doctrine's applicability to a set of facts has been confirmed, that is, Supreme Court has decided that the asserted declarations of position are indeed contradictory, Court reviews for an abuse of discretion the trial court's decision whether the doctrine should be applied, and

      2. positions taken by lessee in counterclaim for conversion and in affidavit seeking relief from default judgment were not clearly inconsistent, and thus judicial estoppel did not preclude assertion of counterclaim.

      Reversed and remanded.

      Carney, J., filed dissenting opinion.


    5. Josiah M. v. Department of Health & Social Services

      Supreme Court of Alaska. September 30, 2020 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2020 WL 5814199


      The superior court terminated both parents' rights to four children after finding the children in need of aid due to the mother's substance abuse, neglect, and failure to protect them from sexual abuse, and due to the father's abandonment, neglect, and his risk of sexual abuse to his daughters. The court concluded that the Office of Children's...



    6. C.D. v. State

      Supreme Court of Alaska. January 24, 2020 458 P.3d 81 2020 WL 400187


      FAMILY LAW Juvenile Justice. Fairness required exclusionary rule in juvenile jurisdiction waiver hearings such that testimony cannot be used against juvenile in subsequent proceedings.

      Synopsis

      Background: Juvenile was charged with murder. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District,


      Anchorage, Kevin M. Saxby, J., granted state's petition to waive juvenile jurisdiction. Juvenile appealed. The Court of Appeals certified the appeal, and Supreme Court accepted the certified appeal and assumed jurisdiction.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

      1. fundamental fairness requires adoption of an exclusionary rule when a minor bears the burden of rebutting the statutory presumption of being unamenable to treatment in the juvenile justice system: the minor's testimonial evidence at the waiver hearing cannot be used as substantive evidence over the minor's objection at any subsequent juvenile adjudication or adult criminal proceedings, and

      2. judge's allegedly biased comments in waiver order did not warrant assignment of a different judge on remand.

      Vacated and remanded.


    7. Pamiuqtuuq C. v. Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

      Supreme Court of Alaska. November 25, 2020 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2020 WL 6940433


      1. These consolidated appeals arise from the superior court's orders terminating parental rights to three Indian children. The appeals focus on the court's denial of the parents' motions to continue the termination trial and on related admissions of expert witness testimony. We therefore do not need to describe the earlier course of the child in...



    8. Ted S. v. Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

      Supreme Court of Alaska. October 28, 2020 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2020 WL 6327942


      A father appeals the termination of his parental rights. He makes three arguments. He first asserts the superior court clearly erred when it found his children were in need of aid due to his incarceration and failure to make adequate arrangements for their care. He also argues that the court clearly erred when it found that he had not remedied his...



    9. Alaska Laser Wash, Inc. v. Department of Transportation & Public Facilities

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 08, 2020 463 P.3d 176 2020 WL 2299931


    REAL PROPERTY Attorney Fees. State, which prevailed on car wash owner's inverse condemnation claim, was entitled to award of attorney's fees based on pretrial offer of judgment.

    Synopsis

    Background: Owner of car wash brought inverse condemnation action against the State, claiming business damages resulting from State's acquisition of car wash site as part of highway improvement project. Following jury trial, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eric A. Aarseth, J., denied State's motion for directed verdict, entered jury verdict in favor of owner, and awarded attorney's fees and costs to owner. State appealed, and the Supreme Court reversed, vacated, and remanded, 382 P.3d 1143. On remand, the Superior Court awarded attorney's fees to the State as the prevailing


    party pursuant to pretrial offer of judgment, and car wash owner appealed.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Bolger, C.J., held that State was entitled to award of attorney's fees based on pretrial offer of judgment.

    Affirmed.


    66. Alleva v. Municipality of Anchorage

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 24, 2020 467 P.3d 1083 2020 WL 4249429


    LITIGATION Settlements. Settlement of landowners' prior lawsuit against city and operators of soup kitchen and homeless shelter barred later lawsuit against same defendants.

    Synopsis

    Background: Property owners brought action against city and the operators of a charitable soup kitchen and a homeless shelter, which leased property from the city, for trespass, nuisance, and inverse condemnation arising out of the conduct of patrons of the soup kitchen and homeless shelter. City moved to dismiss on the basis of a settlement agreement executed in prior litigation between the parties, which released future claims, and operator of the homeless shelter joined the motion. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Jennifer S. Henderson, J., 2018 WL 8621715, granted the motion to dismiss. Property owners appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

    1. trial court could consider the settlement agreement on city's motion to dismiss without converting the motion into a motion for summary judgment, and

    2. settlement agreement barred the lawsuit. Affirmed.


    67. Rose D. v. Department of Health & Social Services , Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 08, 2020 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2020 WL 3830597


    A mother who relinquished her parental rights to a child retained the right to request a hearing if the Office of Children's Services (OCS) denied the grandmother's request to have the child placed with her. After the grandmother's request was denied, the mother requested a hearing. The superior court concluded that OCS had presented clear and...



    68. Matter of April S.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 24, 2020 467 P.3d 1091 2020 WL 4249431


    FAMILY LAW Child Protection. Mental health professional qualified as an expert, for purpose of ICWA, even though she did not possess knowledge of Alaska Native culture.

    Synopsis

    Background: Juvenile, an Alaskan Native teenager associated with Native Village who had been adjudicated a child in need of aid, requested a placement review after her arm was injured by staff at


    residential treatment facility where juvenile had been placed. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No. 3AN-18-00394, Yvonne Lamoureux, J., authorized a transfer to a new residential psychiatric treatment center. Juvenile appealed.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that mental health professional qualified as an expert, for purpose of Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA).

    Affirmed.

    Winfree, J., filed a concurring opinion in which Carney, J., concurred.


    69. Leigh v. Alaska Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 10, 2020 467 P.3d 222 2020 WL 3886434


    LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT Workers' Compensation. Workers' Compensation Board could require claimant to sign a release for mental health records, even though she did not request mental health benefits.

    Synopsis

    Background: During workers' compensation case, employer requested that workers' compensation claimant sign a release allowing it to access all of her mental health records for the preceding 19 years because of her pain complaints. Claimant sought a protective order. The Workers' Compensation Board's designee granted the order and employer appealed. A Board panel reversed and claimant petitioned for review. The Workers' Compensation Appeals Commission declined review. Claimant petitioned for review.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Bolger, C.J., held that the Board had the authority to require the claimant to sign a release for mental health records, even when the claimant had not requested compensation related to the claimant's mental health or otherwise put her mental health at issue. Vacated and remanded.


    70. Lovely v. Baker Hughes, Inc.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 20, 2020 459 P.3d 1162 2020 WL 1316364


    LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT Workers' Compensation. Entity must engage the services of, and enjoy the beneficial use of work performed by. contractor to be a project owner.

    Synopsis

    Background: Injured workers of contractor retained to work on project brought suit to recover for their injuries from company that had hired the contractor to perform this work and from its affiliated corporations. Defendants, each asserting the status of project owner, filed motions for summary judgment under exclusivity provision of the Workers' Compensation Act. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No. 3AN-15-06199, Eric A. Aarseth, J., 2018 WL 1612052, granted motion, and workers appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

    1. project owner, as that term is used in Workers Compensation Act, is someone who engages the services of, that is, contracts with a person to perform specific work and enjoys the beneficial use of that work, and

    2. fact questions precluded entry of summary judgment. Reversed and remanded.



    1. Helmericks v. Peak Trust Company

      Supreme Court of Alaska. September 30, 2020 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2020 WL 5814200


      After one beneficiary challenged the modification of a family trust, leading to over a decade of litigation, the trust beneficiaries reached and recorded an oral settlement following court-ordered mediation. The primary beneficiaries agreed that they and their descendants and heirs would be bound by the terms of the agreement. All beneficiaries...



    2. Loren R. v. Sharnel V.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. July 22, 2020 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2020 WL 4200124


      A mother petitioned for a domestic violence protective order against the father of their young daughter. She also filed a complaint for custody of the child. The court granted a 20-day ex parte protective order. After a hearing, it also granted the mother's petition for a long-term protective order. The father appealed the order. The superior court...



    3. Mouritsen v. Mouritsen

      Supreme Court of Alaska. March 13, 2020 459 P.3d 476 2020 WL 1223507


      FAMILY LAW Child Custody. Term presently resides in UCCJEA's exclusive, continuing jurisdiction provision is interpreted consistently with residency under Alaska law.

      Synopsis

      Background: Father filed post-divorce motion to enforce request for vacation time with children. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Yvonne Lamoureux, J., granted the request, and, following mother's motion for clarification, determined it did not have exclusive, continuing jurisdiction over its initial custody order in light of father's and mother's separate moves to South Carolina.

      Following denial of his motion for reconsideration, father appealed.

      Holdings: As matters of first impression, the Supreme Court, Bolger, C.J., held that:

      1. term presently resides in Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement Act (UCCJEA) provision governing exclusive, continuing jurisdiction should be interpreted consistently with residency under Alaska law, and

      2. father presently resided in Alaska and thus parties' physical presence in South Carolina did not deprive Alaska superior court of exclusive, continuing jurisdiction under the UCCJEA.

      Vacated and remanded.


    4. Israel v. Department of Corrections

      Supreme Court of Alaska. March 20, 2020 460 P.3d 777 2020 WL 1316359



      HEALTH Malpractice. DOC was not liable in inmate's medical malpractice action seeking rescission of psychiatric diagnosis, given the unrebutted correctness of diagnosis.

      Synopsis

      Background: Following paranoid schizophrenia diagnosis by psychiatrists employed by Department of Corrections (DOC), inmate brought medical malpractice action against DOC, seeking rescission of his diagnosis and damages. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Frank A. Pfiffner, J., granted DOC summary judgment, denied inmate's motions for reconsideration and for disqualification of the trial court judge, and subsequently entered final judgment against inmate and awarded DOC attorney fees. Inmate appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

      1. DOC was not liable on medical malpractice claim given the unrebutted correctness of inmate's diagnosis;

      2. trial court did not abuse its discretion by denying inmate's motion to compel discovery;

      3. appointment of expert advisory panel was not required to assist inmate in disproving his diagnosis;

      4. trial court did not abuse its discretion in denying inmate's motion to disqualify trial judge for bias;

      5. inmate was not immune to attorney fee award against him under statute shielding certain litigants from adverse attorney fee awards if they raised constitutional claims; and

      6. trial court did not abuse its discretion by awarding attorney fees to DOC. Affirmed.


    5. Lewis v. Brim

      Supreme Court of Alaska. June 12, 2020 473 P.3d 694 2020 WL 3116962


      LITIGATION Judgment. Foreign state judgments were not enforceable given later appellate decisions in that state.

      Synopsis

      Background: Judgment creditor brought enforcement action against judgment debtor after receiving foreign state judgments. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, No. 3PA-16-01814 CI, Jonathan A. Woodman, J., entered order in favor of creditor and awarded attorney's fees to creditor, and it denied debtor's motion to reconsider. Debtor appealed.

      [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that foreign state judgments at issue were not enforceable in Alaska.

      Reversed and remanded.


    6. Seater v. Estate of Seater

      Supreme Court of Alaska. April 10, 2020 461 P.3d 421 2020 WL 1814580


      REAL PROPERTY Water. Term high water line in orders enforcing easement by requiring removal of boulders below such line referred to average, not extreme, high tide.

      Synopsis

      Background: After partition of a parcel of coastal real property into northern and southern lots, and


      establishment of an easement in favor of the northern lot across the northwest corner of the southern lot, owner of the northern lot filed motions to enforce the easement. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Kenai, Carl Bauman, J., entered orders requiring owner of the southern lot to remove any boulders placed below the high water line on his property, and Jennifer K. Wells, J., defining high water line as the extreme high tide line, requiring removal of boulders below that line, and authorizing owner of the northern lot to remove such boulders herself and seek reimbursement. Owner of the southern lot appealed.

      [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Bolger, C.J., held that term high water line referred to the average or mean high tide, rather than the extreme high tide.

      Vacated and remanded.


    7. Matter of Annika G.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. April 29, 2020 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2020 WL 2062269


      A respondent appeals the superior court's 90-day involuntary commitment order, arguing that the court erred by finding she was gravely disabled and there was no less restrictive alternative than commitment. Seeing no error, we affirm the superior court's order. Annika G. is diagnosed with schizoaffective disorder, causing her to experience complex...



    8. Julio A. v. Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

      Supreme Court of Alaska. August 05, 2020 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2020 WL 4497830


      A father appeals the superior court order terminating his parental rights to his daughter, an Indian child under the Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA). We conclude that the record contains sufficient evidence to support the superior court's challenged findings that: (1) OCS met its active efforts burden and (2) returning the daughter to the father...



    9. McCormick v. Chippewa, Inc.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. March 20, 2020 459 P.3d 1172 2020 WL 1316367


      TORTS Judgment. Issue of whether seaman and ship's owner formed enforceable settlement agreement on seaman's personal injury claim precluded summary judgment.

      Synopsis

      Background: Seaman brought action seeking enforcement of purported settlement agreement between him and ship's owner. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Dani Crosby, J., 2015 WL 13203315, denied seaman's motion to compel discovery, granted owner's motion to exclude seaman's expert witness testimony and report, and granted summary judgment for owner. Seaman appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, C.J., held that:

      1. trial court did not abuse its discretion by limiting discovery to documents created surrounding settlement negotiations;

      2. trial court did not abuse its discretion by excluding seaman's expert witness testimony and report of


        attorney; but

      3. issue of whether parties formed enforceable settlement agreement precluded summary judgment. Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

      Stowers, J., dissented with opinion.


    10. M.M. through next friend Kirkland v. Department of Administration, Office of Public Advocacy

      Supreme Court of Alaska. April 24, 2020 462 P.3d 539 2020 WL 1969484


      FAMILY LAW Guardians. Public guardian may contract with service providers to help meet quarterly visitation requirement.

      Synopsis

      Background: Ward, by his next friend, brought declaratory judgment action against defendants including Office of Public Advocacy (OPA), which was ward's court-appointed public guardian, challenging OPA caseloads and standards of practice. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No. 3AN-15-10448 CI, Patrick J. McKay and Jennifer Henderson, JJ., granted summary judgment to OPA and awarded attorney's fees. Ward appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

      1. statute requiring public guardian to visit each of its wards at least once per quarter, read in conjunction with statute allowing OPA to contract for services necessary to carry out its duties, allows OPA to help meet quarterly visitation requirement by contracting with service providers to visit wards and report back to OPA, and

      2. attorney fee statute governing award of fees in an action involving an incompetent plaintiff, directing the court to hold the guardian by whom the plaintiff appeared in the actionresponsible for the paymentas if the guardian were the actual plaintiff does not direct courts to hold a next friend personally liable for attorney's fees.

      Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded. Bolger, C.J., dissented in part and filed opinion.


    11. Edna K. v. Jeb S.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. July 17, 2020 467 P.3d 1046 2020 WL 4033121


      FAMILY LAW Child Custody. Trial court committed legal error when it applied collateral estoppel to bar consideration of domestic violence in child custody modification proceeding.

      Synopsis
