      Background: Father of out of wedlock child filed a motion to modify child custody agreement to grant him primary physical custody of child. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Michael

      P. McConahy, J., declined to modify child custody. Mother appealed.

      [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that the trial court committed legal error when it applied collateral estoppel to preclude consideration of evidence of domestic violence in child custody modification proceeding.

      Reversed and vacated.


    12. Kendra H. v. Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

      Supreme Court of Alaska. May 13, 2020 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2020 WL 2464851


      A mother appeals the superior court's order terminating her parental rights to her two young children. The mother complied with the early stages of her Office of Children Services' (OCS) case plan, but due to learning difficulties failed to internalize the teachings of parenting courses. As the case advanced the mother ceased engaging in her case...



    13. Alaska Police Standards Council v. Maxwell

      Supreme Court of Alaska. June 12, 2020 465 P.3d 467 2020 WL 3116955


      LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT Public Employment. Substantial evidence did not support Police Standards Council's decision that officer who sought Permanent Fund Dividend (PFD) lacked respect for law.

      Synopsis

      Background: Police officer, who moved outside of Alaska for 70 days in one year, and 59 days in the following year, applied for and received Alaska Permanent Fund Dividend (PFD), based on his claim that he was an Alaska resident during both of those years. Thereafter, Alaska Police Standards Council determined he was dishonest and revoked his police certificate. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Ketchikan, Trevor N. Stephens, P.J., 2018 WL 3241692, reversed Council's decision. Council appealed.

      [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that substantial evidence did not support Council's decision that officer was not of good moral character, on the basis that he lacked respect for the law, and thus Council's revocation of officer's police certificate was unwarranted.

      Affirmed.

      Stowers, J., filed dissenting opinion.


    14. Baker v. Alaska State Commission for Human Rights

      Supreme Court of Alaska. September 18, 2020 476 P.3d 1120 2020 WL 5587313


      LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT Discrimination. Decision of Commission on Human Rights not to bring enforcement action even though it found marital status discrimination did not offend due process.

      Synopsis

      Background: Employee sought review of decision of Commission on Human Rights, which found that employer engaged in marital status discrimination but declined to bring enforcement action. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, No. 3AN-17-08687 CI, Jennifer Henderson, J., affirmed. Employee appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, C.J., held that:

      1. Commission's decision not to bring enforcement action was not so arbitrary and capricious as to offend due process;

      2. statute vesting Commission with substantial prosecutorial discretion did not violate due process; and


      3. evidence was sufficient to support finding that termination of employee was not retaliation. Affirmed.


    15. Robert A. v. Tatiana D.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. October 23, 2020 474 P.3d 651 2020 WL 6252917


      FAMILY LAW Visitation. Exceptional circumstances did not exist under law of the case doctrine to allow father seeking supervised visitation to relitigate sexual abuse claim.

      Synopsis

      Background: Father, who previously had been found to have sexually abused mother's child, filed motion to begin supervised visitation. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Philip M. Pallenberg, J., granted the motion in part and denied the motion in part, and father appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

      1. exceptional circumstances did not exist under the law of the case doctrine to allow father to relitigate sexual abuse claim;

      2. court appropriately exercised its discretion when it requested more information, including visitation plan with more detail, before ordering supervised visitation; and

      3. preponderance of the evidence standard was appropriate evidentiary standard at trial. Affirmed.


    16. Disciplinary Matter Involving Stockler

      Supreme Court of Alaska. February 07, 2020 457 P.3d 551 2020 WL 596917


      LEGAL SERVICES Discipline. Willful failure to file income tax returns warranted 18-month suspension from practice of law, with six months suspended, followed by probation.

      Synopsis

      Background: Bar Association and attorney entered into a stipulation for discipline by consent. [Holding:] The Supreme Court held that willful failure to file income tax returns warranted 18-month suspension from practice of law, with six months suspended, followed by probation for two years.

      Suspension ordered.


    17. West v. Alaska Mental Health Trust Authority

      Supreme Court of Alaska. July 24, 2020 467 P.3d 1064 2020 WL 4249420


      GOVERNMENT Public Lands. Sale of five parcels of public trust land was in trust's best interest.

      Synopsis

      Background: Opponent of sale of public trust land petitioned for judicial review from Land Office's decision approving sale. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Kenai, Lance Joanis, J., affirmed, and opponent appealed.

      [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that sale of five parcels of public trust land was in


      trust's best interest. Affirmed.


    18. Barnebey v. Department of Administration, Division of Motor Vehicles

      Supreme Court of Alaska. April 10, 2020 473 P.3d 682 2020 WL 1814582


      TRANSPORTATION Motor Vehicles. Excluding breath test instrument's margin-of-error evidence in license revocation case does not violate due process rights.

      Synopsis

      Background: Driver appealed Department of Motor Vehicles' (DMV) revocation of driver's license for driving under the influence of alcohol (DUI). The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Michael P. McConahy, J., 2017 WL 5957294, affirmed and awarded attorney's fees to State. Driver appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

      1. excluding breath test instrument's margin-of-error evidence does not violate due process rights;

      2. substantial evidence supported hearing officer's decision to uphold revocation;

      3. license revocation statute did not provide unfair notice in violation of due process; and

      4. the Superior Court was required to address driver's claimed constitutional exception to paying attorney's fees.

      Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.


    19. Bachner Company, Inc. v. Department of Administration, Division of General Services

      Supreme Court of Alaska. July 10, 2020 468 P.3d 703 2020 WL 3886436


      REAL PROPERTY Landlord and Tenant. State tenant did not breach lease by failing to pay for 1400 extra square feet when renewing lease after initial ten-year lease term expired.

      Synopsis

      Background: Landlord appealed Commission of Administration decision that State tenant had not materially breached lease by failing to pay for additional leased space. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Pamela Scott Washington, J., affirmed in part, and both landlord and State appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

      1. substantial evidence supported finding that state's failure to pay rent for 1400 square feet of formerly free space did not deprive landlord of a significant inducement to the making of the lease;

      2. substantial evidence supported finding that State did not breach lease by any failure to perform within a reasonable period of time in connection with rent for 1400 square feet of formerly free space;

      3. evidence was sufficient to support ALJ's finding that State tenant acted in good faith;

      4. landlord's notice was insufficient to terminate lease, and thus State validly exercised right to renew lease; and

      5. landlord waived claim for rent for extra space during initial ten-year lease period, but did not waive claim for rent for the extra space after State tenant exercised its option to renew lease.

      Affirmed in part and remanded. See also 387 P.3d 16.



    20. Office of Public Advocacy v. Superior Court, Third Judicial District

      Supreme Court of Alaska. May 01, 2020 462 P.3d 1000 2020 WL 2091833


      FAMILY LAW Child Protection. Sufficient evidence established indigent putative father as parent of baby, even absent scientific evidence, supporting appointment of counsel.

      Synopsis

      Background: Office of Children's Services (OCS) filed emergency petition to adjudicate newborn baby as child in need of aid (CINA). Mother and putative father requested counsel at emergency temporary custody hearing. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, Kari Kristiansen, J., appointed Public Defender Agency to represent mother and appointed Office of Public Advocacy (OPA) to represent putative father. OPA petitioned for discretionary review.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

      1. a putative father's parentage, for purposes of authorizing appointment of public agency counsel to the putative father in a CINA proceeding, may be judicially established without scientific proof of a genetic relationship, and

      2. evidence was legally sufficient to establish putative father as parent of newborn baby, even absent scientific, genetic testing, and thus, Superior Court could appoint OPA to represent putative father. Affirmed.


    21. Adams v. Workers' Compensation Benefits Guaranty Fund

      Supreme Court of Alaska. July 24, 2020 467 P.3d 1053 2020 WL 4249217


      LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT Workers' Compensation. Property owner was an employer under Workers' Compensation Act with respect to carpenter's injuries as result of fall from residence.

      Synopsis

      Background: Carpenter, who fell from roof of multifamily residence and suffered incomplete spinal cord injury and who worked for property owner that had no workers' compensation insurance, appealed from decision of the Workers' Compensation Appeals Commission, which reversed Workers' Compensation Board's finding that carpenter's injury was compensable.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

      1. property owner was an employer under Workers' Compensation Act, and

      2. having little income did not remove property owner's real estate business from the business or industry standard, as set forth in provision of Workers' Compensation Act defining employer. Reversed and remanded.


    22. Disciplinary Matter Involving White

      Supreme Court of Alaska. May 08, 2020 463 P.3d 169 2020 WL 2299577


      LITIGATION Judges. Judge's conduct in allowing case to remain undecided for ten months and in signing pay affidavits during the period violated the code of judicial conduct.



      Synopsis

      Background: Judicial disciplinary proceedings were initiated against now-retired judge. The Commission on Judicial Conduct filed a recommendation to accept agreed findings of fact and impose a public reprimand.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

      1. judge's conduct in allowing a matter to remain undecided for over ten months and in signing seven pay affidavits that indicating there was no matter referred to her which had been undecided for a period of more than six months violated the code of judicial conduct, and

      2. public sanction of judge was warranted. Public reprimand ordered.


    23. Beardsley v. Robert N. Jacobsen & Darlene F. Jacobsen Living Trust

    Supreme Court of Alaska. September 18, 2020 472 P.3d 500 2020 WL 5587280


    COMMERCIAL LAW Guaranty. Genuine issues of material fact surrounding aircraft business buyers' guarantees precluded summary judgment on claim they were liable for leases.

    Synopsis

    Background: Sellers of regional airline business brought action against buyers after buyer-controlled entity defaulted and declared bankruptcy. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Philip M. Pallenberg, J., granted judgment on the confession, entered partial final judgment against buyers and their purchasing group for the remaining principal on replacement note plus interest, and granted seller's motion for summary judgment on claim that buyers were personally liable for bankrupt entity's default. Buyers appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

    1. genuine issue of material fact as to whether buyers and sellers intended that buyers' original guarantee cover aircraft leases precluded summary judgment;

    2. genuine issue of material fact as to the extent of buyers' personal guarantee precluded summary judgment; and

    3. genuine issue of material fact as to whether sellers and buyers intended latest airplane leases to be new leases or extensions of old leases precluded summary judgment.

    Reversed and remanded.


    94. Matter of Arthur A.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. February 07, 2020 457 P.3d 540 2020 WL 596277


    HEALTH Mental Health. Thirty day involuntary commitment order would be vacated because committee's self-representation request was denied without adequate findings.

    Synopsis

    Background: Committee appealed from the 30-day involuntary commitment order entered after the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Michael A. MacDonald, J., determined that he was mentally ill, posed risk of harm, and was gravely disabled.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

    1. committee in involuntary commitment proceeding has at least an implied statutory right to self-


      representation, although that right is not absolute;

    2. if committee in involuntary commitment proceeding clearly and unequivocally invokes the self-representation right, superior court must hold preliminary hearing and consider factors outlined in McCracken v. State, 518 P.2d 85; and

    3. 30-day involuntary commitment order would be vacated because committee's self-representation request was denied without adherence to framework set forth in McCracken v. State.

    Vacated.


    95. Stephan P. v. Cecilia A.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 29, 2020 464 P.3d 266 2020 WL 2781240


    FAMILY LAW Witnesses. Finding as to competency of child to testify was required on remand prior to admitting recording of child describing incident as an exited utterance.

    Synopsis

    Background: Mother of child diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder filed petition for protective order against child's father, alleging that father kicked the child during an altercation that took place at arcade. Following transfer and hearing, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, Vanessa H. White, J., found that father committed assault and criminal trespass, granted petition, required father to undergo psychological evaluation, and subsequently denied father's motion for reconsideration and ordered father to pay mother's attorney fees. Father appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

    1. threshold finding as to competency of child to testify was required on remand prior to admitting recording of child describing incident;

    2. there was no evidence supporting finding that eyewitness was not confident that she had witnessed entire incident;

    3. statement in eyewitness's affidavit supporting motion for reconsideration was a clarification of the record; and

    4. evidence was insufficient to support finding that father committed criminal trespass. Reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded with instructions.


    1. Sykes v. Lawless

      Supreme Court of Alaska. October 23, 2020 474 P.3d 636 2020 WL 6252371


      REAL PROPERTY Easements. Property owner did not unreasonably interfere with access easement by installing locked gates to keep out traffic that was outside easement's scope.

      Synopsis

      Background: Easement holder brought action against property owner, alleging that owner's installation of locked gates across an access easement wrongfully interfered with holder's easement rights. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Douglas L. Blankenship, J., 2018 WL 8454322, granted owner's motion for enhanced attorney fees, and 2018 WL 8345387, entered total judgment in amount of $ 53,150.07 for owner. Holder appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

      1. owner's defenses were not barred by claim preclusion;

      2. owner's defenses were not barred by issue preclusion;


      3. easement did not include 40-acre parcel that holder had purchased from the state;

      4. owner did not unreasonably interfere with holder's easement rights by installing locked gates across easement;

      5. holder's failure to meet deadline for requesting extension of time for post-trial motions was not due to reasonable neglect; and

      6. award of enhanced attorney fees to owner was warranted. Affirmed.


    2. Galipeau v. Bixby as Trustee of Irrevocable Trust of Rose E. Fong

      Supreme Court of Alaska. November 13, 2020 476 P.3d 1129 2020 WL 6686114


      REAL PROPERTY Covenants and Restrictions. Neighbor's breach of subdivision's restrictive covenants in cutting trees was not independent tort for which he could be liable for punitive damages.

      Synopsis

      Background: Landowners brought action against neighbor, who was adjoining landowner, for breach of subdivision's restrictive covenants arising from neighbor's cutting down trees on his property to build a cabin. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Valdez, Jonathan A. Woodman, J., granted partial summary judgment for landowners on issue of liability and, after a bench trial on damages, entered judgment for landowners. Neighbor appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

      1. restoration costs was not an appropriate measure of damages;

      2. economic value of timber that was cut was not an appropriate measure of damages;

      3. there was no evidence of diminution in value of landowners' property that would allow more than nominal compensatory damages;

      4. landowners had no remedy for waste;

      5. as matter of first impression, landowners had no remedy for private nuisance;

      6. landowners had no remedy for trespass to trees; and

      7. neighbor's breach of restrictive covenants was not an independent tort for which neighbor could be liable for punitive damages.

      Vacated and remanded with instructions.


    3. Martinez v. Government Employees Insurance Company

      Supreme Court of Alaska. September 04, 2020 473 P.3d 316 2020 WL 5269204


      TORTS Negligence. Tortfeasor's insurer did not owe duty to property with respect to clean-up of fuel spill caused by tortfeasor, independent of duty owed to tortfeasor.

      Synopsis

      Background: Cabin owner brought action against tortfeasor's insurer, named insured, and tortfeasor who crashed his vehicle into cabin, causing damage to cabin heat fuel tank, resulting in fuel spill onto property, for damages for personal injury and property damage, and for damages relating to clean up of heat fuel that spilled onto property. Parties settled owner's claims against insured and tortfeasor, resulting in dismissal of claims against them with prejudice. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Michael P. McConahy, J., entered summary judgment for insurer on remaining claim on


      basis that insurer owed no actionable duty to owner. Owner appealed. The Supreme Court, 389 P.3d 27, reversed and remanded for determination whether insurer owed independent duty to cabin owner relating to clean-up. On remand, the Superior Court granted insurer's motion to preclude insured and tortfeasor from further participation in litigation, and then entered final judgment for insurer following hearing. Owner appealed. Insured and tortfeasor appealed from order barring them from participation in case.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

      1. hearing and judgment entered on remand did not exceed scope of Supreme Court's mandate on prior appeal, remanding case for further proceedings consistent with this opinion;

      2. insurer did not owe duty to cabin owner with respect to clean-up of fuel spill, independent of duty owed to tortfeasor;

      3. owner's proposed findings of fact and conclusions of law were filed on date they were received by trial court, not date they were mailed;

      4. trial court's issuance of findings of fact and conclusions of law before it received cabin owner's proposed findings and conclusions did not violate due process;

      5. trial court did not violate owner's right to due process when, on remand following appeal, it informed insurer that it did not need to file second motion for attorney fees and costs that had been awarded prior to appeal, and that those would be included in final judgment for insurer; and

      6. insured and tortfeasor were no longer parties to litigation after execution of settlement agreement, pursuant to which all claims that were or could have been asserted against them were dismissed with prejudice.

      Affirmed.


    4. Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services v. Dara S.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. January 24, 2020 458 P.3d 90 2020 WL 400248


      FAMILY LAW Child Protection. Any error in finding that mother and caregiver were similarly situated as to bond with child was harmless in proceedings to reinstate parental rights.

      Synopsis

      Background: Mother, whose parental rights to her son had been terminated as a result of her mental health issues, sought post-termination review and reinstatement of parental rights. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Pamela Washington, Judge Pro Tem, granted review and ultimately granted reinstatement request. Office of Children's Services (OCS) and the child's guardian ad litem (GAL) appealed. The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., 426 P.3d 975, affirmed in part and remanded in part with directions to make additional findings to support best interests determination. On remand and following evidentiary hearing, the Superior Court, Washington, Judge Pro Tem, confirmed its best interests determination. OCS and the GAL appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

      1. trial court complied with remand directions to make additional findings to support determination that reinstatement was in child's best interests;

      2. trial court's finding that mother and child's aunt, with whom child had been placed, were similarly situated with respect to their bonds with child was not clearly erroneous;

      3. any error in finding that mother and aunt were similarly situated with respect to their bonds with child was harmless;

      4. trial court was not precluded from making findings on remand based on status quo at time of original reinstatement proceedings;

      5. finding that aunt and uncle were not able to provide for child's emotional well-being because they


        refused to facilitate visitation with mother was not clearly erroneous;

      6. trial court did not improperly discount testimony from OCS's expert when determining whether it would be in child's best interests to reinstate mother's parental;

      7. record supported finding that child wanted to live with his mother, as would support determination that reinstating mother's parental rights was in child's best interests; and

      8. finding that OCS negligently supervised child while he was in the care of his aunt and uncle was not clearly erroneous.

      Affirmed.


    5. Jill Y. v. Casey Y.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. May 15, 2020 463 P.3d 833 2020 WL 2507348


      FAMILY LAW Child Custody. Evidence supported finding that there was connection between wife's use of alcohol and risk of violence to child.

      Synopsis

      Background: Husband filed divorce complaint, and wife moved for interim child custody, visitation, and support. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Bethany Harbison, J., consolidated divorce with petitions for domestic violence that each party had filed against the other, and, after series of hearings over six months, granted decree of divorce and issued custody, visitation, and support order. Wife appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carney, J., held that:

      1. superior court did not clearly err by finding, based upon credibility of witnesses' testimony, that wife failed to prove by a preponderance of the evidence that husband sexually assaulted her;

      2. evidence supported finding that there was connection between wife's use of alcohol and risk of violence to child;

      3. evidence supported finding that neither parent accepted or understood that continued substance use could expose child to harm;

      4. evidence supported finding that parents' substance abuse exacerbated domestic violence and led to their incarceration; and

      5. superior court appropriately considered and weighed statutory factors in restricting wife's use of alcohol and other substances when she had custody of child.

      Affirmed.


    6. Traugott v. ARCTEC Alaska

      Supreme Court of Alaska. June 12, 2020 465 P.3d 499 2020 WL 3117869


      LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT Workers' Compensation. Substantial evidence supported Board's determination that claimant's work was the substantial cause of his foot condition and resulting disability.

      Synopsis

      Background: Workers' compensation claimant sought benefits for osteomyelitis, a foot condition. The Workers' Compensation Board awarded benefits and employer appealed. The Workers' Compensation Appeals Commission reversed and claimant appealed.

      [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Carney, J., held that substantial evidence supported Board's


      determination that claimant's work was the substantial cause of his foot condition and resulting disability.

      Reversed and remanded.


    7. Downing v. Country Life Insurance Company

      Supreme Court of Alaska. October 09, 2020 473 P.3d 699 2020 WL 5988226


      INSURANCE Life. Insured did not have reasonable expectation that paid-up additions rider to whole life policy had a million-dollar flat death benefit in second year.

      Synopsis

      Background: Insured's assignee brought action against life insurer, seeking payment of a flat death benefit of $1,095,741 pursuant to the paid-up additions rider (PUAR) to whole-life policy for insured's accidental death that occurred in second year of policy. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eric A. Aarseth, J., granted summary judgment for insurer. Assignee appealed. [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Carney, J., held that insured did not have a reasonable expectation that PUAR had a flat death benefit of over one million dollars in second year of policy.

      Affirmed.


    8. Ott v. Runa

      Supreme Court of Alaska. May 08, 2020 463 P.3d 180 2020 WL 2299935


      FAMILY LAW Child Custody. Record supported finding that mother was not motivated by illegitimate secondary motives when she sought permission to relocate out of state with child.

      Synopsis

      Background: After the parties divorced, mother sought to relocate out of state with child. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Thomas A. Matthews, J., modified custody and allowed mother to relocate out of state with child. Father appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

      1. the trial court correctly applied the legitimacy standard when determining whether mother's motivation for requesting to relocate out of state with child was legitimate;

      2. the record supported finding that mother was not motivated by illegitimate secondary motives when she sought permission to relocate out of state with child;

      3. evidence supported the trial court's finding that the best interest of the child factor that considered the capability and desire of each parents to meet child's needs favored mother; and

      4. evidence supported the trial court's finding that the best interest of the child factor that considered the emotional stability provided by child's extended family in Alaska favored mother.

      Affirmed.


    9. Antenor v. Department of Corrections

      Supreme Court of Alaska. April 17, 2020 462 P.3d 1 2020 WL 1898214



      CIVIL RIGHTS Prisons. Department of Corrections (DOC) did not violate Alaska Constitution's free speech provision by denying inmate access to computer programming book.

      Synopsis

      Background: Inmates in Department of Corrections (DOC) custody brought motions to enforce agreement settling prior class action lawsuit, enumerating inmates' rights, and guaranteeing the availability of specific rehabilitative programs based on allegations that increased charges for local telephone calls violated the agreement and inmates' state rights to rehabilitation and telephone access and that officers' decision not to permit inmate to have a certain computer programming book violated his rights to free speech and reformation. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Pamela Scott Washington, Judge pro tem, denied motions. Inmates appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carney, J., held that:

      1. record did not provide sufficient evidence for Supreme Court to determine whether the rates charged for local telephone calls violated inmates' statutory right to reasonable telephone access, warranting remand;

      2. as matter of first impression, DOC did not violate Alaska Constitution's free speech provision by denying inmate access to computer programming book; and

      3. DOC did not violate inmate's constitutional right to reformation by denying inmate access to computer programming book.

      Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.


    10. Hurd v. Henley

      Supreme Court of Alaska. December 31, 2020 478 P.3d 208 2020 WL 7778996


      REAL PROPERTY Adverse Possession. Adverse possession prescription of good faith but mistaken belief does not require that belief of ownership be reasonably as well as sincerely held.

      Synopsis

      Background: Southern landowner brought action against northern landowner for trespass, negligence, slander of title, and to quiet title to his property after northern landowner build shed and then a larger shop on portion of southern landowner's property. Northern landowner counterclaimed to quiet title to the contested property, asserting that he had adversely possessed the disputed area. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Kenai, Anna M. Moran and Lance E. Joanis, JJ.,

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, C.J., held that:

      1. evidence was sufficient to support finding that northern landowner regularly graveled and repeatedly parked vehicles in contested area;

      2. northern landowner's actions demonstrated continuous, hostile, and notorious possession required for adverse possession;

      3. Court's definition of the area adversely possessed was adequate;

      4. as a matter of first impression, adverse possession statute's prescription of a good faith but mistaken belief does not require that the claimant's belief of ownership be reasonably held as well as sincerely held; and

      5. evidence was sufficient to support finding that northern landowner possessed a good-faith belief that disputed portion of southern landowner's parcel where northern landowner build shed was part of his own property.

      Affirmed.


    11. Anderson v. Alaska Housing Finance Corporation

      Supreme Court of Alaska. April 17, 2020 462 P.3d 19 2020 WL 1898227


      REAL PROPERTY Mortgages and Deeds of Trust. Failure of state housing corporation which held deed of trust to provide mortgagor opportunity to be heard before foreclosure violated due process.

      Synopsis

      Background: Mortgagor brought action against Alaska Housing Finance Corporation (AHFC), which held deed of trust and promissory note, alleging due process violations arising out of non-judicial foreclosure. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Frank A. Pfiffner, J., No. 3AN-17-05945 CI, granted summary judgment of AHFC. Mortgagor appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

      1. AHFC was government actor that was required to satisfy restrictions imposed on state action by due process clause;

      2. mortgagor's interest in home was sufficient property interest to invoke due process;

      3. mortgagor did not waive due process rights by signing promissory note and deed of trust;

      4. AHFC's failure to expressly provide opportunity to be heard prior to non-judicial foreclosure violated due process; and

      5. mortgagor was not required to demonstrate prejudice. Reversed and remanded.

      Stowers, J., filed dissenting opinion.


    12. Basey v. Department of Public Safety, Division of Alaska State Troopers, Bureau of Investigations

      Supreme Court of Alaska. April 24, 2020 462 P.3d 529 2020 WL 1969446


      GOVERNMENT Records. State employee disciplinary records are confidential personnel records subject to disclosure only if related to discipline as to legislative audits.

      Synopsis

      Background: Arrestee filed action seeking disclosure of alleged public records relating to investigation of his criminal case, including two state troopers' disciplinary records. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Douglas L. Blankenship, J., dismissed. Arrestee appealed. The Supreme Court, 408 P.3d 1173, reversed and remanded. On remand, the Superior Court entered judgment denying request. Arrestee appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

      1. State's waiting until remand from prior appeal to assert an additional exception to disclosure was not a per se waiver of exception;

      2. law of the case doctrine did not apply to bar consideration of issue of disclosure of state employee disciplinary records; and

      3. state employee disciplinary records are confidential personnel records subject to disclosure only if records reflect discipline for violation of provision concerning legislative audits.

      Affirmed.


    13. Kenneth P. Jacobus, P.C. v. Kale nka


      Supreme Court of Alaska. June 05, 2020 464 P.3d 1231 2020 WL 3025199


      LEGAL SERVICES Attorney Fees. Attorney was entitled to reasonable value of services provided prior to when conflict of interest arose, but was not entitled to fees after that date.

      Synopsis

      Background: Probate proceeding was initiated, in which discharged attorney sought to recover attorney fees for work performed in administering estate and wrongful death action that resulted in settlement. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Mark Rindner, J., entered orders prohibiting attorney from revealing confidential information to estate beneficiary, finding that attorney violated his duties to his client, and forfeiting attorney's contingency fee in wrongful death action.

      Attorney appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carney, J., held that:

      1. trial court's order prohibiting attorney from revealing confidential information did not require him to violate rule of professional conduct;

      2. trial court did not err in concluding that attorney violated duty of loyalty by creating trust for settlement funds;

      3. attorney violated duty of loyalty when he made unauthorized disbursement of settlement funds to himself for attorney's fees;

      4. attorney was entitled to attorney fees for reasonable value of services provided prior to conflict arising but was not entitled to any attorney's fees after conflict arose; and

      5. trial court acted within its discretion in determining that attorney's ethical breaches were so egregious as to warrant forfeiture of contingency fee.

      Affirmed.


    14. Angelica C. v. Jonathan C.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. March 20, 2020 459 P.3d 1148 2020 WL 1316362


      FAMILY LAW Child Custody. Court committed legal error when it failed to account for father's sexual abuse of mother in its analysis of best interest of child factors.

      Synopsis

      Background: Unwed father sought to modify custody order, while mother sought to terminate father's parental rights because his paternity was rooted in a criminal sex act. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Louis J. Menendez, J., dismissed mother's petition and awarded sole custody to father, with visitation for mother and both sets of grandparents. Mother appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

      1. termination of parental rights statute permitted mother to petition for termination of father's parental rights in the pending child custody modification case;

      2. superior court committed legal error when it failed to account for father's sexual abuse of mother in its analysis of best interest of child factors; and

      3. mother's unwillingness to facilitate relationship between child and father should have been excluded from trial court's analysis when determining best interest of child.

      Reversed and remanded.


    15. Thiele v. Thiele


      Supreme Court of Alaska. October 02, 2020 473 P.3d 327 2020 WL 5856768


      FAMILY LAW Marital Property. Court appropriately focused on husband's professional corporation, rather than medical clinic, when valuing property in divorce action.

      Synopsis

      Background: Wife filed for divorce. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Kenai, Anna M. Moran, J., entered property division orders and declined to award costs or attorney's fees. Wife appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carney, J., held that:

      1. court appropriately focused on husband's professional corporation, rather than medical clinic, when valuing property;

      2. wife failed to show that husband's medical practice was part of the marital estate;

      3. evidence supported finding that husband did not intend that his medical practice business be marital;

      4. wife failed to carry burden of showing that husband's medical practice increased in value during the marriage; and

      5. court properly exercised its discretion when it declined to award wife attorney's fees and litigation costs.

      Affirmed.


    16. Butts v. Department of Labor & Workforce Development

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 10, 2020 467 P.3d 231 2020 WL 3886856


    LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT Workers' Compensation. Doctors' opinions were sufficient to rebut the presumption that claimant suffered any work-related injury beyond the left knee contusion.

    Synopsis

    Background: Administrative assistant for the Department of Labor and Workforce Development petitioned for review of decision of the Workers' Compensation Appeals Commission affirming Workers' Compensation Board's decision awarding compensation for assistant's left knee and back for only a limited period of time following workplace fall.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, C.J., held that:

    1. Board appropriately considered claimant's knee injuries and back injury as distinct injuries and used the three step presumption analysis, to evaluate the compensability of claim, individually for each alleged injury;

    2. doctors' opinions were sufficient to rebut the presumption that claimant suffered any work-related injury beyond the left knee contusion;

    3. Board did not create a medical opinion, and instead, Board relied on specific medical evidence to craft its legal decision about which of claimant's conditions was compensable; and

    4. Board, which found claimant's left knee arthroscopic surgery to be compensable, was not legally required to order additional medical care.

    Affirmed.


    112. Rosenbaum v. Shaw

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 13, 2020 459 P.3d 467 2020 WL 1223505



    FAMILY LAW Child Support. Parent's voluntary overpayments of child support, while SSA is making CIB payments, cannot be used as credit against future child support.

    Synopsis

    Background: Father filed suit against mother for overpaid child support, alleging that mother received four years of children's insurance benefit (CIB) payments from Social Security Administration (SSA), in addition to regular monthly child support payments from father. Father also requested reimbursement or credit for overpaid health insurance premiums. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Jennifer S. Henderson, J., denied reimbursement for either overpayment, and father appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

    1. as matter of first impression, parent's voluntary overpayments of child support, while SSA is making CIB payments, cannot be used as credit or setoff against future child support payments and cannot be reimbursed;

    2. as matter of first impression, if parent has no child support arrearages and makes duplicative child support payments, even after SSA begins making CIB payments, appellate court will treat those duplicative payments as gratuity;

    3. as matter of first impression, father was not entitled to credit for overpaid child support; and

    4. regardless of whether father gave mother notice of his purchase of health insurance, father's continued full payment of child support was a voluntary overpayment which was not subject to reimbursement or credit.

    Affirmed.


    113. James v. Alaska Frontier Constructors, Inc.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 31, 2020 468 P.3d 711 2020 WL 4380623


    LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT Workers' Compensation. There was no evidence that worker was sister company's special employee, precluding immunity on such basis under Workers' Compensation Act.

    Synopsis

    Background: Construction worker, who was injured while working on ice road project, filed personal injury lawsuits against two companies, including sister company of worker's employer and company with which sister company had business relationship, alleging that sister company negligently and recklessly sent worker out in dangerous weather conditions and that companies were operating a joint venture. After actions were consolidated, the Superior Court, Second Judicial District, Utqiagvik (Barrow), Romano D. DiBenedetto, J., 2018 WL 8189696, granted companies summary judgment on basis of statutory employer immunity from injury claims under Workers' Compensation Act. Worker appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

    1. there was no evidence that worker's employer and sister company were joint venturers;

    2. there was no evidence that worker was sister company's special employee under lent employee doctrine;

    3. fact issues as to whether companies were contractors for project precluded summary judgment in favor of companies on such basis under Act's exclusive liability provision;

    4. fact issue as to whether sister company was subcontractor for project precluded summary judgment in favor of companies on such basis under Act's exclusive liability provision; and


    5. fact issue as to whether worker's employer had subcontractor relationship with sister company precluded summary judgment in favor of companies on such basis under Act's exclusive liability provision.

    Reversed, vacated, and remanded.


    114. Matter of Rabi R.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 31, 2020 468 P.3d 721 2020 WL 4380962


    HEALTH Mental Health. Court did not err by finding clear and convincing evidence that committee was gravely disabled, which was requirement for involuntary commitment.

    Synopsis

    Background: Committee appealed from decision of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Andrew Peterson, J., adopting the standing master's recommendations that he be involuntarily committed for 30 days and that involuntary medication petition be granted.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carney, J., held that:

    1. it was error for trial court to fail to conduct or order mental health professional to conduct screening investigation after filing of the involuntary commitment petition to hospitalize committee for evaluation;

    2. trial court's error in failing to conduct or order mental health professional to conduct screening investigation, after filing of the involuntary commitment petition, was harmless;

    3. it was not error for trial court to rely on psychiatrist's expert testimony;

    4. testimony supported trial court's finding that committee mistakenly believed that he had been cured, despite stopping his medication;

    5. evidence in involuntary commitment proceeding did not support allegations that committee was minimally verbal and unable to keep food down and that he had been hospitalized for 49 of the past 57 days;

    6. trial court's error in relying on allegations that were only made in petitions for involuntary commitment and evaluation, which had not been admitted as evidence, was harmless;

    7. trial court did not err by finding clear and convincing evidence that committee was gravely disabled, which was requirement for involuntary commitment;

    8. trial court did not err by finding clear and convincing evidence that there was no less restrictive alternative to involuntary commitment of committee; and

    9. trial court did not err by granting the involuntary medication petition. Affirmed.


    1. Reinstatement Brion

      Supreme Court of Alaska. April 03, 2020 460 P.3d 1224 2020 WL 1647853


      LEGAL SERVICES Discipline. Disbarred attorney failed to comply with requirements for his reinstatement.

      Synopsis

      Background: Attorney disciplinary proceedings were commenced. After the Supreme Court of the State of Alaska, 212 P.3d 748, ordered disbarment, attorney petitioned for reinstatement.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

      1. process afforded attorney in reinstatement hearing comported with due process;


      2. disbarred attorney failed to comply with conditions required for his reinstatement; and

      3. disbarred attorney failed to demonstrate he fully accepted responsibility for his actions or that he was morally fit to practice law.

      Petition denied.


    2. Daphne O. v. Department of Health & Social Services , Office of Children's Services

      Supreme Court of Alaska. April 22, 2020 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2020 WL 1933651


      The parents of an Indian child appeal the termination of their parental rights, arguing that the Office of Children's Services (OCS) failed to meet its active efforts burden and that the superior court's qualification of the expert witness required by the Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA) was erroneous. We previously remanded this case for...



    3. Larson v. Department of Corrections, Board of Parole

      Supreme Court of Alaska. November 20, 2020 476 P.3d 293 2020 WL 6815061


      CRIMINAL JUSTICE Pardon. Information release requirement for clemency applicants did not violate unconstitutional burdens doctrine.

      Synopsis

      Background: Prisoner serving sentence for murder brought action for declaratory and injunctive relief against Board of Parole, alleging that Board's refusal to forward his clemency application to Governor, unless he executed a general information release form and a medical information release form that were required under administrative framework for clemency, violated procedural due process and the unconstitutional conditions doctrine. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, Kari Kristiansen, J., granted summary judgment to Board. Prisoner appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

      1. a clemency applicant has procedural due process protection against being unreasonably prevented from accessing the clemency process; but

      2. there was no risk of erroneous deprivation of privacy interest allegedly protected by procedural due process;

      3. state had sound reasons for requiring information release forms as part of initial application package; and

      4. unconstitutional burdens doctrine was not violated. Affirmed.


    4. Department of Transportation and Public Facilities v. Osborne Construction Company

      Supreme Court of Alaska. May 01, 2020 462 P.3d 991 2020 WL 2091831


      GOVERNMENT CONTRACTS Limitations. Public works contract did not require notice of denial of informal claim for additional compensation to trigger 90-day limit to submit written claim.



      Synopsis

      Background: Public contractor sought review of decision of Department of Transportation and Public Facilities (DOT) denying claim for additional compensation for renovation of airport building and improvement of building site to withstand earthquakes. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Erin B. Marston, J., reversed. DOT petitioned for review, which was granted.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carney, J., held that:

      1. contract did not require DOT to notify contractor of a denial of informal claim for additional compensation to trigger 90-day limitation period for submitting written claim, and

      2. contractor knew or should have known that it had potential claim for additional compensation, triggering 90-day window to submit claim, at the very latest when project was completed. Reversed.


    5. Burns v. Burns

      Supreme Court of Alaska. June 26, 2020 466 P.3d 352 2020 WL 3478073


      FAMILY LAW Evidence. Court improperly relied on exhibit, that was never admitted into evidence, for its finding that ex-wife inaccurately reported that ex-husband interrogated children.

      Synopsis

      Background: Ex-husband filed motion for child custody modification. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Dani Crosby, J., modified custody by granting ex-husband primary physical custody and denied ex-wife's motion for reconsideration, and she appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, C.J., held that:

      1. superior court did not deprive ex-wife of due process, nor did it err in assigning her psychological evaluation little weight;

      2. superior court made findings based on the statutory best interests of children factors, and record did not support ex-wife's contention that superior court modified custody to punish her;

      3. superior court did not clearly err in finding that overall tenor of ex-husband's calls with children was loving, engaging, creative and appropriate;

      4. superior court improperly relied on exhibit, that was never admitted into evidence, for its finding that ex-wife inaccurately reported that ex-husband interrogated the children daily about what ex-wife was doing; and

      5. superior court's error in relying on exhibit, that was never admitted into evidence, for its finding that ex-wife inaccurately reported that ex-husband interrogated the children daily about what ex-wife was doing, was harmless.

      Affirmed.


    6. Roman v. Karren

    Supreme Court of Alaska. April 17, 2020 461 P.3d 1252 2020 WL 1898219


    FAMILY LAW Child Custody. Alaska was not an inconvenient forum for child custody proceeding, even though the parties were no longer Alaska residents.

    Synopsis

    Background: As part of dissolution of marriage proceeding, which was converted to divorce


    proceeding, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Andrew Guidi, J., issued divorce decree, and following separate custody trial, awarded custody to father with visitation to mother. Mother appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

    1. Alaska court had initial jurisdiction to determine child custody;

    2. Alaska was not an inconvenient forum, even though the parties were no longer Alaska residents;

    3. court appropriately weighed custody investigator's report and testimony when making child custody determination; and

    4. court appropriately considered all relevant statutory factors when awarding custody. Affirmed.


    121. Cora G. v. Department of Health & Social Services , Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. April 24, 2020 461 P.3d 1265 2020 WL 1969400


    FAMILY LAW Child Protection. Expert witness as to a child's mental injury must be offered and affirmatively accepted as qualified expert in judge-tried child in need proceeding.

    Synopsis

    Background: A child in need of aid (CINA) proceeding was brought seeking to terminate mother and father's parental rights. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Seward, Charles T. Huguelet, J., terminated rights in a judge-tried case. Mother and father appealed, and appeals were consolidated. Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

    1. as a matter of first impression, an expert witness as to a child's mental injury must be offered and affirmatively accepted as qualified expert in a judge-tried CINA proceeding;

    2. trial court's error in failing to qualify State's witness as an expert witness on child's mental injury was not harmless; and

    3. clear and convincing evidence did not support finding that conduct by or conditions created by parent resulted in mental injury to child.

    Vacated and remanded.

    Bolger, C.J., filed dissenting opinion.


    1. Vue v. Walmart Associates, Inc.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. November 06, 2020 475 P.3d 270 2020 WL 6535023


      LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT Workers' Compensation. Employer did not rebut presumption of compensability for post-traumatic stress disorder of claimant who was shot during loss-prevention job at store.

      Synopsis

      Background: Claimant, an asset protection worker who was shot in face at store, sought review of decision of Workers' Compensation Appeals Commission affirming Workers' Compensation Board's partially denying request for temporary total disability (TTD) benefits relating to post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

      1. TTD claim relating to PTSD was a physical-mental claim;


      2. claimant's testimony and medical records were sufficient to attach presumption of compensability;

      3. employer did not rebut presumption of compensability; and

      4. employer's controversion of medical care and TTD benefits was frivolous. Reversed and remanded with instructions.


    2. State v. Pulusila

      Supreme Court of Alaska. July 02, 2020 467 P.3d 211 2020 WL 3581636


      CRIMINAL JUSTICE Probation. In probation revocation proceedings, court should first ask whether defendant violated condition of probation and then determine disposition to be made.

      Synopsis

      Background: Probation revocation proceedings were brought for fifth time against defendant, who allegedly violated conditions of probation by ingesting methamphetamine and by possessing ammunition and drug paraphernalia. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Paul E. Olson, J., revoked probation and imposed remainder of time on defendant's sentence. Defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, 425 P.3d 175, reversed. State filed petition for hearing, which was granted.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

      1. in probation revocation proceedings, first, the trial court should ask a whether the defendant has in fact acted in violation of one or more conditions of his probation, and, second, it must determine the disposition to be made once violation of the conditions of probation is established, abrogating Silas v.

        State, 425 P.3d 197, and Charles v. State, 436 P.3d 1084, and

      2. conditions of probation prohibiting the possession of contraband will be construed to refer to careless or negligent misconduct.

      Judgment of Court of Appeals reversed; remanded to superior court.


    3. Seal v. Welty

    Supreme Court of Alaska. December 18, 2020 477 P.3d 613 2020 WL 7416543


    LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT Workers' Compensation. Workers' Compensation Board's approval of wrongful death settlement did not convert settlement payment to workers' compensation benefits.

    Synopsis

    Background: Deceased construction worker's mother, as personal representative of his estate, brought wrongful death action against contractor and property owner, neither of which had workers' compensation insurance. Mother also filed claim for workers' compensation death benefits with the Workers' Compensation Board, including a claim against the Workers Compensation Benefits Guaranty Fund. Mother entered into a settlement of her wrongful death claim against the property owner, which was approved by the Workers' Compensation Board, and the workers' compensation action was dismissed in its entirety. Mother also dismissed her wrongful death claims against property owner but expressly preserved her claims against contractor. Contractor filed motion for summary judgment on the basis of workers' compensation exclusivity, and the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Thomas A. Matthews, J., granted the motion. Mother appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:


    1. settlement agreement established mother's election of a civil remedy, rather than a workers' compensation remedy, and

    2. Board's approval of settlement did not convert the settlement into a payment of workers' compensation.

    Reversed, vacated, and remanded.


    125. Weaver v. ASRC Federal Holding Company

    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 05, 2020 464 P.3d 1242 2020 WL 3025201


    LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT Workers' Compensation. Workers' Compensation Board reasonably interpreted its own regulations as requiring a separate written claim for each injury.

    Synopsis

    Background: Workers' compensation claimant brought action seeking review of Workers' Compensation Appeals Commission's decision affirming Workers' Compensation Board's denial of his claim for temporary total disability and continuing medical benefits due to back pain.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, C.J., held that:

    1. employer rebutted presumption of compensability;

    2. claimant's due process rights were not violated when Board excluded physicians' reports, even though claimant did not waive right to cross-examine either physician; and

    3. Board reasonably interpreted its own regulations as requiring a separate written claim for each injury.

    Affirmed.


    1. Edna L. v. Department of Health & Social Services , Office of Children's Services

      Supreme Court of Alaska. December 24, 2020 477 P.3d 637 2020 WL 7653949


      FAMILY LAW Child Protection. Parents did not waive right to have reasonable-time-to-remedy determination made on individual case basis in termination proceedings.

      Synopsis

      Background: After mother and father opted into Families with Infants and Toddlers (FIT) Court for their child-in-need-of-aid (CINA) cases, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, Vanessa H. White, J., terminated their parental rights, based on findings that they failed within a reasonable time to remedy the conduct that rendered their two children in need of aid. Mother and father appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

      1. FIT Court's 12-month timeline to reach permanency contravened statutory command that reasonable time to remedy be determined on case-by-case basis, and

      2. mother and father did not knowingly and voluntarily waive their rights to fact-based determination of whether they had reasonable time to remedy when they opted into FIT Court.

      Reversed and remanded.


    2. Chinuhuk v. State

      Supreme Court of Alaska. September 18, 2020 472 P.3d 511 2020 WL 5587314


      CRIMINAL JUSTICE Sentencing. Defendant could not take advantage of ameliorative sentencing provisions at probation revocation proceeding.

      Synopsis

      Background: In multiple cases, sex offenders moved for discharge from probation. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Gregory Miller and Michael Spaan, JJ., and the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Bethel, Michael Spaan, J., denied motions. Offenders appealed. The Court of Appeals, 413 P.3d 1215, affirmed. Offenders petitioned for hearing, which was granted.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

      1. use of word reduced, in statute governing sentencing for felonies, providing that the period of probation of sex offender's initial sentence is in addition to any sentence received under [section of statute governing sentences for certain sex offenses] and may not be suspended or reduced, refers to the period of probation;

      2. State's saving statute is not limited to situations where the repeal of a statute would have abated a prosecution at common law; and

      3. defendant was not sentenced anew when he appeared before court in probation revocation proceeding, and thus, pursuant to saving statute, defendant could not take advantage of ameliorative sentencing provisions, as created by repeal of statute, at that proceeding.

      Affirmed.

      Carney, J., filed dissenting opinion.


    3. Meyer v. Alaskans for Better Elections

      Supreme Court of Alaska. June 12, 2020 465 P.3d 477 2020 WL 3117316


      GOVERNMENT Elections. Ballot initiative embraced single subject of election reform, and, thus, initiative complied with Alaska Constitution's one-subject rule.

      Synopsis

      Background: Sponsor of ballot initiative instituting three substantive changes to Alaska's election laws brought action challenging lieutenant governor's certification denial based on finding that initiative violated constitutional requirement that proposed initiative bills be confined to one subject. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Yvonne Lamoureux, J., 2019 WL 6499035, granted summary judgment in favor of sponsor and denied lieutenant governor's motion for summary judgment, and, 2019 WL 6499033, entered final judgment for sponsor. Lieutenant governor and state's elections office appealed.

      [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that initiative embraced single subject of election reform, and, thus, initiative complied with Alaska Constitution's one-subject rule.

      Affirmed.


    4. Phillips v. Bremner-Phillips

      Supreme Court of Alaska. December 18, 2020 477 P.3d 626 2020 WL 7416721



      FAMILY LAW Equitable Distribution. Trial court's presumptively equitable 50/50 division of the marital estate was not clearly unjust.

      Synopsis

      Background: Husband filed for divorce. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Andrew Guidi, J., divided the marital estate equally, awarding the rental properties to husband and a large equalization payment to wife, and both parties appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

      1. appreciation and income from the community trust properties remained husband's separate property;

      2. although husband proved that funds in bank account were income from community trust property, that had been husband's separate property, he did not overcome the strong presumption that, by placing the rental income in the joint account, he intended to make it marital;

      3. trial court did not clearly err when, in awarding the fourplex to husband, it reasoned that he had lived there significantly longer than wife had; and

      4. trial court's presumptively equitable 50/50 division of the marital estate was not clearly unjust. Affirmed.


    5. Forrer v. State

      Supreme Court of Alaska. September 04, 2020 471 P.3d 569 2020 WL 5269487


      GOVERNMENT Securities. Bonding scheme creating corporation to issue subject-to-appropriation bonds to purchase oil and gas exploration tax credits was unconstitutional.

      Synopsis

      Background: Taxpayer brought action against the State and the Commissioner of the Department of Revenue in his official capacity, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief on the grounds that bonding scheme in statute creating public corporation capable of borrowing up to $1 billion through the issuance of subject-to-appropriation bonds to purchase outstanding oil and gas exploration tax credits violated state constitution. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Sitka, M. Jude Pate, J., granted State's motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim, and taxpayer appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that:

      1. State's submission of statutory history materials not in the pleadings did not require court to convert motion to dismiss into motion for summary judgment;

      2. scheme violated state constitution's prohibition against state debt absent ratification by the voters;

      3. scheme did not limit recourse to the leased property;

      4. scheme improperly created long-term obligation binding future generations or Legislatures;

      5. scheme was not merely refunding indebtedness of the state;

      6. scheme did not permissibly establish revenue bonds; and

      7. scheme was unconstitutional in its entirety.

      Affirmed in part, reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.


    6. Peidlow v. Williams

      Supreme Court of Alaska. March 20, 2020 459 P.3d 1136 2020 WL 1316358



      NATIVE AMERICANS Child Welfare. Superior Court was required to grant full faith and credit to Tribal Court custody order.

      Synopsis

      Background: Father brought action for shared custody of Indian child, mother requested sole legal custody and primary physical custody, and grandparents petitioned for visitation. The Superior Court, Second Judicial District, Utqiagvik (Barrow), Angela M. Greene, J., awarded sole legal and physical custody of child to father, and allowed mother supervised visitation, and further found that the Tribal Court had no jurisdiction over the case. Mother subsequently moved to modify custody. The Tribal Court claimed jurisdiction, and ordered that the child would be placed in trial physical custody with the mother, but remain in the legal custody of the tribe. The Superior Court, Second Judicial District, Utqiagvik (Barrow), Angela M. Greene, J., denied mother's motion to modify custody and ruled the Tribal Court's order was not enforceable. Mother appealed. The Tribal Court's motion to intervene was denied, and it appealed.

      [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Bolger, C.J., held that the Superior Court was required to grant full faith and credit to Tribal Court custody order.

      Vacated and remanded.

      Stowers, J., filed dissenting opinion.


    7. Southeast Alaska Conservation Council, Inc. v. Department of Natural Resources

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 21, 2020 470 P.3d 129 2020 WL 4913634


    GOVERNMENT Public Lands. Exchange of Statehood Act selected parcel for Mental Health Act selection was disposal of interest in state lands under public notice clause.

    Synopsis

    Background: Conservation organization brought action against Department of Natural Resources (DNR) and Mental Health Trust Authority, seeking to invalidate DNR's transfer of bay to the mental health trust based on arguments that the transaction violated contractual and statutory terms of earlier mental health trust settlement and violated constitutional public notice requirement. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Frank A. Pfiffner, J., granted summary judgment in favor of DNR and Trust Authority and partially granted organization's motion for judicial notice. Organization appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Bolger, C.J., held that:

    1. DNR's exchange of Alaska Statehood Act selected parcel for Alaska Mental Health Enabling Act selection was disposal of interest in state lands within meaning of Alaska Constitution's public notice clause;

    2. DNR's conversion of bay from Statehood Act selected parcel to Mental Health Act selection conflicted with statute that authorized settlement of breach of fiduciary duty claims under Mental Health Act and set forth list of parcels that would not be designated as mental health trust land; and

    3. organization's motion for judicial notice that provisions of Mental Health Act and Alaska Land Transfer Acceleration Act barred the DNR and federal government from signing agreement closing out State's entitlement under Mental Health Act fell outside scope of judicial notice.

    Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

    Winfree, J., filed opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part. Stowers, J., filed opinion dissenting in part.


    133. Department of Health & Social Services , Office of Children's Services v. Zander B.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. October 30, 2020 474 P.3d 1153 2020 WL 6373346


    FAMILY LAW Child Protection. Court did not err in finding that Office of Children Service's decision to place child with paternal grandmother was abuse of discretion.

    Synopsis

    Background: Office of Children's Services (OCS) appealed from decision of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, Kari Kristiansen, J., finding that OCS abused its discretion when it decided to place child with his paternal grandmother in child in need of aid (CINA) proceeding.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

    1. allowing foster parents to intervene as a matter of course in CINA proceedings is contrary to goals of CINA statutes, and courts should be hesitant to allow it;

    2. superior court did not abuse its discretion when it allowed foster parents to intervene in CINA proceeding;

    3. superior court did not err in finding that OCS's decision to place child with paternal grandmother was an abuse of discretion; and

    4. OCS could consider additional information bearing on child's best interests as it came in, especially if it showed that a placement decision already made by OSC should be reconsidered.

    Affirmed.

    Winfree, J., dissented and filed opinion in which Carney, J., joined.


    134. Disciplinary Matter Involving Gonzalez-Powell

    On June 3, 2019, the Area Hearing Committee (AHC) issued a report to the Alaska Bar Association Disciplinary Board with Findings of Fact, Conclusions of Law, and Recommendations in the disciplinary matter of attorney Erin R. Gonzalez-Powell; the Area Hearing Committee recommended disbarring Gonzalez-Powell. The Disciplinary Board agreed with the...

The mother appealed, arguing that the superior court improperly admitted and relied on hearsay evidence to make its termination findings and erred by finding that the Office of Children's Services (OCS) made reasonable efforts to reunify the family.       Fourteen years after the Alaska Board of Dental Examiners imposed a five-year period of probation on a dentist, he asked the Board to take him off probationary status.       A mother appeals the termination of her parental rights, arguing that the superior court committed legal error by considering the potential permanency of the child's foster placement in its best interests determination.       Supreme Court of Alaska. March 09, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 701866


      Divorced parents disagree about vaccinating their two minor children. The father wants to vaccinate the children per their pediatrician's recommendation.     12. Mulligan v. Department of Law, Office of Attorney General

      Supreme Court of Alaska. June 08, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 2066044


      The superior court dismissed an unrepresented woman's complaint because of its failure to state a claim upon which relief could be granted. The woman appeals, but in her briefing she fails to address any of the superior court's reasons for dismissal. Because she waived any argument that might allow her to succeed in overturning the superior court's...

    30. Chang v. Rhee

    31. Nordlund v. Department of Corrections

      Supreme Court of Alaska. December 09, 2022 520 P.3d 1178 2022 WL 17543859


      CRIMINAL JUSTICE Prisons. Prisoner was not prejudiced by refusal of Department of Corrections hearing officer to accept in-person testimony at prison disciplinary hearing.

      Synopsis

      Background: Prisoner appealed after Department of Corrections hearing officer imposed suspended sentence of ten days' punitive segregation for conduct or language likely to interfere with institution's orderly administration and security and prison superintendent denied his appeal. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Catherine M. Easter, J., determined that Department's decision was supported by some evidence. Prisoner appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

      1. prisoner was not prejudiced by refusal of Department hearing officer to accept in-person testimony;

      2. absence from trial court record of surveillance footage of incident between prisoner and correctional officer did not prejudice prisoner;

      3. as matter of first impression, trial court properly relied on some evidence standard of review;

      4. as matter of first impression, standard satisfies Alaska constitution; and

      5. evidence against prisoner satisfied such standard. Affirmed.
