    37. Matter of Jonas H.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 22, 2022 513 P.3d 1019 2022 WL 2900291


    HEALTH Mental Health. Clear and convincing evidence supported trial court's determination that patient with mental health history was gravely disabled, as required for involuntary commitment.

    Synopsis

    Background: State psychiatric institution filed petitions for order authorizing commitment of patient for up to 30 days to undergo mental health treatment and authorizing involuntary administration of psychotropic medication. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Herman G. Walker, J., adopted findings of special master and granted petitions. Patient appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carney, J., held that:

    1. clear and convincing evidence support determination that patient was gravely disabled, as required for involuntary commitment up to 30 days, and

    2. failure by master and trial court to adequately address best-interests factors set forth in Myers v. Alaska Psychiatric Institute, 138 P.3d 238, required vacatur of medication order.

    Affirmed in part and vacated in part.


    38. Wooden v. Wooden

    Supreme Court of Alaska. January 12, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 108600


    The superior court modified an original child support order. The father moved for reconsideration, arguing that the order improperly imputed income and miscalculated his G.I. Bill education benefits. The court denied reconsideration because the father's motion was untimely, and we affirmed that order on appeal. Two years later, in response to each...



    1. Barton v. City of Valdez

      Supreme Court of Alaska. January 21, 2022 504 P.3d 910 2022 WL 189008


      GOVERNMENT Immunity. City's decision whether to remove hazardous tire swing overhanging a cliff was not planning-type decision protected by discretionary function immunity.

      Synopsis

      Background: Resident brought negligence action against city, seeking to recover damages for injuries she sustained when a tire swing overhanging a cliff in an undeveloped area of a city park bumped into her while she was standing at the edge of a bluff, causing her to fall over the bluff and leaving her partially paralyzed and in a wheelchair. Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Valdez, Patrick J. McKay, J., entered summary judgment for city. Resident appealed.

      [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Borghesan, J., held that city was not protected by discretionary function immunity.

      Reversed and remanded.


    2. Arthur v. Arthur


      Supreme Court of Alaska. September 07, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 4092433


      The superior court divided marital assets in a divorce case. One party contends that the court erred in its analysis of relevant statutory factors, abused its discretion in the asset division, and made insufficient findings for meaningful appellate review. We remand two issues for further proceedings; we affirm the remainder of the court's...



    3. Parlier v. CAN-ADA Crushing & Gravel Co.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. July 20, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 2825997


      A corporation sued the owners of corporate shares for failure to pay annual fees during a two year period. The defendants included two LLCs, a man, and his daughter. The man filed numerous counterclaims alleging mismanagement of corporate property and two claims alleging fraudulent transfer of assets. After lengthy litigation, the superior court...



    4. Young v. State

      Supreme Court of Alaska. January 28, 2022 502 P.3d 964 2022 WL 259952


      GOVERNMENT Elections. Public interest exception to mootness doctrine did not apply in voter's challenge to pre-certification distribution of initiative booklets.

      Synopsis

      Background: Voter brought action for declaratory and injunctive relief against State, Division of Elections, and state officials, relating to initiative to change state's election laws, and alleging that initiative process under state Constitution would be violated if Division made signature booklets available to initiative's sponsors, pursuant to court-approved stipulation, before initiative had been certified. In response, State and sponsors entered new stipulation providing that State would not make signature booklets available until the court ordered it. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Yvonne Lamoureux, J., 2020 WL 5269634, granted summary judgment to State and state officials, based on mootness and voter's lack of standing. Voter appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

      1. public interest exception to mootness doctrine did not apply, and

      2. voluntary cessation exception to mootness doctrine did not apply. Affirmed.


    5. Walsh v. Singleton

      Supreme Court of Alaska. June 08, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 2092566


      A father and mother both living in Anchorage have been engaged in a longstanding child custody dispute. In 2021 the mother purchased a home in Wasilla, where she planned to relocate, and she filed a motion in the superior court requesting a permanent change of school. The court determined that the parties existing shared custody schedule...


    6. Office of the Lieutenant Governor, Division of Elections v. Corbisier ex rel. B.L.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. December 30, 2022 522 P.3d 174 2022 WL 17999196


      GOVERNMENT Elections. Injunction prohibiting certification of special mail-in election due to concerns of visually-impaired advocacy organization was not warranted.

      Synopsis

      Background: Advocacy organization for visually impaired Alaskans filed action seeking a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction that would prevent the Division of Elections, which had created an online ballot delivery system for special election for vacant seat in the U.S. House of Representatives, from certifying election results until visually impaired voters were able to participate independently. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Una Gandbhir, J., granted the injunction, and the State appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

      1. interests of the Division of Elections in an orderly and timely election were legitimate and shared with the general public, and could not be adequately protected during the pendency of an indefinite injunction;

      2. organization failed to clearly show a probability of success on the merits; and

      3. injunction was insufficiently specific to inform the Division what was required to comply. Reversed and vacated.


    7. Alice H. v. Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    12. Kristine S. v. David I.

      Supreme Court of Alaska. September 14, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 4231241

    13. Ziegler v. Atsbeha

      Supreme Court of Alaska. December 21, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 17826659


      A mother appeals a custody modification order giving the father primary physical custody of their child and allowing him to relocate out of state with their child.     14. Workers Compensation Benefits Guaranty Fund v. Adams


      Supreme Court of Alaska. October 07, 2022 518 P.3d 280 2022 WL 5332648


      LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT Workers' Compensation. Substantial evidence supported determination that claimant's intoxication did not proximately cause injury when cribbing underneath ladder gave way.

      Synopsis

      Background: Claimant, a carpenter who used alcohol and cocaine before his work-related injury in a fall from ladder, sought review of Workers' Compensation Appeals Commission's decision that reversed the Workers' Compensation Board's finding of non-compensability for the injury, which occurred when cribbing underneath ladder gave way. The Supreme Court, 467 P.3d 1053, reversed and remanded.

      The Commission affirmed Board's decision. Workers Compensation Benefits Guaranty Fund appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carney, J., held that:

      1. Board could discount intoxication-related testimony of witness who did not testify about proximate cause of injury;

      2. substantial evidence supported Board's determination that claimant's intoxication did not proximately cause his injury;

      3. Board's findings about claimant's impairment were adequate; and

      4. claimant's equivocal testimony about checking the cribbing was not an admission of intoxication as cause of injury.

      Affirmed.


    15. Duvall v. Portfolio Recovery Associates, LLC

      Supreme Court of Alaska. December 21, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 17826658


      Portfolio Recovery Associates, LLC (PRA) is a debt collection agency. PRA filed a complaint against Jeannie Duvall to collect roughly $1,700 in unpaid credit card debt. Duvall challenged PRA's claims under a number of legal theories, including violations of Alaska's Unfair Trade Practices and Consumer Protection Act (UTPCPA). In April and May 2020...



    16. Miller v. Miller

      Supreme Court of Alaska. May 11, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 1486171


      Brian and Loreta Miller divorced after nearly 15 years of marriage. During their marriage, Brian served in the United States Navy and worked as an anesthetist, acquiring an education, sizeable earnings, and retirement benefits. Meanwhile, Loreta was primarily a stay-at-home mother working occasional jobs. The superior court divided the marital...



    17. Evertson v. Sibley

      Supreme Court of Alaska. November 18, 2022 520 P.3d 157 2022 WL 17073028


      REAL PROPERTY Deeds. Deeds conveyed as a result of fraud in the factum are void and confer no protection on even a bona fide purchaser or lender.



      Synopsis

      Background: Grantor's son brought action against bank, which attempted to foreclose on property which daughter had used as security for loan secured by deed of trust, alleging that daughter had committed fraud in the factum and that a trust held title to the property through unrecorded quitclaim deed. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Palmer, Jonathan A. Woodman, J., granted summary judgment to bank, dismissed the complaint, and entered final judgment. Son appealed.

      Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

      1. lender bank did not have actual, constructive, or inquiry notice of any other deed that would affect bank's bona fide lender status;

      2. alleged indicia of fraud did not obligate lender bank to investigate into any third-party claim to the property when making loan;

      3. deeds conveyed as a result of fraud in the factum are void and confer no protection on even a bona fide purchaser or lender; and

      4. allegations of fraud in the factum with regard to deed to grantor's daughter were sufficient to survive dismissal.

      Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.


    18. Jacoby C. v. Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

      Supreme Court of Alaska. April 20, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 1162514


      A father appeals the termination of his parental rights, arguing that the Office of Children's Services (OCS) failed to make active efforts to reunify him with his child as required by the Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA). In particular, he argues that OCS's efforts in the second half of the case did not cure its failure to make active efforts in...



    19. Clark v. Ide

      Supreme Court of Alaska. December 07, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 17484923


      A divorcing couple agreed to joint legal custody of their two children. Over the next few years the parents litigated the issue of the children's schooling: the father wanted the children to remain in their brick-and-mortar school but the mother wanted them home-schooled. Six years after their divorce the parties filed cross-motions for...



    20. McDonald v. Department of Corrections, Alaska Parole Board

    Supreme Court of Alaska. October 28, 2022 519 P.3d 345 2022 WL 15595954


    CRIMINAL JUSTICE Parole. Inmate should have filed post-conviction relief application instead of a lawsuit to have parole denial vacated and parole application reconsidered.

    Synopsis

    Background: Inmate brought pro se action against the Department of Corrections (DOC), the DOC's commissioner, and the Parole Board to have the denial of his discretionary parole application vacated


    and to have the application returned to the Board for reconsideration. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Kenai, Lance E. Joanis, J., dismissed action. Inmate appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

    1. inmate was required to bring his claim in an application for post-conviction relief rather than in a separate civil lawsuit, and

    2. trial court should have converted the action to a post-conviction relief application. Affirmed.


    59. Jerome S. v. Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. April 06, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 1022032


    The Office of Children's Services (OCS) took custody of a boy when he was almost two years old. His mother struggled with substance abuse, and his father was incarcerated for significant periods of time. OCS primarily directed its efforts toward the mother and did not meaningfully involve the father in case planning or maintain contact with him....



    60. TREVOR PAUL FAIRBANKS, Appellant, v. CARA EILEEN FOX, f/k/a Cara Fox Fairbanks, Appellee.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 18, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 1565677


    In this divorce case a man appeals issues related to the division of property and the child support award. With regard to the property division, we conclude: (1) the superior court's findings are insufficient to support its decision about the husband's contribution of separate assets to the construction of the marital home; (2) the husband waived...



  3. Fairbanks v. Fox

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 17, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 3443662


    In this divorce case a man appeals issues related to the division of property and the child support award. With regard to the property division, we conclude: (1) the superior court's findings are insufficient to support its decision about the husband's contribution of separate assets to the construction of the marital home; (2) the husband waived...



  4. Griffith v. Hemphill

    Supreme Court of Alaska. December 16, 2022 521 P.3d 584 2022 WL 17726651


    COMMERCIAL LAW Contracts. Commercial tenants were properly awarded over $19,000 in damages against landlord for roof damage despite tenants' lack of receipts to prove damages.

    Synopsis


    Background: Landlord of commercial building brought holdover action against tenants after lease expired, and tenants counterclaimed for breach of contract and related claims, seeking damages for landlord's alleged failure to properly maintain property and to maintain property insurance. After a bench trial, the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Andrew Guidi, J., entered judgment for tenants on their breach-of-contract counterclaim, awarding $19,330 in damages and over $59,000 in attorney fees based on landlord's having rejected tenants' offer of judgment, and dismissed other claims and counterclaims. Landlord appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Borghesan, J., held that:

    1. tenants' breach-of-contract claim based on landlord's failure to maintain roof accrued when clogged scuppers on roof caused it to fail, an event that occurred within the limitations period, and did not accrue during previous unrelated incident of roof leakage that occurred outside the limitations period;

    2. landlord waived argument that tenants' damages evidence should have been excluded based on their alleged failure to comply with initial-disclosure requirements;

    3. superior court's damages award was not clearly erroneous; and

    4. superior court's attorney-fee award was not erroneous. Affirmed.


  5. Slade R. v. Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 31, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 3906701


    The Office of Children's Services (OCS) took emergency custody of a young child after she sustained serious injuries while in her mother's care. In the two years afterward, the child's father moved in and out of jail and the mother left Alaska. OCS petitioned to terminate the father's parental rights. The superior court granted the petition,...



  6. Matter of Estate of Lionel D

Supreme Court of Alaska. November 30, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 17333062


In this appeal from probate proceedings the primary issues are whether the superior court erred or abused its discretion by denying a request to compel discovery, by removing the estate's personal representative for self-dealing and conflict of interest, and by approving the successor personal representative's final distribution of the estate....



65. J.P. v. State

Supreme Court of Alaska. March 18, 2022 506 P.3d 3 2022 WL 817583


FAMILY LAW Child Protection. Foster parents' appeal of order transferring child in need of aid case involving Indian child to tribal court was rendered moot.

Synopsis

Background: In child in need of aid case involving Indian child, Indian tribe petitioned to transfer jurisdiction to tribal court. The Superior Court, No. 3AN-17-00032, transferred jurisdiction. Foster parents moved to stay the transfer order, and for reconsideration, which was denied. Foster parents


appealed.

[Holding:] The Supreme Court held that foster parents' appeal of order transferring child in need of aid case involving Indian child to tribal court was rendered moot.

Appeal dismissed.

Winfree, J., filed a concurring opinion in which Carney, J., joined.


  1. LaPoint v. Watkins

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 06, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 2452380


    The superior court granted a husband's request to leave the courtroom during his divorce trial until after his wife concluded her testimony. At the conclusion of the wife's testimony, the court heard her closing argument and tentatively decided some aspects of the divorce. The court thereafter issued final written orders. The husband appeals the...



  2. Notti v. Hoffman

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 15, 2022 513 P.3d 245 2022 WL 2761570


    FAMILY LAW Settlements. Parties' property settlement agreement was enforceable between them when the parties signed it.

    Synopsis

    Background: Ex-wife brought action against ex-husband, alleging sexual assault, which she termed rape by fraud, misrepresentation, and intentional infliction of emotional distress. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, William F. Morse, P.J., granted ex-husband's motions to dismiss and for summary judgment, and ex-wife appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carney, J., held that:

    1. Alaska law does not recognize a tort of rape by fraud;

    2. ex-husband's allegedly false assertion that he wanted to continue in the marriage, which statement was made immediately before the parties had sex and before their divorce, was not actionable; and

    3. property settlement agreement was enforceable between the parties upon its execution. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.


  3. Guy v. Providence Health & Services Washington

    Supreme Court of Alaska. January 14, 2022 502 P.3d 13 2022 WL 128833


    HEALTH Medical Records. Court incorrectly applied vicarious liability rule in jury instructions for patient's breach claim arising from unauthorized disclosure of his records.

    Synopsis

    Background: Patient brought action against hospital, alleging that it had breached its contractual obligations to him when a hospital employee disclosed his health information without authorization in violation of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA). The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Jennifer Henderson, J., entered judgment for hospital after jury returned a


    verdict in its favor. Patient appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Borghesan, J., held that:

    1. trial court applied incorrect legal standard for breach of contract by instructing the jury on vicarious liability, and

    2. patient demonstrated prejudice warranting reversal of judgment for hospital. Reversed and remanded.


  4. Matter of Carl S.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 27, 2022 510 P.3d 486 2022 WL 1699181


    HEALTH Mental Health. Civil commitment order based on statutory ground of extreme neglect as form of grave disability that was not pleaded in petition violated due process.

    Synopsis

    Background: State filed petition for 30-day civil commitment on statutory ground of grave disability under theory of distress and deterioration. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Adolf

    V. Zeman, J., rejected committee's objection to magistrate judge's recommendation for commitment on statutory ground of grave disability predicated on extreme neglect, adopted recommendation in full, and issued commitment order. Committee appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Borghesan, J., held that:

    1. civil commitment order on petition that was signed only by treating psychiatrist, rather than statutorily required two mental health professionals who had evaluated committee, was not product of magistrate judge's or trial court's open disregard of requirement, and thus did not relieve committee of obligation to prove obvious prejudice from error, under plain error rule, and

    2. commitment order based on statutory ground of extreme neglect as form of grave disability that was not pleaded in petition violated due process.

    Vacated.


  5. Jones v. Biggs

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 06, 2022 508 P.3d 1121 2022 WL 1464091


    GOVERNMENT Municipalities. Allegation that assembly member violated emergency order was sufficient to state prima facie case for recall, on basis of misconduct in office.

    Synopsis

    Background: Citizen appealed municipal clerk's denial of his application for petition to recall member of municipality's assembly, which alleged that assembly member committed misconduct in office. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Kevin M. Saxby, J., 2021 WL 6288658, reversed municipal clerk's denial of application. Municipality appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carney, J., held that:

    1. trial court's error in referencing edition of Black's Law Dictionary that followed enactment of current grounds for recall, rather than version that preceded such enactment, in discussing definition of misconduct in office was harmless;

    2. municipal clerk improperly determined that misconduct in office required component of dishonesty, private gain, or improper motive; and

    3. citizen's allegation was sufficient to state prima facie case of misconduct in office.


    Affirmed.


  6. Gottstein v. Gottstein

    Supreme Court of Alaska. September 14, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 4231226


    A divorcing couple negotiated a settlement of issues related to division of their property and payment of spousal support. Under the terms of the settlement, which was adopted in the court's divorce order, the husband was permanently required to pay spousal support in monthly installments and provide security to guarantee the payments. The husband...



  7. Matter of Office of Public Advocacy

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 12, 2022 514 P.3d 1281 2022 WL 3331561


    LITIGATION Counsel. Indigent father was entitled to designation of counsel in child custody proceeding, during which mother was represented by appointed pro bono counsel.

    Synopsis

    Background: Father, against whom mother had initiated child custody action, while represented by counsel provided through Alaska Legal Services Corporation (ALSC), moved for assistance of counsel. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Bethel, Terrence P. Haas, J., granted motion, ordering Office of Public Advocacy (OPA) to designate counsel to assist father. Office petitioned for interlocutory review, which was granted.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Carney, J., held that:

    1. interlocutory review proceeding was moot; but

    2. public interest exception to mootness applied; and

    3. father was entitled to appointment of counsel by OPA. Affirmed.

    Borghesan, J., filed concurring opinion.


  8. Pederson v. Arctic Slope Regional Corporation

    Supreme Court of Alaska. September 23, 2022 517 P.3d 606 2022 WL 4392734


    BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS Shareholders. Corporate shareholder, who had requested to inspect corporation's records and documents, had proper purpose in making inspection request.

    Synopsis

    Background: Corporate shareholder brought action against corporation, alleging violation of statutory right to inspect certain records and documents. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Andrew Peterson, J., 2019 WL 11593023, sanctioned shareholder for failing to appear for deposition, and the Superior Court, William F. Morse, J., 2020 WL 7973958, later determined the shareholder did not assert proper purpose for inspection request. Shareholder appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. shareholder had proper purpose in making inspection request;


    2. shareholder's statements did not establish shareholder disclaimed such purpose; and

    3. imposition of sanctions on shareholder for failing to comply with discovery was warranted. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.


  9. Matter of B.G.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. January 26, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 222712


    A man was involuntarily committed for mental health treatment. He appeals the commitment order, contending that the superior court erred by determining that there was a reasonable expectation his condition could improve and that commitment was the least restrictive treatment available. Because we conclude that the superior court did not clearly err...



  10. Park v. Spayd

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 20, 2022 509 P.3d 1014 2022 WL 1594771


    HEALTH Limitations. Wife's negligence claim against ex-husband's provider for allegedly overprescribing opioids to husband, which led to his addiction, was time-barred.

    Synopsis

    Background: Wife brought pro se action against former husband's medical provider, asserting claims for negligence and malpractice due to provider's alleged overprescription of opioid medications to husband, which had role in his drug addiction and caused injury to wife, in form damage to wife's and husband's business and the marital estate. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Peter Ramgren, J., entered summary judgment in provider's favor. Wife appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Borghesan, J., held that:

    1. wife's claims were time-barred;

    2. equitable estoppel did not apply; and

    3. even if it applied, equitable tolling would not have saved untimely claims. Affirmed.


  11. Matter of Adoption of J.R.S.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 04, 2022 505 P.3d 234 2022 WL 628548


    FAMILY LAW Adoption. Birth father did not willfully fail to support or communicate with child and thus consent of birth father to adoption was required.

    Synopsis

    Background: Prospective adoptive parents, who were child's maternal aunt and uncle, petitioned for sole legal and primary physical custody of child. Prospective adoptive parents filed motion for interim custody of child, and Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Yvonne Lamoureux, J., granted the motion. Prospective adoptive parents subsequently petitioned to adopt child, and the Superior Court ordered that the custody and adoption cases be heard together and bifurcated the trial. After trial, the Superior Court found that birth father's consent to adoption was required and dismissed the


    adoption petition. Prospective adoptive parents appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

    1. birth father's failure to communicate with child was not unreasonable or without justification;

    2. birth father did not abandon child for period of at least six months; and

    3. birth father did not willfully fail to support child. Affirmed.


  12. Miller v. Department of Administration, Division of Retirement and Benefits

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 03, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 3059638


    A participant in a defined benefit plan of the Alaska Public Employee Retirement System (PERS) appealed a denial of benefits through the administrator's internal appeals process, but the denial of benefits was affirmed. The participant then filed a notice of appeal to the Office of Administrative Hearings (OAH) with the Division of Revenue and...



  13. Dunham v. Johnson

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 10, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 3225384


    A mother and father each sought primary physical custody of their nineyear-old son. Following a custody trial, the superior court decided that the child's best interests required that the mother, who lives in Oregon, have primary physical custody. The father appeals, arguing that the court failed to give proper weight to the child's need for...



  14. Dapo v. Department of Health & Social Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 13, 2022 509 P.3d 376 2022 WL 1511525


    TORTS Negligence. Adoptive mother's equitable apportionment claim against agency, seeking to shift liability for son's damages from sexual abuse, was not assignable.

    Synopsis

    Background: Adoptive son brought action against adoptive mother seeking damages for her alleged sexual abuse of him 13 years earlier. Mother filed third-party equitable apportionment claim against Office of Children's Services (OCS), which she assigned to son in exchange for his releasing her from liability. The Superior Court denied OCS's motion to dismiss the apportionment claim based on the statute of repose. The Supreme Court granted a petition for review, and vacated and remanded. On remand, the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Michael P. McConahy, J., granted OCS's motion to dismiss the apportionment claim. Son appealed. The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., 454 P.3d 171, reversed and remanded. On remand, the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Michael P. McConahy, J., granted OCS's motion to declare the assignment void, dismissed the equitable apportionment claim with prejudice, and awarded OCS attorney fees. Son appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Jennifer S. Henderson, J., held that:

    1. OCS had standing to challenge the assignment;

    2. law of the case doctrine did not preclude OCS's challenge to the assignment;

    3. as a matter of first impression, mother's equitable apportionment claim against OCS was not


      assignable;

    4. agreement between mother and son was unenforceable; and

    5. trial court abused its discretion by dismissing mother's equitable apportionment claim with prejudice. Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded with instructions.


  15. Karine W. v. Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 16, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 792088


    A mother with an extensive history of substance abuse appeals the termination of her parental rights to her daughter. The Office of Children's Services (OCS) took custody of the daughter as an infant after the mother used drugs while pregnant. Over four years later, the superior court terminated the mother's parental rights. The court acknowledged...



  16. Reed S. v. Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. December 30, 2022 522 P.3d 182 2022 WL 17999271


    FAMILY LAW Child Protection. Evidence was sufficient to support finding that child's injury was more likely than not a result of father's actions or omissions.

    Synopsis

    Background: Office of Children's Services (OCS) filed petition for adjudication of child as a child in need of aid (CINA) and for temporary custody of child, alleging that mother had allowed contact between child and father in contravention of a military protective order and of a temporary custody order entered on OCS's earlier emergency petition for CINA adjudication based on incident in which child was injured while in father's care. Following bench trial, the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Patricia L. Haines, J., entered CINA adjudication. Mother and father appealed. During pendency of appeal, OCS moved to release custody of child and close case on basis that there were no longer active safety concerns, which motion the Superior Court granted. Mother and father moved to dismiss appeals as moot and vacate CINA adjudication order.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

    1. collateral-consequences exception to mootness doctrine applied to allow Supreme Court to review merits of parents' appeal;

    2. evidence was sufficient to support finding that child's injury was more likely than not a result of father's actions or omissions, as could support CINA adjudication based on substantial physical harm or risk of substantial physical harm; and

    3. evidence was sufficient to support finding that mother's conduct in response to no-contact restrictions between father and child created substantial risk that child would suffer substantial physical harm, as would support CINA adjudication.

    Affirmed.


  17. Jones v. Jones

    Supreme Court of Alaska. March 04, 2022 505 P.3d 224 2022 WL 628545



    FAMILY LAW Settlements. Federal law did not bar enforcement of indemnity provision of property settlement agreement after husband's military retirement changed to disability pay.

    Synopsis

    Background: Former wife filed motion to enforce property settlement agreement that was entered in divorce action, seeking payment of her monthly share of former husband's military retirement pay after his retirement was converted to disability pay. After the motion was denied, former wife filed motion to set the settlement agreement aside. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Andrew Guidi, J., ruled that it was unnecessary to set aside the settlement agreement and instead enforced the agreement's indemnity provision, ordering former husband to make the monthly payment and to pay arrears. Former husband appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Borghesan, J., held that:

    1. indemnity provision of the property settlement agreement required former husband to directly pay former wife $1,200 per month, which was amount she had been awarded from the non-disability portion of his military retirement, after the retirement had been converted to disability pay;

    2. federal law did not prohibit trial court from enforcing the indemnity provision of property settlement agreement;

    3. law-of-the-case doctrine did not bar trial court from enforcing the indemnity provision even though former wife's prior motion to enforce had been denied;

    4. indemnity provision of the property settlement agreement was not unconscionable; and

    5. trial court did not impermissibly rely on an unpled theory. Affirmed.


  18. State v. Alaska Legislative Council

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 12, 2022 515 P.3d 117 2022 WL 3331488


    EDUCATION Finance. Requirement that budget be determined annually was not subject to an exception for forward-funded appropriations for public education.

    Synopsis

    Background: State Legislative Council, acting on behalf of Legislature, brought action against Governor for declaratory judgment that the governor violated his constitutional duties by failing to execute appropriation for public education and an injunction requiring him to do so. Non-profit education advocacy group intervened in support of appropriation bill. On cross-motions for summary judgment, the Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Daniel Schally, J., 2019 WL 8643544, entered judgment against Governor and awarded attorney's fees to Legislative Council and advocacy group as prevailing parties. Governor appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

    1. implicit in the budgetary clauses of state constitution, namely the Dedicated Funds Clause, the Budget Clause, the Appropriations Clause, and the Veto Clause, is a requirement that the budget be determined annually, not through forward-funded appropriations, and

    2. constitutional requirement that budget be determined annually was not subject to an exception to allow forward-funded appropriations for public education.

    Reversed and vacated.


  19. Rock H. v. Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 22, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 2236187


    A father appeals the superior court's termination of his parental rights to his young daughter. He disputes two findings made by the superior court: first, that his daughter was a child in need of aid based on abandonment, neglect, and physical harm; and second, that the Office of Children's Services (OCS) made reasonable efforts toward family...



  20. Caswell v. Ahtna, Inc.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. May 20, 2022 511 P.3d 193 2022 WL 1594772


    REAL PROPERTY Landlord and Tenant. Miner's dispute with corporate landowner, with which it had entered into lease, fell within scope of forcible entry and detainer (FED) proceedings.

    Synopsis

    Background: Corporate landowner, with which miner had entered into lease for access to mining operation, brought forcible entry and detainer (FED) action against miner and company. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Thomas A. Matthews, J., 2019 WL 12021722, granted FED judgment. Miner appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

    1. miner's dispute with landowner fell within scope of FED proceedings;

    2. trial court did not abuse discretion in determining miner was not entitled to discovery;

    3. landowner provided miner with effective notice to quit; and

    4. evidence supported conclusion that company was person in possession, for purposes of FED statute.

    Affirmed.


  21. Anniskett v. Tracey

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 13, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 2717712


    Three sisters disputed various aspects of their parents probate proceedings, including the disposition of their parents stock in regional and village corporations. The sisters entered into a settlement agreement in the probate proceedings resolving all pending disputes, including the dispute about their parents stock, but one...



  22. Triem v. Kake Tribal Corporation

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 08, 2022 513 P.3d 994 2022 WL 2552762


    LITIGATION Class Actions. Forgiveness by shareholder class of corporation's debt to class arising from judgment in class action was arguably subject to class-settlement rule.

    Synopsis


    Background: Following resolution of two related shareholder class actions against corporation that was later reorganized in bankruptcy proceedings, classes voted to relieve corporation of its debts to the classes arising from the actions, the first of which ended in a judgment and the second of which ended in a settlement, and moved for court approval of debt forgiveness. In first action, the Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Daniel Schally, J., 2020 WL 5269627, denied class attorney's and former class representative's motion to enforce original judgment and, 2020 WL 5269628, granted class's motion for debt forgiveness, which it treated as a motion for relief from judgment. In second action, the Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Daniel Schally, J., granted class's motion to appoint new representative and for debt forgiveness, which it again treated as a motion for relief from judgment.

    Former class representative in first action, and representative's attorney in first action on attorney's own behalf, appealed denial of motion to enforce judgment in first action and appealed orders in first and second actions approving debt forgiveness. The appeals in both actions were consolidated.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court held that:

    1. former class representative in first action lacked standing to appeal order forgiving corporation's debt entered in second action;

    2. class attorney in first action lacked standing to appeal order forgiving corporation's debt entered in second action;

    3. superior court had jurisdiction over motions in both actions;

    4. class attorney in first action lacked standing to appeal orders in that action declining to enforce judgment and forgiving corporation's debt;

    5. class attorney's appeal of trial-court order sanctioning him in first action for filing a frivolous motion or opposition was not properly before Supreme Court; and

    6. further briefing was required on whether rule governing class-action settlements applied to motion to forgive corporation's debt to class arising from judgment and, if so, whether rule's requirements were met.

    Ordered accordingly.


  23. Duffus v. Baker

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 15, 2022 513 P.3d 264 2022 WL 2761574


    BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS Limited Liability Companies. Whether settlement funds were a distribution originating from LLC required remand in action involving judgment creditor's charging order.

    Synopsis

    Background: Corporate manager of apartment complex and its sole owner, who was 50% member of limited liability company (LLC) apartment complex owner, brought action against other member, alleging the had violated his fiduciary duties and failed to make capital contributions. Following settlement, judgment creditor of other member attempted to intervene, alleging that his charging order applied to settlement funds., and seeking his own charging order in the current litigation. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, 2019 WL 11593028, Jennifer Henderson, J., granted the order, but, after discovering the filing of an attorney's lien arising out of prior litigation, the Court, 2020 WL 7973965, determined lien priority. Judgment creditor appealed, and other LLC member cross-appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, J., held that:

    1. whether settlement funds were a distribution originating from LLC required remand;

    2. attorney's lien was valid; and

    3. evidence was insufficient to establish value of legal services which law firm rendered. Vacated and remanded.


    See also 441 P.3d 432.


  24. Laura M.-J. v. Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 20, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 2825676


    After the superior court terminated a mother's parental rights to a young child, the Office of Children's Services (OCS) placed the child with a woman in Washington, who fostered the child for nearly three years and intended to adopt. After the woman lost her foster care license and Washington authorities received reports of conflict in her home,...



  25. Allison O. v. Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. November 16, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 16955533


    A mother's parental rights to her son were terminated by the superior court three years after the Office of Children's Services (OCS) took emergency custody. The superior court found that the mother had failed to remedy the conduct that placed her son at risk. The mother appealed and disputed the court's findings, arguing that they were not...



  26. Aparezuk v. Schlosser

    Supreme Court of Alaska. July 29, 2022 514 P.3d 283 2022 WL 3009198


    FAMILY LAW Child Support. Former husband's payment of majority of family expenses following separation agreement precluded collection of child support arrearages.

    Synopsis

    Background: Former husband moved to abate garnishment of his wages and to preclude Child Support Services Division (CSSD) from collecting child support arrears. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Sitka, M. Jude Pate, J., granted the motion. Former wife appealed.

    [Holding:] The Supreme Court, Jennifer S. Henderson, J., held that husband's payment of majority of family expenses following separation agreement precluded collection of child support arrearages.

    Affirmed.


  27. D.A.M. v. Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 31, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 3907719


    A father appeals the termination of his parental rights, arguing the superior court erred by finding that he had abandoned his child and that the Office of Children's Services (OCS) made active



    efforts to reunify his family. We conclude the superior court did not err and affirm its termination order. D.A.M. and K.J. are the parents of nine-year-old...



  28. Fairbanks North Star Borough v. Victory Ministries of Alaska, Inc.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 12, 2022 515 P.3d 111 2022 WL 3331366


    TAXATION Real Property. Superior court lacked jurisdiction to sua sponte decide merits of tax appeal that had been closed.

    Synopsis

    Background: Taxpayer, a ministry, sought review of borough's decision revoking taxpayer's charitable property tax exemption based on taxpayer having rented lodging to the general public. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Michael P. McConahy, J., initially remanded to borough and closed the case but subsequently entered sua sponte order granting taxpayer's appeal on merits, 2020 WL 9073493. Borough appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

    1. superior court lacked jurisdiction to sua sponte decide merits of appeal, and

    2. even if superior court had jurisdiction to decide merits, procedure employed to do so was insufficient to satisfy appellate procedural requirements.

    Vacated.


  29. Tiffany B. v. Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. June 08, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 2066045


    A mother appeals the termination of her parental rights to her daughter, an Indian child as defined by the Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA). The mother argues that the Office of Children's Services (OCS) did not make active efforts to provide remedial services and rehabilitative programs as required by ICWA, that the superior court improperly relied...



  30. Matter of Amy D.

    Supreme Court of Alaska. January 14, 2022 502 P.3d 5 2022 WL 128831


    FAMILY LAW Guardians. Trial court did not sufficiently establish that ward's waiver of counsel was knowing and voluntary before allowing ward to waive right to counsel.

    Synopsis

    Background: Court visitor filed report in guardianship proceeding recommending that ward's mother be replaced as ward's full guardian by Office of Public Advocacy (OPA) public guardian. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Juneau, Philip M. Pallenberg, J., allowed ward to waive her right to counsel and appointed public guardian as ward's full guardian. Ward appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Borghesan, J., held that:


    1. guardianship statutes afforded ward the right to appointed counsel when trial court considered guardian's request to resign and have new guardian appointed, and

    2. trial court's brief colloquy with ward did not establish that ward was capable of presenting her arguments in coherent manner or with modicum of courtroom decorum or that ward understood the benefit of counsel, and, thus, trial court did not sufficiently establish that ward's waiver of counsel was knowing and voluntary.

    Reversed and remanded with instructions.


  31. Red Hook Construction, LLC v. Bishop

    Supreme Court of Alaska. October 19, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 10826078


    A property owner contracted with an excavation contractor to build a retaining wall as part of a duplex project. The excavation contractor worked on the project in phases, billing the owner after completing a phase despite the contract stating payment was due on completion. After the owner failed to pay an invoice, the contractor abandoned the...



  32. Borer v. Eyak Corporation

    Supreme Court of Alaska. April 01, 2022 507 P.3d 49 2022 WL 983436


    NATIVE AMERICANS Alaska Natives. Question of whether Alaska Native Corporation's confidentiality agreement could be inconsistent with fiduciary duties was not ripe for adjudication.

    Synopsis

    Background: Winning candidate for seat on board of directors of Alaska Native Corporation, who had declined to sign confidentiality agreement and code of conduct, brought declaratory judgment action against corporation after it denied him seat on board and sought preliminary injunction. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Gregory A. Miller, J., denied injunction motion, entered summary judgment in favor of corporation, 2020 WL 5269637 and 2020 WL 5588773, and granted corporation attorney's fees, 2020 WL 5269639. Candidate appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Borghesan, J., held that:

    1. question of whether confidentiality agreement could be inconsistent with fiduciary duties of director was not ripe;

    2. question of whether provision in code of conduct that required that each director acknowledge that board of directors acted as group and noted that directors could not undermine public or shareholder confidence in board or corporation was unlawfully restrictive was not ripe;

    3. question of whether provision of corporation's code of conduct that authorized withholding of director's compensation and travel expenses if director on board of directors violated code constituted unlawful sanction was not ripe;

    4. question of whether provision in code of conduct that permitted board of directors to sanction directors by barring them from reviewing any proprietary or confidential information was unlawful was not ripe;

    5. statement of corporation's attorney was not improper, for purpose of determining whether denial of award of attorney's fees to corporation was warranted;

    6. candidate failed to establish award was so onerous that it would have deterred similarly-situated litigants from voluntary use of courts; and

    7. extent to which granting award to corporation caused candidate economic hardship did not warrant denial of award.


    Affirmed.


  33. Anna S. v. Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services

    Supreme Court of Alaska. August 31, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 3906717


    At the conclusion of a termination trial, the superior court found by clear and convincing evidence that three children were in need of aid because of their mother's substance abuse. The court also found by clear and convincing evidence that the Office of Children's Services (OCS) had made reasonable efforts to reunify the mother with her children....



  34. Short v. Office of Management & Budget

    Supreme Court of Alaska. September 30, 2022 520 P.3d 142 2022 WL 4588632


    EDUCATION Scholarships and Loans. Higher Education Investment Fund was subject to the state's annual budgetary sweep of certain unappropriated funds into the budget reserve.

    Synopsis

    Background: Students brought action against members of the State's executive branch, alleging that the Higher Education Investment Fund (HEIF), which provided annual grants and scholarships to students pursuing post-secondary education in the state, was not subject to the executive branch's annual budgetary sweep of certain unappropriated funds into the constitutional budget reserve fund. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Adolf V. Zeman, J., 2022 WL 3209622, granted summary judgment for defendants. Students appealed.

    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, C.J., held that:

    1. HEIF was sweepable into the constitutional budget reserve fund, and

    2. sweeping HEIF into the budget reserve fund did not violate the separation of powers doctrine. Affirmed.


  35. Alborn Construction, Inc. v. Department of Labor & Workforce Development, Labor Standards & Safety Division

    Supreme Court of Alaska. April 08, 2022 507 P.3d 468 2022 WL 1053272


    LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT Hours and Wages. Renovation project for office building leased exclusively by State was public construction subject to state prevailing wage requirements.

    Synopsis

    Background: Contractor hired to perform renovations on office building leased to state agencies brought action against the State, the Labor Standards and Safety Division of the Department of Labor and Workforce Development, and the Division's director challenging the Division's determination that the renovation project fell under the prevailing wage requirements of the Little Davis-Bacon Act. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Peter Ramgren, J., 2020 WL 7973977, affirmed.

    Contractor appealed.


    Holdings: The Supreme Court, Winfree, C.J., held that:

    1. summary adjudication without an evidentiary hearing before the ALJ was appropriate;

    2. Department of Labor made final agency decision subject to reasonable basis review;

    3. the renovation project was public construction subject to prevailing wage requirements of the Little Davis-Bacon Act;

    4. second lease amendment specifying building upgrades was a sham contract that attempted to circumvent the Act;

    5. the Department was not equitably estopped from enforcing determination the renovation project was subject to the Act; and

    6. contractor was not denied due process when litigating before the Department the validity of second lease amendment.

    Affirmed.


  36. Cook Inlet Fisherman's Fund v. Department of Fish and Game

Supreme Court of Alaska. August 12, 2022 514 P.3d 1250 2022 WL 3331490


ENVIRONMENTAL LAW Fish. Alaska Statehood Act did not impose specific ongoing federal requirements on salmon fishery management in state waters.

Synopsis

Background: Nonprofit entity representing commercial fishers brought action against Alaska Board of Fisheries and the Department of Fish and Game, alleging that the State's salmon fishery management practices in Cook Inlet were unjustified and violated federal law and national standards. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Kenai, Jason M. Gist, J., 2020 WL 9073486, granted defendants' motion to quash plaintiff's deposition notices, and granted defendants' summary judgment motion. Plaintiff appealed.

Holdings: The Supreme Court, Maassen, J., held that:

  1. Alaska Statehood Act did not impose specific ongoing federal requirements on fishery management in state waters;

  2. Alaska was not required to follow national standards in the federal waters of Cook Inlet during years at issue; and

  3. superior court did not abuse its discretion by limiting evidence to administrative record. Affirmed.


102. Fredrickson v. Hackett

Supreme Court of Alaska. December 07, 2022 Not Reported in Pac. Rptr. 2022 WL 17481783


In this appeal of a child support award, we hold that the superior court did not err by calculating support according to the formula prescribed by Alaska Civil Rule 90.3, even if the former spouses had agreed to a different formula, because the obligor spouse did not show that manifest injustice would result from following the rule. We affirm most...



103. Dex T. v. Department of Health & Social Services, Office of Children's Services
